Will you look at that!" Robson stares, eyes wide with wonder, as the giant mechanism eases its trunk up towards the stadium roof. Blessed with a range of expression and breadth of gesticulation that Kenneth Branagh would be pressed to match, Robson is the most enthusiastic man in football. Age cannot wither the passion for life, for football, of the most successful England manager since Sir Alf Ramsey. Nor can a stiff leg. Less than 24 hours earlier surgeons had pulled out half the cartilage in his left knee. When he thinks about it, or when he stands up after sitting still for a while, he grimaces in pain. But he doesn't think about it very much. What is it we're going to talk about, then? The evolution of the game, how coaches, tactics, players have changed; about the things that have stayed the same. He nods, and his face becomes a picture of concentration. And he talks for the next three hours. The Fifties Coaching didn't exist when Robson, aged 17, started playing professionally for Fulham, then one of the leading English clubs. Preparation for a First Division match consisted, he says, of "Five, Four, Three, Two, One - run five laps, walk one, run four, walk one, and so on. We'd ask, 'Can we have a ball for training?' And the reply would come: 'What do you want a ball for? You'll get one on Saturday. That was the way it was in every club." And team talks? What was his manager, Bill Dodgin, telling them? "Very little. We'd be up against, say, Man United and you'd just play your natural game. The manager picked a team, he had this 'WM' formation, told each player where to go. 'You can head the ball so you play centre half,' and so on. We might be losing at half-time and he'd say nothing tactical. More like, 'What d'you make that mistake for? How could you miss that one?". The WM formation? Robson grabs a pen and paper. "Everybody in England used it. No one imagined you could play any other way. I mean, the war had only ended five years earlier..." He begins to draw dots. "You had two wingers and a centre forward, two inside forwards, two midfielders, a centre half and two full backs." He makes a dot for each position, then joins the dots, five in the shape of a W, five in a superimposed M (try it at home, it sort of works). Today the WM might be called a 5-3-2, or a 3-2-3-2. In those days maths was not the strong point of the game's cognoscenti. Robson identifies the moment he realised English football was, tactically at least, in the dark ages. He was at Wembley in 1953 and watched the Hungarians put six past England. "You might think now that our tactics, or lack of them, were a bit crude, but we still reckoned we were the best in the world. And then the Hungarians beat us 6-3. First time England had ever been beaten at home. I'll never forget it. Near-post crosses, far-post crosses, two wingers working in tandem, the double centre forward." And the Hungarians did know their maths. "Oh yeah. They put a player there," (he marks dots on paper again) "they put two against the centre half, four defenders against three attackers - they played 4-2-4. We'd never seen anything like that! And then they'd switch to 4-4-2. They hammered us! Because against our old WM their system did us in. But also - ah! - what play!" Robson starts waving his arms around, eyes like a madman. He waxes so lyrical he starts to sound, and look, like Hamlet on a roll. "Their touch, their passing, their spinning, their dribbling ability, their crossing, the overlapping play of the two full-backs! And the support play - one man on the ball and always two to give it to. Their football was scintillating. It had width, it had depth. It was compact. It moved like a train." Robson accepted an offer to take lessons in a revolutionary new discipline at the London Football Coaches' Association. "Don Howe, Ron Greenwood, Jimmy Hill came along too, all of us interested in coaching, all of us having seen the Hungarians take the game to a higher plane, wanting England to play at that level." If the tactics were unrecognisable to today's players, so too were the finances. "I was paid £7 a week in the winter, £6 in the summer. I was a young boy of 17 but even the maximum salary at that time - I think I'm right in saying this - was £10 in the winter and £8 in the summer. "So if you were Stanley Matthews or Tom Finney, the best in the game, that's all you could earn. Plus a bonus, set by the FA, of £2 for a win and £1 for a draw. Which meant that, other than your personal motivation, there was little financial incentive to do better because, however great you were, nobody paid you any more money." What was more, the conditions of employment amounted to a form of slave labour. "Yeah. Slave labour. The clubs retained the players' registration as professionals. You could not leave without their permission. If you wanted a transfer and the club denied it you could do nothing about it. If you insisted on leaving they could put you out of the game, they froze you out of football, until you eventually came back to them begging." The fans were different, too. "No hassle, no punch-ups, no blasphemy. Not even chants, songs." No 'there's only one Bobby Robson!'? "Oh no, no. None of that. Even after I played my first games for England I could walk down Putney High Street without anybody recognising me. " The Sixties Football in England made "a huge leap", Robson says, between 1950 and 1966. Two critical developments set the stage for England's World Cup victory: the abolition of the maximum wage, and the dramatic evolution of coaching. "In 1960 the maximum wage went up to £20. But the players weren't satisfied. We asked for £5 a week more. The clubs, the FA said no. So we went on strike. That was in 61-62. Jimmy Hill, who was very eloquent, was our spokesman. We went all the way. And we won. Johnny Haynes became the first £100 a week player - five times the previous salary! Nobody could believe it! Suddenly there was a financial incentive to become a better player." Ramsey plotted England's World Cup triumph but the man Robson credits with having laid the foundations is Ramsey's predecessor, Walter Winterbottom. "Walter did more than anyone to to modernise English football. Now it wasn't 'what do you want a ball for?' any more. Walter understood that if you didn't train with the ball in the week when it came to Saturday you wouldn't know what do with it. So under his guidance, planned training, varied training, shooting practice, crossing practice all became part of the game. All clubs now were looking for training grounds. Before, they trained inside the stadium, ran around the block. Hardly surprisingly, pace went up, skill went up." Robson's first glimpse - and glimpse is the word - of the Brazilian phenomenon came during a World Cup game in 1958. "I played for England there, at inside right. It was the hardest football I've ever played in my life. It was at a pace I'd never known, against a class of player I'd never seen on the same pitch. They had a lightness we did not have, an exquisite touch. Somehow, we drew that game 0-0. Pele came into the side in the next match, at 17. That was it. That was the year Brazilian football exploded on the world scene. Fabulous!" If the game became more beautiful, it was also in good measure because of the change in the characteristics of the ball. "It was lighter, weatherproof. When I started we had this leather ball that absorbed water. It was like heading a bloody cannonball. Kicking it more than 60 metres was a terrific feat. Now with the new ball, which is basically the one we use today, you could ping it 60 yards with precision. Pinging wasn't an option in the 1950s." Football not only became a better spectacle, with the 1966 victory the game acquired a new fascination in England. "People think football was always as popular in England as it is today. Well it wasn't. After the '66 World Cup the game's popularity shot up. Attendances the following season were dramatically higher. And now you had a huge demand for televised football. Players suddenly became instantly recognisable on the streets, to become celebrities in their own right - George Best was the first of his kind in England. And there was a terrific spin-off commercially. The textile trade took off - shirts, scarves, merchandise. In the Fifties football had been a game. In the Sixties it was becoming an industry." The Seventies After the defeat by West Germany in the 1970 World Cup, the national side had a run of abysmal failure despite a generation of wonderfully skilful English players. "Yeah. Yeah. You had Hudson, Osgood, Bowles, Marsh, Tony Currie. The sort of talent you were more used to seeing on the continent. But they didn't get a regular run in the England set-up. Maybe some of those players lacked a bit of behavioural attitude, of discipline." Unable to afford to bring such players to Ipswich, Robson instead initiated a revolution. In 1978 he brought two of the first foreign (or rather non-British or Irish) players into the English game - the Dutchmen Arnold Muhren and Frans Thijssen. Why? "We'd become a bit stereotyped. We got the ball from the back to the forwards very quickly and did not play through the midfield very much. And so we lost the ball too much. If you over-hit or under-hit, you lost the ball. The long ball is the best ball in the game if it's spot-on (Hoddle was the great long-ball player in those days). But you only get seven or eight of those precision long balls in a match. You can't get 30. The percentage returns of the long-ball game are not good. "So we had to bring in a change. To play through the midfield, not bypassing it. Play it in stages, shorten our game. We looked and looked but I could not find the player I needed in England - the best ones were in the big clubs. So we went abroad and I found two, the two Dutchmen. "The Holland team that made the World Cup final in 1974 and 1978 didn't win but they were the Hungarians of the Seventies. They brought the game to a new level, a new tactical plane. They played without a centre forward, remember? Cruyff and Neeskens sat back, and the two opposing centre halves didn't know who to mark." That was the team that invented total football. "Yeah. And you know what total football is? Every player in the team is a footballer. Every player - the centre half, the full backs - could dribble, pass, control it. Everyone played like an inside forward. Everyone could keep possession. The Dutch then were like the Hungarians because you could say there was a before and an after. They set a new standard. And the starting point was that they kept possession, rarely lost it. The danger with that game is that you sometimes overplay, end up after nine passes where you began. But the good Dutch teams had the players to add penetration to possession. That's the secret of any team: play to the players' strengths. They didn't have any great headers of the ball, so they played ground football, which was a great, great game to watch." The Eighties The Eighties was a decade of new ideas. Of constantly changing patterns of play. "For example, a coach would see the other team play 4-2-4 and he'd shift to 4-3-3 to dominate the midfield and create some space. A lot of teams shifted to 4-3-3. So then others said, OK, now we'll go to 4-4-2. You play three in midfield, we'll play four. Always what you're doing is trying to have a spare man, to create numerical superiority. That's the point. And now teams play five in midfield, 3-5-2. But there comes a time when you can't change any more. You can't put six in midfield, because there's no space. There are only four or five realistic systems. But the main thing is to be able to adapt the system to your players." Tactically, the team Robson most admired during his England reign was France. "Funny that. It was not so long before that we thought of France as a poor footballing nation. We played them in my first game as an England player. I scored twice and we won 4-0. But look at that team, so unlucky not to win the 1982 World Cup. What the coach [Michel Hidalgo] did was really imaginative. He played with one winger, one front player, and no player on the right at all." Robson grabs his pen and paper again and starts furiously drawing arrows, more dots."The team was built on the midfield trio of Platini, Giresse and Tigana. Platini, who could thread the ball through the eye of a needle, was in the hole, looking for the counter-attack, doing next to no defensive work. When France regained the ball they passed it to him. Behind Platini was little Giresse, knitting the midfield with the back four. Tigana had amazing pace and endurance. He did not operate wide, but he worked the right channel up and down. What you had here was a clever coach who was aware of his weaknesses and found a way of playing that suited his players, while at the same time causing confusion in the opposing team. I mean, what do you say to those two guys playing on the right in the other team who have no one to mark? No one mastered that problem." Hidalgo, in other words, got the best out of his best players and made a virtue of his deficiencies. Did his wit offer any lessons to the current England side, whose lament is the absence of left-sided players? Robson does not rise to the bait. "Mmm," he says. "Mmm, What you do, is you get by. You find a way to get by." Robson did a lot more than get by when he was England coach. But did he impose a discernible, Bobby Robson system of play on his teams? He pauses to reflect. "Well, look," he says,"first of all I always liked wingers. Later at Barcelona, for example, I played with Figo on the right and Luis Enrique on the left. I think that when you're in trouble the easiest, safest, thing is to pass it wide. Then, as to what you do with it, I was lucky to have players like Barnes and Waddle, and Kenny Sansom coming up from left back. "What maybe set my team apart from other England teams was that we played ground football. We had to. Beardsley and Lineker were this high." He gestures with his hand at chest height. "I couldn't hit the high ball down the middle, or long crosses to the back post. As for the system, it was 4-2-4 or 4-4-2 - the two are basically interchangeable - because that is the system we most play in England. "But you*ve got to be flexible at the highest level. And if in a World Cup we came across opposing strikers who might be too good, we brought in a sweeper - Mark Wright - to drop off and play behind everybody." Try as Robson does to impose some science on the game, there is always the luck factor. "Yeah, sure, yeah," says Robson, who was knocked out of one World Cup by the 'hand of God', another by penalties. "You can't buy critical decisions that go against you. Or players that under-perform, way below their level in club football." Whereupon, for the first time, he ventures a criticism of the current England team. "Look at Dennis Wise, who is a little hubbub of a player for Chelsea but played so poorly for England in Euro 2000. "He played nowhere near his club form, like several others. This is what you find as England coach. That there are players who don't cope with the pressure. Who can handle things in their own sitting room, but can't handle going to meet the Queen at the palace. You've got to find out about those players, because they'll let you down. They'll crumble on the day. They'll shirk the responsibility. They'll disappear." The best example Robson came across of a player who did not shirk his responsibility, ever, was Bryan Robson. "He could play anywhere in the world at the same level, whether it was the Azteca Stadium or Crewe Alexandra. The world stage did not frighten him. Nothing did." The Nineties The football industry, fattened by all the money television poured in, became fully globalised. Players, and coaches no longer felt any constraint to play their football in the land where they were born. Robson offers a perfect illustration of the trend. Upon leaving the England job in 1990 he headed to PSV Eindhoven, setting off on a pilgrimage that took him to Lisbon, to Porto, to Barcelona and back to PSV, before returning home to take over the Newcastle job from Ruud Gullit at the end of 1999. Why all this movement? "There are three reasons, basically. One is money. Two, experience. And three, success. I went abroad to get an education, but I also doubled the salary I had as England manager." What did he learn in Holland? "That the possession game comes first, penetration later. That passing well is the key." Why can't the English do this? "It's because we believe in the tennis game of football. We believe in getting the ball forward and getting it forward early. So we think the first pass must be a front pass. It's not on abroad, is it? What you see is that they get in a difficult position, a cul-de-sac, and so what do they do? They bring it back, play it square, start again. We don't do that." But the English understand this is how the game should be played, don't they? "I suppose so. The problem, maybe, is that we need the confidence and we lack the skill factor." Which is why, following Robson's old Arnold Muhren principle, English managers look abroad. "You'll never get a Newcastle team with 11 Geordies now. The best you can do is retain a British nucleus. I am trying to do that at Newcastle. But beyond that, you're dreaming." But is this new reality good for the game? "Well, we're getting used to it now, but it's bad for the national side, no doubt about it. We've even got, disastrously, some clubs whose reserves are full of foreigners, so where is the English player getting a chance?" Yet Robson has just bought two Argentines. "Well, yeah," he shrugs, chuckling. "I am a hypocrite. But I am trying like everybody else to get success. It's a Catch 22, but I like everybody else have to start buying foreign players. And we'll do so till the country starts producing good ones of its own." What did he find had changed for the better when he returned to English football? "A lot. Much greater professionalism. More attention to diets, to getting just the right protein and carbohydrate intake at just the right time. More scientific monitoring of fitness levels. Greater seriousness from the players, greater awareness that their careers are short and they had better look after their bodies." That said, Robson was shocked to discover how deep the English culture of drunkenness remained, not just among the fans, but among the top players. "You try to stop them from drinking alcohol but they still like a drink, more in England than in any other country I know. In Portugal they never drank, in Barcelona they never drank. It's a cultural thing. It's been in the game a long time, and the young players come in, meet it, get the swing of it, and become the same. Not every player, but there is far too much drinking of alcohol in English football, far too many players getting drunk at weekends." What's changed in 50 years What strikes Robson is how dramatically the manager's job has evolved. "You've got to be so meticulous in your preparations. There's a lot more one-to-ones with players, analysing their games, trying to personalise their coaching to make them better players - which is now what the coach's job is supposed to be, in large measure. As for team talks, the sorts of things I'd say in my Ipswich days were much more general. Like, 'they take the long throw, watch out for the long throw.' That's not sufficient now. Now I say that for the long throw I want you in front of that player, and you get behind him and, between the two of you, sandwich him in." At Barcelona, where he had difficulty with the language, he used flip charts to explain tactics. He liked the system, and uses it still. "I spend about 90 minutes preparing the charts, about 16 pages in all." Using the wall of his lounge, he acts out the part of a coach with his flip-chart. "I mark down each player for each particular duty: for an attacking corner and defensive corner; how to line up against a lateral free-kick, where precisely each player should stand; how far back or forward the last line of defence should be, depending on the angle of approach of the ball. I have a separate sketch for each permutation." The key question is whether all these sophistications have improved the quality of the game. "Oh yes. Yes. Absolutely. I remember Walter Winterbottom telling me, when I played midfield for England, that a midfield player does about 6,000 yards in a match - 2,000 yards of that in sprint form, and another 4,000 in checking and going back and covering. Today it's about 10,000 metres, so that's nearly 5,000 yards more per match. If you'd said to me back in the Fifties that I'd have to run 5,000 yards more I would have told you it was not possible. So, for instance, you were the full back then, the message from the manager was, 'Don't you ever cross that halfway line! Your job is to defend!' Now look at the overlapping full back, look at Lizarazu, Roberto Carlos, Thuram - the ground they cover! "As the game has got faster the technique has gone up. Because before you had time to get it down, look up. Before, if your first touch was bad and the ball bounced three or four yards, it was still your ball. Today, if you've miscontrolled it, you've lost it. Now the moment you get the ball there is someone at you. The pressure on the ball has increased manyfold. So, yes, the quality of skill has got dramatically better." Is it possible to compare teams today with teams when he began? "Certainly. I can tell you without a shred of doubt: a good team today would murder a good team of the Fifties. A good game today is a much better game to watch than a good game in the Fifties or Sixties. Because the game has been progressing all the time." On the other hand, the great players then, subjected to present conditions, would be great today. "If Matthews or Finney played today they*d be fitter and faster and still brilliant. George Best would be George Best today. He'd probably be better." Perhaps the most obvious difference is in the incomes and lifestyles of the players. "You can say that again! A professional who plays eight years today, if he is sensible, can avoid the need to ever work again. In my day you assumed you'd have to go back to work. That was why my parents insisted I finish my electrician's apprenticeship before I took up the game. We absolutely assumed that was what I'd do after I turned 30." As for the celebrity the players enjoy, and the power to control their own destinies they so patently lacked 50 years ago, it does pose new challenges. "Before the players' respect for the manager was unquestioned. Now you have to work harder to get it, because top players, the ones you really don't want to lose, can threaten to leave. Ronaldo is the perfect example. He had an eight-year contract with Barcelona and after a year he was gone. But he was a good lad, all the same. He treated senior players with respect. He always listened to what I had to say. Except when I asked him to stay at Barca. But that was the agent's fault." Could he imagine a player having an agent in 1950? "I can't. What for? There was nothing to negotiate. Now it's gone too far the other way. Some agents are good, but many are a nightmare - perpetuating the player's unrest, never satisfied. Always looking to get a bigger cut, even if it is against their player's long-term interests. As happened, tragically, with Ronaldo. I'll never forget what he said when I asked him, during the negotiations before he left for Inter Milan, what his agents' view was: 'They said, I need to play football and they need to make money. I have to listen to them.'" That's a long way from the thoughts that occupied Robson as he strolled unnoticed down Putney High Street in the Fifties. So much has changed. What hasn't? "I'll tell you what hasn't changed. I'll tell you what no amount of money can change," he says, his eyes lighting up, oozing devotion to the game that has been his life. "The players play for the love of the game. They really do. Always. Money doesn't come into it when they're on the pitch. Once they are out there playing, it doesn't matter whether they are on 10 pounds or two million. That hasn't changed, and I don't believe it ever will. That stays the same. The love of the game, yes, that has always been the same."

fields.trailText: When George Weah trotted out for his Manchester City debut at Edgeley Park he did so with the faintly condescending air of someone unaccustomed to such homely surroundings. By the time he drooped off 90 minutes later, City's optimism having been comprehensively sandbagged by the poor relations, it had probably dawned on him that he could well be back here next season. He certainly swelled the gate for Jim Gannon's testimonial game. Weah had not even managed to touch the ball by the time Stockport took the lead. fields.body:
When George Weah trotted out for his Manchester City debut at Edgeley Park he did so with the faintly condescending air of someone unaccustomed to such homely surroundings. By the time he drooped off 90 minutes later, City's optimism having been comprehensively sandbagged by the poor relations, it had probably dawned on him that he could well be back here next season. He certainly swelled the gate for Jim Gannon's testimonial game. Weah had not even managed to touch the ball by the time Stockport took the lead. Not surprising really, as the match was only 35 seconds old when Ian Moore picked up the ball on the right and cut through a non-existent City defence to find the top corner of the net with insolent ease.

If that goal was cheeky, the next was positively disdainful. When the ponderous Alfie Haaland was caught out by Kevin Cooper after 12 minutes and was penalised for the clumsiest of fouls on the edge of his area, Tony Dinning exposed Weaver's poor positioning by nonchalantly clipping in the free-kick off his right-hand post.

Richard Jobson is getting too old, Gerard Wiekens is still unpredictable and new signing Haaland was simply an embarrassment. Cooper and Moore conjured a fourth goal before the end to emphasise County's superiority. fields.headline: Prutton's on the button
fields.standfirst: Six to follow:  Checking out emerging talent in the Nationwide League
fields.body:
Following England's Euro 2000 debacle, attention this season will be trained on young players with the potential to return some optimism to the national game. One such could well be Nottingham Forest's 18-year-old midfield prodigy David Prutton. Prutton, all 6ft 1in of him, is a leggy runner, strong in the tackle and developing his passing ability apace, being a quick and willing learner. He has already trained with the England under-21 squad prior to their departure for their own European championship finals in May. 'He could quite easily go on to get international honours. I would be surprised if he wasn't in an under-21 squad this season,' says his Forest manager David Platt. 'He's come back and his passing's better. Perhaps it's that bit of experience, perhaps the summer has given him a chance to reflect. His awareness is also there. He mustn't lose his fundamentals, mainly the work rate. He closes down like nothing you have ever seen and snaps into the tackle. He picked up a few yellow cards last season, but he's not dirty.' Such is Prutton's progress that Platt will move him infield from the right side of midfield to increase his influence. 'He's got pace,' adds Platt. 'He's not an out-and-out passer, though he'll pass it all right, at the right pace, and keep the ball moving, but he's not going to see a really clever pass. I think he can score more goals this season. He's been working on hitting the target more. After every session he will go and strike 50 balls into an empty net. 'He is intelligent and tries things. He listens and takes things on board, takes things from every game. And there are no airs and graces, no edge to him. If you had 25 of him your squad you wouldn't have a problem. Big clubs are aware of him. Several managers have asked about him but we haven't received any bids. This season will be a big test of whether we can or can't hold on to him and it probably won't be a financial thing. It will depend on the season we have and David has.' Forest have developed some outstanding midfield players to England's benefit in recent history. To Neil Webb and Nigel Clough could be added David Prutton. And there are more in the Nationwide hinterland...

CHRIS LLEWELLYN

(Norwich) 20

He had a major test last season when filling the gap left by striker Darren Eadie's move to Leicester - not the easiest job considering his comparative inexperience and Eadie's popularity with the fans. But Norwich's manager, Bryan Hamilton, enthuses: 'The mental strength he showed in coming through it was fantastic.' This element, combined with Llewellyn's athleticism and ability with either foot, causes Hamilton to suggest that there is 'definitely a top-class player in there'. But whether the Welsh under-21 player will continue to show it as a striker - like his fellow Welshman at Norwich, Craig Bellamy - is another matter. Hamilton has been using him recently as an attacking left back and says: 'I think that could be his best role.'

PAUL IFILL

(Millwall) 20 Millwall insiders claim that, of their group of youngsters who have attracted the attention of First Division and Premiership scouts over the past 12 months - Neil Harris, Tim Cahill, Richard Sadlier and Ifill - it is Ifill who has been the subject of the most inquiries. Although he joined Millwall as a striker it is in a wide-right role that this six-footer has established himself in the first team, and emerged as such a prominent eye-catcher. 'He is an exciting player, isn't he?' says Millwall's co-manager, Keith Stevens. 'He has a lot of pace and he does so much off the cuff - I am not sure that even we know what he is doing on the ball sometimes.'

JAMES O'CONNOR

(Stoke) 20

The Dublin-born O'Connor, an Irish Republic under-21 star, is the archetypal little red-headed midfield dynamo. Last season was his first as a regular first-team player, but his high-octane impact was such that Stoke have already found it necessary to reassure their fans that he will be remaining at the club. Stoke's coach, Nigel Pearson, says that he finds O'Connor's work rate 'phenomenal'. At this stage of the player's development, the downside is that his enthusiasm can lead him into trying to do too much; and, because of his love of a hard tackle, incurring the displeasure of referees is inevitably another problem. 'But he is learning,' Pearson reminds us. 'It seems difficult to believe that he has become so important to us in such a short space of time. The fact is, he is a winner.'

TOMMY MILLER

(Hartlepool) 21

When manager Chris Turner started working with the tall midfielder 17 months ago, he encouraged him to make more runs beyond his strikers. The result is that Miller, whose football education at Hartlepool has included the experience of playing alongside Peter Beardsley, scored as many as 16 goals last season. Turner acknowledges that this will be an even more important season for him ('He has to show that he is not a one-season wonder') and, indeed, that he will soon need to move out of the Third Division in order to make further progress. But he has no doubts that Miller would look comfortable in a First Division or Premiership squad. 'Apart from his ability, he looks after himself correctly. He is a model pro.'

IAN STONEBRIDGE

(Plymouth) 18

It is not unusual for players to get to the top after being rejected at this level at the start of their careers, and Plymouth suggest this could be the case with the Taunton-born Stonebridge. He joined them at the start of last season, via a spell on the books of Tottenham, and did well enough - until hit by a groin injury - to gain selection for England's under-18 team. Plymouth's assistant-manager, Steve McCall, says: 'He probably needs to get a little bit quicker but the great thing about him is his eye for goals. Because of his positioning, alertness and touch, he is magnificent at our level, and this should give him the confidence to keep progressing.'

fields.headline: Owen rescues it
fields.standfirst:
Benfica (Poborsky 64, 73) 2
Liverpool (Camara 10, Owen 47) 2
fields.trailText: Michael Owen a wonderful goal to grace this match, but Liverpool still spurned a two-goal lead before winning the Carlsberg Belfast Challenge on goal difference.
fields.body:
Michael Owen a wonderful goal to grace this match, but Liverpool still spurned a two-goal lead before winning the Carlsberg Belfast Challenge on goal difference.

Owen underlined his value - when free of injury - to Liverpool and his goal served notice of how much he is worth with the opening rounds of his new contract negotiations underway.

Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier described it as 'a magnificent goal', but added: 'We have to learn that when you are two up - whether it's a friendly or an important league match - you can't throw away a lead like that. You have to finish the game off and protect what you've got. But we play games like this to learn and prepare.'

Former Manchester United winger Karel Poborsky had scored two fine goals in the space of 10 minutes to slightly spoil Liverpool's Belfast party.

Owen's strike was a sensation, though, following a first-half header from Titi Camara. When Benfica finally woke up, Poborsky exposed worrying holes in Liverpool's defence with a spectacular strike of his own, and then a jinking run from halfway before slipping home the equaliser.

It was the English side who took control after 10 minutes. Vladimir Smicer sent over a tempting cross to the far post, where Camara's typically brave header beat exposed keeper Robert Enke.

Liverpool consistently threatened to score again. Owen's pace was a constant worry for Benfica, and he was put clear by Smicer after 20 minutes, his chip over Enke dropping just wide of the far post.

Carlos Marchena was then booked for a late tackle on Owen that enraged Gary McAllister and Stephane Henchoz. Owen was involved in the next flashpoint when from the resulting free-kick he was was body-checked by Fernando Meira, who surprisingly came off worse in the collision with the slight striker.

Owen made another mark two minutes after the break. His stunning goal was created by a powerful right- wing run from Markus Babbel. The German's cross was met perfectly on the volley by Owen in full flight.

Poborsky claimed an equally fine goal on 64 minutes. Ricardo Rojas crossed from the left. Poborsky took off to produce a stunning scissor kick that rivalled Owen's earlier effort.

Poborsky struck again, on 73 minutes, after being allowed to skip through a mass of Liverpool defenders before cleverly creating space for a shot which he steered wide of a diving Sander Westerveld.

webTitle: Platt sees the light at Forest

fields.headline: Platt sees the light at Forest
fields.trailText: For every fan and every player, for a host of differing reasons, every season is a big season. And while the marketing of a Premiership still cranking up for yet more razzmatazz may already be cloying, a little more hyperbole than usual from the clubs of the Nationwide League's First Division is forgivable this time around. Quite probably the 46-game grueller that starts on Saturday is indeed the biggest one yet.
fields.body:
For every fan and every player, for a host of differing reasons, every season is a big season. And while the marketing of a Premiership still cranking up for yet more razzmatazz may already be cloying, a little more hyperbole than usual from the clubs of the Nationwide League's First Division is forgivable this time around. Quite probably the 46-game grueller that starts on Saturday is indeed the biggest one yet.

Picture this. Next summer, the Premiership's new cable, satellite, digital and coming-out-of-your-ears television deal kicks in, at a premium to the elite of some £15 million a year each. Div One chairmen's eyes light up, agents scour the team-sheets for players to recruit and bank managers book holidays in Barbados. Promotion will matter as never before.

If not of razor-sharp quality, already we know the First Division competition to be cut-throat keen. From this early vantage point, at least a dozen biggish clubs will be vying for the three plum positions. The fascination will be twofold; watching them take points off one another, the balance of power shifting weekly until the spring scramble, and seeing which are willing to speculate in the winter to accumulate come the summer.

'Massive,' is how the Nottingham Forest manager, David Platt, his club one of those desperate dozen, views the season. 'A lot of clubs will be saying, "We have got to be in the Premiership", and will be putting their necks on the line financially. That's the feeling here. We're at a level where if we don't go up, we will have to trim things.'

The First Division is a different world, he concedes. 'You find that out just making an enquiry about a reserve player in the Premiership. Ask about his salary and it blows your mind what he is on. That's where you notice most how big the gap is.'

In quality, too, he admits. 'There's a mixture. The majority of clubs want to play football. But I don't think there are many exceptional strikers, who would score goals in the Premiership, though there are quite a few who will at this level. Because of that, you can afford to go at teams. You don't get punished as much for mistakes in Division One.

'There's not so much of a divide here, though. In this league, you will get beaten by teams you don't expect. It's not often that Manchester United, Arsenal and Chelsea lose to sides you expect them to beat. The top of the pools coupon is more predictable these days. I think that's why this division will be interesting. There's a depth of competition.'

He expects, naturally, the moneyed clubs to be the main rivals; Blackburn and Fulham. And, a little surprisingly, relegated Sheffield Wednesday, 'because they've got quality players they probably won't be able to sell even if they want to because of the wages they're on'. And Huddersfield, and Wolves 'depending on who they get to replace Ade Akinbiyi'. And Watford and Birmingham City, and ... the list goes on.

Platt is aware that it is a big season for him, too. He is a man with a high reputation, having captained England and played for Juventus, Sampdoria and Arsenal. He needs success to satisfy his personal drive. He also nurtures ambitions one day to manage the national team, having already worked as an assistant to Howard Wilkinson with the under-18 team as part of his nine months learning the coaching trade. During that period, he also visited Lazio and Juve and observed Louis Van Gaal's enlightening sessions at Barcelona.

A few months in charge of Sampdoria, his first managerial position, when he cut his losses amid opposition from the Italian managers' association because he did not possess the Uefa B coaching licence (since obtained), does not appear to have damaged him. Another season of treading water with Forest, similar to the last after relegation, and doubts about his capabilities will surface, however.

'It's never really worried me,' he says. 'But I'm under no illusions about the importance of doing well. I don't need this financially but I do need the success. I've not gone into management to pass my time away. I could do that on the golf course. The great thing about this club is that if it got into the Premiership there is still some growth there. It's not a stepping stone for me. I could see myself being here for a number of years.'

The bust of Brian Clough still dominates the reception at the City Ground, and photos of a European Cup-winning era never likely to be repeated for a medium-size city club abound but Platt does not feel intimidated. 'I welcome it,' he says. 'It's an inspiration.'

What were the lessons of his first full season in management? 'In hindsight, it took me too long to get a settled side,' he says. 'I might have been better off saying, "These are my best 11", and sticking with them, win, lose or draw. Because we started losing games, I perhaps changed things around too often. But I had to do that in the early stages because I was still assessing players. 'That's something I will take into this season. I think the best teams are those who have eight regulars and three floaters, even if sometimes it does change because of form and the nature of the opposition.'

He is imposing 'his' football more and more, he says. 'I want us to pass the ball forward,' he says. 'I don't mind it being passed long but I don't want it kicked long. I like forward-thinking teams and we do a lot of sessions on that. The easiest thing to defend is the square ball from a centre-half to a full-back. Forward passes take people out of the game. I like us to be compact and not defend deep and to win the ball in the middle third.'

So far he has kept his powder dry in the transfer market. Gary Jones has come on 'a Bosman' from Tranmere as a goalscoring midfield player - Platt smiles when you suggest he was looking for a player in his own mould - while Nigel Quashie has been sold to Portsmouth and Mark Crossley and Ian Woan released to free up places on the wage bill.

He remains in the market for a defender, midfield player and striker, however, but is in no rush, with the prospect of more timely moments for reinforcements during the campaign likely to present themselves. In addition, he believes he has the nucleus of a promotion side in Dave Beasant, Riccardo Scimeca, Colin Calderwood, Jones, Alan Rogers, the exciting teenager David Prutton, Jack Lester and Stern John.

'I could do with a deeper squad,' he admits. 'I would like seven or eight players unhappy at being left out rather than five or six. But if we steer clear of injuries and suspensions - and that's the difficult bit - we will be competitive.'

That word again. Affording promotion to the Premiership is one thing, but when it comes to being competitive, Nationwide League First Division clubs can't afford not to be.

A few months in charge of Sampdoria, his first managerial position, when he cut his losses amid opposition from the Italian managers' association because he did not possess the Uefa B coaching licence (since obtained), does not appear to have damaged him. Another season of treading water with Forest, similar to the last after relegation, and doubts about his capabilities will surface, however. 'It's never really worried me,' he says. 'But I'm under no illusions about the importance of doing well. I don't need this financially but I do need the success. I've not gone into management to pass my time away. I could do that on the golf course. The great thing about this club is that if it got into the Premiership there is still some growth there. It's not a stepping stone for me. I could see myself being here for a number of years.' The bust of Brian Clough still dominates the reception at the City Ground, and photos of a European Cup-winning era never likely to be repeated for a medium-size city club abound but Platt does not feel intimidated. 'I welcome it,' he says. 'It's an inspiration.' What were the lessons of his first full season in management? 'In hindsight, it took me too long to get a settled side,' he says. 'I might have been better off saying, "These are my best 11", and sticking with them, win, lose or draw. Because we started losing games, I perhaps changed things around too often. But I had to do that in the early stages because I was still assessing players. 'That's something I will take into this season. I think the best teams are those who have eight regulars and three floaters, even if sometimes it does change because of form and the nature of the opposition.' He is imposing 'his' football more and more, he says. 'I want us to pass the ball forward,' he says. 'I don't mind it being passed long but I don't want it kicked long. I like forward-thinking teams and we do a lot of sessions on that. The easiest thing to defend is the square ball from a centre-half to a full-back. Forward passes take people out of the game. I like us to be compact and not defend deep and to win the ball in the middle third.' So far he has kept his powder dry in the transfer market. Gary Jones has come on 'a Bosman' from Tranmere as a goalscoring midfield player - Platt smiles when you suggest he was looking for a player in his own mould - while Nigel Quashie has been sold to Portsmouth and Mark Crossley and Ian Woan released to free up places on the wage bill. He remains in the market for a defender, midfield player and striker, however, but is in no rush, with the prospect of more timely moments for reinforcements during the campaign likely to present themselves. In addition, he believes he has the nucleus of a promotion side in Dave Beasant, Riccardo Scimeca, Colin Calderwood, Jones, Alan Rogers, the exciting teenager David Prutton, Jack Lester and Stern John. 'I could do with a deeper squad,' he admits. 'I would like seven or eight players unhappy at being left out rather than five or six. But if we steer clear of injuries and suspensions - and that's the difficult bit - we will be competitive.' That word again. Affording promotion to the Premiership is one thing, but when it comes to being competitive, Nationwide League First Division clubs can't afford not to be.

fields.headline: My team: Raith Rovers
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
I was brought up in Kirkcaldy, near to where Raith play. I started going in the 1950s when I was about seven or eight.

The first game I remember seeing was an East Fife-Raith Rovers derby on New Year's Day. My father took my older brother, John, and myself. For much of my youth John and I sold programmes outside Stark's Park on matchday. You queued up before the season began to become a programme-seller; once you had your slot you had it for the whole season. I went along on a Saturday about two hours before the match started, sold the programme and then, before half-time, I was allowed in free to watch the game, as well as being paid.

The great Jim Baxter was playing for us then. He was a superb left-half, a tremendous passer of the ball. I remember the time he was playing for Scotland against England and taunted the English by playing keepy-uppy.

We snapped him up while he was working as a miner in Fife: many of the Rovers players came from mining backgrounds. Becoming a footballer was seen as a way out of the mines. I think that's why so many players, and also managers such as Jock Stein and Bill Shankly, came from mining areas like Lanarkshire and Ayrshire.

When Baxter left us after three seasons for Rangers, people complained that the transfer fee ( £20,000) was a disgrace, that he'd been sold far too cheaply. It was said that Baxter left Rovers because he'd had a fight with the chairman's wife - as if Raith Rovers could have held onto a player of his special talent for another few years!

Sadly Raith have never had as much success as I'd like. People sometimes ask why politicians talk about skills and training all the time. I tell them they would too if they had to go and watch Raith every week.

Our best moment was beating Celtic in the final of the Scottish League Cup in 1994. The match was played at Ibrox - I'm sure Rangers helped us by flooding the pitch or something! The tragedy for me was that I had to do a television interview in London that morning and my plane to Glasgow afterwards was cancelled: I had to listen to the radio commentary on the match being played down a friend's phone. We won 6-5 on penalties after a 2-2 draw. It's still the only major trophy Raith have won.

We then drew Bayern Munich in the Uefa Cup and at half-time in the second leg over there the scoreboard carried the immortal scoreline: Bayern Munich 0 Raith Rovers 1. (We lost 2-1). Part of the reason we aren't any better is that there are three other teams in the area: Dunfermline, Cowdenbeath and East Fife. So I'm not very popular in some parts of my constituency because I support Raith.

Of course there are many more glamorous clubs that have huge amounts of money and watching them on television is very enjoyable. But I'm a firm believer that supporting your local team, the team you've been brought up with, is very important.

Gordon Brown, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is MP for Dunfermline East. Interview by Denis Campbell

webTitle: How we blew £10m on World Cup loss

fields.headline: How we blew £10m on World Cup loss
fields.standfirst: England tried to woo world football chiefs with helicopter trips and five-star junkets. Denis Campbell reports on a home defeat
fields.trailText: The team behind England's disastrous bid to host the 2006 World Cup spent millions on swanky receptions, overseas trips, glossy documents and pampering football's power-brokers - but still suffered a humiliating defeat.
fields.body:
The team behind England's disastrous bid to host the 2006 World Cup spent millions on swanky receptions, overseas trips, glossy documents and pampering football's power-brokers - but still suffered a humiliating defeat.

Official accounts for the doomed campaign reveal for the first time the full extent of how England spent the £10 million given to them to 'bring football home'. In the end, though, just two of the 24 football dignitaries they were trying to impress actually backed England.

The confidential accounts, which have been passed to The Observer, show that £288,425 was spent last year alone on 'ambassadors/VIPs/hospitality'. That included the efforts of football legends turned 2006 frontmen Sir Bobby Charlton, Sir Geoff Hurst and Gary Lineker to bring the World Cup 'home to England', their still-undisclosed fees for helping the £10m bid, and both hospitality and undisclosed gifts for the game's decision-makers.

A total of £623,686 went into advertising the bid, £361,914 on visits abroad, £646,251 into the 1,000-page bid document and a further £506,570 on other publications during 1999. More than £100,000 was spent trying to impress visiting inspectors from Fifa, football's world governing body, with five-star hotels and helicopter trips.

The accounts, which detail how £4.18m was spent last year, will be seized upon by critics who doubted the wisdom of mounting the 2006 bid from the outset.

Labour MP Derek Wyatt, who has tabled parliamentary questions about how the £10m was used, said the figures were 'extraordinary. Ten million pounds is a huge amount of money to spend and only get two votes. Last year's £4.18m strikes me as excessive. In retrospect the bid does seem to have been totally misguided and extraordinarily expensive.'

Wyatt said disclosure of the 2006 accounts made it much more likely that the Commons culture, media and sport select committee, which he belongs to, would now investigate the whole £10m budget as part of a planned inquiry this autumn into Britain's troubled recent record of funding major sports projects.

The 2005 World Athletics Championships in London, the £475m revamp of Wembley Stadium and the 2002 Commonwealth Games in Manchester, which needed a £12m Treasury handout last month to stay afloat, will also be examined.

MPs may order the release of information to obtain full details of where the entire £10m went, not just the £3.1m lottery grant provided by Sport England, which was spent solely on staff salaries and administration. The Football Association and the Premier League each gave another £3m. MPs could demand to know, for example, exactly how much Charlton and Hurst, who have both been knighted for their services to football, were paid for their four years' work.

The document, written in April, illustrates the misplaced optimism that fuelled England's bid, which critics described as naive, arrogant and misguided, especially as it was not backed by European football's ruling body.

Under the heading 'travel and subsistence', bid director Alec McGivan explains spending £361,914 on overseas visits by saying: 'During 1999 the campaign team visited 20 countries (some more than once) and travelled nearly 150,000 miles.

The policy of seeing members of the Fifa executive committee in their own countries has proved to be the right one and has paid dividends.'

Three months later events proved McGivan spectacularly wrong when only two Fifa executive committee members, both Scots, endorsed England's bid. One of those was New Zealand's Glasgow-born representative Charlie Dempsey, who effectively handed Germany the tournament 12-11 ahead of favourites South Africa when he abstained after England's early exit.

The accounts also show that much of the Premier League's £3m donation went straight back into their pockets because the 2006 team invested heavily on advertising on pitch-side hoardings at Premiership grounds. They spent £400,000 on those in the 1998-99 season, followed by another £340,000 between August and December 1999.

Another £426,569 was spent last year on 'events/exhibitions', such as attending football trade fairs in Cannes and Los Angeles. Their German and South African rivals, both of whom spent far less than England, claimed that McGivan's team usually turned up at such events with bigger delegations than them, and put the largest amount of effort into rolling out the red carpet for Fifa bigwigs.

Two-thirds of the Fifa 24 and their partners enjoyed a four-day visit to London around the 1999 FA Cup Final. When five Fifa inspectors arrived last autumn, helicopters from the Royal Squadron carried them around.

FA sources say that 'full disclosure' of the £10m budget is planned.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: Throw a football 46 metres
fields.trailText: Throw a football 46 metres.
fields.body:
The short explanation is, I've really no idea. It's something I picked up by chance as a boy and first used to my advantage on trial with the England U-18s.

When they needed a new throw-taker, I volunteered, launched a couple and landed a place in the first team (the throw became part of our tactical plan straight away). It's only since then that I've thought seriously about technique.

Grip, speed and timing are the keys; it's got very little to do with strength.

You need to judge your throw like a golf swing, with the same precision, and with grip your first priority. If you don't have a tight grip on a dry ball, you'll have very little control over trajectory and distance. That's why we have towels all around the pitch at Prenton Park, and why, when Wembley banned towels last season, we considered using light-weight rubber gloves with bobbled surfaces. We only ruled that one out on fashion grounds.

You also need to extend your fingers as fully as possible, with your thumbs touching. When I get it wrong - usually when I'm wet and the weather's wet - the ball loops. When I get it right it can be as accurate and dangerous as a Beckham cross.

It's still difficult to be consistent though - my world record throw of 46.34m came after 29 dreadful attempts.

The other factors are run-up and aim. Fifa cleared long run-ups last season, with the proviso that they're only illegal if judged to be a tool for time-wasting. I'd recommend 10 steps - at Tranmere there's only room for three, but at the bigger grounds like Wolves you can really launch.

And as for aim - go for the far post. Even if your strikers don't score from the first ball they frequently will from the second. Critics still seem to think that it's cheating - an insult to the game. Frankly, they can say what they want but we'll carry on using it. You can and should use any piece of skill you can. This one happens to be mine.

webTitle: Britain's hold on Fifa is slipping

fields.headline: Britain's hold on Fifa is slipping
fields.trailText: Britain's vice-presidency on football's world governing body, Fifa, has survived but the stay of execution may last just four years.
fields.body:
Britain's vice-presidency on football's world governing body, Fifa, has survived but the stay of execution may last just four years.

As expected, the proposal to abolish the assured British representative was withdrawn by the Trinidad Football Association at Fifa's annual congress in Zurich yesterday.

Scotland's David Will, who currently holds the post, was absent from the congress as he is recovering from an operation on his spine. Will is due to stand down in 2002, by which time the proposed revamp of Fifa statutes will be well under way.

The work will be completed in 2003 and is expected to be implemented the following year to mark the anniversary of Fifa's centenary.

The automatic vice-presidency is a legacy of the prominence Britain used to enjoy in the football world. But it has come under increasing threat as Fifa continues to grow and will be subjected to close scrutiny when general secretary Michel Zen Ruffinen examines current statutes.

The stay of execution will be welcomed by the FA and the other Home associations but the continuing debate over Britain's grace-and-favour position highlights the diminishing influence wielded by the British Isles.

Recent events have underlined this with the debacle of England's 2006 World Cup bid and the revelation by Tony Banks, the Prime Minister's special envoy to the bid, that he had privately warned that the English bid was doomed well before the final vote went to Germany.

Further, the acceptance by Fifa that the World Cup should be rotated around its member federations from 2010, has underlined England's weakness.

The Zurich congress agreed to introduce a harmonised football calendar from 2002, which should help to ease the ongoing row between club and country over star players. This area of potential conflict has caused problems in the recent past with Arsenal and Chelsea players going 'AWOL' in last year's African Nations Cup and controversy over Dwight Yorke's loyalty to club and country - Manchester United and Trinidad and Tobago respectively. Now dates have been incorporated within the calendar between the middle of February and the middle of December for international qualifying matches, for which players must be released, with a further four for friendly games.

Tournaments such as Euro 2000 and the African Nations Cup must be played in a four-week block either between January and February or June and July.

Fifa has also defined the roles of four new committees, including the Football Committee, which includes Sir Bobby Charlton and Professional Footballers' Association chief executive Gordon Taylor among its members.

In what was a record attendance for a congress, with just North Korea and Tanzania absent, Bhutan were admitted as Fifa's 204th member, accepting the official pendant in national dress to applause from the assorted gathering.

President Sepp Blatter also highlighted the work of Fifa's 'Goal' project, which has invested £40million worldwide in the past 18 months trying to develop the game through communities, with Slovakia and Bosnia the main European beneficiaries.

It was confirmed that the next Club World Championship will take place in Spain next year, with 12 countries taking part. It was the first such tournament, in Brazil last season, that caused so many problems for Manchester United. They insisted they were under strong pressure to take part from the government to back England's World Cup bid and, as a consequence, decided to withdraw from last season's FA Cup. Their decision attracted massive criticism.

fields.headline: Advocaat demands improved attitude
fields.trailText: Scotland's battle with Europe through the past decade have been generally about as well-balanced as a match between an unarmed pygmy and a gorilla, leading to an understandable national apprehension each time the annual renewal of hostilities approaches.
fields.body:
Scotland's battle with Europe through the past decade have been generally about as well-balanced as a match between an unarmed pygmy and a gorilla, leading to an understandable national apprehension each time the annual renewal of hostilities approaches.

Even if Rangers last season managed to dispel much of the old trepidation by beating Parma to qualify for the first group phase of the Champions League, their effort proved to be short-lived.

Rangers once again will be expected to carry the banner this week, when all four Scottish representatives - Celtic, Hearts and Aberdeen in the Uefa Cup are the others - are engaged, but it has been hard in the last fortnight or so to miss a certain loss of buoyancy among those who had eagerly anticipated great things from Dick Advocaat's team.

The kindness of the draw for the two qualifying rounds - pairing Rangers first with Zalgiris Kaunas of Lithuania and then with the Danish champions, Herfolge - had hardened the assumption that reaching the league stage of the competition was a mere formality and that Rangers would use these outings simply as practice for the real thing next month. As is often the case, the rehearsal has not been deeply impressive.

The 4-1 victory over the Lithuanians at Ibrox 11 days ago ensured that there would be no disaster in last Wednesday's return leg, but the scoreline that night was much healthier than the performance. When the 90 minutes were up and Kaunas were down to nine men, having had two ordered off, the Scottish champions were only 2-1 ahead, and that thanks to a penalty kick.

The double which Billy Dodds produced in stoppage time gave the result much more substance than had seemed likely. With some new players in the team and the usual rustiness at the start of a season doubtless influential factors, Rangers could be expected to improve sufficiently to handle Herfolge, a small-town - they could almost be called a village - team who reputedly won the Danish championship by diligence rather than inspiration or brilliance.

'At the moment, I don't know a great deal about them,' said Advocaat on Friday, shortly before travelling to watch his opponents in action against the Danish Cup winners, Viborg. 'The little I do know is that they are a very hard-working team and that's how they won the championship. Our attitude to the games we've played has not been good and we saw it again in Lithuania on Wednesday. Our team will be very well prepared, but they simply have to go into the game with a better attitude.'

A benevolent draw should see the other three Scottish clubs over their first obstacles. Aberdeen's presence in the Uefa Cup, by virtue of finishing runners-up in the Scottish League Cup while ending last season bottom of the league, does appear bizarre, but even Ebbe Skovdahl's under-achievers are entitled to favouritism against Bohemians of Dublin.

Martin O'Neill himself, if given the opportunity, could hardly have picked less threatening opponents for Celtic than Jeunesse Esch in Luxembourg and Hearts are also scheduled to travel to their first match against IBV Vestmannayer of Iceland. The small plateau which passes for a stadium is so unsuitable that Thursday's first leg will be played in Reykjavik.

As is often the case, the rehearsal has not been deeply impressive. The 4-1 victory over the Lithuanians at Ibrox 11 days ago ensured that there would be no disaster in last Wednesday's return leg, but the scoreline that night was much healthier than the performance. When the 90 minutes were up and Kaunas were down to nine men, having had two ordered off, the Scottish champions were only 2-1 ahead, and that thanks to a penalty kick. The double which Billy Dodds produced in stoppage time gave the result much more substance than had seemed likely. With some new players in the team and the usual rustiness at the start of a season doubtless influential factors, Rangers could be expected to improve sufficiently to handle Herfolge, a small-town - they could almost be called a village - team who reputedly won the Danish championship by diligence rather than inspiration or brilliance. 'At the moment, I don't know a great deal about them,' said Advocaat on Friday, shortly before travelling to watch his opponents in action against the Danish Cup winners, Viborg. 'The little I do know is that they are a very hard-working team and that's how they won the championship. Our attitude to the games we've played has not been good and we saw it again in Lithuania on Wednesday. Our team will be very well prepared, but they simply have to go into the game with a better attitude.' A benevolent draw should see the other three Scottish clubs over their first obstacles. Aberdeen's presence in the Uefa Cup, by virtue of finishing runners-up in the Scottish League Cup while ending last season bottom of the league, does appear bizarre, but even Ebbe Skovdahl's under-achievers are entitled to favouritism against Bohemians of Dublin. Martin O'Neill himself, if given the opportunity, could hardly have picked less threatening opponents for Celtic than Jeunesse Esch in Luxembourg and Hearts are also scheduled to travel to their first match against IBV Vestmannayer of Iceland. The small plateau which passes for a stadium is so unsuitable that Thursday's first leg will be played in Reykjavik.

webTitle: Moyes' boys in a Lancashire hot spot

fields.headline: Moyes' boys in a Lancashire hot spot
fields.standfirst: Preston North End are finally back in the First Division and have plenty of local rivals for company
fields.trailText: David Moyes is nothing if not thorough. Preston North End's determined and ambitious young manager was still dissecting Monday evening's 5-0 thrashing by Everton at the training ground two days later, and a steward gravely passed on the information that our prearranged interview might have to wait. 'It's still only half time. There's all the second half yet, and that's not counting all the pauses and replays.'
fields.body:
David Moyes is nothing if not thorough. Preston North End's determined and ambitious young manager was still dissecting Monday evening's 5-0 thrashing by Everton at the training ground two days later, and a steward gravely passed on the information that our prearranged interview might have to wait. 'It's still only half time. There's all the second half yet, and that's not counting all the pauses and replays.'

This was only a pre-season friendly after all, and from all accounts Everton turned in an unexpectedly accomplished performance, but Moyes is the meticulous type. Either that or he enjoys the sound of his Glaswegian tones berating this first touch or that misplaced pass, and he certainly has no qualms about keeping journalists hanging around. All in all, it is not too difficult to work out why his unofficial nickname is Young Fergie.

'I've heard that, but I don't know where people get it from,' Moyes said. 'The only similarity I can see is that we are both managers and we're both from Glasgow.' Get on the wrong side of Moyes, as one or two people have discovered, and there are further similarities with the tyrant of Old Trafford, but this is no time to be tactless. Moyes, who peppers his team talks liberally with motivational quotes from the Red Knight's autobiography, is one of Fergie's biggest fans. 'I think everybody is a fan of Sir Alex,' he said. 'He's had great success, he's achieved everything, and he's done it all by himself, starting at the bottom and working his way up.'

Moyes, whose Preston side won the Second Division last season in only his second full season as coach, reckons he is lucky to be starting out on the managerial ladder a rung or two higher than where Ferguson's career began. North End is a solid, well-run club that ought to be able to find a niche for itself in Division One despite operating at lower levels for the past 20 years. 'The set-up here is First Division at least,' Moyes said. 'I'm not going to make any daft boasts, and I'm not going to use the word consolidation either, not at this stage of the season anyway. But the stadium, the club and the fan base are First-Division sized. I'm fairly confident we can make a go of it but we need to see how the players respond.'

On the face of it Moyes should have few worries in that respect. It is precisely his ability to get the best out of his players, not to mention turning Preston from a long ball side to the most cultured passers in the Second Division, which has got him noticed. Already earmarked at the age of 37 as a manager to watch, Moyes has been linked with a couple of Premiership vacancies since Old Trafford's interest alerted everyone to the fact that Preston had a promising young coach.

Moyes is reluctant to talk about why he never actually became Ferguson's assistant at United, though it is clear the episode was more than mere speculation and that somewhere along the line he was disappointed. He would have had a tough decision anyway, between being a manager in his own right or accepting a lesser role at a much bigger club, though given his reverence for the personality involved and the certainty that the chance to work with Ferguson will be gone in two or three years' time, one suspects he would not have needed too long to make up his mind.

'There's no need to talk about what is in the past,' he said. 'I have won a championship since and I'm very proud of that, and there is plenty of potential. But speaking theoretically, if I had the chance of a job where I felt I could learn more, or learn faster, I'd take it.'

To say Moyes is eager to learn would be understating the case considerably. He qualified as a coach at the age of 22, and has been on practically every FA or SFA course to have come along since. 'He's got coaching badges coming out of his ears,' as a local journalist put it. Moyes was involved in Euro 2000, assessing selected games for yet another SFA qualification and working alongside Roy Hodgson for Uefa. Had things turned out differently he might have been encountering Hodgson again this season, but instead it will be Graeme Souness, bringing Blackburn Rovers to Deepdale for one of several keenly anticipated local derbies. With Preston, Blackburn, Bolton and Burnley all reunited in the First Division once again, it should be just like old times in Lancashire.

Moyes rates Blackburn as the team most likely to succeed, simply because, like Fulham, they have money to spend mid-season. Bolton, as Sam Allardyce has frankly admitted, are in a healthy financial situation following the sale of Eidur Gudjohnsen and Claus Jensen, but are not as strong a side as last season. Money is tighter at Burnley and Preston, though having spent an unprecedented £850,000 already this summer, Moyes claims there is a modest amount at his disposal should things start to go badly wrong.

'We've not got millions, but we have a board who are young, bright and helpful,' Moyes said. 'That's why this club is gradually moving in the right direction. It might have taken a while for us to get back into Division One, but I'd like to think it will be a while before we go back down again. Playing at this level is what Preston supporters want and deserve. I can't wait for the atmosphere at all those derbies. Many fans have been brought up on lower league football and half-empty grounds. Only the old timers can remember this club in the old First Division, but you would have to be into your thirties to even remember us in Division Two.'

The nerve-centre of Preston's climb back into the relative big time has to be seen to be believed. Moyes's 'office' is just a desk, a diary and a telephone shoved into a corner of what is already a very small changing room. 'I'm a coach, my place of work is on the training field,' he explained. 'I try to give myself as little office work as possible, as you can probably tell.'

On the same training field, as recently as six years ago, Moyes the Preston player laboured under John Beck's uncomplicated and uncompromising regime. Kick it long, coaching badges coming out of your ears or not. Surprisingly he is not bitter. 'Some of John's ideas were not easy for me to accept, but it was a great learning curve, and I must admit I'm still using some of his drills,' Moyes said. 'That's the nature of football. There's no right or wrong, no good or bad, you just take out what works for you and leave the rest. I like it when people say Preston play attractive football, but I don't kid myself I wouldn't be just as happy with a scruffy game and three points. You play for a result and that's all there is to it. It's a matter of using your players as effectively as possible. That's what coaching is all about.'
