webTitle: In the court of King George

fields.headline: In the court of King George
fields.standfirst: As a player he has done it all. He made money and friends in high places. Now George Weah faces his toughest goal  - to help the child soldiers traumatised by  civil war in Liberia. Jason Burke, in Monrovia, sees a local legend cast his spell.
fields.trailText: As a player he has done it all. He made money and friends in high places. Now George Weah faces his toughest goal - to help the child soldiers traumatised by civil war in Liberia. Jason Burke, in Monrovia, sees a local legend cast his spell.
fields.body:
The Reverend Myer S. Wesseh was once the slickest, coolest, middleweight boxing champion Monrovia had ever seen.

We sit on the concrete porch of his home, looking out on the jumbled alleys of one of the Liberian capital's poorest quarters. He is trying to convince me that his grand-nephew should have followed him into the fight game. "It's a great shame," he says, slapping a thin thigh for emphasis. "But the young boy kept having this dream in which he saw himself playing football and scoring goals, lots of goals. It was God's way of showing him his destiny. And he had to follow that destiny. The 'young boy' was George Weah.

The house where Wesseh still lives, and where a pre-pubescent Weah dreamt of footballing greatness, is a warren of interconnected rooms and corridors. It's in Claratown. Elsewhere Claratown might be called working-class but here, where only a fraction of men have jobs, the term is hardly appropriate.

It's a battered mass of nailed planks and rusting corrugated iron split by narrow lanes full of mud in the rainy season and dust in the dry. The only way to distinguish Weah's house from those all around is to look for where the wooden walls stop and the concrete walls (built with the footballer's recent wealth) start.

Not one building has a second floor. A few yards from where I am sitting five young men are playing draughts and arguing quietly. A pot of peanuts is boiling on a brazier. Some boys kick a ball against a wall. The rain has stopped. And then the thudding of ball on wall stops too. Everyone looks up. There is a sudden silence. Then every male under 35 starts to move towards the main street. And the whisper reaches the Reverend and I, sitting on the porch.

George Weah (the first African to become a global football star, World, African and European footballer of the year 1995, winner of Serie A, captain of the recently victorious Liberian national side, multi-millionaire, Unicef ambassador) is coming home.

Within seconds, preceded by a swarm of young boys, he strides easily into the small courtyard. He is wearing a black Tommy Hilfiger-style skull cap, shades, a black Versace T-shirt and belt, white slacks and open-toed brown leather mules. On one wrist he has a gold chain and a set of cheap beads, on the other an expensive-looking but unshowy watch. He wears two plain silver rings on one finger and is slimmer and slighter and more youthful looking than I had expected. He moves with the languor of the very fit and the very rich and eases himself into a chair next to me (it's the only one available), nods hello and shakes hands courteously if with enough limpness to indicate our relative stations in life.

The porch fills rapidly with relatives, neighbours, passers-by, fans, goggling children, old friends. The crowd is five deep outside and stretches down the lane to where he has parked his Porsche Boxster - registration '4 Me Only'.

Weah, without getting up, shakes hands with his relatives. He takes off the Versace shades. There is a pause and no one seems entirely sure what to do or say. I'm feeling embarrassed that he has come home to find journalists talking to his relatives so I apologise. He lifts a finger and almost imperceptibly shakes his head to indicate my explanation is unnecessary.

There is another pause so I ask if he is pleased to be home. He nods very slightly. "This was my life. These are my own people. I love being here."

There are at least 70 people watching us now. At my back ranks of faces are pressed against the chicken wire. They are silent with reverence. Further away, however, others are singing and someone is blowing a whistle repeatedly. A large lady in a hat has sat almost on my lap and I am writing my shorthand on a damp notepad balanced on her right thigh. More people squeeze onto the porch. A chicken, trapped and worried by the press of people, is pecking my shoe and the sweat is coursing down my back. Though he still looks impossibly relaxed I am ridiculously happy to see that drops are forming on Weah's forehead too and the Versace T-shirt is darkening with sweat.

Later in the week he is scheduled to launch a Unicef (United Nations Children Fund) football tournament for children. The project is aimed at raising awareness of polio and HIV/Aids in Liberia. How important is his work for charity to him? "I come from a poor family. I do what I can." I point out that a lot of footballers don't. "Different people have different priorities." Can football really help Liberia, or Africa? "It speaks to a lot of people. It keeps them off the street ..." Another pause.

A gap-toothed woman wearing an ancient Hard Rock cafe T-shirt and a fantastically dirty towel on her head shoulders her way forward and embraces Weah. She is followed by what can only be described as an ancient crone with wrinkled dugs who pinches Weah's cheek, wags a finger and squeezes the remnants of her right breast. Though I can't follow her English it is clear what she means: "I remember when I used to suckle you and you were so high ...". For a moment Weah looks like an embarrassed seven-year-old.

"She was my grandmother's best friend," he explains. "These are all my aunts. They always wanted to beat me when I kicked balls into their houses on the street. We had real respect instilled in us. Real respect for our elders. I have come a long way from here. Football has been good to me. Everyone has their destiny but you have to make use of the opportunities. I have spent 15 years at the top of my game. It makes me happy. I love the game. I love scoring goals. But I have always taken it seriously. It is not what the game gives you, it is what you give it. It is what you choose. You've got to work hard and make things happen."

Weah speaks quietly, fluently and unemotionally. It is clear that this is a medley of the phrases he has repeated in a thousand interviews. He doesn't even ask for the questions.

A few days later I see him sitting in his room at the hotel (his own in fact) that the national side use as a base when in Liberia. The room is full of money men, agents, hangers-on, women, all looking for a piece of George Weah. But the great man has stretched his long frame out in an armchair with a walkman and a stack of hip-hop CDs and is just watching them with the same detached, courteous superiority that I saw on the porch in Claratown.

Only three times in the week we spent in Liberia do I see him so much as raise his voice.

Once in the changing room before the Cape Verde game, once when his squad turn up late for training and once when I ask him, sitting on the porch of the house he grew up in, if he has always felt that people have believed in him. Then suddenly, unexpectedly, his voice is black.

"When I left Liberia everyone said I would be wasting my time." He almost spits, almost snarls it. "But they were wrong. I showed them they were wrong. I went to Cameroon and I dominated. I went to France and they doubted me and I dominated. I went to Italy and they said it was the hardest league in the world and I dominated there too."

But then he pauses and reverts to his earlier deadpan softness.

We spend a moment talking about the attractions of Chelsea Harbour where he has been living while playing at Stamford Bridge last season and I ask him what his plans are now and he refuses to tell me.

Then he invites me to the Lone Stars training that afternoon. We talk about the Nigeria game and the African Nations Cup qualifier in three days time (Liberia have to win by two goals) and then his friend passes him a mobile and he grins as he shouts into it: "Hey bro', how you doing? Been trying to get you but can't get through." I don't get to speak to him again.

Liberia lies on what was once known as the 'slave coast' of Africa. From the seventeenth through to the mid-nineteenth century the tribes living in the thick tropical jungle of this part of the West African coast provided much of the forced labour required by Western Europe's new overseas colonies.

With its malaria, yellow fever, cholera, snakes and hostile tribes, it was known in Europe as 'the white man's graveyard'.

When the northern American states turned against the slave trade and people raised the idea of repatriating 'the blacks' to Africa it was to the slave coast they were sent.

In 1822 a group of philanthropists and black activists organised the dispatch of 5,000 freed slaves back across the Atlantic to form a new state. It eventually became Liberia.

The new immigrants quickly set about enslaving the indigenous people. They built their own plantation-style estates and even sold their captive labour force overseas.

The villas they built in their new capital of Monrovia (named after President Monroe) even mimicked the houses of the owners from whom they'd escaped. They ruled over the local tribes, unchallenged, for more than a century. Their slave trade was still thriving in the 1930s.

King George Oppong Weah was born in a small village outside Monrovia in 1966 into the Kru tribe. He had 12 brothers and sisters, long, strong legs but little else.

His parents, following local custom, sent him to be raised by his grandmother in Monrovia itself.

We arrived in the capital two days after the Lone Stars ( the national side ) had beaten the Nigerian Super Eagles 2-1 in a crucial World Cup qualifier. The win had been against all expectations.

Monrovia had, we were told, gone wild. But by Tuesday the post-match euphoria had been washed away. It had been raining steadily since the game. The roads had been churned to red mud and stinking black; rubbish-strewn pools were everywhere.

As we drove into Claratown a stream of people parted around us, their heads lowered against the downpour. Only the children looked at our car.

The moment we mention Weah the atmosphere changes. People are delighted, smug, proud, welcoming, loud. Sampson Cole, 32, leads us proudly through the lanes towards the house where Weah grew up telling stories of kicking make-shift balls around with him 25 years before.

Weah, tall for his age, started off as a goalkeeper before moving to the wing. "He used to play with anything. Even a tin can", Cole says. "But he was good, so good."

By his early teens Weah was playing semi-professionally. He would go to school, run back to play a match with his Claratown friends, then go on to train with his league team. He would come home at seven exhausted, day after day.

Life wasn't easy. His grandmother would get up at 6am to start selling fish. When there wasn't enough food (and often there wasn't) Weah would be fed by his neighbours, the 'aunts'. He started playing for the local Claratown team. All afternoon, every afternoon.

He wasn't an angel. Friends tell stories of drinking and smoking " not just tobacco" at the local 'Shaolin Temple', a kind of youth club-cum-bar-cum-pool hall.

But his focus on football soon became complete. From 1981 to 1984 Weah played with Young Survivors. They were a fourth division side when he joined them, a second division side when he left.

Parlee Dixon, who coached him in his first year with the club, told me it was immediately clear "he was a genius".

In his first game for the side he scored two spectacular goals, one hit from such a tight angle that it went in-off having struck both posts. Weah clearly knew his own ability. "He was always talking about the national team", Dixon said. "He was totally confident he would play for them."

Weah was soon picked up by Bong Range United. He came on as a substitute and was, former teammates say, so psyched by his exclusion from the game that he seemed to score by sheer will.

He was picked up by Mighty Barolle and then moved on to their arch-rivals Invincible Eleven where he was soon captain and top scorer. He was spotted by a scout for Tonerre de Yaounde of Cameroon and after a season there Claude Leroy, the Cameroon national coach, mentioned the young star to Arsene Wenger, then at Monaco.

The story goes that Wenger flew down to Africa to watch the youngster and signed him on the spot for £12,000.

Wenger watched over his young charge carefully. Weah wasn't going to let him down. He watched his diet, slept well, didn't drink and didn't mess around. He stayed on after training to practise. Soon he had a regular place in the first team and when the goals started going in they didn't stop.

Weah went on to Paris St.Germain and in the summer of 1995 put on the red and black of AC Milan. In his four years at the club Milan won back the Italian title, Weah scored one of the greatest individual goals in the history of the game (against Verona in 1996: an impossible waltz down the length of the pitch, beating seven players) and became the first player ever to be European, African and World player of the year in the same season.

He had a stunning Jamaican-American wife, two kids, four homes on three continents and a ridiculous amount of money. The boy from Claratown had done what he had set out to do.

Like Weah, John Jupilay is 34, though he looks 20 years older. His life has taken a rather different course. He was a trader in Monrovia until his leg was blown off by a mine in 1994 at the height of the civil war.

We met him at a Unicef-sponsored prosthetic clinic in the forest by Liberia's northern border. "I was out foraging for something to eat in the fields behind my house when there was a huge bang and I was thrown 10 feet through the air. I never felt anything. When I came round I was in hospital and my leg had gone. Then the pain began," he said, rocking back and forth gingerly on his new plastic limb watched by his physiotherapist.

It had taken him a year to save up the money (about $3) needed for the journey from the capital.

The Liberian civil war (fought between different ethnic factions aligned with different external powers) killed an estimated 150,000 people and left millions more homeless.

Today the average life expectancy in Liberia is 55, 80 per cent of the 2.5 million people live below the poverty line and most of the country has no healthcare, no schools and no roads. Last month an acre or so of central Monrovia was connected to power lines. The rest of Liberia gets no electricity at all.

It's a country that is so poor children rush out to pick up road kill and offer it for sale to passing traffic, so backward that when a child is savaged by a baboon local people launch a witch hunt to find the man who transformed himself into an ape to carry out the attack.

The winner of the war was Charles Taylor, the leader of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia. He was elected President in 1995 by a populace so tired of war that they were happy to vote for him (the most brutal of the gunmen) if it brought peace.

The war left other legacies. In Buchanan, 80 miles down the coast from Monrovia, we meet Curtis and Moses and Junior. They were among an estimated 15,000 child soldiers who fought with the rebels.

The dozen boys we meet at another Unicef project, a rehabilitation centre, saw and took part in appalling atrocities. One watched his family burning to death as their home was torched. They will admit to killing people but they say it was in combat.

In fact the rebels routinely massacred civilians, raped girls, tortured and executed prisoners. They employed the tactics of terror. Often the worst culprits were the younger troops. The rebels' Small Boys Units were infamous for their cruelty.

In one corner sits a 13-year-old with no hands. They were amputated in Sierra Leone by the rebels there. He is playing draughts with his stumps. In Phebe hospital, deep in the heartland of Liberia, there are four stinking wards full of more children. A child a day dies. There are a dozen children who have the pinched, blank faces of the very weak. Their heads and bellies are huge, their limbs thin. There has been no emergency famine here. For 10 years there have simply been a lot of people in Liberia without enough to eat.

Nearby is a three-year-old on a ventilator. It has been keeping him alive. But now there is no fuel for the generator so it lies useless. The boy pants frantically. The hospital administrator tells me the power will come on again in a few hours. He hopes the child won't die before then.

Two days after the Nigeria game and three before they have to play Cape Verde, the Lone Stars gather for training in the national sports stadium.

It is 3.30pm and Weah has been waiting for 90 minutes for all the squad to turn up. Last in is George Gebeo, a phenomenally talented 19-year-old currently playing in Greece. He arrives in a battered yellow taxi. It is raining again. Weah, appointed technical director of the Lone Stars by personal decree of the President, is a picture of suppressed fury.

In his boots and strip he looks a lot older and a lot bigger than he did when we met him at home. Gathering the players in the centre of the pitch he starts to lay into them. "What do you mean by coming so late?" he asks. "Some of you play in Europe. You wouldn't do that there. Why do you do it here when you are playing for your national side? I left my family's house to come here two hours ago to be here on time. Where is your respect?" The players shift uneasily from foot to foot.

Wearing the colours of a dozen of Europe's top teams and worth tens of millions of pounds between them they look out of place in the battered, bullet-scarred stadium with its weed-strewn, half cut grass. Christopher Wreh stands quietly in the yellow and blue of the Arsenal away strip. I wonder quite what their managers would think if could see their players now, on the scrubby grass, with their socks down, no shinpads, no physios, no trainers, no real coaches.

Weah is almost apoplectic. You can see his barely contained anger in his every movement. It is clear he simply can't understand how other people don't want this as badly as he does. Because even at 34, with the best of his career behind him, Weah still wants it badly.

They huddle for a short prayer and then start to train. For 40 minutes they dribble round cones and do short passing exercises.

The subs by the bench start listing the African players who have made it in Europe, swapping their $20 a month local salaries for the megabucks of modern Western football.

They talk about the Nigerians Nwankwo Kanu and Celestine Babayaro, who play at Arsenal and Chelsea for approaching £40,000 a week, and Shaun Bartlett, the South African currently playing in Switzerland and valued at £4m.

(This is not idle speculation. Luis Figo cost Real Madrid around £40m, almost exactly the Liberian government's annual expenditure.) "I'd love to see that," he says. "That is our dream."

On Saturday the rain had cleared. The news was full of heavy fighting against insurgents in the north of the country (up towards the hospital we visited early in the week) and presidential engagements. And, of course, the afternoon's Cape Verde game.

When they had travelled to Praia, the Lone Stars had been beaten 2-0. Now, to qualify for the Africa Cup, they needed to win by two goals at home.

In between the fence and the stadium are hundreds of police and soldiers armed with whatever they could lay their hands on - guns, batons, bits of wood, their own heavy belts. Their task is to catch those streaming across the fence and they are not particular about how they do it.

Those caught get an appalling beating. "Pain is the only language these people understand," said one fat, heavily sweating police officer. Inside the stadium the atmosphere is very different. Even the witchdoctors on the touchline are happy.

Below, deep inside the grandstand, Weah is psyching up his team. He tells them what they have to do, why they have to do it and that they can do it. And then they gather in a huddle for a short, fervent prayer. Which appears to have been heard. After only three minutes Weah smashes the ball into the Cape Verde net. A second goal straight after half-time takes the Lone Stars through to the next round of the Africa Cup - and the crowd close to hysteria.

Weah scores again after 77 minutes, and that seems to settle it. Then, in injury time, a penalty. If Cape Verde score they are through. For five seconds nowhere on the entire African continent is as quiet as that stadium. And Clayton saves it. Spreading to his left he palms the ball around a post.

It's all over. The crowd go mad, streaming onto the pitch. The players are leaping on top of each other. Clayton is crying, the witchdoctors are waving all sorts of odd things in the air. And everyone is singing. And dancing. And singing.

I think about a comment I'd heard a few days earlier in Claratown. Two young men were leaning against a shack 50 yards from Weah's home, drinking sangria and watching the crowds swarming around the great man. I stood around and started talking with them. They were brothers, both first division footballers and childhood friends of Weah.

fields.bodyText: The Reverend Myer S. Wesseh was once the slickest, coolest, middleweight boxing champion Monrovia had ever seen. We sit on the concrete porch of his home, looking out on the jumbled alleys of one of the Liberian capital's poorest quarters. He is trying to convince me that his grand-nephew should have followed him into the fight game. "It's a great shame," he says, slapping a thin thigh for emphasis. "But the young boy kept having this dream in which he saw himself playing football and scoring goals, lots of goals. It was God's way of showing him his destiny. And he had to follow that destiny. The 'young boy' was George Weah. The house where Wesseh still lives, and where a pre-pubescent Weah dreamt of footballing greatness, is a warren of interconnected rooms and corridors. It's in Claratown. Elsewhere Claratown might be called working-class but here, where only a fraction of men have jobs, the term is hardly appropriate. It's a battered mass of nailed planks and rusting corrugated iron split by narrow lanes full of mud in the rainy season and dust in the dry. The only way to distinguish Weah's house from those all around is to look for where the wooden walls stop and the concrete walls (built with the footballer's recent wealth) start. Not one building has a second floor. A few yards from where I am sitting five young men are playing draughts and arguing quietly. A pot of peanuts is boiling on a brazier. Some boys kick a ball against a wall. The rain has stopped. And then the thudding of ball on wall stops too. Everyone looks up. There is a sudden silence. Then every male under 35 starts to move towards the main street. And the whisper reaches the Reverend and I, sitting on the porch. George Weah (the first African to become a global football star, World, African and European footballer of the year 1995, winner of Serie A, captain of the recently victorious Liberian national side, multi-millionaire, Unicef ambassador) is coming home. Within seconds, preceded by a swarm of young boys, he strides easily into the small courtyard. He is wearing a black Tommy Hilfiger-style skull cap, shades, a black Versace T-shirt and belt, white slacks and open-toed brown leather mules. On one wrist he has a gold chain and a set of cheap beads, on the other an expensive-looking but unshowy watch. He wears two plain silver rings on one finger and is slimmer and slighter and more youthful looking than I had expected. He moves with the languor of the very fit and the very rich and eases himself into a chair next to me (it's the only one available), nods hello and shakes hands courteously if with enough limpness to indicate our relative stations in life. The porch fills rapidly with relatives, neighbours, passers-by, fans, goggling children, old friends. The crowd is five deep outside and stretches down the lane to where he has parked his Porsche Boxster - registration '4 Me Only'. Weah, without getting up, shakes hands with his relatives. He takes off the Versace shades. There is a pause and no one seems entirely sure what to do or say. I'm feeling embarrassed that he has come home to find journalists talking to his relatives so I apologise. He lifts a finger and almost imperceptibly shakes his head to indicate my explanation is unnecessary. There is another pause so I ask if he is pleased to be home. He nods very slightly. "This was my life. These are my own people. I love being here." There are at least 70 people watching us now. At my back ranks of faces are pressed against the chicken wire. They are silent with reverence. Further away, however, others are singing and someone is blowing a whistle repeatedly. A large lady in a hat has sat almost on my lap and I am writing my shorthand on a damp notepad balanced on her right thigh. More people squeeze onto the porch. A chicken, trapped and worried by the press of people, is pecking my shoe and the sweat is coursing down my back. Though he still looks impossibly relaxed I am ridiculously happy to see that drops are forming on Weah's forehead too and the Versace T-shirt is darkening with sweat. Later in the week he is scheduled to launch a Unicef (United Nations Children Fund) football tournament for children. The project is aimed at raising awareness of polio and HIV/Aids in Liberia. How important is his work for charity to him? "I come from a poor family. I do what I can." I point out that a lot of footballers don't. "Different people have different priorities." Can football really help Liberia, or Africa? "It speaks to a lot of people. It keeps them off the street ..." Another pause. A gap-toothed woman wearing an ancient Hard Rock cafe T-shirt and a fantastically dirty towel on her head shoulders her way forward and embraces Weah. She is followed by what can only be described as an ancient crone with wrinkled dugs who pinches Weah's cheek, wags a finger and squeezes the remnants of her right breast. Though I can't follow her English it is clear what she means: "I remember when I used to suckle you and you were so high ...". For a moment Weah looks like an embarrassed seven-year-old. "She was my grandmother's best friend," he explains. "These are all my aunts. They always wanted to beat me when I kicked balls into their houses on the street. We had real respect instilled in us. Real respect for our elders. I have come a long way from here. Football has been good to me. Everyone has their destiny but you have to make use of the opportunities. I have spent 15 years at the top of my game. It makes me happy. I love the game. I love scoring goals. But I have always taken it seriously. It is not what the game gives you, it is what you give it. It is what you choose. You've got to work hard and make things happen." Weah speaks quietly, fluently and unemotionally. It is clear that this is a medley of the phrases he has repeated in a thousand interviews. He doesn't even ask for the questions. A few days later I see him sitting in his room at the hotel (his own in fact) that the national side use as a base when in Liberia. The room is full of money men, agents, hangers-on, women, all looking for a piece of George Weah. But the great man has stretched his long frame out in an armchair with a walkman and a stack of hip-hop CDs and is just watching them with the same detached, courteous superiority that I saw on the porch in Claratown. Only three times in the week we spent in Liberia do I see him so much as raise his voice. Once in the changing room before the Cape Verde game, once when his squad turn up late for training and once when I ask him, sitting on the porch of the house he grew up in, if he has always felt that people have believed in him. Then suddenly, unexpectedly, his voice is black. "When I left Liberia everyone said I would be wasting my time." He almost spits, almost snarls it. "But they were wrong. From the seventeenth through to the mid-nineteenth century the tribes living in the thick tropical jungle of this part of the West African coast provided much of the forced labour required by Western Europe's new overseas colonies. With its malaria, yellow fever, cholera, snakes and hostile tribes, it was known in Europe as 'the white man's graveyard'. In 1822 a group of philanthropists and black activists organised the dispatch of 5,000 freed slaves back across the Atlantic to form a new state. It eventually became Liberia. The new immigrants quickly set about enslaving the indigenous people. They built their own plantation-style estates and even sold their captive labour force overseas. It had taken him a year to save up the money (about $3) needed for the journey from the capital. The Liberian civil war (fought between different ethnic factions aligned with different external powers) killed an estimated 150,000 people and left millions more homeless. Last month an acre or so of central Monrovia was connected to power lines. The rest of Liberia gets no electricity at all. It's a country that is so poor children rush out to pick up road kill and offer it for sale to passing traffic, so backward that when a child is savaged by a baboon local people launch a witch hunt to find the man who transformed himself into an ape to carry out the attack. The winner of the war was Charles Taylor, the leader of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia. fields.headline: A brief history of the football
fields.trailText: In medieval times the parental rebuke "stop playing with your food" could be taken a little more literally: long before the creation of the Football League in 1888 footballers were partial to playing keepy-up with a hog's head.
fields.body:
In medieval times the parental rebuke "stop playing with your food" could be taken a little more literally: long before the creation of the Football League in 1888 footballers were partial to playing keepy-up with a hog's head.

Historians also reported that hundreds of years ago victorious English soldiers used the skulls of fallen enemy in their post-battle football games (cue morbid cries of "on me 'ead son").

The first properly made ball was simply a pig or sheep's bladder, inflated by good old fashioned lung power and knotted at the end. A leather casing would then be fitted around the bladder to provide durability. The resulting ball was rounder than a rugby ball, although still far from spherical. It was the invention of an india-rubber bladder in 1862, along with a pump to inflate it, which meant that a round ball which retained its shape could be easily produced.

The football changed relatively little in the first half of the 1900s. The basic structure of a rubber bladder cased within stitched leather panels remained. The main problem with the design was found out by the persistent wet weather in Britain. Even when treated with liberal amounts of dubbin, balls would quickly become waterlogged and more than double in weight. A player literally risked his neck going up for a header (indeed, Billy McPhail, who played for Celtic in the 1950s, claimed in court two years ago that his pre-senile dementia was caused by repeatedly heading sodden, old-style leather footballs).

The first completely non-leather ball appeared in the 1960s, but Fifa preferred leather, albeit with a fully waterproof coating, for World Cups until Mexico 1986, when the synthetic Adidas Azteca was used.

Now that football involves such huge levels of financial investment, even the balls themselves are big business . Manufacturers no longer permit them to be thought of as a plain old bladder in a bag. The latest generation of balls have sleek, go-faster names like Nike Geo Catalyst and Adidas Equipment Terrestra Silverstream.

High-tech tests are carried out to gauge their performance. Scientific jargon worthy of NASA is used to market them: Premium carbon latex 6-wing bladder (Nike); Micro fibre compuste layers with Pre Lamine, Toyo ink printing (Reebok); Gas filled micro-balloons of equal size and equal distance apart using Syntactic foam (Adidas): All a long, long way from 'Lillywhite's No.5', the first football ever used by the Football Association.
fields.bodyText: In medieval times the parental rebuke "stop playing with your food" could be taken a little more literally: long before the creation of the Football League in 1888 footballers were partial to playing keepy-up with a hog's head. Historians also reported that hundreds of years ago victorious English soldiers used the skulls of fallen enemy in their post-battle football games (cue morbid cries of "on me 'ead son"). The first properly made ball was simply a pig or sheep's bladder, inflated by good old fashioned lung power and knotted at the end. A leather casing would then be fitted around the bladder to provide durability. The resulting ball was rounder than a rugby ball, although still far from spherical. It was the invention of an india-rubber bladder in 1862, along with a pump to inflate it, which meant that a round ball which retained its shape could be easily produced. The football changed relatively little in the first half of the 1900s. The basic structure of a rubber bladder cased within stitched leather panels remained. The main problem with the design was found out by the persistent wet weather in Britain. Even when treated with liberal amounts of dubbin, balls would quickly become waterlogged and more than double in weight. A player literally risked his neck going up for a header (indeed, Billy McPhail, who played for Celtic in the 1950s, claimed in court two years ago that his pre-senile dementia was caused by repeatedly heading sodden, old-style leather footballs). The first completely non-leather ball appeared in the 1960s, but Fifa preferred leather, albeit with a fully waterproof coating, for World Cups until Mexico 1986, when the synthetic Adidas Azteca was used. Now that football involves such huge levels of financial investment, even the balls themselves are big business . Manufacturers no longer permit them to be thought of as a plain old bladder in a bag. fields.headline: Dodds to the rescue again
fields.trailText: It was fun while it lasted, but defending champions Rangers outlined their perennial powers of recovery by turning a potential defeat into an improbable, yet ultimately convincing victory at Rugby Park.
fields.body:
It was fun while it lasted, but defending champions Rangers outlined their perennial powers of recovery by turning a potential defeat into an improbable, yet ultimately convincing victory at Rugby Park.

Inside 10 minutes, Kilmarnock were two ahead, courtesy of an Andy McLaren brace - deserved reward for a storming start. Rangers were unusually slow to respond, but the turning point was at last created on 34 minutes when the home side's Kevin McGowne was dismissed for a second bookable offence, after dragging back a breaking Rod Wallace.

Billy Dodds calmly netted the resulting penalty, and from then on the home side were put firmly on the back foot as they tried to protect their one-goal lead.

Until then, Rangers, sporting an unfamiliar third-choice red kit, had looked distinctly off-colour, Cristophe Cocard's brilliant turn past Sergio Porrini typifying Kilmarnock's flair.

Circumstances suddenly conspired against Kilmarnock when, two minutes later, Gary Holt's needless foul on Neil McCann saw Rangers awarded a penalty.

Dodds stepped up to convert from the spot for his fifth goal of the season in only his fourth match to make it 2-1.

As the visitors strived for an equaliser the match became increasingly bad-tempered. Kilmarnock's Peter Canero, himself booked before the break, was hauled down by Sergio Porrini, earning the Rangers defender a 52nd minute caution.

Rangers continued to press urgently, with first McCann beating two men before firing straight at Gordon Marshall, then the Kilmarnock keeper saving at the second attempt from a Barry Ferguson shot.

Amoruso flicked a header wide before Rangers brought off Porrini and Wallace for youngster Kenny Miller and Turkish international Tugay with 25 minutes remaining.

Veteran Ally McCoist replaced Vareille on 70 minutes for the home side and within moments almost produced a goal as he found a way past Amoruso, only to send a long-range effort wide.

Time ran out for the home side after 75 minutes, as the visitors' numerical advantage began to tell. Van Bronckhorst's corner was met firmly by the head of the prolific Dodds who, not for the first time this season, had secured his side an unlikely reprieve.

A mere two minutes later Rangers twisted the knife, Miller pouncing to drill in his first goal since switching from Hibernian.

Miller then headed over before Tugay rounded Marshall and composed himself before smashing the ball into an empty net. Game over. But what a game it was.

fields.headline: The day Barclays left town
fields.standfirst: Colin Friers on how a small Hertfordshire village is still coming to terms with its loss
fields.trailText: Colin Friers on how a small Hertfordshire village is still coming to terms with its loss.
fields.body:
On 3 September 1999, Barclays closed its branch in Wheathampstead, a small village of 5,000 people in rural Hertfordshire. After 62 years, the bank gave its customers two weeks' notice. It had been the last bank or building society in the village.

At the time, Paul Barber, Barclays' director of communications, said: 'Customers are very important to us, and we don't want customers to leave.' But from being a village with a bank at its centre, the residents of Wheathampstead found themselves, almost overnight, in the 15 per cent of the population living furthest from a bank or building society branch. Almost a year later, Wheathampstead's former vicar, Tom Purchas, who took part in the demonstration against the closure, recalls Barclays departure 'as a sad day for the village'.

Derek French, director of the Campaign for Community Banking Services, is a veteran of many such closure battles. He recalls the passion that the Wheathampstead closure provoked. 'There were people with white sticks, and young mothers pushing prams protesting,' he says. 'This is middle England, where most people have bank accounts, and where people are inconvenienced rather than disadvantaged by branch closures - though some quite badly.' As the first anniversary approaches, it is a departure many in the village are still coming to terms with.

Dolly Smith, who lives in Wheathampstead, has been a Barclays customer since 1988. She was one of those outside the doors of the bank the day it closed despite being aged 80 and suffering from arthritis. Like many elderly residents of the village, she prefers face-to-face banking. 'The lady in Barclays was very nice, it was all very good, and then they went and closed it,' she says.

'I don't think closing it is very good, but you have to carry on,' she adds. Dolly Smith has remained loyal to Barclays, though she now has to travel further afield.Banking now involves a 15-minute journey, rather than 'five minutes down the road', and, not having a car, she is reliant on others to take her. 'I get my brother-in-law to take me to Marshalswick,' she says.

However, not all of Wheathampstead's Barclays customers have remained so loyal. Joanne Sandvoss, who works in the village store, left Barclays three or four months ago. She said: 'I didn't have time to get to Barclays branches in Harpenden or St Albans. I told Barclays the reasons, took all my money out, closed my account and opened one with the Post Office,' she says. And she has no regrets. 'The Girobank service is as good as Barclays was,' she says.

Tracey Canfield, 24, who works in Hair Afayre in the village, is another affected by the closure. Before it closed, she says she used to go there a couple of times a week. Now, because of the hours she works, she finds it difficult to get to Barclays in Marshalswick before it closes. And for nights out she is dependant on the ATM in the village not running out of money. When it does: 'I have to travel to St Albans, or borrow money from my mum,' she says.

Stephen Larkham, chairman of the Wheathampstead and District Preservation Society, says that since Barclays closure things have been tough. 'There has been a lot of anger,' he says. Larkham believes there is still a role for traditional banking in places such as Wheathampstead. 'There is a lot of hype surrounding telephone and internet banking, and a reaction against call centres and being put on hold, which drives people up the wall,' he says.

However, Maureen Field is one resident who has embraced the new technology. 'I am on the internet with Barclays, and I find it okay,'she says. Now she only needs to visit a branch occasionally. 'I would only go to the bank to get a loan,' she says.

Field's main concern is that the cash machine remains. 'If they took the machine away, it would be really dire,' she says.

But while the alternatives offered by the banks do have some appeal, Larkham believes that in a place such as Wheathampstead, take-up is likely to be limited.

'They are useful for a certain section of the village,' he says. 'But there is still a need to pay in cash and cheques, and you can't do that by internet or by phone.'

One man unlikely to go online is Ronald Benson. Now in his 70s, he has been a Barclays customer since the end of the war. At the time of the closure he wrote to Barclays chief executive. 'Stupidly I took it quite personally,' he says. Benson says that he considered changing to another bank, but decided to stick with Barclays 'because there are no alternatives'.

But rather than drawing money from the Barclays machine in the village, which he says 'doesn't appeal', or rely solely on the telephone to transfer money between accounts, he prefers to make the 15-minute drive to Welwyn every Monday to draw cash over the counter.

So almost a year on, does Barclays have any regrets? According to a spokesperson: 'Barclays is committed to a branch network and to new technology.' He adds that while the bank appreciates the difficulties caused to some customers when branches close, Barclays can't afford to keep them open where they are not commercially viable.

However, the spokesperson said that Barclays has finalised an arrangement allowing customers to pay in cash and cheques and to write cheques at any of the 15,500 Post Offices in England and Wales.

'This has been well received, especially in rural communities where the branch has closed.'

As to the long-term future of Barclays branch network: 'Wherever there is Barclays, there will be branches.' But how many will remain, and how many will go the way of Wheathampstead, Barclays is not prepared to say.

'I can't tell what will happen tomorrow,' said the spokesperson.

webTitle: Escape at last from the annuity trap

fields.headline: Escape at last from the annuity trap
fields.standfirst: Buying a retirement income need no longer be a life sentence because of a new five-years-at-a-time scheme
fields.trailText: Buying a retirement income need no longer be a life sentence because of a new five-years-at-a-time scheme.
fields.body:
Innovative thinking is one of the financial services industry's strengths, according to its leaders. Try telling that to many private pension investors who have retired in the last five years on lower pensions than they expected.

Pension providers blame the so-called annuity trap - annuity rates that have been falling for 12 years (see box below). It is a problem they have failed to solve.

Until now, that is. Peter Quinton, managing director of the Annuity Bureau, a specialist adviser, says insurer Canada Life's new Annuity Growth Account 'squarely meets a need for people to be given more flexibility in the current climate of low annuity rates'.

It is a bold departure from a conventional annuity, which means handing over your pension fund to an insurer in exchange for a fixed annual income for life.

With the Annuity Growth Account, you buy an annuity that pays a fixed annual income for only five years, which costs less and leaves part of your fund untouched.

A 65-year-old man buying the same income from a five-year annuity as he could buy for a lifetime would use up 40 per cent of his total. Over the next five years, he could go on investing the rest of his fund. At the end of that time, he could switch to a lifetime annuity or buy another five-year product.

This approach has several advantages. It may be that in five years, lifetime annuity rates will be better, so he will have avoided locking into today's lower rates. Investing his pension fund for a further five years could increase its value.

There are catches, however. Chiefly, leaving your fund invested makes you vulnerable to market movements. Canada Life offers a choice of 22 funds and, says Jon Briggs, associate director of independent financial adviser Chartwell Investment, 'the five-year outlook should give you some time to take a reasonable risk'.

Even so, the new scheme is not suitable for risk-averse investors, Briggs says. He is concerned about double-charging: some of the Canada Life funds are provided by Mercury Asset Management, which levies its own fees in addition to those of the insurer.

Quinton warns: 'You are required to lock into Canada Life's annuity rates and they may not be so competitive in five years' time.' He says most investors will need specialist financial advice on the product, which will mean further costs.

Nevertheless, Quinton believes the Annuity Growth Account is a major advance for the sector and that Canada Life's rivals will launch copycat products. It is 'excellent news for consumers', he says.

In some ways, the Canada Life product is a more flexible version of an investment-linked annuity. These differ from conventional annuities in that the income they pay each year moves up and down in line with a portfolio of underlying investments.

With-profits annuities, for example, are linked to the with-profits funds run by insurers, which pass on returns to investors through annual bonuses. Annuitants set an anticipated bonus rate (ABR) when they first buy the contract. The higher the ABR set, the higher your initial income. But if your insurer ever announces a bonus rate lower than your ABR, your income falls. Equally, if your ABR is lower than the actual bonus, your income will rise.

A new product from Standard Life allows annuitants to vary their ABR up to three times during retirement free of charge, or to switch to a conventional annuity. This flexibility allows them to react to market conditions.

This type of product is different from the Canada Life newcomer in that investment performance affects income immediately. With-profits annuities generally suit less risk-averse investors, though Standard Life's annuitants will be able to hedge their bets to an extent.

What it and Canada Life offer above all is the sort of flexibility that has been sorely missed from the annuity market until now.

Unlucky for many in cruel retirement lottery

The annuity trap affects tens of thousands of investors each year. On retirement, anyone with a personal pension, as well as many occupational pension scheme investors, must convert their pension fund into a retirement income via an annuity.

But once you've bought an annuity, the rate of income it pays is fixed for life. If you have to buy at a time when annuity rates are low, that's simply tough luck.

Unfortunately, annuity rates have been falling for much of the last 10 years. In May 1990, a 60-year- old man with a £100,000 pension fund could have bought a yearly income of about £11,850. By May this year, the figure had fallen to £7,100, a 30-year low. Income drawdown schemes, products that allow you to defer buying an annuity and draw an income directly from your pension fund, are a solution to the problem for a some investors.

Income drawdown is expensive, however: it's complicated and really only suits investors with large pension funds - those worth more than £250,000.

webTitle: Maria Scott on local credit unions and trusts

fields.headline: Now we can all be in the money
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott on how local credit unions and trusts are reaching out to those left in the cold as banks increasingly close branches
fields.trailText: Maria Scott on how local credit unions and trusts are reaching out to those left in the cold as banks increasingly close branches.
fields.body:
You hate your bank, but how much? Enough to start one of your own?

Some people are fighting branch closures and general disgruntlement with banks by forming credit unions and, more recently, a new type of financial institution, the community reinvestment trust. In some cases they are even moving into the branches left empty by fleeing banks (see case study).

The new trusts and unions also provide an alternative source of loans to people on low incomes who would otherwise turn to back-street money lenders. They offer a way for people who do not have a bank account - around one in five adults - to cope with the day-to-day running of their finances.

Amanda Winkworth, manager of the fledgling Portsmouth Savers Credit Union, which hopes to open for business in the autumn, explains: 'A lot of people get paid with cheques but don't have bank accounts. There are a lot of agencies set up to cash cheques that charge commission. The credit union will be able to offer a free cheque-cashing service.'

Portsmouth Savers, which is awaiting final approval from the credit union regulatory authorities, will potentially be one of the largest unions in the country because almost 230,000 people from the Portsmouth area will be eligible to join.

At present the self-help banking movement is a relatively small one with a limited range of services. Credit unions do not have the power to offer cash machine services, overdrafts or mortgages. But they have big ambitions and hope they may eventually be able to offer a much wider range of services.

Within the next two months the Association of British Credit Unions hopes to announce details of an initiative that will involve banks and building societies offering support services to credit unions. Last week NatWest said it was keen to market its new 'basic' current account, which will be aimed at people on low incomes, through credit unions.

Credit unions themselves want to be able to offer banking facilities and Portsmouth Savers will be offering cards that members can use at various sites around Portsmouth to deposit money.

Provisions in the Financial Services and Markets Bill, due to come into effect within two years, will abolish some of the restrictions on credit unions. In future, there will be no maximum loan limit, no limit on the number of people who can be members and no ceiling on the amount someone can save.

Restrictions on credit unions have been loosened gradually in the 20 years since the Credit Unions Act was implemented in 1979. One of the most important was a change in 1996 creating a new definition of the 'common bond' that must unite credit union members.

This allowed unions to open to people living and working in one particular area, which allows for a more mixed membership, with varied income levels. It is hoped this will help the organisations to gain the power and credibility they have elsewhere in the world. In Ireland half the population are members of a credit union, compared with less than 1 per cent here, and in North America, according to credit union legend, even Steven Spielberg is a member.

It is questionable whether credit unions will ever entirely fill the gap left by bank branch closures. But they would like to be seen as mainstream forms of financial provision, rather than a last resort for the poor.

As mutual organisations, where profit is not the main criteria for success, the credit unions should have a head start over banks in becoming viable in areas where the big financial institutions have failed.

The rates of interest they charge on borrowing can be no more than 1 per cent a month on the reducing balance, which works out at 12.68 per cent a year. You can borrow on a credit card for a fraction of this - but only if you can get a card. The more competitive card operators are generally choosy over the customers they take on, requiring high incomes and stable employment.

Banks rarely lend personal loans of less than £500, which credit unions do, and at 12.68 per cent the rate is better than that available from most high street banks on loans up to about £5,000. As credit union managers quickly point out, 12.68 per cent is a fraction of the 100 per cent plus interest loans that members would otherwise end up with if they went to a back-street lender.

One aim of the credit unions is to encourage saving and most require members to have saved a set amount for 13 weeks before they can borrow. Savers receive dividends; the amount depends on the strength of the union but the maximum is 8 per cent. The Greater Manchester Police Force credit union lends at 8.65 per cent and for the last five years has paid 7 per cent on savings.

The aim is to involve local people in their management. In the Salford unit, which is to open shortly, members of the management committee have been sent to local colleges to learn how to become directors.

In some cases they are even moving into the branches left empty by fleeing banks (see case study). The new trusts and unions also provide an alternative source of loans to people on low incomes who would otherwise turn to back-street money lenders. They offer a way for people who do not have a bank account - around one in five adults - to cope with the day-to-day running of their finances. There are a lot of agencies set up to cash cheques that charge commission. The credit union will be able to offer a free cheque-cashing service.' Portsmouth Savers, which is awaiting final approval from the credit union regulatory authorities, will potentially be one of the largest unions in the country because almost 230,000 people from the Portsmouth area will be eligible to join. At present the self-help banking movement is a relatively small one with a limited range of services. Credit unions do not have the power to offer cash machine services, overdrafts or mortgages. But they have big ambitions and hope they may eventually be able to offer a much wider range of services. Within the next two months the Association of British Credit Unions hopes to announce details of an initiative that will involve banks and building societies offering support services to credit unions. Last week NatWest said it was keen to market its new 'basic' current account, which will be aimed at people on low incomes, through credit unions. fields.headline: Unlock the handcuffs holding us to banks
fields.trailText: It is inspiring to see the energy, commitment and enthusiasm of the groups of people setting up credit unions and the new money- lending trusts. After years in the financial backwaters the credit unions are inching towards the mainstream.
fields.body:
It is inspiring to see the energy, commitment and enthusiasm of the groups of people setting up credit unions and the new money- lending trusts. After years in the financial backwaters the credit unions are inching towards the mainstream.

They are receiving some assistance from banks, under orders from a Government that believes credit unions should flourish. But there is irony in the way the Government has championed this cause while virtually ignoring the plight of building societies, founded by people with much the same aims.

The societies' high street role has diminished to the point where they are no longer the dominant forces in the savings and mortgage markets. This has reduced the competition that Ministers crave in a market where the Cruickshank report concluded that customers were being overcharged by up to £5 billion a year.

The measures the Government announced last Friday should help improve the range of services and products the banks offer. But don't expect to see sudden dips in the profitability that earns them as much as £63 a second. Much of the detail has yet to be hammered out, and it will require a firm hand on the banks if consumers are to be able to desert the institutions that rip them off.

The banks' efforts to streamline the system for switching current accounts - now being overhauled - will need particularly careful monitoring. These accounts are the handcuffs that immobilise customers so effectively, making them easy targets to be sold other inferior products.

The Government should also continue to monitor the building societies, which remain under pressure from people wanting to turn them into banks.

Straight talking from the Commons Social Security Select Committee on the state pension is welcome. The pension should be linked to earnings; and pensioners need £90 a week to live on. This is anathema to a Government which has chosen an elaborate and confusing mixture of means tests and tax credits to appease pensioners' anger about this year's 75p increase.

As charities point out, the elderly are a growing force among voters, and the Government would be unwise to ignore them.

webTitle: Is mental illness grounds for sack?

fields.headline: Is mental illness grounds for sack?
fields.trailText: I was diagnosed with depression last summer and put on anti-depressants. This treatment seems to have worsened my condition. Although I have been open with my employer and done my best to stay in work as much as possible, I am running into difficulties. They are putting pressure on me to return full-time. What can I do?
fields.body:
I was diagnosed with depression last summer and put on anti-depressants. This treatment seems to have worsened my condition. Although I have been open with my employer and done my best to stay in work as much as possible, I am running into difficulties. They are putting pressure on me to return full-time. What can I do?

You should have protection under the Disability Discrimination Act. When this was enacted three years ago, there were different views about whether it would cover depression. But since then it has been established that depression is covered.

The company needs to treat you fairly and try to accommodate your difficulties. If it neglects its own procedures and starts threatening you with dismissal, for instance, without taking reasonable steps to help you, you could make a claim under the Act.

Damages are unlimited. The highest awards so far have been more than £100,000. If you are in a union, you will probably want to get it to fight your case for you. Cases involving medical issues are often extremely complicated and usually involve expert medical evidence.

 Legal advice from Lewis Silkin

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Boots tries polish to nail critics

fields.headline: Boots tries polish to nail critics
fields.standfirst: The chemist is going upmarket to avoid an M&S-style flop
fields.trailText: Sales at Boots the Chemist have risen by an average of 5.5 per cent a year over the last 12 years, and its margins have jumped from 5.3 per cent to 12.4 per cent, the third highest in retailing. It has a formidable 26 per cent share of the market for toiletries and health and beauty products. Its profits have grown every year and, at £491.6 million for the year to last March, were almost five times higher than in 1988.
fields.body:
Sales at Boots the Chemist have risen by an average of 5.5 per cent a year over the last 12 years, and its margins have jumped from 5.3 per cent to 12.4 per cent, the third highest in retailing. It has a formidable 26 per cent share of the market for toiletries and health and beauty products. Its profits have grown every year and, at £491.6 million for the year to last March, were almost five times higher than in 1988.

So why have Boots' shares slumped from a high of 1070p at the end of 1998 to only 489.5p last Friday, making it one of the lowest-rated retailers?

The answer is simple: the City is convinced that Boots is the next Marks & Spencer. Only two years ago, M&S's position as Britain's biggest clothing retailer seemed unassailable. Yet its customers have deserted for rivals such as Matalan and Next, its profits and margins have halved, its share price has withered to less than a third of its historic peak. Worse, there is no sign that it has worked out a strategy to return to glory.

On the face of it, the comparison is reasonable. Just as M&S was wounded by competition, so the City expects Boots to be hurt by supermarket groups such as Tesco and Asda, now part of the international empire of Wal-Mart. Both are determined to win a bigger share of their customers' spending, and both are targeting such areas as shampoos and skin creams, which are ripe for price competition.

Almost everyone in Britain is within driving distance of a Boots or M&S store, so there is little scope for raising sales by opening new ones. Both have been expanding internationally but not, so far, with huge success.

Indeed, Boots is now re-examining its investment in the Netherlands, which it had hoped would be a bridgehead for continental expansion, while M&S has pulled out of Canada, done badly in the US and has yet to convince the City that its investments in Europe will achieve a satisfactory return.

There are signs that Boots is feeling the strain. According to government figures, the price of chemists' goods are now falling by around 2 per cent a year. Boots' sales mix is different from most rivals, and says its prices are still rising, but only by 0.5 per cent. That is hardly going to get profits soaring.

Indeed, the rate of sales growth has been falling for three years and, judging by figures announced at last month's annual meeting, that drop is continuing. Margins last year were similar to those five years ago. Most analysts expect these, too, to fall.

The result is steadily falling profit forecasts. Philip Dorgan of WestLB Panmure points out that, less than two years ago, most analysts expected Boots to make £745m profit for the year to next March. Now the consensus is closer to £600m, and it could fall further.

That, however, says as much about analysts' abilities to predict the future as it does about Boots' business. More pertinent is that most analysts still expect Boots' profits to rise over the next three years. Contrast that with M&S and Sainsbury, the other fallen retailing star, where, even in the year to March 2003 profits are expected to be below where they were in 1998.

But the real difference is that M&S and Sainsbury were taken by surprise when disaster struck, and were ill-prepared to cope. Boots, in contrast, is doing everything it can to make sure its sales and profits keep moving ahead.

Boots does not publicly admit to a problem. Finance director David Thompson says he sees no reason why margins should fall and is confident that sales will keep growing. But the pace of new initiatives across the group suggests it is well aware of the threats to its core chemist chain.

What really sets Boots apart from the fallen stars is the quality of its management. Both M&S and Sainsbury had a history of paternalism. Sainsbury's chairman until 1988 was David Sainsbury, a scion of the founding family. Sir Richard Greenbury, M&S chairman until last year, was the first person from outside the family to run the chain. Even then he had been there all his working life and did little to change its traditions.

Most crucially, both companies initially refused to admit anything was wrong but, as crisis deepened, were forced to bring in new management from outside.

At Boots, by contrast, the succession has been smooth. Lord Blyth, chairman since 1998 and chief executive for 11 years before that, retired last Monday and was replaced by Steve Russell, who has run the core retail chain since 1995.

Ever churlish, the City even finds that a cause for complaint, asking whether Boots might have benefited from some new blood.

There is, however, no sign that the management has run out of ideas. The company is testing an unprecedented number of initiatives to capitalise on the strength of Boots' name, one of the most trusted British brands.

'We no longer think of Boots the Chemist in isolation,' said Thompson. 'We think of the brand and what it stands for.' It has been testing demand for dental services and based on the success of the six surgeries it has so far opened, is rolling them out nationally. There will be 50 by the end of the year, and up to 2,000 eventually.

In two years' time, Boots estimates, these should each have sales of around £1m and profits of £200,000. It is now testing health and beauty centres in its stores in London's Kensington High Street and Milton Keynes. These shops will offer services such as weight management, beauty treatments, physiotherapy, massage and aromatherapy.

In the new year, it will open two independent sites, in north London and Northwich in Cheshire, to be called Boots Body 360. These will offer fitness studios, swimming pools, saunas and spas as well as beauty therapies.

In September, it will launch a credit card based on its Advantage loyalty card, which will earn users points wherever it is used. On a smaller scale, it is opening nail bars in a number of branches, chiropody services in others.

It has tested a Boots Men concept, offering things like shaving and grooming and, while the concept did not succeed in attracting enough male customers, it is a good way of getting women customers to buy more for their partners. Boots is fine-tuning the idea and putting them into some larger stores.

It is also working on what it calls its 'power brands' such as No7 and No17 make-up and the Botanics range. More are being launched, including Glitter-babes, for the Tweenies generation. It is even trying perfumes, branded with the names of designers such as Patrick Cox and Philip Treacy. These will be available in Boots and in Harvey Nichols.

The chain is also working on an internet service, which will be separate from its existing handbag.com. The details are still secret but it is likely to involve the 'power brands' and international expansion.

The aim of all the initiatives is to move the Boots brand steadily upmarket, reducing its exposure to areas of fiercest competition. Such commodity products as Pantene shampoo already account for less than 16 per cent of sales. The group does not mind if its customers buy supermarket shampoo, but still come to Boots for make-up and perfumes.

The initiatives are taking up so much management time that it has separated the running of services such as dentistry and chiropody from overseeing the stores, which, says Thompson, 'needs full-time attention'.

Boots has appointed small teams of young managers to handle the other initiatives. 'They want to make their name, so there is a lot of dynamism and enthusiasm.'

It is still too early to say how successful these will be. Analysts are divided between those who think the share price has fallen too far and those who warn that profits are about to follow. The current price seems to imply that profits will halve. Yet even the most pessimistic analyst would admit that is unlikely.

As West LB's Dorgan says: 'We are in the extraordinary situation whereby if profits at Boots go up, the bears will say it is only a matter of time before they fall. If, in fact, profits were to fall, then the bears will believe that they are set to collapse.'

fields.headline: Working this summer? It may be taxing
fields.standfirst: Students who fail to learn the murky ways of the Revenue will lose hard-earned money, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Students who fail to learn the murky ways of the Revenue will lose hard-earned money, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
If you are a student working this summer, you could easily find yourself being overcharged for tax. Only those students who have got to grips with the paperwork are likely to end up paying the right amount. So, unless you have completed a form P38(S) or a form P46 or seen a P45, you could benefit from reading this article.

The basic situation is that, like all other UK residents under 65, you have a tax allowance of £4,385 for the current tax year. If you earn less than that amount - equal to £84.32 a week - you should not be taxed on it. But, in practice, the system does not work as smoothly as this.

Jane Moore of the charity TaxAid says: 'The tax system is really designed for people who start work after school for one employer and do that same job until they retire.'

To make sure tax is not deducted from your first pay packet, you have to prove to your employer you have not earned enough this tax year to bring you into the tax net. You can do this in three ways.

If you have been working since the start of the tax year on 6 April, you need to get a P45 from your last employer. This will state how much you have earned. Your new employer will be able to calculate how much of your personal allowance of £4,385 is still available to you.

If, however, you have not been in the labour market this financial year, you can ask your employer to give you a form P46 to fill in. In signing this form you give your word that you have not worked since April. Alternatively, there is a special form for students, a P38(S), which you can sign if you are doing the job just for this vacation period and if you calculate that your earnings will fall under £4,385.

Tax specialist Paul Falvey of accountant Grant Thornton suspects many students end up out of pocket: 'I wouldn't be surprised if they lost out on a few hundred pounds this way. Big employers should be pretty well geared up, but small ones often aren't.' Many students and their advisers will assume that employers will automatically get the paperwork right. But the onus is on the individual to ensure they are not caught out. It will be far easier for many employers to deduct basic rate tax at 22 per cent and then leave it to the student to reclaim overpaid tax later. In the worst situation, a student could pay £964 in tax on earnings that should have been exempt.

About 85 per cent of students work over the summer, according to research by NatWest. And about half of all students have a part-time job during term time. Since they graduate with an average debt of nearly £5,300, accord ing to Barclays, they could find their annual tax payments are a crucial issue.

The National Union of Students is concerned that students will fall into 'all sorts of pitfalls' over tax. For instance, the pay as you earn tax system - through which employers deduct tax at source for employees - functions poorly for people with two or more part-time jobs. It is extremely likely that a student earning less than £4,385 from two different, but concurrent, part-time jobs will overpay tax and will need to reclaim.

Another hideous tax situation is dealing with tax authorities abroad. If you are working outside the UK, get the tax situation sorted out in advance, says Falvey. 'It would be a nightmare to try to reclaim a few hundred pounds from the French authorities on a French tax form.' If, however, your French employer knows which forms you need, you may save yourself money.

Students may feel tempted to avoid the tax system altogether if they are under the threshold. But they can easily get themselves into difficulties if a subsequent employer goes by the rule book. If a student is going through the system without getting P45s when they leave jobs, they will not be getting the benefit of any past tax deductions from their next employers.

Reading University is typical of many students unions in not seeing the tax issue as particularly worrying. That may be because so few people understand the system. But, like many other students unions, it has a welfare advisory service that can offer basic advice on how to deal with employers and tax.

If the worst happens, students who are taxed on earnings inside their personal allowance should be able to get a refund. The normal mechanism is to fill in a form P50 or contact the relevant tax office, which will need to be the one that deals with the affairs of the student's employer. The administration can, of course, assume nightmarish proportions for people hopping from job to job. If they can avoid it, students should keep out of the self-assessment tax return system. Moore says: 'If you ask for a tax return, you could find your fall into that system, never to emerge. They would keep sending you a return each year when you might not have to fill one out at all.'

There may be some hope for bemused students, however. The Low Incomes Tax Reform Group has started to examine the bureaucratic meshes that the undergraduate population may become trapped in, and may come up with some recommendations to make life simpler and fairer in the next few months.

'Income Tax for Students' is available free from the Inland Revenue on its web site, www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk or from local tax offices.

'Students and Income Tax' is available free from the Welfare Unit, the National Union of Students, 461 Holloway Road, London N7 6LJ.

webTitle: Credit union branches into bank's old premises

fields.headline: Credit union branches into bank's old premises
fields.trailText: In some parts of the country, credit unions are now beginning to take over premises deserted by the high street bank.
fields.body:
In some parts of the country, credit unions are now beginning to take over premises deserted by the high street bank.

In Salford, near Manchester, the River Valley Credit Union, moved into a former NatWest branch a year ago.

Ann Falsey, chair of the River Valley Credit Union, believes the union's high street presence has helped to push membership up dramatically.

At the time of the move, it had 225 active members and 90 child members (who can save with a credit union but cannot borrow). Now there are 800 active members and 400 juniors.

Enquiries have increased again recently because the union has linked with Manchester General Hospital to let staff there have payments to the union transferred directly from wages.

Falsey says there have been 200 enquiries, representing a little under 10 per cent of staff at the hospital. Membership also looks set to swell as a result of recent publicity on television.

Falsey was once a customer of the NatWest branch, which had lain empty for two years since it was closed. 'I was passing by with my son and said "wouldn't it be wonderful if the credit union could get that",' she says.

She organised a bid for the premises and got it for £61,000, which was less than the asking price.

The credit union received funding from a local housing association, Irwell Valley, which bought the building and leased it to the union.

Funds were also obtained from the European Regional Development Fund and the European Social fund, as well as a local regeneration fund.

Falsey is a staunch advocate of credit unions; she is on secondment from Salford City Council, where she was a development officer for credit unions and has been a credit union member for 10 years, having borrowed £4,500 to buy her car.

But she feels they could play a much bigger part in their communities if they had wider powers. 'There is no reason why we can't do mortgages and credit cards,' she says.

She also wants to see greater freedom over the terms credit unions can offer. The maximum repayment period for loans, two years, is two short, she argues.

It is a great frustration to her credit union that it was turned down for lottery funding because it is not classified as a philanthropic organisation.

fields.headline: Work well with volunteers
fields.trailText: 1 RECOGNISE that volunteers can be extremely dangerous for your business. Unrestrained by the bonds of hierarchy and financial dependence, unpaid volunteers do not respond to the carrots and sticks that keep most employees in harness. One character in Nick Hornby's book and film High Fidelity is an aggressive record shop assistant who works on a partly unpaid basis and drives customers away with waves of contempt and threatened fisticuffs.
fields.body:
1 RECOGNISE that volunteers can be extremely dangerous for your business. Unrestrained by the bonds of hierarchy and financial dependence, unpaid volunteers do not respond to the carrots and sticks that keep most employees in harness. One character in Nick Hornby's book and film High Fidelity is an aggressive record shop assistant who works on a partly unpaid basis and drives customers away with waves of contempt and threatened fisticuffs.

2 DO NOT be frightened to turn down offers of free help. The Samaritans weed out applicants who try to tell callers what to do rather than listening. Work out why people are volunteering. While many have good motives, there are some who are there for the perks, the status or some less honourable reason. One incompetent person can have a disastrous effect on a small organisation. Charities are increasingly looking for volunteers with particular skills in areas such as marketing and finance, says Ben Furner of the Disability Rights Commission.

3 MAKE sure the terms of engagement are clear with the volunteer - preferably through a job description. 'That places clear expectations and responsibilities on the volunteer,' says Furner. Also ensure they get some rewards and recognition. At the very least, they should get a cup of tea and a biscuit each time they turn up. Chocolate biscuits can go a long way in generating goodwill.

4 WORK OUT the degree to which you will treat them just like the paid employees, suggests Bharti Patel of the Low Pay Unit, an operation which regularly works with volunteers. 'It can be a difficult issue. Are you more flexible with them, recognising that they are donating their time? How much do you involve them in policy issues, knowing they might not be too familiar with all the issues?'

5 RECOGNISE that volunteering is likely to grow - as people live longer in retirement and younger workers try to broaden their experience. Volunteering to be on a management committee is a useful way of getting management experience if you want to climb the greasy pole at work. There are 700,000 volunteers, according to the charity CSV Volunteers, a charity that places volunteers. As politicians devolve decision-making to local areas, more people will become involved in charities, re-generation and childcare projects and other voluntary schemes.
