fields.headline: Danaides
fields.trailText:
intermittently they stop
with plybome spines
and fingers rusted...
fields.body:
intermittently they stop
with plybome spines
and fingers rusted
open and hearing
their work pouring
through these holes
their minds swinging
side to side
and far away
their feet hollowed
out and gone
smooth with turning
they stare down
in a horrible fag-break
gloom at water's
cloning loops its
frays and flumes
and vacillations
and clings and rips
and cloops and
splashy cleats all
water's wilfull
unresistance
to its own
cascading condition
and
one by one
begin to lift
to lift it
like a Christ

(The Danaides murdered their husbands. When they died they had to carry water in a leaking jar as a punishment.)

 This poem was specially commissioned by the BBC Poetry proms, which are broadcast during the interval of every Wednesday's Prom.

fields.headline: Travel wisely
fields.standfirst: Titles that reveal the real Spain
fields.trailText: Titles that reveal the real Spain
fields.body:
The New Spaniards, by John Hooper (Penguin, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

The best all-round guide in English to modern Spanish society, and not just because it's written by a Guardian journalist. Packed with facts and figures, it interprets how much Spain has changed since Franco's death and how much it has remained the same.

Barcelona, by Robert Hughes (Harvill, £14)
Buy it at BOL

This boisterous and iconoclastic book, brought out for the 1992 Olympics, focuses on the history and politics of the city, which boasts its greatest cultural expression in its buildings: from the medieval old city to the Art- Nouveau architecture - financed by slave owners returned from Cuba - of a century ago.

Roads to Santiago, by Cees Nooteboom (Harvill, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

An acclaimed Dutch author drives through empty inland Spain, investigating churches in forgotten villages and composing an erudite history of the country through its Romanesque architecture. Packed with anecdotes and digressions, which in the end become the point of his wandering.

Blood of Spain, by Ronald Fraser (Pimlico, £14)
Buy it at BOL

History from below: the Civil War told in its participants' own words. Fraser interviewed 300 people from both sides of the conflict and of every possible ideological shade. Their testimony gives the feel of what it was like to tackle the concrete day-to-day problems of revolution and war.

fields.headline: Viva Espana
fields.standfirst: Continuing our series on European fiction,  Michael Eaude  hears the many voices of multilingual Spain
fields.trailText: Continuing our series on European fiction, Michael Eaude hears the many voices of multilingual Spain
fields.body:
Gerald Brenan wrote that a "note of hunger" sounds in Spanish literature from 17th-century picaresque novels to The Hive, Nobel prize-winner Camilo José Cela's 1950s masterpiece. But Spain has been transformed in the last 50 years from a rural into an urban economy, from a dictatorship into bourgeois democracy, and from an unusual society in which factories and feudal estates, proletarians and serfs coexisted into one that is on the surface little different from any other modern European country. After these tumultuous social upheavals, hunger is no longer the dominant note of Spanish literature.

Today, Spanish fiction ranges from the intellectual fireworks and hatred of oppression of Juan Goytisolo (profiled in next Saturday's Guardian) to the erotic panache of Almudena Grandes; from the psychological subtlety of Carmen Martín Gaite to the bestselling thrillers of Pérez-Reverte. The 1970s transition from dictatorship meant censorship (and self-censorship) could be forgotten. New registers of irony, drama and psychology entered Spanish novels, which tackled with brio the taboos of the previous 40 years. A new readership was created too: nearly all the writers mentioned in this article, however literary, are big sellers.

Spain's "normalisation" as a parliamentary democracy gave it something no other European country has: literature in four languages. Since the 1978 Constitution, Basque, Galician and Catalan, suppressed under Franco, are again taught in schools (they were always spoken in the home), and an audience has arisen for literature written in these languages.

The best-known writer from the geographical periphery is the Basque Bernardo Atxaga. Born in 1951 in a village near San Sebastian, Atxaga tells how as a boy he accompanied his grandfather to collect electricity payments from the small hill farms. While his elders sipped wine, the child drank in the legends of the valley. Atxaga's great work, Obabakoak , exudes this oral tradition of the Basque countryside; its 27 interlinked stories recreate a world of winter evenings talking by the fireside. This may give the impression of a mythologising flight from the contemporary world into some lost and longed-for rural paradise, but there is no nostalgia in Atxaga; his stories are tough. The magical village of Obaba, which seems remote in history, is part of the modern world. His characters go abroad, speak foreign languages and drive cars to and from Obaba, which lies just an hour or so from the coastal cities where they work, engage in politics and go to bars.

Boldly, after the worldwide success of Obabakoak , Atxaga switched genres in his next novel The Lone Man , an action thriller that brings off the difficult challenge of making the inner voice of its protagonist, the ex-terrorist Carlos, enthralling. Atxaga's style is calm and clear; he excels at writing unsentimentally about emotion.

The new star of literature from the Celtic nation of Galicia, perched on top of Portugal, is Manuel Rivas. Galicia is a misty country of spectacular fjords, afflicted with rural poverty and emigration. Rivas's lyrical, yearning language captures how the old society of magical beliefs and sea legends underlies the modern. One of the best Spanish films of recent years, Butterfly , based on several Rivas stories, will introduce his work to Britain this summer.

The elements of myth and fantasy found in Atxaga and Rivas, as they knit together rural history and urban worlds, are absent from the harsher, realist writers of proletarian Barcelona. Juan Marsé has achieved what very few writers are capable of: creating his own fully imagined world, a Yoknapatawpha County in the city's Guinardó quarter. Marsé, and his near contemporaries Manuel Vázquez Montalbán and Eduardo Mendoza, portray neither the revolutionary city of 1936 that Orwell described nor the triumphant host of the 1992 Olympics. Marsé's subject matter is the hungry - with him at least, Brenan's dictum still holds - and violent children growing up in the 1940s under the dictatorship, with mothers in despair and fathers absent in graves, jails or exile. His narrative power arises from his angry nostalgia for childhoods destroyed by the long shadow of the Civil War.

Though a lesser writer than Marsé, Vázquez Montalbán is better known internationally. He is the Raymond Chandler of Spain, and Barcelona is his Los Angeles. His detective Pepe Carvalho is, like Philip Marlowe, a tough, honest sceptic equipped with the wisecracks and weapons required to deal with an evil urban world; he is also a sensual Mediterranean gourmet with a streak of melancholy. In Southern Seas and Off-side (a devastating satire on Barcelona Football Club), Vázquez Montalbán portrays a rough, corrupt city. Reading him is a fierce corrective to the view promulgated by Barcelona's ruling elite that the city is a haven of exquisite architecture and harmonious living.

Eduardo Mendoza is the most elegant of the Barcelona novelists. The Truth about the Savolta Case and City of Marvels are picaresque satires on the triumph of capitalism between Barcelona's two great exhibitions of 1888 and 1929. Mendoza, Marsé and Vázquez Montalbán all seek to reconstruct memory, too readily erased by an official Spain which is bent on forgetting a troubled past in its headlong rush to be more European than Brussels and more north American than the USA.

The above three novelists write in Castilian Spanish. Jesús Montcada's The Towpath is written in Catalan, a thriving literature with over 5,000 titles published annually. Montcada tells the story of a rural town drowned under the flood waters of a dam on the Ebro, and through it the history of Catalonia this century. The Towpath contains a warning: if we lose our memories, we become like the citizens of the novel's new town, built to replace the old, living dull lives "in identical houses on symmetrical streets scoured by the wind".

Completely different from these Catalan writers is Madrid's Javier Marías, whose inventive novels are sombre meditations on failure and deceit and who won the 1997 IMPAC award for the best European novel with A Heart so White . He can be an irritating writer, given to long philosophical conceits and pedantic dissertations (it is no accident that he has translated Laurence Sterne into Spanish). Yet he is capable too of hilarious tours de force and dramatic action - the suicide in A Heart so White is one of the great openings in modern literature.

No roundup of Spanish novels would be complete without the bestselling Arturo Pérez-Reverte, whose thrillers, well-researched and exciting, revolve around an intellectual problem, whether chess, fencing or computers. The plots, however, are in the end unsatisfying - something revealed in the poor films of his books, including Polanski's The Ninth Gate . Pérez-Reverte has a predilection for heroines who are exceptionally intelligent and beautiful; indeed, his characters often slip into stereotype. The settings, though, are strong, particularly The Fencing Master , which evokes 19th-century Madrid, or The Seville Communion, a recommended companion for visitors to Andalucia's capital.

One of the best Spanish films of recent years, Butterfly , based on several Rivas stories, will introduce his work to Britain this summer. The elements of myth and fantasy found in Atxaga and Rivas, as they knit together rural history and urban worlds, are absent from the harsher, realist writers of proletarian Barcelona. Juan Marsé has achieved what very few writers are capable of: creating his own fully imagined world, a Yoknapatawpha County in the city's Guinardó quarter. Marsé, and his near contemporaries Manuel Vázquez Montalbán and Eduardo Mendoza, portray neither the revolutionary city of 1936 that Orwell described nor the triumphant host of the 1992 Olympics. Marsé's subject matter is the hungry - with him at least, Brenan's dictum still holds - and violent children growing up in the 1940s under the dictatorship, with mothers in despair and fathers absent in graves, jails or exile. His narrative power arises from his angry nostalgia for childhoods destroyed by the long shadow of the Civil War. Though a lesser writer than Marsé, Vázquez Montalbán is better known internationally. He is the Raymond Chandler of Spain, and Barcelona is his Los Angeles. His detective Pepe Carvalho is, like Philip Marlowe, a tough, honest sceptic equipped with the wisecracks and weapons required to deal with an evil urban world; he is also a sensual Mediterranean gourmet with a streak of melancholy. In Southern Seas and Off-side (a devastating satire on Barcelona Football Club), Vázquez Montalbán portrays a rough, corrupt city. Reading him is a fierce corrective to the view promulgated by Barcelona's ruling elite that the city is a haven of exquisite architecture and harmonious living. Eduardo Mendoza is the most elegant of the Barcelona novelists. The Truth about the Savolta Case and City of Marvels are picaresque satires on the triumph of capitalism between Barcelona's two great exhibitions of 1888 and 1929. Mendoza, Marsé and Vázquez Montalbán all seek to reconstruct memory, too readily erased by an official Spain which is bent on forgetting a troubled past in its headlong rush to be more European than Brussels and more north American than the USA. The above three novelists write in Castilian Spanish. Jesús Montcada's The Towpath is written in Catalan, a thriving literature with over 5,000 titles published annually. Montcada tells the story of a rural town drowned under the flood waters of a dam on the Ebro, and through it the history of Catalonia this century. The Towpath contains a warning: if we lose our memories, we become like the citizens of the novel's new town, built to replace the old, living dull lives "in identical houses on symmetrical streets scoured by the wind". Completely different from these Catalan writers is Madrid's Javier Marías, whose inventive novels are sombre meditations on failure and deceit and who won the 1997 IMPAC award for the best European novel with A Heart so White . He can be an irritating writer, given to long philosophical conceits and pedantic dissertations (it is no accident that he has translated Laurence Sterne into Spanish). Yet he is capable too of hilarious tours de force and dramatic action - the suicide in A Heart so White is one of the great openings in modern literature. No roundup of Spanish novels would be complete without the bestselling Arturo Pérez-Reverte, whose thrillers, well-researched and exciting, revolve around an intellectual problem, whether chess, fencing or computers. The plots, however, are in the end unsatisfying - something revealed in the poor films of his books, including Polanski's The Ninth Gate . Pérez-Reverte has a predilection for heroines who are exceptionally intelligent and beautiful; indeed, his characters often slip into stereotype. The settings, though, are strong, particularly The Fencing Master , which evokes 19th-century Madrid, or The Seville Communion, a recommended companion for visitors to Andalucia's capital.

fields.headline: Dundee's cakewalk
fields.trailText: Dundee enjoyed a convincing 3-0 win over Dunfermline at Dens Park.
fields.body:
Dundee enjoyed a convincing 3-0 win over Dunfermline at Dens Park.

They took the lead within 10 seconds as Javier Artero stormed down the right hand side and outpaced defender Barry Smith before whipping in a low cross. Justin Skinner could only watch in agony as the ball slid past keeper Marco Ruitenbeek. Seven minutes after the break Dundee got a penalty when Nemsadze looked certain to score before being pulled down by Pars skipper Ian Ferguson. Sara stepped up and gave Ruitenbeek no chance with his spot kick.

And three minutes later, Dundee were awarded another penalty when Doesburg hauled Caballero to the ground. This time it was Caballero who netted sending Ruitenbeek the wrong way.

webTitle: Trade unions - not just there for the nasty things in life

fields.headline: Trade unions - not just there for the nasty things in life
fields.standfirst: Training, counselling and legal advice are all part of the service
fields.trailText: Training, counselling and legal advice are all part of the service
fields.body:
Ever thought of joining a trade union? Perhaps not. You've got enough on your plate trying to get your career off the ground. And anyway, unions are for middle-aged men who smoke roll-ups and work in factories in the north of England. Aren't they?

Not any more, it seems. According to government statistics, these days, you're just as likely to belong to a union if you're a graduate, a woman or working in a profession.

"Things are changing," says Frances O'Grady, head of organisation at the Trades Union Congress, the umbrella group for 76 unions in the UK. "Some 37% of employees with a degree belong to a union. And 49% of people in professional jobs are union members, making them the most unionised sector of the population."

So, why do people join? Mainly because belonging to a union is rather like having an older, more informed brother who can stick up for you if the big boys are giving you a hard time. The idea is that if you're unhappy with some aspect of your job, your union representative can advise you of your legal rights or mediate between you and your employer to help you reach an agreement.

"Unions are also very involved with training these days," O'Grady explains. "We work closely with employers setting up educational programmes for staff and we can also help where a group of employees want to be sent on a course. We persuade the employer that it's in their best interests to train their staff.

"Some unions also offer members cheap insurance and money off household bills," she adds.

The TUC would like to see more people join a trade union while they're still at university. "More and more students are having to take on part-time work in order to make ends meet," O'Grady points out. "They can find themselves up to their eyes in debt, so they're often forced to take on jobs that no-one else will do in places like fast-food restaurants and private nursing homes.

"Unfortunately, there will always be unscrupulous employers and students need support," she says. "For example, when the minimum wage came in, some students working in pizza chains had their taxi allowance for travelling home after a late shift taken away. We campaigned against this."

Fine arts graduate Eleanor Grant has had mixed experiences of union assistance. When she first left college some years ago, she found a job working nights for the post office. Although it wasn't an obvious career move, the work was well-paid and she hoped to save up to go travelling before settling down to a "real" job.

"I joined the union when I started there," she says, "but I didn't really think about it. It was just something everyone did and it only cost a couple of quid a month.

"When I was ready to go travelling, I handed in my notice but just before I left, my mum died," she continues. "Obviously, it wasn't the right time for me to go away, so I contacted my employers to ask if I could withdraw my resignation. They couldn't be bothered with the hassle, so they just ignored my requests."

Frustrated, she consulted her union representative who found that legally, she was entitled to keep her job. They liaised with her bosses and Eleanor continued working until she was ready to travel a few months later.

Some years later, she was working as a development officer with an Afro-Caribbean arts organisation and struggling to cope with a temperamental boss. When he took disciplinary measures against her, which she considered unfair, she once again called on her union for help.

"It was useful to be able to talk to someone impartial about what was a very difficult time for me," she explains, "but I don't think my representative was experienced enough to handle my case properly. He only worked part-time and was busy dealing with other, more complex cases than mine.

"I think he was also put off because he knew some members of the management committee where I worked and he didn't want to rock the boat," she says.

"My grievance was dismissed and I wasn't allowed to appeal, even though my contract stated that I could.

"I would definitely advise people to join a union but at the end of the day, it's down to you to do your own research and sort out your own problems. You can't always rely on other people to do it for you."

 The TUC offers an information line on all aspects of union membership. Contact it on 0870 600 4882.

webTitle: How to... stay motivated during a long, hot August

fields.headline: How to... stay motivated during a long, hot August
fields.standfirst: Our cure to the summertime blues
fields.trailText: Our cure to the summertime blues
fields.body:
Summertime... and the living is easy. Or it would be, if it wasn't for the small matter of landing a job. You know you need to keep writing those letters. You know you need to keep making those calls. And you have been - up until now at least. But for some reason your drive to keep on keeping on has stopped. It's probably no coincidence that right now the sun is shining, tempting you further to abandon your mission of starting a career and to do, well, anything else instead.

"It is entirely natural for graduates to get frustrated and fed up with looking for a job at this point in time", says Sophie Rowan a psychologist with Career Psychology. "By now they've been out of university for quite a few weeks and have probably already contacted between 50 and 100 companies. They may have had some encouraging feedback. But equally they may have had very little feedback. So that all important first break can start to seem impossible to attain. In these circumstances it is very easy to lose one's self-motivation."

So how do you get it back?

The first thing is to remember that you are playing a long game. The second thing is to be serious about how you play it. "Finding a job is a job in itself and you need to treat it as such", says Paul Farrer, managing director of The Graduate Recruitment Company. This means getting yourself up early and being 'at work' by 9am.

It also means following a structure. Divide your week into certain tasks and focus only on those tasks.

For example, Monday is for writing applications, Tuesday is for following them up, Wednesday is for future research. Set objectives for each of those days. And make sure they are SMART. That is - and no apologies for repeating this well known management mantra - specific, measurable, achievable, realistic, and to a time scale.

Then, and this is the third thing, just get on with it.

But herein lies the rub. Because even if you know what to do, and even if you know why you should do it, your mind can still be more interested in dreaming about lazy summer afternoons than applying itself to yet another 'graduate opportunity'. So what do you do then?

"In this case it might be best to actually take a break," suggests Sophie Rowan from Career Psychology. "Decide to take a day, a weekend, even a week off. And don't feel guilty about it." But make sure, she cautions, that you put a deadline on your time out.

If you don't remember anything else...

Remind yourself that you are not alone. Feeling apathetic or uninspired can affect the best of us. Personal coach Chris Widener explains further. "I've never found anyone, regardless of their level of success, who doesn't sometimes find themselves simply not wanting to do the things that they need and want to do. It is a part of human nature.

"What separates those who will become successful is the ability, at those very crucial moments when we are making decisions about what we will do, to choose to find the inner motivation that will enable us to conquer our complacency and move on in action."

If these words of wisdom still don't help, you can always draw strength from the song Summertime when "one of these mornings you're gonna rise up singing, and you'll spread your wings, and you'll take to the sky".

webTitle: Bright sparks need smart bosses who understand them

fields.headline: Bright sparks need smart bosses who understand them
fields.standfirst: Neat and punctual or creative and dynamic?
fields.trailText: Neat and punctual or creative and dynamic?
fields.body:
Toby Beresford likes to be different. He's independently-minded, outspoken and likely to be a challenge to authority. Untidy and dismal with detail, he is intellectually curious and may well take risks.

In short, he is a textbook example of the kind of graduate every competent recruiter should be looking to employ.

Ask a recruiter of the past what they looked for in a potential employee and they'd list vague competencies such as "creativity" and "communication skills". More frightening still would be the reply, 'the candidate least likely to fail' - aka The Safe Option.

But times have changed - and to compete in the millennial workplace, organisations need to be innovative.

Step forward Toby, who possesses many of the key characteristics now acknowledged to define an innovative graduate. To succeed, companies need to be aware of how to attract and handle graduates who are more challenging and radical so they can bring added value to business through their innovative potential.

The Department of Trade and Industry defines innovation as "the professional exploitation of new ideas". At Nottingham Business School, Fiona Patterson has gone further, developing a model that accounts for aspects of intellect and personality - a perspective on what the characteristics associated with innovation in the workplace.

"In effect, you're putting your head above the parapet and taking a risk to promote your creativity," she says. "It's the only way through which you can gain a competitive advantage in a changing technological environment."

So are innovators born - or can they be created? According to Dr Patterson, innovation can be attributed to a combination of influences - from natural aptitude or the way you're brought up, to the way you're taught at university.

"An extremely high innovator is going to be innovative anyway, regardless of what you do," she says. "However there are people who have some capacity and who will thrive in the right environment."

Carl Gilleard, chief executive of the Association of Graduate Recruiters, is in agreement - and anxious to warn employers against practices that quash innovation.

"If you run a very hierarchical organisation, there's always somebody who wears the stripes and you're constantly being told what to do," he says. "Eventually people stop thinking for themselves.

"Your innovative graduate will fall off the end of a graduate trainee programme like any other graduate and go into a work situation where they'll be responsible to a line manager," he adds. "Companies must be consistent in their approach - how senior managers respond to graduates coming through the firm is very important."

Trotman Publishing, a recruitment communications consultancy, works with a selection of companies to pre-select innovative graduates and entice them to apply. Trotman has worked on such initiatives as a "strategic games" section on the Boston Consulting Group's website and Andersen Consulting's successful e-commerce challenge last year. Even graduate literature has evolved, says Trotman director, Andrew Eccleston.

"As part of our work for ICI we created an innovative brochure that focused on what the brand did to the individual through stimulating the senses," he says. "This large, square publication has scratch and sniff patches, gel bags - elements you can touch, feel, see, smell. The brochure was distributed throughout Europe - and we also promoted their brand considerably in countries like Spain, Germany, France and The Netherlands."

Once past the literature, the assessment process and proposed career structure is vital. Toby Beresford, our innovative graduate who left Durham in 1996 with a first in computer science, knew IBM wasn't for him when his interviewer produced a diagram of his potential career path.

"She drew a small dot on a piece of paper and then a big circle around it and explained that in order to be the big circle, I needed to complete certain segments over the next four years," he recalls. "What turned me off was the concept that my career wasn't opportunity-driven or exciting - it was a number of stages I had to work through. I didn't want to approach it that way."

Toby felt all the big strategic consultancies had a similar approach. "They were so large and structured that I felt it would take an awfully long time to get onto any exciting work or projects," he says. "A guy at one consulting firm pretty much said that 'it's going to take you four years before you're interesting to us'.

"When I applied to other consulting firms, I was on the look-out for project or group-based interviews - and would have preferred applying to a specific area of the firm, such as e-business strategy, and having the opportunity to be an apprentice within that area."

Toby now works at Agora, a smaller consultancy where he likes the flat structure, the exposure to the top people and the fact his ideas go straight to the client. And here he's been instrumental in such innovations as telemedicine - implementing the technology used by photographers at Formula One grand prix to email their pictures to news desks for remote diagnosis in the medical world.

"This sector is results-based - it's very obvious if someone's not coming up with any ideas or projects because there's nothing appearing," he points out. "If someone's producing great ideas and software - who cares if they turn up on time?"

Of course, there are competencies lacking in innovators that are attractive to some companies. You wouldn't want an air traffic controller who's going to continually pursue new routes - and yet, new and improved products and approaches are needed whatever sector you work in.

"Being reliable, neat and punctual - doing what you're told and turning up on time aren't the things that we should be rewarding in an innovative organisation," says Patterson. "They may be important but they're not what's going to make the difference."

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Azzemour

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Azzemour
fields.standfirst: Giles Milton
fields.trailText: Giles Milton
fields.body:
Why: It is a crumbling old port about an hour's drive south of Casablanca, and no one ever goes there for the simple reason that there is no particular reason to go there.

It is one of those old walled Moroccan cities, and in the 16th century it was an important port, built by the Portuguese. The reason I first went to Azzemour was that a fairly eccentric relative of mine used to live there, in the former palace of the Pasha. So I went to see him.

The relative in question went to Morocco during the war, fell in love with the country, moved back when peace was declared and got married. He spent all his time, effort and money on restoring this palace to what it would have looked like in the 16th century.

It is a stunningly beautiful place with a central atrium and a Portuguese fountain. Moroccan tiles have been laid on the floor, there are stained-glass windows, a roof terrace that affords views over the estuary, and even a tomb to a holy man.

I first visited Azzemour during my gap year, and then returned a few times. When I got married, my wife and I went there on our honeymoon, but I haven't been back since my relative died.

What's the best thing: I love the Portuguese influence, which you can see in the towns on the Moroccan west coast. They still have their walls and the fortifications. But they are crumbling, which adds to their attraction. They are different from Casablanca - quite a modern town, which I would avoid.

My advice: Go along the Atlantic coast and see the Portuguese influence. If you want a more easy-going trip, choose the Berber south over the Arabic north.

How do I get there? GB Airways flies from Gatwick to Casablanca for £340 plus taxes in August. Check for special offers on 0845 7733377.

 Big Chief Elizabeth, by Giles Milton is published by Hodder and Stoughton at £14.99.

It is one of those old walled Moroccan cities, and in the 16th century it was an important port, built by the Portuguese. The reason I first went to Azzemour was that a fairly eccentric relative of mine used to live there, in the former palace of the Pasha. So I went to see him. The relative in question went to Morocco during the war, fell in love with the country, moved back when peace was declared and got married. He spent all his time, effort and money on restoring this palace to what it would have looked like in the 16th century. It is a stunningly beautiful place with a central atrium and a Portuguese fountain. Moroccan tiles have been laid on the floor, there are stained-glass windows, a roof terrace that affords views over the estuary, and even a tomb to a holy man. I first visited Azzemour during my gap year, and then returned a few times. When I got married, my wife and I went there on our honeymoon, but I haven't been back since my relative died. What's the best thing: I love the Portuguese influence, which you can see in the towns on the Moroccan west coast. They still have their walls and the fortifications. But they are crumbling, which adds to their attraction. They are different from Casablanca - quite a modern town, which I would avoid. My advice: Go along the Atlantic coast and see the Portuguese influence. If you want a more easy-going trip, choose the Berber south over the Arabic north. How do I get there? fields.headline: This month in the med
fields.standfirst: For those stricken with a sudden urge to feel the sand between their toes, and taste the wine and olives of the Mediterranean, here are a few last-minute ideas.
fields.trailText: For those stricken with a sudden urge to feel the sand between their toes, and taste the wine and olives of the Mediterranean, here are a few last-minute ideas.
fields.body:
Croatia: the Dalmatian coast remains one of Europe's most appealing. The all-inclusive Osmine Hotel is set in pine woods, less than an hour north of Dubrovnik. Refurbished in 1997, it has steps leading to a small beach of tiny stones you can walk on comfortably. All inclusive covers buffet meals, beer, wine (not hard liquor) and sports such as windsurfing.

Holiday Options (01444 244499) offers a week there for £449 (£309 for children aged two-11 inclusive) departing from Gatwick on August 21.

Hammamet: Tunisia's busiest resort attracts swarms of holidaymakers, and temperatures soar well over 30C during this month. But it has a glorious, long sandy beach. And when the heat of day diminishes, you can stroll to the delightful little medina and watch the sun go down over a glass of mint tea with pine nuts at the Sdi Bou Hdid café.

According to Wigmore Holidays (020-7836 4999), the company can offer a week's half-board at Le Hammamet Hotel (three stars), but with better cooking than most four-star properties, for £529 - including return flights from either Gatwick or Heathrow.

Halki: Alternatively spelt Chalki. Total escape. This rocky, barren little island a short ferry-ride from the package-tour honeypot of Rhodes has a half-dozen or so tavernas, some idyllic beaches, a monastery - and scarcely any motorised transport. Bizarrely, it has a road called Tarpon Springs Boulevard, after the Florida town where many of its residents emigrated to fish for sponges.

Laskarina Holidays (01629 822203) has a two-level, semi-detached, self-catering property there, a short walk from the beach, with stunning views of Rhodes from its terrace and balcony. Two weeks, for two or three people, departing from Manchester on August 20 will cost £635.

Turgutkoy: South of the lively western Turkish resort of Marmaris, but it might as well be in a different world. Just a few small restaurants and a quiet beach with a rural backdrop. The 40-room Hydas Rana hotel is about 15 minutes' walk from the sea. It is set in impressive gardens, and the rooms are equipped with air conditioning.

Tapestry Holidays (020-8235 7777) has one-week, bed-and-breakfast holidays available, with flights departing from Manchester on August 27, for £510.

Crete: Seclusion on the north coast - with a hire car to explore the archeological sites and the wild, mountainous interior of the island. Greek Island Holidays (020-8232 9780) has two-week packages available at Mirabello Bay. The Vangelis Apartments are a 10-minute drive from a quiet beach but they have their own pool in case you can't wait to take to the water. Packages cost £643 for two, £493 for four. Flights are from Gatwick.

Barcelona: For those with reasonably elastic budgets, the Hotel Arts, on the sea by the Olympic port, offers a near perfect combination of swanky accommodation - there are in-room CD players - and access to beach and city. And the array of seafood restaurants that are a short stroll from the door are among the Mediterranean's most splendid.

Kirker Holidays (020-7231 3333) offers a week's B&B there this month, including flights from Heathrow or Gatwick and transfer by car, for £1,144. If that sounds too much, three nights cost £648.

Rapallo: Another option for those with cash to spare. The five-star Excelsior Palace, which opened in 1901, is surrounded on three sides by the sea and is a short hop from the smart resort of Portofino on Italy's Ligurian coast. The views from its bedroom balconies - most rooms have them - are spectacular. It has a beach club with a bar.

Italian Expressions (020-7435 2525) can offer a week's B&B there this month, including flights and a hire car, for £1,120.

These holidays were all available as this article was written - but they can vanish quickly. A good starting point for your search is the Association of Independent Tour Operators (AITO) directory. To obtain a copy, call: 020-8744 9280.

fields.headline: Ibiza covered
fields.standfirst: www.beachbeats.com
fields.trailText: www.beachbeats.com
fields.body:
What's that awful racket in the distance?
It's the sound of hordes of British youths enjoying a hedonistic week in Ibiza. Driven abroad by the demise of the Radio 1 Summer Roadshow, these young people are forced to endure extremely high temperatures, cheap accommodation, ear-bleeding decibels and the ever-present threat of "trouble" in the pursuit of pleasure.

What does beachbeats.com do for these hapless young people?
It warns them of the current temperature in Ibiza and Ayia Napa, providing practical guides to each of the resorts. Tips include a list of things to bring (passport, condoms, whistle) and things to avoid (staying out until only midnight, mouthing off to the Guardia Civil). And it gives away a crate of Smirnoff Red each week to help prepare clubbers for their holidays. Travellers can also book their flights and accommodation via the well-established bargainholidays.com: week-long packages start at around £250, although Cyprus is more expensive.

Is the website just as noisy?
Not initially, but depending on the power of their speakers, clubbers can play a number of dance videos loudly enough to annoy their parents and flatmates. They can also arrange to have details of club nights sent to their mobile phones. Still, given how slowly the pages load, it's more likely that these impatient young people will get bored and phone their friends for advice instead.

fields.headline: Turquoise delight
fields.standfirst: Patara, Turkey: it's got one of the longest beaches in the Med, Roman ruins and a wonderful hotel that won't break the bank
fields.trailText: Patara, Turkey: it's got one of the longest beaches in the Med, Roman ruins and a wonderful hotel that won't break the bank
fields.body:
I glanced down and saw a baby tortoise crawling past my toes. His shell was a murky green and his tiny head no larger than my little finger. I picked him up, whereupon he stretched out his head, eyes open, and peed. I put him down and turned once more to the scene I'd left behind. The sun, low in the sky, was throwing striped shadows across the broken columns of Patara's Roman amphitheatre. Scores of local schoolchildren, transfixed in the stone seats, listened to an archaeology professor spinning them stories of the city in which they sat: Xanthos - whose terrible massacres, wars, glory and heroism have been described by Homer, Herodotus and Plutarch.

Patara is a small village on the south-west Aegean coast of Turkey, known as the Turquoise Coast, and is famous for having one of the longest beaches in the Mediterranean. Its 18km of sand provides plenty of raw material for armies of children to build metropoli of sandcastles, as well as a nesting place for turtles, which between June and August emerge at night to lay their eggs in the sands.

Patara is said to be the birthplace of Apollo and, when the Roman empire was at its height, it was one of the most important harbours in the western Mediterranean, sheltering ships from all over the ancient world. You can still find the remains of merchants' bath-houses, their roofs open to the skies. Fallen Porphyry columns lie beside the largest avenue that the Romans ever built.

Most atmospheric of all, though, is Patara's Roman amphitheatre. Once it seated 10,000 citizens, now half of it lies buried under an enormous sand dune. Shelley could have had this place in mind when he wrote his famous sonnet, Ozymandias - "Round the decay/Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare/The lone and level sands stretch far away".

In 1992, when tourism was just beginning to make its mark on Patara, the Turkish government slapped a preservation order on the town to protect the ruins. The locals were furious, and one miscreant hotel builder (his creation is the only scar on the wooded horizon) has been sent to prison for building without permission. But for the visitor, it is a godsend that this peaceful refuge cannot be developed further.

The most wonderful thing about Patara - ruins, turtles and beach aside - is the Viewpoint Hotel, owned by Muzaffer Otlu. Despite sounding like a B&B in Eastbourne, the Viewpoint is a very special place. This is not because of the accommodation, although the rooms are perfectly adequate; nor because of the amazing food, but because of the years of toil and thought that have gone into it. The tables, bar, flooring - even the ashtrays - have been fashioned from the same white-and-black marble quarried in central Anatolia, according to Muzaffer's personal specification.

Behind the two-storey building is a terraced orchard, planted with lemon, orange, fig and apricot trees. "Eat as much as you like," says Muzaffer. But the Viewpoint's pièce de résistance is its Ottoman terrace, roofed in bamboo, the sides open to the stars. In the evenings, guests recline on the low cushions - in one hand an aperitif made from Turkish almonds, in the other a pair of backgammon dice. The sweet smell of burning cedarwood wafts across the terrace. I spent every evening out here listening to the crickets.

Muzaffer also runs tours. One day, we set off for a boat trip along the coast, stopping on the way to see the tomb of St Nicholas. That's right - Santa Claus, otherwise known as Lapland's most famous son, who was born in Patara and spent much of his life as a bishop in Myra.

We boarded a wooden boat with a sundeck roof. From the sea, the Taurus mountains looked like the backs of dinosaurs; the dark, blue ridges curving into the water one after another, so that there were 10 horizons visible at once. We passed pirate hide-outs - caves formed by centuries of waves lapping on limestone outcrops - and stopped in a secluded bay to dive into the cool, clear, aquamarine water. The captain cooked a barbeque on the beach. Then we set off for Kekova island. In the 5th century BC, before the water level rose, there was a thriving city here. Stairways, foundations of houses and the arch of a temple are still visible still under the sea.

On another trip, winding up into the Taurus foothills, we came upon the Saklikent gorge, through which a river flows down to a sun-filled plain. Walking down a footpath above the rushing torrent, you come to a shady clearing, and from the feet of the cliffs, as if from the rocks themselves, splurges of spring water gush over boulders to join the river.

Enterprising locals have built bamboo platforms a foot above the torrent, upholstered in cushions of Turkish carpet. I lay upon one, splashing the icy water on my face, watching the kingfishers play mating games in the fig trees overhead. What a place for a midnight encounter, in August, when the figs are ripe.

The practicals

Turkish Airlines (020-7766 9300) offers return flights from Heathrow to Dalaman via Istanbul for £323pp inc tax/psc. British Airways flies to Istanbul for £197 plus £35 tax (Sat night stay required). The Viewpoint Hotel (0242 843 5184, www.pataraviewpoint.com) costs £10 per night per person.

webTitle: Planning a walking holiday in Mallorca

fields.headline: Planning a walking holiday in Mallorca
fields.standfirst:
My partner and I are planning a walking honeymoon on Mallorca in November. We want to do this as cheaply as possible. Can anyone recommend a good website for flights leaving from either Exeter or Bristol and reasonably-priced accommodation?
Mary Butler
fields.trailText: My partner and I are planning a walking honeymoon on Mallorca in November. We want to do this as cheaply as possible. Can anyone recommend a good website for flights leaving from either Exeter or Bristol and reasonably-priced accommodation?
fields.body:
 Try www.flightlineflights.com for the cheapest flights to Palma from Exeter or Bristol. I have walked many times in Mallorca using the guide Landscapes of Mallorca by Valerie Crespi Green. I usually stay with friends in the north of the island but suggest the Hotel Bon Sol in Illetas, which is a family-run four-star hotel where Errol Flynn once stayed.
Celia Goodman

 Headwater offers walking in Mallorca in November. They have a guided walking holiday with departures on November 5, 12 and 19 based at the three-star Hotel Es Port in Port de Soller. The hotel has an indoor swimming pool, Jacuzzi and sauna. The walking is varied with some routes starting at the hotel. On other days, a minibus is used to get past the initial steep gradients and up into the "best bits" in the mountains. The price is £569pp. Details on 01606 813367.
JS

fields.headline: Browsing the shelves
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor browses through the internet's travel bookshops
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor browses through the internet's travel bookshops
fields.body:
I've been hoping for some time that the specialist London travel bookshop Stanford's would launch a website, but there are no signs that it plans to do so. In the meantime, Amazon and Bol (www.bol.com) both have a good selection of travel titles, although Amazon probably has the edge in terms of customer service.

Some publishers' sites can be very useful if you need to update an existing guidebook, or if you want an idea of the style and scope of the books available - although sadly neither the idiosyncratic Blue Guides nor the well-written Cadogan series can be sampled online.

Amazon
Amazon usually offers around 20% off books - more if the title is a bestseller - and it has recently launched a recommendations service for people travelling to a particular country. Visitors to France, for example, are offered a Michelin Red Guide, Madame Bovary (but not, sadly, Posy Simmonds's version), Elizabeth David's French Provincial Cooking and the Time Out guide to southern France. Solo travellers can choose Hitchhiking Vietnam and Travel Alone and Love It.

Time Out
Chiefly useful for its event recommendations, this is not a substitute for buying the books, but the cut-down accommodation and sightseeing information does convey their distinctive style.

The Travel Bookshop
The Travel Bookshop trades somewhat on its association with Hugh Grant in the film Notting Hill, but despite the lack of discounts it remains a friendly site where visitors can enquire about old and out-of-print books or consult the Guide to Guides, which succintly sums up the strengths and weaknesses of the various imprints.

Vacation work
Order the Directories of Summer Jobs in Britain, USA and Abroad, the backpackers' Work Your Way Around the World and Taking a Gap Year for a £2 discount. The updated job vacancy list and message boards are a reasonably good place to look for opportunities or advertise yourself.

Fodors
If Fodors' guides can sometimes seem rather old-fashioned, its website is an excellent resource that improves all the time. (Fodors probably assumes that its usual clientele is unlikely to bother to economise on a guidebook by printing out pages at home). The links provided for each city are so very comprehensive that I hesitate to put this page at risk by recommending them. Visitors also have the opportunity to review and rate restaurants around the world. These tend be of the Savoy rather than the Pizza Express variety.

Lonely Planet
At the opposite end of the spectrum lie the Lonely Planet titles. A limited amount of information is available here, alongside guidebook updates and a rather clunky ordering service. The less adventurous, but potentially useful Rough Guides site can be accessed at www.travel.roughguides.com

Stanford's
Stanfords is one of the most famous travel bookshop in the world: for those familiar with The Hound of the Baskervilles, it is the source of Sherlock Holmes' map of the Devon moor where the beast roams. The site provides a range and depth of helpful information which Amazon et al just can't match, and postage is also generally cheaper - folded maps cost 30p first-class to the UK and 50p by airmail, while paperbacks are £2. Items are usually dispatched within 48 hours. The site also lists the names and contact details of its staff, so you don't have to rely on email to resolve any difficulties.

Items are usually dispatched within 48 hours. The site also lists the names and contact details of its staff, so you don't have to rely on email to resolve any difficulties.

fields.standfirst: Mary Butler wanted advice on planning a walking honeymoon in Mallorca this November. She wanted to do it as cheaply as possible and wanted a good website for flights leaving from either Exeter or Bristol as well as advice on reasonably-priced accommodation.
fields.trailText:
Try www.flightlineflights.com for the cheapest flights to Palma from Exeter or Bristol. I have walked many times in Mallorca using the guide Landscapes of Mallorca by Valerie Crespi Green. I usually stay with friends in the north of the island but suggest the Hotel Bon Sol in Illetas, which is a family-run four-star hotel where Errol Flynn once stayed.
Celia Goodman

fields.headline: Hollywood's altar  ego
fields.standfirst: Even if Steven Seagal never wins an Oscar in this life, his reward may come in the next. Will Hodgkinson pays tribute  to the film world's most cosmic star
fields.trailText: Even if Steven Seagal never wins an Oscar in this life, his reward may come in the next. Will Hodgkinson pays tribute to the film world's most cosmic star
fields.body:
Bodh Gaya is a hot and dusty town at the heart of Bihar, one of India's poorest states. It was here that Siddhartha Buddha, the founder of Buddhism, was said to have reached enlightenment while sitting under a bo tree, and Bodh Gaya is now an important pilgrimage site, with a complex of temples attracting thousands of pilgrims every day, as well as a semi-permanent beggar population who give the pilgrims a chance to improve their karma by throwing them a few rupees. At the centre of it all is the Mahabodhi Temple, the seventh-century homage to Siddhartha built on the spot where the great one found his calling, and which contains a bo tree believed to be the direct descendant of the one under which Buddha sat.

In February 1997 I visited Bodh Gaya for a few days. The narrow streets were filled with Tibetan monks, Japanese pilgrims and Western travellers, and it was clear that some sort of a celebration was taking place. One of the monks told me that I had arrived at a very auspicious time: after years of searching, the reincarnation of a legendary Buddhist master, or lama, had been found, and he was currently being inaugurated into his new role at Mahabodhi. Usually the reincarnation of a lama is found when still a child. If he recognises the possessions of the former master, he will be accepted as the new one. So I went to the golden-spired temple, hoping to catch a glimpse of a serene five-year-old, wise and innocent, blessing the faithful. At the throne under the bo tree was a large middle-aged white man with not-quite good looks and a rather ratty ponytail.

It was chunky action hero Steven Seagal, star of such video shop bargain bin blockbusters as Time To Kill, Under Seige and The Patriot. Seagal may not be up there with the Hollywood greats, but in the Buddhist hierarchy, he is just a notch down from the Dalai Lama himself.

Lama Seagal is the ultimate bombastic Buddhist, cracking skulls one minute and contemplating the infinite nature of nothingness the next. Being recognised as a master who has achieved enlightenment but, out of his limitless compassion, has vowed to take rebirth to help reduce the suffering of all sentient beings is merely the latest in a long line of Zen-like achievements for Seagal. Born in 1951 in Michigan, he discovered the wisdom of the East at the age of seven, when he took up the martial art of aikido and professed to his parents that he was not of this cosmic realm. As a young man he migrated to Japan, and, not wishing to reveal his abilities at astral projection to those who might wish him harm, went by plane. Soon after, the young lama may or may not have worked for the Shah of Iran, Bishop Tutu, Anwar Sadat and the CIA; Seagal's claims have not been verified by anyone other than himself, but just as in his films, it seems that his life has been coloured by all kinds of secret conspiracies against him, plotted by those who have strayed from the path that leads to deliverance from all human forms of suffering.

Seagal returned to the States as a master of aikido, and well-versed in Zen Buddhism and acupuncture, and in 1987 he set up a martial arts school in California. One of the students there was all-powerful Hollywood agent Mike Ovitz, who listened to his master's request to spread the message of holiness via one of the world's most effective mediums - action movies. By the time Seagal was recognised as a tulku (reincarnation) of the 17th-century translator-teacher Terton Chungdrag Dorje, he had established a familar screen alter ego for himself: a karate-chopping defender of the underdog, fighting evil and corruption with his bare hands and dispensing brutal justice to all who stand against him.

But while the great Tibetan leader Penor Rinpoche recognised the special qualities of a lama within Seagal, the Hollywood establishment found it difficult to accept the new-found godlike status of one of its most lowly micro-stars. Big-hitters of the entertainment world like Richard Gere and Tina Turner have, after all, followed Tibetan Buddhism devoutly for many years, but while they rule the roost in cinemas and concert halls the world over, it is Terton Chungdrag Dorje (Seagal) who was sitting on that throne in Bodh Gaya.

Strictly speaking, Gere et al, mere followers of the great Buddha, should exalt the pony-tailed one as the all-compassionate being he is, but Seagal was at once accused of bribing Penor Rimpoche and other high-ranking Buddhist leaders into recognizing him as the reincarnated lama. The great one replied to such accusations with typical magnanimity: "Whenever someone has asked me if I am a tulku [reincarnation], I have said that I don't believe it is very important who I was in my last lives. I think it is important what I do in this life. And what I do in this life is only important if I can ease the suffering of others, if I can somehow make the world a better place, if I somehow serve Buddha and mankind, if I can somehow plant the seed of bodhicitta [the search for enlightenment] into people's hearts." Lama Terton Chungdrag Dorje Seagal's way of planting the seed of bodhicitta into people's hearts - by making incredibly violent B-movies - has caused some confusion, but just as the Buddha-nature is in all living things, so the message of the path to nirvana is in all of Seagal's films.

In 1990's Hard To Kill, Seagal plays an LAPD officer who witnesses and tapes dirty dealings between a California senator and the mob. For most of the film the senator's hoods try to hunt him down, but his Buddha-nature eludes them. Perhaps the tape could be seen as a metaphor for the secret of enlightenment: he's got it, they can't have it, and they cannot realise that they are going the wrong way about searching for it. (A happy note: it was during the making of this film that Seagal met his very own "Lady In Red", 80s sex symbol Kelly Le Brock. They divorced in 1996.)

In 1991's Out For Justice, he stars as Gino Felino, a tough Brooklyn cop whose hip-hop head wiggle reveals his wrong-side-of-the-tracks childhood. Gino's mission is to blow a doped-up gangster off the face of this material realm and into the Third Bardo, and in doing so help those who are suffering under the malign force of this wicked spirit. Here we have a classic example of Seagal showing compassion for the most lowly sentient beings, including a stray puppy who he befriends after an awesomely bloody shootout. Word, lama.

Seagal hit the big-time with 1992's Under Seige, in which he plays a cook on a navy destroyer captured by deranged veteran Tommy Lee Jones. Seagal dispenses with an awesome number of baddies in this movie, but so what? Accepting the cycle of rebirth, he is merely moving these sentient beings into their next incarnation, where, with any luck, they will improve their karma by living more virtuous lives as sewer rats or mosquitoes. Then there's 1998's The Patriot, in which he plays a doctor fighting against a lethal virus. The virus, of course, is a symbol of all the ignorance in the world. Only Lama Seagal can cure it. Just like the endless lives through which we must pass until we reach nirvana, Seagal's films all melt into one another after a while, but the message is clearly there. Nobody could doubt his buddha-nature after watching a few of his subliminal positive-message classics - not even Lil' Kim, the inauspiciously dressed rap star whom Lama Seagal is currently hoping to make his spiritual partner. And after seeing that haughty, slightly overweight stallion of a man rightly enthroned under the bo tree at Bodh Gaya, I shall never again view Out For Justice as the sleazy piece of trash I was once misguided enough to judge it.

 The Patriot is out on video on Monday (Cinema Club, £5.99)

fields.headline: The new Euro star
fields.standfirst: Lille has been put on the map by the Chunnel and has transformed itself into a chic weekend destination
fields.trailText: Lille has been put on the map by the Chunnel and has transformed itself into a chic weekend destination
fields.body:
Just 15 years ago Lille was an ailing industrial city. Since then, it has had a radical face-lift, attracted a stylish retail industry and got itself on the London-Paris, London-Brussels high-speed rail network. So what does it have to offer the London crowd only two hours away?

Ignore the sprawling glass structure that is the Euralille shopping centre and keep on walking past the handsome Lille-Flanders station (originally built in Paris but moved here brick by brick), cross the road and begin to breathe easy as you near the Grand' Place less than 100 yards away.

Also known as the Place du Général de Gaulle (after one of the town's more famous sons), this was originally a bustling market place that nowadays has enough cafés and terraces to make it the obvious starting point for any tour.

Notable buildings around the square include the Vieille Bourse, or old stock exchange, which was built in 1653 by Julien Destrée as a result of the persistent ill-health of the Lillois bankers and merchants. Trading had always taken place at the open the Fontaine-au-Change, whatever the weather, and the bankers endured regular bouts of flu and colds. By 1651 they had had enough and took their wheezy deputation to the Magistrate who, in turn, consulted Philip IV, King of Spain and the Count of Flanders. The result was a quadrangle of 24 ornately-decorated houses. Trading took place in the interior courtyard. Destrée, a wood-carver, fashioned lions' heads, cherubs and other symbols of wealth and power in the Lezennes limestone. Though no longer the stock exchange, there is a daily second-hand book and flower market here.

Le Grand' Garde building, on the square, was erected almost a century later by the Sun King, Louis XIV - the pediment shows his sun emblem and Lille's coat of arms - and is now the Théatre du Nord. The square is also home to the biggest bookshop in Europe, Le Furet Du Nord, with its tangle of footbridges and aerial stairways. In the middle is the Goddess statue, commemorating the Austrian siege of Lille in 1792 and the French resistance to it. You can still see cannon balls protruding from the facades of the houses in Rang de Beauregard on Place du Théatre, just behind the Vieille Bourse.

The new stock exchange, which opened in 1903, is in the Place du Théatre, and the neighbouring building is the famous Opéra du Nord.

Museums

Palais de Beaux Arts

Place de la République (Monday 2pm-6pm, Wednes day to Sunday 10am-6pm, closed Tuesday)

Lille's Fine Arts museum is regarded in France as second only to the Louvre. The 19th-century building houses masterpieces by Rubens, Van Dyck, Goya (in particular Youth and Age), Delacroix , Courbet and 40 drawings by Raphael.

Charles de Gaulle Museum

Rue Princesse (10am-noon & 2pm to 5pm except Monday, Tuesday and Bank Holidays)

Charles de Gaulle was born in this house, inhabited then by his grandmother. Souvenirs of his childhood, his military career and his presidency are displayed here.

Museum of the Hospice Comtesse Rue de la Monnaie (10am-12.30pm, 2pm to 6pm except Tuesday).

The Hospice was founded in 1237 by Jeanne of Constantinople, but is now used as a museum to "mirror Lille and the old Low Countries" through Flemish and Dutch paintings, local porcelain, wood carvings and tapestries. There are also rare and ancient musical instruments within the Hel Collection.

Shopping for fashion

Every designer label seems to have a retail outlet within the old town. It is hard to know where to flash your credit card first.

In rue Grande Chausée, the Hermès shop was "awarded" its opulent leather staircase because it has the highest turnover outside of Paris.

La Botte Chantilly sells quality branded shoes. But even if shoes are not top of the agenda, go in and look through the rear glass wall to the elegant building that was the musketeer D'Artagnan's house.

Xandres is an exclusive, chic Belgium import that has premiered in Lille, targetting women aged between 20 and 45 with a range of smart clothes and sportswear.

Deschilder (6 rue des Chats Bossus) is a "maroquinerie" selling fancy leather goods. Planet London (rue des Clefs) sells silver satin trousers and other couture to ensure clubbers look the techno part in any disco.

In rue Esquermoise, fashion shops include Clergerie, whose fabulously expensive clothes are frequently paraded in Elle. Accessoir'In is best described as a designer version of Accessorize and alongside the unusual jewellery is a collection of gloves, bags, scarves and hats by Christian Lacroix, Yves Saint-Laurent, Kenzo and Karl Lagerfeld.

At La Compagnie Des Marques, there is a daily delivery of branded clothes at reduced prices and, with a little digging, you can uncover some good bargains.

But serious bargain-hunters should head for the factory shopping outlets of L'Usine or McArthur Glenn in Roubaix, 10 minutes outside Lille. Both offer great savings on quality clothing.

Shopping for food

Philip Olivier Fromagerie 3 rue du Curé Saint-Etienne

Lille has its own pungent but tasty cheese called Vieux-Lille. Buy it here along with other regional cheeses such as Maroilles.

Chocolat Passion Trogneux 67 rue Nationale

Chocoholics are in good hands here for this is where the Chocolate Passion Club is based. Be adventurous and try the chocolates à les bière de Jenlain - a dark chocolate mixed with Jenlain beer.

Comtesse du Barry 21 rue Esquermoise

Among the deli products here, try Flemish goodies such as prunes in armagnac tart as well as the typically French foie gras de canard - duck's liver paté.

Le Vins Gourmands 33 rue Esquemoise

A quaint outlet offering not just wine, but also a range of regional spirits.

The local market

The district of Wazemmes, about a mile from the old town, refuses to modernise. Shopping is done on Sundays in the famous market, where everything from antiques, fresh food and vegetables, flowers and regular jumble are on sale. The local shops in Rue Leon Gambetta stay open late to accommodate the extra custom.

Where to eat

There are restaurants galore in Lille offering food from all over the world. But it would be a shame to miss out on the city's unique Flemish cuisine. If you find dishes you cannot get your tongue around, you know they have to be Flemish. The two most popular are potjevleisch , comprising a terrine of three meats - veal, pork and rabbit, or chicken, duck and rabbit - cooked with onions, garlic, white wine, lemon and tomatoes and served cold in a golden jelly. The second is Carbonnade à la Flamande , a beef stew dish slow-cooked in beer and onions then sweetened with brown sugar. Wash it down with a regional beer and finish it off with the local tipple, genièvre.

Hochepot 6 rue du Nouveau Siècle

Regional food with a dash of pananche in the 17th-century Porte de Gand. Menu from FF185.

La Terrasse des Ramparts Logis de la Porte de Gand, Rue de Gand

Mini menu from FF95, à la carte from FF180.

Estaminet Trijsel 25 rue de Gand

For authentic Flemish food and atmosphere, this café has simple wooden furniture brightened up by antique pots, jugs and other earthenware, and is decorated with hops and barley. From approx FF60.

Where to stay

Mister Bed 57 rue de Béthune, tel: 03 20 12 96 96.

A simple but clean hotel situated in a central pedestrianised zone - from FF160 to FF329.

Le Breughel 3/5 parvis st Maurice, tel: 03 20 06 06 69.

Charming two-star opposite the magnificent Saint Maurice church in the heart of Lille, from FF245 to F420 a night.

Carlton Hotel 3 rue de Paris, tel: 03 20 13 33 13

Facing the opera house, this is elaborately furnished with Louis XVI and Louis XV antiques and has marble bathrooms. Pavarotti, Yehudi Menuhin and Kiri Te Kanawa have all stayed here when performing in Lille. Rooms from FF840 to FF2,600.

The practicals

Eurostar Holidays Direct (08701 676767) is offering a day-trip to Lille plus two-course lunch with drink and coffee in a restaurant for £60pp for travel until September 17. A regular return fare on Eurostar (08701 606600) costs £90 return including a Saturday night stay.

Sharron Livingston is the author of a series of Channel Hopper's Guides. The Lille edition, published by Passport Guides, is due out next month, and is available direct from the publisher (020-8905 4851) for £5.99.

Charles de Gaulle Museum Rue Princesse (10am-noon & 2pm to 5pm except Monday, Tuesday and Bank Holidays) Charles de Gaulle was born in this house, inhabited then by his grandmother. Souvenirs of his childhood, his military career and his presidency are displayed here. Museum of the Hospice Comtesse Rue de la Monnaie (10am-12.30pm, 2pm to 6pm except Tuesday). The Hospice was founded in 1237 by Jeanne of Constantinople, but is now used as a museum to "mirror Lille and the old Low Countries" through Flemish and Dutch paintings, local porcelain, wood carvings and tapestries. There are also rare and ancient musical instruments within the Hel Collection. Shopping for fashion Every designer label seems to have a retail outlet within the old town. It is hard to know where to flash your credit card first. In rue Grande Chausée, the Hermès shop was "awarded" its opulent leather staircase because it has the highest turnover outside of Paris. La Botte Chantilly sells quality branded shoes. But even if shoes are not top of the agenda, go in and look through the rear glass wall to the elegant building that was the musketeer D'Artagnan's house. Xandres is an exclusive, chic Belgium import that has premiered in Lille, targetting women aged between 20 and 45 with a range of smart clothes and sportswear. Deschilder (6 rue des Chats Bossus) is a "maroquinerie" selling fancy leather goods. Planet London (rue des Clefs) sells silver satin trousers and other couture to ensure clubbers look the techno part in any disco. In rue Esquermoise, fashion shops include Clergerie, whose fabulously expensive clothes are frequently paraded in Elle. Accessoir'In is best described as a designer version of Accessorize and alongside the unusual jewellery is a collection of gloves, bags, scarves and hats by Christian Lacroix, Yves Saint-Laurent, Kenzo and Karl Lagerfeld. At La Compagnie Des Marques, there is a daily delivery of branded clothes at reduced prices and, with a little digging, you can uncover some good bargains. But serious bargain-hunters should head for the factory shopping outlets of L'Usine or McArthur Glenn in Roubaix, 10 minutes outside Lille. Both offer great savings on quality clothing. Shopping for food Philip Olivier Fromagerie 3 rue du Curé Saint-Etienne Lille has its own pungent but tasty cheese called Vieux-Lille. Buy it here along with other regional cheeses such as Maroilles. Chocolat Passion Trogneux 67 rue Nationale Chocoholics are in good hands here for this is where the Chocolate Passion Club is based. Be adventurous and try the chocolates à les bière de Jenlain - a dark chocolate mixed with Jenlain beer. Comtesse du Barry 21 rue Esquermoise Among the deli products here, try Flemish goodies such as prunes in armagnac tart as well as the typically French foie gras de canard - duck's liver paté. Le Vins Gourmands 33 rue Esquemoise A quaint outlet offering not just wine, but also a range of regional spirits. The local market The district of Wazemmes, about a mile from the old town, refuses to modernise. Shopping is done on Sundays in the famous market, where everything from antiques, fresh food and vegetables, flowers and regular jumble are on sale. The local shops in Rue Leon Gambetta stay open late to accommodate the extra custom. Where to eat There are restaurants galore in Lille offering food from all over the world. But it would be a shame to miss out on the city's unique Flemish cuisine. If you find dishes you cannot get your tongue around, you know they have to be Flemish. The two most popular are potjevleisch , comprising a terrine of three meats - veal, pork and rabbit, or chicken, duck and rabbit - cooked with onions, garlic, white wine, lemon and tomatoes and served cold in a golden jelly. The second is Carbonnade à la Flamande , a beef stew dish slow-cooked in beer and onions then sweetened with brown sugar. Wash it down with a regional beer and finish it off with the local tipple, genièvre. Hochepot 6 rue du Nouveau Siècle Regional food with a dash of pananche in the 17th-century Porte de Gand. Menu from FF185. La Terrasse des Ramparts Logis de la Porte de Gand, Rue de Gand Mini menu from FF95, à la carte from FF180. Estaminet Trijsel 25 rue de Gand For authentic Flemish food and atmosphere, this café has simple wooden furniture brightened up by antique pots, jugs and other earthenware, and is decorated with hops and barley. From approx FF60. Where to stay Mister Bed 57 rue de Béthune, tel: 03 20 12 96 96. A simple but clean hotel situated in a central pedestrianised zone - from FF160 to FF329. Le Breughel 3/5 parvis st Maurice, tel: 03 20 06 06 69. Charming two-star opposite the magnificent Saint Maurice church in the heart of Lille, from FF245 to F420 a night. Carlton Hotel 3 rue de Paris, tel: 03 20 13 33 13 Facing the opera house, this is elaborately furnished with Louis XVI and Louis XV antiques and has marble bathrooms. Pavarotti, Yehudi Menuhin and Kiri Te Kanawa have all stayed here when performing in Lille. Rooms from FF840 to FF2,600. The practicals Eurostar Holidays Direct (08701 676767) is offering a day-trip to Lille plus two-course lunch with drink and coffee in a restaurant for £60pp for travel until September 17. A regular return fare on Eurostar (08701 606600) costs £90 return including a Saturday night stay. Sharron Livingston is the author of a series of Channel Hopper's Guides. The Lille edition, published by Passport Guides, is due out next month, and is available direct from the publisher (020-8905 4851) for £5.99.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: See yew
fields.body:
See yew

The 30ft yew wigwam at Antony House near Plymouth was originally built as a vantage point for the lady of the house to watch tennis, but is now home to a wee Cornish pixie.

House and gardens open Sun, Tues, Wed, Thurs and Bank Holiday Mondays, 1.30pm-5.30pm. £4/£2. Torpoint, Plymouth (01752 812191).

Lords and order

The chambers of both the House of Commons and the House of Lords are open to the public this summer as part of a tour of the Palace of Westminster.

Open Aug 7-Sept 16, Mon-Sat, 9.30am-4.15pm. £3.50. Guided tours booked through Ticketmaster (020-7344 9966); www.ticketmaster.co.uk

On a theme

A total of 25m Lego bricks can't be wrong. Especially for under-10s who find the rides, models, mazes and rollercoaster at Legoland utterly more-ish.

Open daily 10am-6pm. £17.50/£14.50/ under-3 free. Windsor, Berkshire (08705 040404).

Fair do

Three days of stalls and amusements inject life into the ancient streets of St Andrews, as the Lammas Fair competes with the golf courses as the most popular tourist attraction.

Sat/Mon/Tues, afternoons and evenings. Kingdom of Fife Tourist Board (01334 472021).

Voice of the valleys

Join choirs, instrumentalists, brass bands, folk dancers, actors and arts and crafts exhibitors at the first National Eisteddfod of Wales this century.

Until Aug 12. £7.50/£4, plus various ticketed evening performances. Millennium Coastal Park, Llanelli, Glamorgan (01554 772000).

You jest?

Perfect your circus skills with Elfic the Jester, the award-winning street entertainer, performing at Totnes Castle on Wednesday.

Aug 8, 15, 22, from 11am. £1.60/80p. Totnes, Devon (01803-864406).

Rally round

Cromford Steam Rally is 30 years old today. Barn engines, fairground organs, steam engines, showmans' engines, vintage cars and an Olde Tyme fairground join the celebrations.

Today, Highacres Farm, Dewey Lane, Brackenfield, Tansley, Matlock, Derbyshire (01629 824263).

The vole story

The Meadow Vole Maze weaves the elements of Muncaster Castle - gardens, wildlife and habitat restoration - with the life of a meadow vole. Art, antiques, gardens, ghosts and World Owl Centre are also here.

Castle open daily except Sat, noon-5pm. Gardens open daily 10.30am-6pm.£6/£5/family £17. Muncaster Castle, Ravenglass, Cumbria (01229 717614).

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: France | Italy | Croatia | Jordan | S Africa | Bhutan | Hong Kong | Laos and Cambodia | Florida
fields.body:
Europe
France:
Two-night trip tasting champagne, from October 7-9, with the opportunity to taste 25 different labels, beginning at breakfast in Reims. Includes visits to top producers. Cost is £269pp. Arblaster & Clarke Wine Tours (01730 893344 www.arblasterandclarke.co.uk).

France:
Doorstep skiing in Isola, self-catering for four. Price £309pp. Pavillion Tours (0870 2410427).

Italy:
Seven nights for four in an appartment at Baveno, Lake Maggiore, coinciding with the Grand Prix at Monza. Depart September 9. Price £425pp. Lakes and Mountains Holidays (01329 844405).

Croatia:
Seven nights in Opatija for singles aged 25-45, at the Hotel Ambassador. Price is £439, departing September 15 from Heathrow. Solo's (020-89512800 www.solosholidays.co.uk. )

Mid East
Jordan:
Seven-night package beginning in the historic city of Amman near the Dead Sea. Travel to the Greco-Roman city of Jerash, visit the desert before moving on to Petra then Aqaba. Departs early October, November, February and March. Price £849pp. Voyages of Discovery (01444 462150).

Africa
South Africa:
One-week rail journey, which includes a visit to Victoria Falls, a trip in to Zimbabwe, as well as Pretoria and a viewing of the eclipse on June 21. Price is £2,980pp. TCA Holidays (01242 224482, www.africanodyssey.co.uk ).

Asia
Bhutan:
Nineteen days' trekking through major towns including Kathmandu, past Mount Everest, through the Paro Valley, visiting villages, temples, old palaces, historic sites and attending a religious festival. Each night is spent in either a hotel or lodge. Departs September 30 and October 28. Price from £3,095. Himalayan Kingdoms (0117 9237163).

Hong Kong:
Five nights for two staying in the three-star South Pacific Hotel. Departures from November 1 to December 10 . Price starts from £539pp. Quest Worldwide (020-8547 3322).

Laos and Cambodia:
Three weeks travelling by riverboat down the Mekong delta, through mountains and jungles. Explore Luang Prabang and Angkor Wat. Depart December 14 from London. Price is £1,750. Gecko Travel (0239 2376799 www.geckotravel.co.uk ).

North America
Florida:
Fourteen nights for eight people in a three-bedroom home with pool, from 2001. Price from £299pp; all-inclusive car insurance from £169 aweek. Travel City Direct (01792 600015).
