fields.headline: Openers leave England frustrated
fields.trailText: This is turning into quite a Test match. A day that began with England in the driving seat ended with the game at a crossroads thanks to a chalk-and-cheese opening partnership of 96 between Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith. This pitch has already shown signs of uneven bounce - mainly when West Indies were bowling this morning - and England won't want to chase more than 150 in the final innings.
fields.body:
This is turning into quite a Test match. A day that began with England in the driving seat ended with the game at a crossroads thanks to a chalk-and-cheese opening partnership of 96 between Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith. This pitch has already shown signs of uneven bounce - mainly when West Indies were bowling this morning - and England won't want to chase more than 150 in the final innings.

On a day of four streakers Campbell flashed merrily and often airily outside off stump on his way to 55, while the more lugubrious Griffith prodded and poked his way to 41 not out, and generally looked about as unflamboyant as is possible when you're wearing that maroon helmet.

It wasn't that England bowled badly (at least not until the final half hour when their determination to pepper Hinds with short-pitched deliveries backfired spectacularly). Andy Caddick beat Griffith repeatedly early on, Darren Gough was pacey, Dominic Cork found some swing and Robert Croft even more turn. But it took a brute of a ball from Craig White to break one of the Windies' weaker links. Worryingly for England, there are stronger ones to come and the deficit is now down to just 15.

It was frustrating stuff after England had grafted a first-innings lead of 146, their biggest over West Indies since the last Test at Old Trafford, in 1995, when the difference was 221. Their total of 303 was a disappointment after the up-and-at-'em heroics of Alec Stewart yesterday - but a recovery after Stewart, Trescothick and White had all gone early to make it 210 for 6. White may be bowling better now than he ever has done for England, but he's still batting a place too high at No. 7.

That England got to 300 at all was thanks to Cork. He only scored 16 but his arrival at the crease was the catalyst for more aggressive running between the wickets - Michael Vaughan seemed energized, and Croft and Gough followed suit. When Cork harries and hassles like this, driving the opposition to distraction and grinning smugly when the fielding errors inevitably come, he really is an asset (not to mention an ass).

West Indies again relied on the Big Two: Curtly - who finally got some reward in this series for some immaculate bowling and moved to 398 Test wickets - and Courtney claimed 8 for 120 between them; the rest managed 2 for 167. Unusually, both Franklyn Rose and Reon King began their spells today with maidens, but the Windies are as far from re-tuning their second strings as they ever were. It could prove costly when England's run chase begins. But for the moment, the psychological force is with West Indies.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Hello, sailor
fields.standfirst: You can learn the basics of sailing in a few days
fields.trailText: You can learn the basics of sailing in a few days
fields.body:
The wind shrieked through the shrouds as I struggled to make off the jib halyard on the cleat; the weather sheet, which I attached to the clew with a bowline, ran freely through the car while my companions adjusted the trim with the jib sheet until the leech tautened in the brisk force four.

Less than a week previously, that sentence might as well have been in Urdu for all the sense it would have made to me. But in five days on a Royal Yachting Association's competent crew course I was turned from a feeble landlubber who didn't know a rolling hitch from a clove hitch into a salty old sea dog, complete with calloused hands and a sunburnt nose.

The competent crew course is designed, as its name suggests, to turn you into a useful person to have onboard a yacht. No one in their right mind would leave you in charge of anything, but when the skipper says jump, you have some idea of how high. Four of us were living and learning on the solid, reliable, and unglamorous Marvin, a five-berth, 32ft yacht with a hull like reinforced concrete and all the style of a school bus. Perfect, in fact, for fools like myself who had never set foot on anything that could be affected by basic stuff such as wind and waves and currents. We would have to try pretty hard to sink this baby.

We set off from Southampton on the first evening against the backdrop of cranes and industrial chimneys with plumes of pollution silhouetted against a hot pink sunset. The Solent is not a pretty place - it is the busiest shipping channel in the world. There's no better place to learn what all those buoys and flags and lights mean - and no place where you'll need to know it more.

The first evening was more of a taster; the main point seemed to be to get to the pub before closing time. We sailed gently down the river, drinking red wine and eating the risotto our skipper, Andy, had whipped up for us on the tiny galley stove. The first practical thing we learned was handling the sails - flaking them neatly when they are not being used, changing them so that we can have a smaller sail for stormier conditions, hauling them up and tying them securely. I quickly broke a nail, my once soft and cared-for hands red from the cold and raw from the rope; my hair, tangled and windswept, had lost any suggestion of style. But I was slipping and cursing just like a proper sailor. Fabulous.

When it gets a bit rough, you have to wear a harness and clip yourself on to the boat for your own safety. We practised the man-overboard drill on a calm day, but frankly it seemed to me that the chances of fishing someone out of the water when it's rough (and after all, that's when you're likely to go over) are pretty slim.

We crossed the Solent to the Isle of Wight with a light wind, taking it in turns at the helm and the sheets - that's the ropes attached to the little sail at the front. Once we had learned to tack and gybe (the same thing, only one is when the wind is coming from the front, and the other when it is behind), it felt like we could really sail. A few practise runs and we were a well-oiled machine; "Ready about!" I would sing, and the others would get ready with the sheets. "Lee-ho!" and we swung around, one girl pulling the jib sail around to the other side, another releasing it, and there we were, sailing!

In control, changing direction with confidence, and using a whole new language. Our confidence burgeoned. We took it in turns at the helm and, as we got more practised, we tried to fine-tune all the angles to get as much speed as possible. The boat streaked along, leaning at a sharp angle with its edge dipping down into the foaming water.

Before hitting the bar, we usually had a task to perform: practising rowing the inflatable dinghy, learning a range of knots from a bowline to a double sheet bend, and going up in the bosun's chair. This hysterical procedure involves getting winched up the mast in a harness until you are so high the boat looks too small to catch you should you fall.

Our last day was what sailing is all about. It was a beautiful sunny day, with a few high clouds draped and feathered across a cornflower sky and a cheerful wind blowing hundreds of yachts around the Solent.

We were all moving about the boat with confidence now, and while one of us stood at the helm the others soaked up the perfect sailing weather with a cup of tea and a biscuit, watching blackheaded gulls and snowy egrets circle the waters, and admiring some of the magnificent boats around us.

There was a sense of a great boating community, made up of all kinds of sailors from potterers to racers, fishermen to cruisers, pros and amateurs, young and old. And in just a few days, we had become part of that world.

The practicals

Anna Rockall completed a five-day competent crew course with Southern Sailing (01489 575511) in Southampton, costing £395 and including meals, on-board accommodation, sleeping bag and waterproofs. The UK Sailing Academy (01983 294941) offers competent crew courses from £166 for a weekend to £663 for an eight days. Its website, www.uk-sail.org.uk has a list of sailing schools around the country.

The Royal Yachting Association training office (02380 627 450) can supply brochures with details of sailing schools around the country. Or look under the training section of the RYA website, on www.rya.org.uk.

Sunsail (0239 222222, www.sunsail.com) offers yacht and dinghy sailing courses on the Solent and on the Firth of Clyde. Its competent crew courses cost between £195 and £350 according to season.

Sailing talk

bend: tie or fasten.

bow: front end of a boat. stern: the back end.

clew: the lower aft corner of a sail, where the foot meets the leech.

gybe: to turn the boat so that the stern (back of the boat) crosses the wind, changing direction.

halyard: rope or wire used for hoisting sails.

helm: the tiller or wheel, and surrounding area.

jib: a foresail. On a cutter this is the forward most sail, as opposed to staysail located between the jib and the main.

leech: the aft edge of a triangular sail.

tack: to turn the boat in order that the wind exerts pressure on the opposite side of the sail.

trim: to adjust the angle of the sails to accord with the wind. Or the way a boat sits in the water.

The boat streaked along, leaning at a sharp angle with its edge dipping down into the foaming water. Before hitting the bar, we usually had a task to perform: practising rowing the inflatable dinghy, learning a range of knots from a bowline to a double sheet bend, and going up in the bosun's chair. This hysterical procedure involves getting winched up the mast in a harness until you are so high the boat looks too small to catch you should you fall. Our last day was what sailing is all about. It was a beautiful sunny day, with a few high clouds draped and feathered across a cornflower sky and a cheerful wind blowing hundreds of yachts around the Solent. We were all moving about the boat with confidence now, and while one of us stood at the helm the others soaked up the perfect sailing weather with a cup of tea and a biscuit, watching blackheaded gulls and snowy egrets circle the waters, and admiring some of the magnificent boats around us. There was a sense of a great boating community, made up of all kinds of sailors from potterers to racers, fishermen to cruisers, pros and amateurs, young and old. And in just a few days, we had become part of that world. The practicals Anna Rockall completed a five-day competent crew course with Southern Sailing (01489 575511) in Southampton, costing £395 and including meals, on-board accommodation, sleeping bag and waterproofs. The UK Sailing Academy (01983 294941) offers competent crew courses from £166 for a weekend to £663 for an eight days. Its website, www.uk-sail.org.uk has a list of sailing schools around the country. The Royal Yachting Association training office (02380 627 450) can supply brochures with details of sailing schools around the country. Or look under the training section of the RYA website, on www.rya.org.uk. Sunsail (0239 222222, www.sunsail.com) offers yacht and dinghy sailing courses on the Solent and on the Firth of Clyde. Its competent crew courses cost between £195 and £350 according to season. Sailing talk bend: tie or fasten. bow: front end of a boat. stern: the back end. clew: the lower aft corner of a sail, where the foot meets the leech. gybe: to turn the boat so that the stern (back of the boat) crosses the wind, changing direction. halyard: rope or wire used for hoisting sails. helm: the tiller or wheel, and surrounding area. jib: a foresail. On a cutter this is the forward most sail, as opposed to staysail located between the jib and the main. leech: the aft edge of a triangular sail. tack: to turn the boat in order that the wind exerts pressure on the opposite side of the sail. trim: to adjust the angle of the sails to accord with the wind. Or the way a boat sits in the water.

fields.headline: The grand tor
fields.standfirst: Countryside campaigner  Kate Ashbrook finds the timeless beauty of Dartmoor's rugged landscape the perfect way to relax
fields.trailText: Countryside campaigner Kate Ashbrook finds the timeless beauty of Dartmoor's rugged landscape the perfect way to relax
fields.body:
There can be moments on the best walks that lodge in your memory forever: something of this kind happened to Kate Ashbrook when she was coming back down the western edge of Dartmoor in the fading light of a December afternoon last year.

"The woods in the winter are such a lovely colour in the Tavey valley, all brown and grey and slightly mauve, and Hill Bridge farm had a trail of smoke coming from the chimney," she says.

"It was such a welcoming sight, and it could have been any time over the past few centuries. It was absolutely timeless, and it really hit me how lovely it was."

As general secretary of the Open Spaces Society and chair of the access committee of the Ramblers' Association, Ashbrook is deeply involved in defending the Countryside and Rights of Way Bill from Opposition ambushes as it struggles towards gaining Royal Assent in Parliament. The Bill will establish the so-called "right to roam".

She is also president of the Dartmoor Preservation Association, which gives her the opportunity for frequent visits to a part of England she's loved ever since she was a child.

Ashbrook has stayed at Hill Bridge farm many times since first taking a riding holiday there when she was 10 years old, and she has completed her favourite walk countless times since then. Beginning a few miles north of the village of Peter Tavey, she follows a five-mile circuit of rocky tors, long ridges, boggy slopes and the hill forts and the standing stones of prehistoric tribes.

The highlight of Ashbrook's walk is the top of White Tor, with its vast, varied and unchanging views in all directions - to Bodmin Moor and Cornwall in the west, to the Tamar estuary in the south, into the great, 15-mile expanse of the moor itself.

In the foreground, for contrast, you can pick out the ancient stone circle on the flank of Langstone Moor, with Great Mis Tor behind it.

The view to the heart of the moor is best described for Ashbrook by a phrase in a letter written to her by the Dartmoor preservation campaigner, Sylvia Sayer, who died in January this year and was a friend for nearly 30 years: "She called it 'Dartmoor's long, calm lines', and I thought, absolutely, that's it - it's not necessarily dramatic, but it's very soothing and comforting, and just knowing that it's there is wonderful."

But there's more to the walk than the landscape: it takes Ashbrook past groups of reddish-brown south Devon cattle, along old bridleways and lanes lined with granite walls, and past banks of wild flowers.

The predominant colour is green in spring and summer, and "a lovely warm brown colour" in autumn and winter, and there are always birds: buzzards, crows, ravens, wheatears, pippets and skylarks.

Unfortunately, there is also the grit in the oyster - the red flags and lookout huts of the army, who use a nearby part of the moor as a firing range. "You pass a standing stone which has been bashed by the military," she says. "They did the most appalling things to ancient monuments until they became more enlightened. It's just wrong that they should occupy this wonderful, wild landscape."

Ashbrook likes walking alone, or with her partner or a friend. "I think it gives me such a feeling of relaxation, but reinvigoration as well. It's getting away from what I normally do, and I find afterwards it's given me a great feeling of well-being.

"I will think things out as well - I can't stop my brain entirely. It's still churning away, but in a relaxed way, which is pleasant. I just let the thoughts come in and come out."

Recently, Ashbrook rounded off her walk with a foray through Creason Wood, to swim in a secluded pool in the Tavey, next to a waterfall with the birds singing around her. "It was so cold, it literally hurt. But it was refreshing and wonderful as well."

The practicals

There are rail stations close to the eastern, southern and western edges of Dartmoor. National Rail Enquiries: 08457 484950. For coaches to devon, call the national Express Enquiry Line on 08705 808080. Local bus details, call DevonBus enquiry line on 01392 382800 or www.devon-cc.gov.uk/devonbus .

A free copy of Dartmoor visitor can be obtained from High Moorland Visitor Centre, Princetown, Devon (01822 890414). Accomodation guide from dartmoor Tourism Association, Princetown, Devon (01822 890567, www.dartmoor-guide.co.uk ). OS Outdoor Leisure map (2 1/2inches to 1 mile), no 28 (Dartmoor), £6.50.

Rights of passage

All but a fraction of the unenclosed moorland on Dartmoor is open to walkers, thanks to long-established rights of way, the Dartmoor Commons Act of 1985, and access agreements negotiated with landowners.

The remaining fraction is likely to be accessible within a few years of the passage of the Countryside and Rights of Way Bill, which will establish the so-called "right to roam" on open country, now being debated in Parliament.

The main restriction on access is the use by the Army of the huge firing ranges for part of the time. There was an outcry when the principal landowner, the Duchy of Cornwall (headed by Prince Charles), granted a 21-year lease to the Ministry of Defence in the early 1990s.

Other threats to the conservation of the moor include the pressure from 10 million visitors a year, the industrial pressure for quarrying and mining, and the growth of areas of bracken at the expense of the heather, which gives much of Dartmoor its character and beauty.

Dartmoor National Park Authority is continuing a campaign called Moor Care, which repairs and restores eroded areas and encourages visitors to support "sustainable tourism" - by avoiding certain paths during wet weather, for example.

fields.headline: Driven to succeed
fields.standfirst: Spike Lee veteran Delroy Lindo is the only decent  man in car caper Gone In 60 Seconds -  perhaps this time people will remember him for longer than that
fields.trailText: Spike Lee veteran Delroy Lindo is the only decent man in car caper Gone In 60 Seconds - perhaps this time people will remember him for longer than that
fields.body:
With his lantern jaw and liquid eyes, British-born Delroy Lindo has become one of the busiest and most admired character actors in Hollywood. From a Spike Lee ensemble player (Malcolm X, Crooklyn, Clockers) to made-for-cable stardom to a movie-stealing run of recent supporting turns in The Cider House Rules, the upcoming Romeo Must Die and current release Gone In 60 Seconds, Lindo has never failed to impress. And in 60, that's not easy, competing as his implacable detective does with a ring of charismatic car thieves, plus 50 of the hottest hot luxury vehicles. It's no surprise that Lindo is about the only one who emerges from this car wreck of a movie with his humanity intact.

Was it weird to play the only honest man in this whole movie?

I'll tell you, when I read the script I said, Damn! I wanna play the chop shop owner that Robert Duvall wound up playing. And the detective was the least well-written of all the parts; but something happened and it turned out OK.

You're usually a serious character actor. Did you have fun making this?

The best part was the sessions I had at Bobby Orr's defensive driving school prior to filming. So consequently, I felt very safe doing those stunts, and that was very liberating. It was very gratifying to do a lot of my own stunt driving.

Are you a safe driver?

Yes I am. My lady may disagree, but I'm a pretty safe driver. But one thing about driving where I live, in New York: it brings out the worst in me. It certainly increases your ability to fend for yourself and look out for Number One, but that's not necessarily the same thing as being the safest person.

You're originally from Britain. Do you think you relate to living in America differently than people who were born there?

I was born in London and came to the US as a teenager. My parents are Jamaican, and we travelled around a lot. I think it's fair to say that that's given me a slightly different perspective than most African-Americans. Or Englishmen.

Any desire to one day be Sir Delroy?

Hell no. Not me.

What's your biggest complaint about Hollywood today?

That's what one calls a loaded question, but I'll try to answer it. Two things seem to be happening. One is that the films and the thrust seem to be getting younger and younger and younger, and that's unfortunate, I think. And I wish there were more adherence paid to the body of one's work. I always feel that people only remember the last thing that I did, and that's unfortunate.

Along those lines, you got great notices for your work in Cider House Rules and now you're part of this major summer action film. Do you feel you're closer now than ever before to achieving your professional goals?

It sounds kind of boring and cliched, but my goal is to do good and interesting work that people want to come see. In terms of visibility, let's go back to Get Shorty and Ransom five years ago: both big commercial successes and I was a major part of those films. That raised visibility, but there isn't necessarily any relationship between being in a big, commercial film and personally translating it to my career going somewhere. It's not a logical progression. Two and two don't make four in my reality. For some actors, it does, but for me it doesn't. It's just ever-evolving.

You seem so intense. Do you ever relax?

Relax... Sure, yeah, I relax. Every once in a while.

fields.headline: Thule roof rack
fields.trailText: Smart roof box for style-conscious skiers, surfers and those who'd like to be either.
fields.body:
What is it?

Smart roof box for style-conscious skiers, surfers and those who'd like to be either.

What happens if I can't ski or surf?

Fill it up with camping gear, picnics, your travelling CDs.

What's it look like?

Canoe designed by Norman Foster or giant inflated surfboard.

How much?

An Alpine 500 model carries four pairs of skis and costs £199.95; an eight-pack is £394.95.

Does it fit all cars, then?

Sure does. The Thule Rapid System holds the Thule Roof Box to the top of any car, says the manufacturer (well, perhaps not a 1904 Spyker or Caterham Super Seven).

But, don't I need a Porsche or an off-roader for maximum style compatibility?

Don't worry. It would look good on the roof of a Reliant Rialto.

Colours?

Black, anthracite or silver - none of those Licorice Allsort coloured jobs you see at Cortina (the resort, not the Dagenham motor of the same name).

British design?

Er, no. Swedish.

Which makes it what?

As reliable as Borg at Wimbledon, as fashionable as . . . Abba?

So, will I look cool, nerdish or just pretentious?

Your Thule-topped car will give the impression that you are the sort of supercool, outdoors type.

But will it affect the stability of my Volvo Estate on its motorway run to Italian crestas and French pistes?

Sensible question. It's low, streamlined and probably has a Cd (coefficient of drag) factor lower than your Volvo. So, no worries on that score.

Sensible these Swedes, eh?

They do the outdoor life more often than most Europeans, so they know a thing or two about how to get out and about with the least fuss.

A wise investment, then?

Probably. Better than tying bits and pieces on top of the car with those snappy elasticated ropes that take your finger nails off.

Where can I get one?

Mail order in the UK from Snow + Rock (0845 1001000).

fields.headline: Call of nature
fields.standfirst: A wonderworld of rainforest and coral reefs in the Indian Ocean
fields.trailText: Madagascar is a wonderful island. Admittedly, it is one of the poorest countries in the world. But that doesn't stop tourists quickly romanticising about the place to an almost absurd extent.
fields.body:
Madasgascar is a wonderful island. Admittedly, it is one of the poorest countries in the world. But that doesn't stop tourists quickly romanticising about the place to an almost absurd extent.

And why not? After all, if everywhere is falling under the stern heel of western culture, isn't it good to fall in love with somewhere that offers a different and more materially modest way of living? And Madagascar, at best, does that, challenging and charming westerners in equal measure.

This island, the fourth largest in the world after Greenland, New Guinea and Borneo (it's twice as big as our rain-soaked sixpence of a country), sits in the shark-infested waters of the Indian Ocean, a jewel of gentle wonder. Here is a little wonderworld of endemic species evolving in splendid isolation - vanga birds with their extraordinary beaks, teddy-bear-faced indri-indri with their soulful cries, forest after intriguing forest of organic surprises.

Most people come to Madagascar after hearing the call of its nature. But, once there, they become equally seduced by the people. To sit in a crowded taxi-brousse (mini-bus), with your face in someone's armpit or chicken, is to realise that this is a land of beautiful people, preternaturally calm in the crush, staring with endless fascination at the red-faced vazha (foreigner) with his impressive collection of insect bites and feeble grasp of the Malagasy language.

Madagascar represented the first time that I had been to a developing country, so the poverty was a tremendous shock. But my guilt about being a tourist in the world's ninth poorest country was constantly challenged. It was all right for me to climb into a rickshaw (known in this former French colony as pousse-pousses ) and be pulled by a barefoot, sweating boy from hotel to ethnographic museum (three miles at least) for the equivalent of 70p, so long as I gave him a good tip. Guilt, after all, is a luxury product.

I was picked up by my main guide, Lalaina Ramaroson, at Itavo airport and driven around the outskirts of the capital, Antananarivo. Immediately, we were in third-world gridlock. My lungs quickly filled with the smells of a million charcoal stoves and with appalling fumes from aged exhausts. But what a fascinating traffic jam: France (which colonised this island from 1895 to 1960 and still sinks its claws deep into Malagasy society) exports its old bangers here, and the Malagasy, inveterate recyclers, keep them going for decades.

You could readily come here to spot species of car that you had thought extinct - taxis are Renault 4s, Peugeots that look like Austin Cambridges still thrive. Look! A lesser-spotted Simca! But the Malgasy don't only recycle, they use everything intensively: not a bicycle passed by without a passenger or an unfeasible load straddling the crossbar. Heads are for carrying water buckets from the village tap. Boys push giggling girls in wheelbarrows. Pairs of zebu (the local cattle) pull carts laden with crops or else sit in the traffic doing nothing but contemplating their cud and causing mayhem. There was the odd, solitary white face behind the tinted windows of a 4x4. Such was my first brush with Madagascar.

At Vakona Lodge, a posh hotel that is made up of pretty bungalows on the edge of the rainforest, I laid my jet-lagged head to rest, lulled by the sound of the indri-indri from nearby trees. These are the biggest of the lemur family, and their communication cry is as plaintive as a whale's, though higher pitched.

At dusk I emerged from my rooms with a torch and the fetching fragrance of mosquito repellent, and went for a night nature walk in the company of an insightful guide Maurice Besoa Ratsiskanana. At first we spotted nothing apart from a boy and a girl out for a tryst in the rainforest. "Homo sapiens," whispered Maurice, like a droller David Attenborough. Then he spied twin red dots drilling through the night and trained his headlamp on them. These were the eyes of the nocturnal mouse lemur, which is as small as a thumb, though infinitely more cute. A green chameleon stuck itself to the underside of a leaf, but Maurice brought it to my attention. Gekkos, panther chameleons, frogs and the female common sunbird anisty perched on a eucalyptus tree kept me captivated. Under such a night sky, you could believe in a beneficent god. And, for a while, I did.

The following morning, I was up, if not with the lark, then with some early-rising Madagascar bird with a tricksy little trill. I was ready for a walk in the Mantadia rainforest, one of the few remaining primary forests on this island. As it rained, we climbed. When the rain stopped, I shook trees for a cooling shower - just what I needed after ascending the difficult paths to the heights of the forest floor.

"Have you ever seen a leech?" asked Maurice. He had one on his jeans. But it was as nothing compared to the one he spotted immediately afterwards on my hand, a big fat number that had spent the previous few minutes sucking down my coffee-and-croissant-charged blood. The little bugger!

At the top of the climb, near a graphite mine, we saw two black-and-white roughed lemurs, grooming each other. Another looked down on us intently from the treetops with orangey eyes. He had a black face with white sideburns and a receding white hairline. He looked like the bloke on the Uncle Ben's rice packets until he flung himself from tree to tree and then dangled upside down from a branch with one black hand. Uncle Ben can't do that.

A close encounter with a family of five indri-indri in the nearby reserve of Perinet provided further proof that lemurs are natural entertainers. Then, fully restored by a good night's sleep, Lalaina and I flew from the rainforest to the desert in the south west. We took a 4x4 up the coast to Lakana Vezo, a beach resort designed for the prosperous to go scuba diving around the Mozambique Channel's exceptional coral reefs.

Such is the vertical integration of Madagascar's tourist trade that, when you wander off the beach and into the village, you abruptly find yourself in a different world. Not a totally terrible one, but one in which happy naked kids play in the dust outside their mud huts to the extraordinary sounds of tsapiky, south Madagascar's barmily fast-paced music. The dearth of old people is disturbing: it's in places like this, rural, ill-educated and remote from the cosmopolitan capital, that healthcare is patchy and, consequently, life expectancy low.

My own life expectancy appeared to be very short when I ventured out for my first attempt at scuba diving. After strapping on all the necessaries, I pushed off underwater with the instructor holding my hand. I have never been so intimate with a Frenchman, nor do I propose to repeat the experience. He was Tinkerbell and I was Peter Pan as we flew through this submarine fairyland of coloured fish, lavender-tipped coral and shy shoals that disappear as soon as you so much as look at them.

On the other side of the reefs sharks hold sway, and it was hard not to swim here without fear. In any event, there were perils enough in these calm waters: the instructor pointed to some speckled stones, which I reached out to touch. He grabbed my hand and pushed me roughly away and we wound up struggling underwater, me thinking in my sudden panic that I was under attack. In fact, he had just saved my life - a well-camouflaged stone fish rose from the bed which, had I succeeded in touching it, would have poisoned me. It takes only seven minutes to kill a human being, and the only way it can be neutralised is by cauterising the poisoned flesh, an operation that is pretty tricky underwater.

My near-death appeared a distant memory as Lalaina and I sat over breakfast in the beachfront restaurant the following morning, under blissful bamboos trees and a scorching sun, three fishermen passing in front of us aboard their pirogue (a catermaran-like fishing boat) singing Muslim prayers. It was a lovely moment, and prompted me to ask Lalaina about Madagascar's religious make-up. According to him, 60% of Malagasy people are Christians, 30% animists and 10% Muslim.

But the reality behind these figures is more complex. Lalaina, for instance, is a Catholic, but he and his family still hold to some ancient Malagasy animistic beliefs. Last year, his family performed a ceremony during which they turned the bones of his grandmother. She died in 1972, but this was the third time they had dug her up and dressed her in new shrouds.

Such Malagasy customs express the belief that death is the most important part of life, and that dead ancestors exert a powerful influence over the living. A house is a temporary dwelling, but often lavish tombs are forever. As a result, in country areas particularly, people live in modest mud huts with bamboo branches for roofs, but when the head of the family dies, a lavish tomb will be built for him which will be surmounted by the skulls of his ritually slaughtered zebu. Zebu symbolise wealth in Madagascar, though this, I suspect, is of little consolation to the surviving members of the family who have to get by without their chief breadwinner and their exceptionally valuable livestock.

But then, animistic Malagasy culture, involving as it does a complex system of taboos called fady, a notion of destiny called vintana (that makes, for instance, Monday an ill-advised day on which to build a house), is so different from anything I have ever known before that it would be arrogant of a westerner to even attempt to make a judgment about it. Better to consider it just one more of the mysteries that make Madagascar a magical and emotive destination.

The practicals

Stuart Jeffries travelled courtesy of Rainbow Tours (tel: 020-7226 1004; fax: 020-7226 2621). A 12-night tour, including return flights from London to Antananarivo, accommodation and internal flights, costs from £1,925.

At present, there are no direct flights from Britain to Madagascar, so flights to Antananarivo go via Paris with Air Madagascar. Rainbow can organise visas on request; otherwise apply to the Malagasy embassy (020 8746 0133). They can be also be obtained on arrival at Antananarivo airport.

Where to eat and drink

Eating and drinking well, and for less than a tenner, is easy for the tourist in Madagascar. The combination of French colonisation, Indonesian settlers as well as wonderful fresh fruit, vegetables and seafood all makes for good meals.

As for drink, the Malagasy wine is vinegary, but the beers (especially Three Horses Beer) are excellent.

Villa Vanille (Antananarivo). An extraordinary place patronised by rich Malagasy and foreign diplomats. It is an old French colonial house staffed by deferential waiters and hostesses brimming with hauteur. Traditional Malagasy music most nights.

O! Poivre Vert (Antananarivo). This is a small place off the capital's main street, l'Avenue de l'Indépendance, which serves the best pizza I have ever eaten in the southern hemisphere (actually the only one, but it was good nonetheless). You can watch the chef cook them in the wood-fired oven, which is nice.

Au Grille du Rova (Antananarivo). I didn't manage to get a table here, but if you can, then go for it. The view (from one of Tana's 12 hills) across the city alone makes this terrace worth dining at, but apparently the food is also wonderful.

Chez Maggie (in the coastal town of Morondava). This is a lovely beach-front hotel run by a delightful Scotswoman called Maggie Macdonald. The restaurant, open to non-residents, serves wonderful seafood. I had fresh crab steamed in coriander and spices, followed by garlicky shrimps - all eaten in a beautiful room built from carved palissandre wood. Eat, drink and be merry while watching the sun set spectacularly below the Mozambique Channel.

webTitle: Ken Lukowiak: Insect repellent | Cigarette papers | A T-shirt

fields.headline: Ken Lukowiak never travels without...
fields.trailText: Insect repellent | Cigarette papers | A T-shirt
fields.body:
A necessity: Insect repellent. I have been badly bitten many times.

A luxury: Cigarette papers. It can be a real problem finding them, so I try to stock up.

A memento: I have a T-shirt which I had made for Jill Tweedie with a picture of the front cover of her book, Eating Children. When I went to Bosnia, I wore it every day.

If only: A device that allows you to speak a sentence in English and have it translated into the language of your choice. It would also have to have a way of conveying the emotion behind the words.

 Marijuana Time, by Ken Lukowiak, is published by Orion at £9.99.

fields.headline: Finders, keepers (II)
fields.trailText: Nothing practical would be gained. A beginner writer sometimes makes mistakes which he can remedy if they are pointed out, but a novelist of Vidia's quality and experience who produces an unconvincing character has suffered a lapse of imagination about which nothing can be done. It happened to Dickens whenever he attempted a good woman; it happened to George Eliot with Daniel Deronda.
fields.body:
Nothing practical would be gained. A beginner writer sometimes makes mistakes which he can remedy if they are pointed out, but a novelist of Vidia's quality and experience who produces an unconvincing character has suffered a lapse of imagination about which nothing can be done. It happened to Dickens whenever he attempted a good woman; it happened to George Eliot with Daniel Deronda.

So I told him. I began by saying how much I admired the many things in the book which I did admire, and then said that I had to tell him (had to tell him!) that two of his three cen-tral characters had failed to convince me. It was like saying Conrad's Lord Jim is a very fine novel except that Jim doesn't quite come off.

Vidia looked disconcerted, then stood up and said quietly that he was sorry they didn't work for me, because he had done the best he could with them, there was nothing more he could do, so there was no point in discussing it. As he left the room I think I muttered something about its being a splendid book all the same, after which I felt a mixture of relief at his appearing to be sorry rather than angry, and a slight (only slight!) sense of let-down and silliness. And I supposed that was that. André must have fought back because there was nothing he hated more than losing an author, but the battle didn't last long. Although I believe I was named, André was kind enough not to blame me. Nor did I blame myself. I went into a rage. I fulminated to myself, my colleagues, my friends: "All those years of friendship, and a mere dozen words of criticism - a mere dozen words! - send him flouncing out in a tantrum like some hysterical prima donna!" I had long and scathing conversations with him in my head; but more satisfying was a daydream of being at a huge and important party, seeing him enter the room, turning on my heel and walking out.

For at least two weeks I seethed... and then, in the third week, it suddenly occurred to me that never again would I have to listen to Vidia telling me how damaged he was, and it was as though the sun came out. I didn't have to like Vidia any more! I could still like his work, I could still be sorry for his pain; but I no longer faced the task of fashioning affection out of these elements in order to deal as a good editor should with the exhausting, and finally tedious, task of listening to his woe. "Do you know what," I said to André, "I've begun to see that it's a release."

fields.headline: Finders, keepers
fields.standfirst: Diana Athill has been one of the most revered editors in publishing. Her partnership with Andr Deutsch entailed working with the very best writers - glimpsing their inner selves. Now 89, in this exclusive extract from her memoir, she looks back on their great coups, from Mailer to Naipaul, and the ones that got away
fields.trailText: Diana Athill has been one of the most revered editors in publishing. Her partnership with Andr Deutsch entailed working with the very best writers - glimpsing their inner selves. Now 89, in this exclusive extract from her memoir, she looks back on their great coups, from Mailer to Naipaul, and the ones that got away
fields.body:
One day in 1944, my housemate and I were having a party, and our friend George brought André Deutsch. André, a Hungarian the same age as I was (26), had come to England to study economics, had been caught by the war, and had been interned as an enemy alien on the Isle of Man. The Hungarians were soon let out on condition that they reported regularly to the authorities, and André now worked for the publishers Nicolson and Watson. His being the first person I had ever met who was "in publishing" was enough to exalt him in my eyes.

He was small, trim and good-looking in a boyish way. I remember thinking that his mouth was as fresh and soft-looking as a child's, and being surprised that I found it attractive - usually I liked my men on the rugged side. He sat on the floor and sang The Foggy, Foggy Dew, which was unexpected in a Hungarian, and charming, so that I was more aware of him than of anyone else in the room. Two days later, when he asked me to dinner and a theatre, I was gratified. After the theatre, we ate an omelette and went to bed together, without - as I remember it - much excitement on either side.

In old age I can still remember the matchless intoxication of falling in love (which may well be a neurotic condition, but still nothing else lights up the whole of one's being in that way) and the more common but no less delicious sensations of a powerful physical attraction; but I have gone blurry about the kind of affair I had with André. I wonder what took me into such affairs, and what held me in them, almost always, until the man moved on. Rather than remembering, I have to work it out.

It was not thinking myself in love when I was not - I was too clear-sighted for that. And it was not simply the nesting instinct, because I was romantic enough (or perhaps realist enough?) to be sure that I couldn't marry a man I didn't love. To start with it was probably curiosity - a cat-like impulse to poke my nose round the next corner - combined with the emptiness of my emotional life at the time: this would at least seem to fill it. And once it had got going . . . well, perhaps the nesting instinct did start to come into it, after all. Although I knew from experience that whenever I genuinely fell in love it happened almost on sight, perhaps in this other kind of affair I allowed myself to slide into a vague hope that this time, given the chance, love might develop. And anyway I was pleased to be wanted; I liked the social and erotic occupations involved; I enjoyed being fond of someone; and I continued to be moved by curiosity. Quite early in my career the image of a glass-bottomed boat came to me as an apt one for sex; a love-making relationship with a man offered chances to peer at what went on under his surface.

It was soon apparent that André and I would not be lovers for long. I felt that I could have enjoyed making love with him if he had been more enthusiastic about making love with me, and given my essential coldness since the shock of losing the man I really wanted - the man I was engaged to, who was serving in the Middle East, had first gone silent on me, then married someone else, then been killed - he probably felt the same about me: less than adequate grounds for an affair. And he was an insomniac whose bed, though a double one, was not wide. When I wanted to sleep, he wanted to sit up and read the Times, and what he wanted to do he did, with much uninhibited rustling: it was his house, his bed - and insomnia commands respect while somnolence is boring. Englishwomen are notorious for somnolence, he told me tetchily. He often remarked on the shortcomings of the English as lovers, a habit shared by many continental men with a touching failure to see how easily it can provoke the bitten-back response, "Who are you to talk?" Rather than enjoying the dozen or so nights we spent together, we went through them "because they were there", and the only sadness I felt when he moved on to another bedfellow was the knee-jerk reaction, "There you are, you see - you're unable to keep anyone." Understanding that I owed this droopy feeling to the fiancé who had jilted me, I didn't hold it against André. It turned out that the slightness of our affair did not matter because - mystifyingly, given how unlike we are in temperament - we had ended it as friends.

We continued to meet, I became his confidante about his love-life, and he introduced me to his other friends. Before long, a feeling of being "family" grew up between André and me. It was this feeling which made it natural for us both to expect me to be involved in his plans when he decided that he would start a publishing house as soon as the war ended . . . not that my own expectations, to begin with, were anything but provisional. He had no money and no connections: how could he possibly start a publishing house? It was like someone saying, "When I win the football pools." But of course if he did win them, I would want to be in on it.

While André was with [the publishing firm] Nicolson and Watson, George Orwell submitted Animal Farm to them and John Roberts, the managing director, asked André to read it for him. André declared it wonderful, but Roberts, when he heard what it was about, said: "Nonsense, laddie - no one nowadays wants to make fun of Uncle Joe." André, who was determined to help the penniless and modest Orwell whom he saw as almost saint-like, decided that Jonathan Cape was the right publisher for him, and Orwell took his advice. Cape accepted the book, but shared Roberts's doubts to the extent of making a condition: it must be checked by some sort of official authority to make sure that it was not considered damaging to the war effort. And it was so considered: His Majesty's Government sincerely hoped that Mr Cape would refrain from publishing something so sharply critical of our Soviet Ally - and Mr Cape did refrain.

Orwell, who by this time was getting pretty desperate and who knew that André was planning to start his own firm as soon as he could raise a little capital, then said to André: "Look, why don't you do it? Why don't you start off your firm with it?' And André, strongly tempted to pounce but still far from sure that he would be able to start a firm however much he wanted to, felt that he must not let a man he liked and respected so deeply take such a risk. No, he said. And the essential resilience of his nature was later to be well illustrated by the fact that the more famous Animal Farm became, the prouder he was of his own early recognition of it and of his not letting Orwell take the risk of giving it to him, with never a moan at having lost this prize.

André started his first publishing house, Allan Wingate, late in 1945; I was his employee, an editor. The most important book in the history of Allan Wingate was Norman Mailer's first novel, The Naked And The Dead, which came to us from an agent desperate because six of London's leading publishers had rejected it in spite of its crossing the Atlantic on a wave of excitement (it was one of those books, always American at that time, which are mysteriously preceded by a certainty that they will cause a stir). Our list had gained substance and our sales organisation was seen to be good, but we were still too small to be any agent's first choice for a big book - or indeed even their seventh choice, had they not concluded that none of the more firmly established houses was going to make an offer.

The book was a war novel, all its characters soldiers going through hell in the Pacific, where Mailer himself had served. He was bent on conveying the nature of these soldiers and their experiences accurately, so naturally he wanted the men in his novel to speak like the men he had known, which meant using the words "fuck" and "fucking", and using them often. His American publishers had told him that although they knew it to be a great book, they could not publish it, and nor would anyone else (which appeared to be true) with those words spelt out. I believe the use of "f-" was suggested; but "fuck" and "fucking" occurred so often that this would have made the dialogue look like fish-net, so "fug" and "fugging" were agreed as substitutes.

It might be argued that the six English publishers who rejected the book because of the obscenity of its language were less ridiculous than the American publisher who accepted this solution. Given the premise from which they were all working, that "fuck" was unprintably obscene, how could another word which sounded so nearly the same, and which was loaded with the same meaning, not be equally obscene? There has never, I think, been a clearer demonstration of the idiocy of making words taboo.

We, of course, pounced. It is many years since I re-read the book and much of it is now hazy in my mind, but I still have a strong memory of a passage in which exhausted men are struggling to manhandle a gun out of deep mud, which makes me think that I was right in feeling that it was very good - a book which had genuinely expanded the range of my imagination. We wanted to restore the "fucks" but dared not; and as it turned out we were right not to dare.

Review copies went out to the press about three weeks before publication, and the literary editor of the Sunday Times left his lying about in his office. The newspaper's editor, who was an old man nearing retirement, ambled in and chanced to pick it up and open it. The first thing to meet his eye was "fug" . . . followed by "fug" and "fug" again. So that Sunday, on the paper's front page, there appeared a short but furious protest, written by the editor himself, against the projected publication of a book so vile that (and he truly did use these words) "no decent man could leave it where his women or children might happen to see it".

As always on a Sunday I was sleeping late, so I was cross when I had to answer the front-door bell at eight-thirty. There stood André, unshaven, a pair of trousers and a macintosh pulled on over his pyjamas, and a copy of the Sunday Times in his hand.

"Read this!"

"Oh my God!"

I was as alarmed as he was. The book was printed and bound - the first printing was large - it was a long book, expensive to manufacture . . . close to the wind as the firm was still having to sail, if this book was banned we would go down.

"Hurry and get some clothes on," said André. "We must rush a copy to Desmond McCarthy - I've got his address."

McCarthy was the most influential reviewer then writing. We scribbled a note begging him to read the book at once and to say publicly that it was not obscene, then we set off to push it through his letter-box. To insist on seeing him so early on a Sunday morning might, we felt, put him off. In retrospect, the chief value of our outing was that it was something to do in this nerve-racking situation: I don't think that McCarthy's eventual response can have been more than civil, or I would not have forgotten it.

Next morning orders started pouring into the office, and only then did it occur to us that if we were not heading for disaster, it might be a triumph. Meanwhile we were instantly served with an injunction against publishing The Naked And The Dead until the Attorney General, Sir Hartley Shawcross, had considered the case and had given us permission to do so (if he did). Whether the injunction was handed over by the large and apparently amiable police detective who spent the morning questioning us all, or whether it came separately, I do not know.

During the next two or three weeks the flood of orders nearly submerged us, the frustration of not being able to supply them became acute, and the encouragement we received from everyone we knew began to make triumph seem more likely than disaster. Finally André persuaded an MP of his acquaintance to ask a question in the House of Commons about the book's fate: was the Attorney General going to ban it or not? The answer was no - a rather grudging one in that Shawcross said that he thought it was a bad book, but still no. So we were off - into, ironically, quite worrying financial problems, because we were hard put to it to pay for the several reprints we had to order.

What we gained from this adventure was more than a good and best-selling novel; more, even, than the presence of Norman Mailer on our list from then on. Overnight we began to be seen as a brave and dashing little firm, worth serious attention from agents handling interesting new writers, and André's welcome when he visited New York became even more richly rewarding.

The poet Stevie Smith found life difficult; although she solved the problem cleverly and decisively by withdrawing from those parts of it that were too much for her and keeping to a well-defined territory of her own. She was amusing, and - strangely, given the cautious nature of her strategy - met one with a beguiling openness, so that I always started our meetings with the feeling that we were about to become close friends. We never did, and I think the reason was sexual. I was still young enough to be at heart more interested in my own sexual and romantic activities than in anything else (though mostly I kept them out of my office life), so Stevie's nervous asexuality distanced her. She almost fainted when she first came into my office, because I had on my wall a print of snakes. All the blood left her face and she could hardly make audible a plea that I should take the print down (after that I always removed it as soon as she was announced). Perhaps the notion that a phobia about snakes relates to their phallic quality is old-fashioned and misguided, but I supposed it to be true, and saw Stevie's phobia as revealing. I'm sorry to say that some part of me slightly despised the fear of sex I sensed in her; and I hope that she got her own back (this is far from unlikely) by slightly despising its opposite quality in me.

We were lucky enough to publish Philip Roth's first books and almost all of John Updike's. Roth, even more than Mailer, was a writer whose fame preceded his work: when his very gifted little first novel, Goodbye, Columbus, crossed the Atlantic it was all but invisible for the haze of desirability surrounding it, so that no one doubted for a moment that we had made a valuable catch. Then came Letting Go, which I thought wonderful, although I agreed with André that it was too long - not "by a third", as he said, but still too long. So we asked each other whether we should raise the matter with Philip and agreed that it would be too dangerous; there was such a buzz going on about him, everyone was after him - annoy him and he would be gone in a flash. And anyway it would be difficult to cut because it was all so good - there was not a dead line in it. Much of that novel is dialogue and I got the impression that Philip's brilliance with dialogue had gone to his head: he had enjoyed doing it so much that he couldn't bring himself to stop. So we accepted it as it was and it didn't earn its advance. (Imagine my feelings when he said to me, several years later: "The trouble with Letting Go is that it's far too long.") Then came a novel called When She Was Good, told from the point of view of a young woman from the Middle West, non-Jewish, who struck me as being pretty obviously Philip's first wife. I never talked to him about this book, so what I say here is no more than my hunch, but I thought, "This is an exercise - he is trying to prove to himself that he doesn't have to write as a Jew and a man." And as I read I kept telling myself, "It must soon come alive - it must." And it didn't.

So we thought, "No more silly money", and decided to calculate the advance on precisely what we reckoned the book would sell - which I think was 4,000 copies at the best - and that was not accepted. As far as I know, When She Was Good was not a success - but the next novel Philip wrote was Portnoy's Complaint.

This space represents a tactful silence.

John Updike , on the other hand, was never set up as a star and never disappointed. From a publisher's point of view he was a perfect author: an extremely good writer who knows his own worth but is also well-informed about the realities of publishing and bookselling. And he is an exceptionally agreeable man, interesting, amusing and unpretentious, who knows how to guard his privacy without being unfriendly. I like John very much, always enjoyed meeting him, and never felt inclined to speculate about whatever he chose to keep to himself, so I have nothing to say about him except the obvious fact that we would have been a much less distinguished publishing house without him.

No one who has read Jean Rhys's first four novels can suppose that she was good at life; but no one who never met her could know how very bad at it she was. I started corresponding with her in 1957; but I didn't meet her until 1964; and as a result I did almost nothing to help her during a long period of excruciating difficulty.

It was not, perhaps, her very worst time. That must have been the last three years of the 40s, when she and her third husband, Max Hamer, were living at Beckenham in Kent, their money had run out, and Max, a retired naval officer, became so desperate that he stumbled into trouble which ended in a three-year prison sentence for trying to obtain money by fraudulent means. During that nightmare Jean, paralysed by depression, could do nothing but drink herself into a state so bad that she, too, was several times in court and once in jail. By the time we were in touch Max had served his sentence, they had crept away to a series of miserable lodgings in Cornwall, and Jean was no longer quite at rock-bottom; but she still had nine terribly difficult years ahead of her before re-emerging as a writer.

She had always been a private person, but she was known in literary circles when her fourth novel, Good Morning, Midnight, came out in 1939. When the war began a lot of people "disappeared" in that they were carried away from their natural habitat on joining the forces or taking up war-work. Jean followed her second husband out of London, so when he died, and she slithered with Max into their misfortunes, she was no longer in touch with former acquaintances and became "lost". It was said that she had drowned herself in the Seine, or she had drunk herself to death.

It was the BBC which found her, when they were preparing to broadcast an adaptation of Good Morning, Midnight. They advertised for information about "the late Jean Rhys", and she answered. Learning of this, we wrote to her, and she replied, saying that she was working on a new book. Responding to our enthusiasm, André Deutsch - Andre's second publishing house, which he set up in 1952 with me as partner - agreed that we should buy the option to see it - for £25.

When people exclaim at how mean this was I no longer blush, simply because I have blushed so often. I tell myself that the pound bought much more in the 50s than it does now, which is true; that this was not, after all, an advance, only an advance on an advance, which is true; and that no one else in those days would have paid much more for an option, and that, too, is true. But it is inconceivable that anyone would have paid less - so mean it was. If we had known anything about Jean's circumstances I am sure that we would have fought for more, but it would be a long time before we gained any idea of them.

The trouble was, she kept up a gallant front. In the letters we exchanged between 1957, when she said that her book would be finished in "six or nine months", and March 1966, when she announced that it was finished, she would refer to being held up by domestic disasters such as leaking pipes, or mice in the kitchen, and she would make the disasters sound funny. Not until I met her did I understand that for Jean such incidents were appalling: they knocked her right out because her inability to cope with life's practicalities went beyond anything I ever saw in anyone generally taken to be sane. Max's health had given out, but her loyalty to him extended beyond keeping silent about his prison sentence to disguising his subsequent helplessness. It was years before I learnt how dreadful her 70s had been as she alternated between the struggle to nurse him and bleak loneliness when he was in hospital. She ate too little, drank too much, was frightened, exhausted and ill - and paranoid into the bargain, seeing their village of Cheriton Fitzpaine, as a cruel place.

For example: she told me that neighbours were saying that she was a witch, and she told it lightly, so that I thought she was making a funny story out of some small incident. But Mr Woodward, the rector, was to say that indeed she had been so accused, and that anyone who thought such beliefs were extinct didn't know Devon. Jean, driven frantic, had run out into the road and attacked the woman who originated the charge with a pair of scissors, which led to her being bundled for a week or so into a mental hospital. "And if you ask me," said Mr Greenslade, one of her few friends in the village, "it was the other one who ought to have been shut up, not poor Mrs Hamer [Rhys]." And not a word of all that appeared in her letters.

Good publishers are supposed to "discover" writers, and perhaps they do. To me, however, they just happened to come. Through friends and colleagues VS (Vidia) Naipaul came to a coffee bar near our office and handed me Miguel Street.

I was delighted by it, and we bought it. Vidia and I began to meet fairly often, and I enjoyed his company because he talked well about writing and people, and was often funny. At quite an early meeting he said gravely that when he was up at Oxford - which he had not liked - he once did a thing so terrible that he would never be able to tell anyone what it was. I said it was unforgivable to reveal that much without revealing more, especially to someone like me who didn't consider even murder literally unspeakable, but I couldn't shift him and never learnt what the horror was - though someone told me later that when he was at Oxford Vidia did have some kind of nervous breakdown.

I did not fail to see the obvious delicacy of his nervous system. Because of it I was often worried by his lack of money, and was appalled on his behalf when I once saw him risk losing a commission by defying the Times Literary Supplement. They had offered their usual fee of £25 (or was it guineas?) for a review, and he had replied haughtily that he wrote nothing for less than 50. "Oh silly Vidia," I thought, "now they'll never offer him anything again." But lo! they paid him his 50 and I was filled with admiration.

I cannot remember how long it was - certainly several months, perhaps even a year - before I learnt that Vidia was married. "I have found a new flat," he would say; "I saw such-and-such a film last week"; "My landlady says": not once had he used the words "we" or "our". I had taken it for granted that he lived in industrious loneliness, which had seemed sad. So when at a party I glimpsed him at the far end of a room with a young woman - an inconspicuously, even mousily pretty young woman - and soon afterwards saw him leaving with her, I was pleased that he had found a girlfriend. The next time he came to the office I asked who she was - and was astounded when he answered, in a rather cross voice, "My wife, of course."

After that Pat was allowed to creep out of the shadows, but only a little: and one day she said something that shocked me so much that I know for certain that I am remembering it word-for-word. I must have remarked on our not meeting earlier, and she replied: "Vidia doesn't like me to come to parties because I'm such a bore."

From that moment on, whenever I needed to cheer myself up by counting my blessings, I used to tell myself, "At least I'm not married to Vidia."

It did not exactly turn me against him, I suppose because from the beginning I had thought of him as an interesting person to watch rather than as a friend. The flow of interest between us had always been one-way - I can't remember ever telling him anything about my own affairs, or wanting to - so this odd business of his marriage was something extra to watch rather than something repellent. Had he ever loved her - or did he still love her in some twisted way? They had married while he was at Oxford: had he done it out of loneliness, to enlarge the minuscule territory he could call his own now that he was out in the world? Or was it because she could keep him? She was working as a teacher and continued to do so well into their marriage. Or was it to shelter him from other women? He had once asked a man of my acquaintance: "Do you know any fast women?", which my friend found funny but which seemed touching to me.

As did Vidia's only attempt to make a pass at me. Pat was away and I had asked him to supper. Without warning he got to his feet, came across the room and tried to kiss me as I was coming through the door carrying a tray loaded with glasses. It hardly seemed necessary to put into words the rebuff which most of him was clearly anxious for, but to be on the safe side I did. Our friendship, I said gently, was too valuable to complicate in any way - and his face brightened with relief. That someone so lacking in sexual experience and so puritanical should have to resort to prostitutes (as he told the New Yorker in 1994, and as a passage in The Mimic Men suggests) is natural; though I guess he did so infrequently, and with distaste.

In A Way In The World, writing (as usual) as though he were a single man, Vidia described himself as "incomplete" in "physical attractiveness, love, sexual fulfilment". How terrible for a wife to be publicly wiped out in this way! Everyone who knew the Naipauls said how sorry they were for Pat, and I was sorry for her, too. But whatever Vidia's reason for marrying, he cannot have foreseen what their marriage, for whatever reason, was going to be like. He, too, probably deserved commiseration.

When his Argentinian friend Margaret first came to London he brought her to lunch with me. She was a lively, elegant woman who, though English by descent, was "feminine" in the Latin-American style, sexy and teasing, with the appearance of having got him just where she wanted him. And he glowed with pride and pleasure. Afterwards he said he was thinking of leaving Pat, and when I was dismayed (could she exist without him?) said that the thought of giving up "carnal pleasure" just when he'd discovered it was too painful to bear. Why not stay married and have an affair, I asked; which he appeared to think an unseemly suggestion, although it was what he then did for many years. What happened later I don't know, but in the early years of their relationship there was no sign of his squashing Margaret. He did, however, make one disconcerting remark. Did I not find it interesting, he asked, that there was so much cruelty in sex?

In 1975 we received the 13th of his books - his eighth work of fiction - Guerrillas. For the first time I was slightly apprehensive because he had spoken to me about the experience of writing it in an unprecedented way: usually he kept the process private, but this time he said that it was extraordinary, something that had never happened before: it was as though the book had been given to him. Such a feeling about writing does not necessarily bode well. And as it turned out, I could not like the book.

The characters did not live; and the woman lived less than the man because that is true of all Vidia's women.

We have now reached the second of my two shocking failures as an editor (I don't intend ever to confess the other one). From the professional point of view there was no question as to what I ought to do: this was one of our most valuable authors; even if his book had been really bad rather than just flawed we would certainly have published it in the expectation that he would soon be back on form; so what I must say was "wonderful" and damn' well sound as though I meant it.

Instead I sat there muttering: "Oh my God, what am I going to say to him?" I had never lied to him - I kept reminding myself of that, disregarding the fact that I had never before needed to lie. "If I lie now, how will he be able to trust me in the future when I praise something?" The obvious answer to that was that if I lied convincingly he would never know that I had done it, but this did not occur to me. After what seemed to me like hours of sincere angst I ended by persuading myself that I "owed it to our friendship" to tell him what I truly thought.

André, a Hungarian the same age as I was (26), had come to England to study economics, had been caught by the war, and had been interned as an enemy alien on the Isle of Man. I remember thinking that his mouth was as fresh and soft-looking as a child's, and being surprised that I found it attractive - usually I liked my men on the rugged side.
