For a young American abroad for the first time, it was an exciting journey. Her pride in her Chinese dress (she was told that "it adds wonderfully to my dignity") and her pleasure at riding a donkey is evident. But, she hastened to add, "I am very happy in China not because of my surroundings but because I am working for Him who left much for me [to] do." Sarah did not take long to feel the hostility of many in Shanxi, who saw the foreign missionaries as bringers of ill fate. During a dry spell in August, "the people carried their rain god along the streets for a few days and nights making a great noise with gongs and drums. Several times in the night they stopped to pound on our street door calling out against the foreigners for keeping the rain away." She observed the life around her carefully, and wrote a detailed description of threshing techniques, methods of making rope and paper, and a street sawmill. Sarah never knew what reception she would receive on her "itinerations". Local inn-keepers might refuse her a room, in which case she would "ask the Lord to lead us to a resting place". Or there might be bugs in the bedding and opium smokers next door. "We can tell them at once," she noted, "by their deathly faces and black teeth". Within a few months, Sarah was musing on marriage - but only to reject it resolutely. "No, I am not 'looking for someone still'," she wrote home in December 1896. "I believe I am chosen to work without a helpmate. It seems to me a woman's work in China is so much hindered by marriage!" Nevertheless, quite soon she met John Young at the mission centre in Lu-an where she was based, and by mid-1898 they had an understanding. He returned to his lonely out-station at Jizhou, and quickly passed the successive grades in the Chinese language demanded by the CIM. In February 1899, he came back "to take me away". Sarah was going to be married in a Chinese dress of blue satin, its sleeves faced with pale pink silk. The mission rallied round with wedding presents, including an eiderdown quilt, a hanging lamp, eight towels, a tea cosy and two large framed texts. No one had any doubt that it was a marriage made in heaven. The send-off given to Anna Jakobsen when she married Cheng Hsiao-yu in the teeth of the CIM's opposition was very different. Who was this resolute young Norwegian who entered in to what may have been the first marriage in China between a western woman and a Chinese man? Anna had worked in Kristiansand, a town at the southern tip of Norway, for the family of a businessman called Rasmussen, who supported the CIM with donations. Two of his daughters later became missionaries, one of them surviving a long trek to Hankou on the Yangtze River to escape the Boxers in 1900. Anna the housemaid - then in her early 20s - volunteered early on, and together with the family governess, Sophie Reuter, joined the CIM in 1884. They became "pioneers in skirts", Norway's first missionaries abroad. Anna and Sophie were sent to the remote station of Hezhou in southern Shanxi - across the hills from Jizhou, where the Youngs would be working 10 years later. They were praised for their "lives of singular Christ-likeness and devotion". Sophie soon married Stanley Smith, a muscular Christian from Cambridge (he had captained the university boat) who was close to Hudson Taylor. Anna must surely have received at least one proposal from fellow missionaries. Marriage was regarded as a stabilising influence within the mission and a solution to the loneliness of the single male. When Sophie died of typhoid in 1891, Stanley Smith remarried within two years. But Anna laboured on alone for seven years, until 1893, when she announced that she was engaged to a fellow evangelist: Cheng Hsiao-yu. Anna did not mention the word love, but chose a more subtle argument. She was determined to work in Hunan, where no foreign mission had yet penetrated. Anna believed, she said, that marriage to a Chinese would make her more acceptable in this "hostile province". On this first occasion, the male hierarchy of the CIM prevailed on Anna to think again. In the words of its standard history, she "had not considered the repercussions upon other single girls in the Mission". Until now, no Chinese male had looked on western women missionaries as eligible for marriage. The precedent they were setting "would expose all the single girls to unwelcome attention by unsuitable men, if not to danger". (In fact, far from making unmarried women missionaries more vulnerable in China, Anna's marriage to a Chinese man may even have helped to diminish popular prejudice. If the women travelled in the company of their male colleagues, they were assumed to be concubines. If they travelled on their own, they would be accused of being prostitutes.) Five years later, in the summer of 1898, Anna declared her intention of marrying Cheng again, and this time she would not be budged. Agitated correspondence from Shanxi to CIM headquarters in Stoke Newington, north London, reveals the reaction of most of Anna's colleagues. "The almost universal feeling of consternation the news produced," wrote missionary A Hoddle to Hudson Taylor, "was succeeded by a perfect storm of protest." A few colleagues rallied to Anna and Cheng's defence. Dr EH Edwards, an experienced medical missionary, and his wife had supported the couple from the start. A sympathetic American Baptist, DH Clapp, agreed to marry them in the house of a Chinese Christian photographer in Taiyuan. On the morning of the wedding, two opponents of the marriage from Anna's mission headquarters outside the city leapt on horseback and rode in at top speed "to expostulate with the Edwards' and Mr Clapp". They cast around for one argument after another: if the couple had children, these might suffer an "awful consequence", especially if they were girls (by having their feet bound, or worse); Anna herself would be mistreated by her husband's family; the union might not be recognised by the Norwegian consular authorities; if they were to be married, why not do it outside Taiyuan - in a country inn, for example? Anna and Cheng's supporters stood firm. Edwards told the objectors that it would be "a sin against God" to try to stop the marriage. Clapp said that he saw no scriptural reason for declining to wed them. Seven missionaries and their families attended the service - their names were promptly reported to CIM headquarters. One of those who attended wrote an abject letter explaining that he had gone merely "so as not to ostracise Miss Jakobsen". At the wedding feast, Cheng let his new wife sit at the top table while he "remained outside in the yard in conversation with the natives". He could not eat his fill, he explained, in the presence of foreigners. This effort to avoid upsetting the foreign guests by his presence was turned against him in the mission's report home. The event was supposed to be a Christian marriage, Anna's critics argued, in which "the woman takes the place of submission to her husband", but Cheng's self-effacing behaviour showed that "here [the relationship] was reversed". The five years between Anna's first declaration and her marriage leave no doubt that she and Cheng were seriously in love. Yet she can also be seen as a forerunner of 20th-century missionary thinking in her commitment to working through the Chinese - a move that roused real fears she might pave the way for an indigenous church. "There was a great danger", wrote Hudson Taylor, "of her heading a party of [Chinese] and together breaking away from the Mission." Anna was certainly a more complex character than most of her colleagues in the CIM. We only know the bare outline of her subsequent life. Anna and Cheng carried out her original plan to preach the gospel in the "hostile province" of Hunan, settling in the town of Xiangtan. They were safer there - but only just. In July 1900, Anna wrote to her former employer in Kristiansand describing a dramatic flight to safety with her one-year-old daughter. At one point, she wrote, "a hundred men were coming, not far from our house, to kill us". Anna continued to work in the southern provinces, supported by funds from mission societies in Norway. She died in 1911 and was survived by her daughter, Mary. Mary was taken to Scotland by the old family friend, Dr Edwards, and educated there. She later married a missionary doctor surnamed Wright and served with him in the Sudan. Mary Wright, the offspring of a remarkable marriage, ended her years in Swindon. The tale of the missionary ordeal in 1900 has received little attention in more recent times - perhaps because it raises some awkward questions for both sides. At the time, it was recorded in a number of what would now be called instant books, mostly by survivors and written from the missionaries' point of view. The most popular (14 editions in 20 years) was A Thousand Miles Of Miracle In China, by the CIM's Archibald Glover; he describes a long trek south to safety with his family and colleagues, during which they endured frequent episodes of robbery, imprisonment and mob violence. His pregnant wife survived the journey, only to die within weeks together with her newly born child. Dr Edwards - the champion two years earlier of Anna's marriage - was away "on furlough" at the time of the massacre. He returned with the official allied mission, acting as interpreter for a while to the German forces, and gathered material for Fire And Sword In Shansi: The Story Of The Martyrdom Of Foreigners And Chinese Christians. When western interest in China's modern history revived in the 1960s and 70s, a more critical view prevailed. The missionaries were seen as tarnished by association with the imperialism of the late 19th century. It seemed covertly racist to dwell on the treatment handed out by Chinese peasants to these western interlopers. At best, the missionaries had strayed into dangerous territory; at worst, they were part of the forces of oppression. Chinese scholarship has had different problems with how to handle the Boxers over the years. Though anti-foreign, they were pro-imperial dynasty, except at the outset, and had no explicit revolutionary aims. And while their courageous but futile battles against western troops could be hailed, it was difficult to dwell on their acts of violence against peaceful missionary families. The solution, even in recent mainland histories, is to skate very quickly over the missionary killings, which are referred to as jiaoan, or "religious cases". Wherever possible, the missionaries are portrayed as presenting a threat or provoking the masses' rage. The Taiyuan-based missionary, Edith Coombs - one of the seven who attended Anna's wedding - died on June 27, 1900, outside the Shouyang Mission. Witnesses, Chinese Christians, said that she had been separated from the main party of those fleeing the mission compound (who themselves were slaughtered days later by Governor Yu Hsien) while she was attempting to protect two Chinese girl converts. By their account, the mission was set on fire by Boxers and their sympathisers, and Edith Coombs was beaten badly and thrown to her death in the flames. A very different version is given in History Of The Boxers' Resistance To The Great Powers' Division Of China, by Lau Anshi, published in 1997. Ms Coombs is accused of provoking the "religious case" by brandishing a pistol and claiming that her bag had been snatched. No mention is made of the compound being burnt down. The same book argues that the missionaries killed in the governor's courtyard were plotting against the government. How did the missionaries themselves view their ordeal? While admitting their fears and foreboding, they viewed everything that happened to them, down to the last detail, as God's will. On the Glovers' long journey south, the occasional acts of charity with which they met were attributed to "the merciful kindness of Him Who had never left us". If God refused to ease their plight by ending the drought, he must have a reason for it. As Dr Clapp argued before his own death, all that happened was "for the glory of God in the end, though, we can't see how now". For the missionaries, as well as for the Boxers, historian Paul Cohen has written, everything was "in the control of Heaven". In many ways, the missionary experience reflected the wider contradictions of the west in China. Here was a group of foreigners prepared to suffer great hardship to bring spiritual light and medical help to the "heathen Chinese". Every diary that survives tells stories of odysseys by mule cart, endless nights in flea-bitten inns, abuse and stoning by angry crowds, all endured with prayers and, whenever possible, "a cup of cocoa". The missionaries took in orphans, sheltered battered wives and helped opium smokers to shake off their addiction. Although the Bible was accused of following the gunboats (and the opium trade), most missionaries kept their distance from the treaty powers. The survivors of the earlier Gutian massacre in Fujian (August 1895) urged forgiveness when they reached Hong Kong. Some foreign protestors accused the missionaries of being too ready to turn the other cheek - although others were irritated by their foolhardy ventures, which jeopardised foreign business. The missionaries were derided for harvesting an absurdly small number of souls - many described as "rice Christians", who consented to conversion in return for material handouts. Yet hundreds of these "native converts" refused to recant to save their lives when offered the chance by the Boxers. There was bigotry on both sides. The Chinese scholar class resented the challenge to their doctrinal authority as custodians of Confucian tradition, and published lurid pamphlets attacking the missionaries. And the missions regarded the Chinese masses as children led astray by the devil. "The officials are demented," wrote Hudson Taylor's colleague Griffith John, "and the people are sheep without a shepherd." Taylor himself talked of converting the Chinese as if he were conducting a military campaign. "Satan [Chinese opposition to Christianity] is simply raging," he wrote, "and the conflict is awful." All the Protestant missions were hostile to the Roman Catholics - whose own losses in the Boxer Rebellion were not included in the lists of victims published by the CIM. And some missionaries became obsessed, cut off at their stations. Dr W L Pruen was convinced that the Chinese people were descended from Japheth, the third son of Noah who was "buried 100 miles dues south of Shanghai". In a sense, the missionaries' commitment was flawed because ultimately they had the backing of foreign military power. Sometimes, they took advantage of the "unequal treaties" imposed by the west. For their part, western powers exploited "outrages" against missionaries to grab territorial concessions, thus fuelling the Boxers' anti-foreign appeal. The entire course of modern China was changed by the murder of the two German missionaries in Shandong in 1897, which gave the Kaiser his chance to brandish an "iron fist". He seized control of the province, thus providing fertile ground for the Boxers, who began their doomed uprising within the next year. The humiliating terms imposed on China by the Boxer Protocol in 1901 gave a new boost to Chinese nationalism, paving the way for the collapse of Manchu imperial rule 10 years later. Missionary activity became more enlightened in the early decades of the 20th century, and advocates of a "social gospel", stressing education and health, prevailed. Chinese Christians (no longer labelled as native) lobbied for independence, laying the foundation for an indigenous church, which survived the Communist Revolution. Chinese law now prohibits foreign missionary activities, but some overseas groups defy the law by sending preachers masquerading as tourists. Others send young missionaries in the role of English-language teachers, taking advantage of local authorities that are willing to employ them at cheap rates without too many questions asked. It is not unusual to meet young westerners - usually from the US - in some remote area. If you ask why they are there, they may say they are interested in "ethnic questions" and, if prodded, admit a "personal connection" to a (usually fundamentalist) Christian sect. CIM missionaries worked in China right up until after the 1949 Communist revolution. Since then, under the name of Overseas Missionary Fellowship (OMF) - and, until 1991, under the leadership of Hudson Taylor's great-grandson, Dr James Hudson Taylor III - it has expanded its work in other parts of Asia: the original CIM monthly publication, China's Millions, was relaunched as Asia's Billions. The Chinese church (Catholic as well as Protestant) has now revived, with tens of millions of adherents both in the officially recognised churches and in illegal "house churches" in the rural areas. Congregations of 5,000-6,000 are common, with the faithful sitting shoulder to shoulder on the ground outside churches too small to accommodate all the faithful. Sarah Young and Anna Jakobsen would hail it as a miracle

fields.headline: A Mouthful of Glass
fields.trailText: An extract from Henk van Woerden's A Mouthful of Glass (Granta, £12.99)
fields.body:
A few minutes after 3pm on September 6 1966, Demitrios Tsafendas, a messenger in South Africa's parliament, walked up to the country's prime minister, Hendrik Vervoerd, in the chamber of the House in full public view and stabbed him four times. Tsafendas was overpowered, disarmed and dragged away. Verwoerd died within the hour. He was one of the architects of apartheid and Tsafendas one of its victims. Born in Mozambique, his father was Greek, his mother a black African. His father disowned his mother and married a Greek woman and they moved to South Africa, where Demitrios was accepted as white. But he soon discovered that he did not fit in anywhere. He became exiled from family, community, heritage, country - and sanity, which undoubtedly saved him from execution after the Verwoerd assassination. Many times and in many countries he was treated for psychiatric disorders. He believed he was possessed by a huge tape-worm that caused the mental torment he suffered throughout his life. After the murder Tsafendas was kept in prison for three decades, at times treated brutally. He was then sent to a psychiatric hospital in Krugersdorp, where he died last year. Henk van Woerden , a Dutch artist brought up in South Africa during the Verwoerd years, has written an account of Tsafendas's life. At the end, he went to visit the old man, expecting to find "an extinguished human being - infantile, deaf, manifestly crazy".

This is what he discovered.

What a fine head of snow-white hair! Demitrios's head was tilted to one side. He glanced at me, as if from an angle; his eye was placatory; his air perplexed. It was midday. Perhaps he had just eaten, and was ready for a nap.

I shouted at him, in English: "Pleased to meet you."

He was wearing a light-blue T-shirt with L-O-N-D-O-N printed across it. He was dressed below in a pair of jogging trousers, bright green in colour, with white stripes running down the sides of the legs. His stomach showed through the gap between his shirt and trousers. His feet were thrust into narrow, ill-fitting, down-at-heel slippers.

His pronunciation of English struck me as odd; I had not imagined that it would sound like this. The intonation was old-fashioned; he had an archaically middle-class accent that took me back to my childhood. I might almost have been listening - had I closed my eyes - to one of the adults I used to hear in those days. Or to a good-natured fatty from one of the British children's books I used to read.

Matron Geyer put her head around the corner. Was everything all right? Yes, fine. Demitrios and I sat and smiled at one another, the old man still holding forth, I responding with nods.

"We Greeks were rivals against the Orientals. Very strong rivals. They brought me up very strict against the Orientals, the Arabs especially . . . I was taken out of the French mission school. I was learning the black language there, Shangaan. It was a big mistake. They should have left me but they sent me to a Catholic Portuguese school. And from there they took me out again and sent me to school in Middelburg, in the Transvaal. I had difficulty because of Afrikaans in one class and English in the other. I didn't know Afrikaans. But I kept on, I persisted, I had no choice because my parents were so strict."

He told the story with evident satisfaction. If he had been some what subdued initially, he was now animated, alert, carried away by his own words. He spoke about his childhood days in Alexandria and the house of his grandmother Tsafandakis. He had long had in his possession a photograph of himself as a little boy, in Arab garb.

"I kept it. I put it in an envelope when I was in Pretoria Central prison. Potgieter, he destroyed it. It disappeared there. I used to keep it, but Potgieter the chief warder destroyed it, also my birth certificate. I had all that. I knew it was historic. But Potgieter was against me, he tore everything up. It would make history, but that stupid Potgieter..."

He trailed off, agitatedly, weeping. Over the following days he repeatedly complained about that incident.

"Potgieter was furious against anything that belonged to me. But his helper was very good to me. I'd like to see him. He sympathised with me and protected me whenever possible, when I was beaten on the skull. Blood used to come in! He was also an Afrikaner, but different.... Completely different, very good-natured," he repeated. A little later, clearly referring still to the prison in Pretoria, he said: "I'd like to go back there, where I used to live in that building. It's been transformed into a holy place now. A hoooly place. You must find out. You must inquire."

At one point he began to sing to me English songs from 50 and more years ago - for old times' sake, he said, the spittle flying out of the corner of his mouth as he said the phrase. By now he had become positively elated. Among the songs was A Bicycle Made for Two ("Daisy, Daisy"). Drawing long breaths, he also burst into a hymn I remembered from my schooldays: "Onward Christian Soldiers/Marching as to war? With the cross of Jesus/Going on before..."

Weeks later the smell of that visit was still with me. It was the smell of old, unwashed men. The rotten sweetness of uncared-for teeth and unwashed armpits, mixed with the odours of half-digested food rising from the bow els and through the pores of the skin. Demitrios was a neglected creature. That was the truth. Matron Geyer was not to be blamed. There was nothing that she could do about it. The hospital was hopelessly understaffed.

Just before I left, he asked: "Are you an enthusiast of flying?"

The question was wonderfully dated. It belonged, I thought, to an era of golfing caps and plus fours on English greens.

The meeting had left me feeling dizzy. I had come assuming that I would meet an extinguished human being. Someone whose illness could only have been exacerbated by three decades of imprisonment and maltreatment. A witness had described after the attack, almost without exception, in wholly unsympathetic terms: a pig, a liar, a nutcase. And, surely I would find him infantile, deaf, manifestly crazy.

What I had found, instead, was a charming chatterbox. A survivor from the detritus of South African history. Why was he still confined in the wretched institution in which I had found him? Between 1942 and 1963 alone - his period abroad - he had been arrested five times, deported five times, twice incarcertated for long periods, and eight times refused entry into South Africa. During the 50s and 60s he had regarded himself as a kind of pilgrim, that much was clear. A man with a mission, even if he could never have said exactly where his Mecca lay. Now that everything was long behind him, he remained one of the few among the huge band of exiles who had never been able to come home again, either literally or metaphorically.

Sitting next to an old man comprehensively saying his piece, I had felt myself to be endowed with an unwanted perspicacity. No doubt his stories sounded like concoctions to those who knew little or nothing of his background. For him, all he had ever been, all he could ever speak of, was secluded within a domain of glass, isolated, viewable only as if through a lens scored by sharp cracks and flaws. I asked myself if I knew of a better way of trying to apprehend the history of his country.

After lunch his thoughts veered off on another tack. "I wanted to have strong children. So I restrained myself from women. I kept myself chaste. No smoking, nothing. Working all the time. No whisky drinking. Milk shakes I drink, Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola. In Egypt we have a special drink from sugarcane, I don't remember what they call it. And pineapples. Water melon. Sweetmelon."

He fell silent.

I wrote on the pad: "Was there a woman in your life?" He read the question slowly, as if spelling it out letter by letter. It did not seem to dismay him. On the contrary, he set about answering it like a conscientious autobiographer, from the very beginning.

"The first woman in my life, I was young, I was underage. She was Portuguese and I used to go with her. She said to me: "What do you like? Do you want to copulate or do you want me to suck you off?" I said to her: "I want to copulate. I want to push." I was very small..." He laughed, relieved and amused at the memory.

"I had a girlfriend in Turkey. She was very intelligent. She got me the job in the college as a professor of English. She spoke to the authorities. And in Athens, one of the Greek girls in my church loved me. But she died. A great love. And in Pretoria I went to the social workers' meetings and there was a Dutch girl there, very beautiful. But the preacher of the Gospel, he kept her away from me, he wanted her for himself... In America, too, there was a beautiful girl, an American, and in Germany one of the workers I like... But I could not compete.

"My biological mother used to call me "Mimis." She liked me, but I was in love with her sister, Annie. Can you remember Marlene Dietrich?"

I nodded.

"Aha!" he laughed. He began to sing: "Falling in love again, what am I to do? Falling in looove again.

"My father was very strict. He always watched you, in case . . ." He made masturbatory gestures with his hand. "He was an engineer. He sacrificed his life to a perpetual motion machine. And I continued in his footsteps. My brother was also a lathe-turner. But my biological mother, she spoiled my brother. In the morning she gives him eggs, fried eggs, scrambled eggs. He, not me. He was born with one leg first, out of my stepmother. Not with the head. She was screaming all night. It was a breech birth. That's why she is like that."

His chin sank towards his chest and he stuck out his lower lip, as if sulking. Then he lifted his head, recalling something important.

"She made a big mistake in Lourenço Marques when a Portuguese chemist discovered that I had a tapeworm. He gave me some medicine, an extract, a powerful poison. He said: 'You must bring the species' head. I must study it.' I drink the extract and the following day it started coming out. I went to the toilet and half of it was out, two or three metres. But the chemist had said: 'You must not throw it away. You must bring it to me. I want to study it.' My stepmother said: 'It's out, out.' She put it in the toilet." He mimed the pulling of a toilet chain.

"A big mistake! A very big mistake! Two or three metres....I think it's still alive in the sewers, because it doesn't die, it's very strong. And the Portuguese chemist was very angry. He said: 'Why do you throw it away?' But the sewer is still there. I want to study the sewer underneath the old house. I want to go back to the sewer."

He gazed at me with amber-coloured eyes. "You must help me." And later, wistfully, after I had taken a photo of him, "I want you to photograph me in front of my house, in front of my property. I want you to help me.

It was difficult to imagine how deeply within himself a man like Demitrios would have felt the dilemma of the "baster" - the bastard, the half-blood. How it must have maimed his sense of self-worth, and the hopelessness he had known as a result. Non-whites were generally regarded by the whites as dirty, animal-like, untrustworthy; but the half-breed was the worst, precisely because he was so close to themselves.

Throughout his life, Demitrios had claimed that somehwhere in southern Africa there was a woman waiting for him, the love of his youth. Even as a figment of his imagination, however, this ideal figure threatened to produce for him dark-skinned progeny, who would bring to light the concealed, hereditary stigma of his bad blood. He could cross the line, go over, "play white", though always carrying within him the self-estrangement of his dark conscience.

Or, once his wanderings over Europe had miserably ended, he could take on the role of the shamed and vengeful Coloured. He would destroy the loud-voiced chief of the white tribe. With or without the help of the tapeworm inside him, he cut off the creature's head.

His deed was the direct consequence of sublunary traumas. The tribal sentiments of the Afrikaner were derived in large measure from some of the sentiments that Tsafendas had harboured within himself: a longing to feel truly at home, a search for acknowledgement, a conviction that he had spent too long a time wandering the wilderness. The Afrikaner was ready to maintain his homeland through violence, the violence of the state if need be. His preoccupation with racial purity and unsoiled blood was central to that aim. Which of the two, then, was more truly crazy: Verwoerd or Tsafendas?

It was hardly possible to exaggerate the importance of what Demitrios had done, I reflected. The attack on Verwoerd was a proclamation of the end of the doctrine of apartheid, of the idiotic dread of "racial mixing". It presaged the hesitant beginning of integration. Of a mixed-up living together - the very idea that had horrified so many generations of white South Africans. Of the birth of the "rainbow nation" which, in a bout of over-excitement and child-like honesty, Demitrios had called for in 1964.

I had never been able to find any words for the feelings which had overwhelmed me on the afternoon of the attack in September 1966. Retrospectively, it now seemed that the power of madness had at that moment shown itself to be equal to the madness of power. The murder was a melancholy manifestation of being, as if nature itself were finally striking the balance between them.

On Friday, March 27, I paid my last visit to Demitrios. I took with me a small Greek stringed instrument, a baglamá , in the hope of diverting him. I showed him the baglamá and strummed a little tune on it.

"Very interesting instrument," Demitrios said. "Small in size. Delicate sound. I would have liked to have been able to play it myself. Or the piano accordion. The organ. Before that I was interested in the bugle. That was in Middelburg."

Then, in a whisper, "Play some more."

The baglamá has a piercing but attractive sound; I was glad that he was able to hear it.

"Do you play the violin, too? The saxophone? That's what I'd really like to do."

The next question came out of the blue. He asked me who was the president of South Africa now.

On my little pad I wrote the name "Mandela" and showed it to him.

"Nelson Mandela...? I would like to speak to him. He's a very strong man."

When I made a few movements with my fists, like a boxer, Demitrios laughed out loud. From the hall behind us a harsh screaming suddenly broke out. If a stone could scream, it would make a noise like that. Then came the sounds of crashing crockery and another loud voice trying to restore order.

Demitrios had fallen silent. If I were ever to ask the question, this had to be the moment. "Do you remember Verwoerd?" I scrawled on my pad with sudden awkward fingers, and handed it to him.

"I didn't know Hendrik Verwoerd personally." Demitrios sighed. He thought for a moment. "I had never spoken to him before..."

The racket in the hall broke out briefly once more. Demitrios moved uneasily in his wheelchair.

"I do regret....." he stammered. "I do regret.....," he said again and yet again, for the third time. "I regret..." He took the paper and pencil out of my hand.

When he returned the pad to me I saw that he had written four words in untidy block letters.

I REGRET WHAT HAPPENED.

He began to cry. I took both his shoulders in my hands and shouted as loudly as I could: "Never mind. Other times. Not your fault."

"A whole other time," he sobbed. "I am not that kind of person. It was something that happened. It was not in my nature. Besides, I was sick."

His striped dressing gown had fallen from his chest. Poor Mimis. In what followed, he placed the blame on the doctors. It was their fault. They should have operated on him. Why hadn't they done it? He pointed to his stomach. Why hadn't they removed the creature in there? Either they could not or they would not do it.

"It will not die. I'm helpless against this Dragon-Tapeworm. I cannot do anything. But they won't investigate. Too difficult and very complicated. At night when I sleep I see orgies. All imagination. Visions."

Then he told me that, while he'd been working in parliament, he had heard from a woman member of the house that Verwoerd was not an upright human being. It was one of the things, he wanted me to know, that had set him thinking of what had to be done. "She came to me - I found out later she was a member of the United Party - and she said: 'Hendrik Verwoerd is a very immoral person.' You see? When she told me that I went down . . . and that's how it started. She stirred me. She made me angry."

Again, he began to weep; then made an effort to compose himself. "I went down to the shopping centre on the Herengracht and I bought a knife. I went inside and I said: 'Give me a knife.' The woman gave me a little knife. I said: 'It's too small. Give me a bigger knife.'

When he had fallen silent I wrote a few more words on the pad.

"Like a real Cretan," Demitrios read slowly. "Yeah," he said calmly. "Nature, hereditary nature.

"It's nature," he said again, with an air of finality. "Human nature."

In it he is said to have stipulated that his body should undergo an autopsy, so that his "worm" might be exposed to the eyes of science at last. I have been unable to find out whether or not his wishes in this matter were heeded.

fields.bodyText: A few minutes after 3pm on September 6 1966, Demitrios Tsafendas, a messenger in South Africa's parliament, walked up to the country's prime minister, Hendrik Vervoerd, in the chamber of the House in full public view and stabbed him four times. Tsafendas was overpowered, disarmed and dragged away. Verwoerd died within the hour. He was one of the architects of apartheid and Tsafendas one of its victims. Born in Mozambique, his father was Greek, his mother a black African. His father disowned his mother and married a Greek woman and they moved to South Africa, where Demitrios was accepted as white. But he soon discovered that he did not fit in anywhere. He became exiled from family, community, heritage, country - and sanity, which undoubtedly saved him from execution after the Verwoerd assassination. Many times and in many countries he was treated for psychiatric disorders. He believed he was possessed by a huge tape-worm that caused the mental torment he suffered throughout his life. After the murder Tsafendas was kept in prison for three decades, at times treated brutally. He was then sent to a psychiatric hospital in Krugersdorp, where he died last year. Henk van Woerden , a Dutch artist brought up in South Africa during the Verwoerd years, has written an account of Tsafendas's life. At the end, he went to visit the old man, expecting to find "an extinguished human being - infantile, deaf, manifestly crazy". This is what he discovered. What a fine head of snow-white hair! Demitrios's head was tilted to one side. He glanced at me, as if from an angle; his eye was placatory; his air perplexed. It was midday. Perhaps he had just eaten, and was ready for a nap. I shouted at him, in English: "Pleased to meet you." He was wearing a light-blue T-shirt with L-O-N-D-O-N printed across it. He was dressed below in a pair of jogging trousers, bright green in colour, with white stripes running down the sides of the legs. His stomach showed through the gap between his shirt and trousers. His feet were thrust into narrow, ill-fitting, down-at-heel slippers. His pronunciation of English struck me as odd; I had not imagined that it would sound like this. The intonation was old-fashioned; he had an archaically middle-class accent that took me back to my childhood. I might almost have been listening - had I closed my eyes - to one of the adults I used to hear in those days. Or to a good-natured fatty from one of the British children's books I used to read. Matron Geyer put her head around the corner. Was everything all right? Yes, fine. Demitrios and I sat and smiled at one another, the old man still holding forth, I responding with nods. "We Greeks were rivals against the Orientals. Very strong rivals. They brought me up very strict against the Orientals, the Arabs especially . . . I was taken out of the French mission school. I was learning the black language there, Shangaan. It was a big mistake. They should have left me but they sent me to a Catholic Portuguese school. And from there they took me out again and sent me to school in Middelburg, in the Transvaal. I had difficulty because of Afrikaans in one class and English in the other. I didn't know Afrikaans. But I kept on, I persisted, I had no choice because my parents were so strict." He told the story with evident satisfaction. If he had been some what subdued initially, he was now animated, alert, carried away by his own words. He spoke about his childhood days in Alexandria and the house of his grandmother Tsafandakis. He had long had in his possession a photograph of himself as a little boy, in Arab garb. "I kept it. I put it in an envelope when I was in Pretoria Central prison. Potgieter, he destroyed it. It disappeared there. I used to keep it, but Potgieter the chief warder destroyed it, also my birth certificate. I had all that. I knew it was historic. But Potgieter was against me, he tore everything up. It would make history, but that stupid Potgieter..." He trailed off, agitatedly, weeping. Over the following days he repeatedly complained about that incident. "Potgieter was furious against anything that belonged to me. But his helper was very good to me. I'd like to see him. He sympathised with me and protected me whenever possible, when I was beaten on the skull. Blood used to come in! He was also an Afrikaner, but different.... Completely different, very good-natured," he repeated. A little later, clearly referring still to the prison in Pretoria, he said: "I'd like to go back there, where I used to live in that building. It's been transformed into a holy place now. A hoooly place. You must find out. You must inquire." At one point he began to sing to me English songs from 50 and more years ago - for old times' sake, he said, the spittle flying out of the corner of his mouth as he said the phrase. By now he had become positively elated. Among the songs was A Bicycle Made for Two ("Daisy, Daisy"). Drawing long breaths, he also burst into a hymn I remembered from my schooldays: "Onward Christian Soldiers/Marching as to war? With the cross of Jesus/Going on before..." Weeks later the smell of that visit was still with me. It was the smell of old, unwashed men. The rotten sweetness of uncared-for teeth and unwashed armpits, mixed with the odours of half-digested food rising from the bow els and through the pores of the skin. Demitrios was a neglected creature. That was the truth. Matron Geyer was not to be blamed. There was nothing that she could do about it. The hospital was hopelessly understaffed. Just before I left, he asked: "Are you an enthusiast of flying?" The question was wonderfully dated. It belonged, I thought, to an era of golfing caps and plus fours on English greens. The meeting had left me feeling dizzy. I had come assuming that I would meet an extinguished human being. Someone whose illness could only have been exacerbated by three decades of imprisonment and maltreatment. A witness had described after the attack, almost without exception, in wholly unsympathetic terms: a pig, a liar, a nutcase. And, surely I would find him infantile, deaf, manifestly crazy. What I had found, instead, was a charming chatterbox. A survivor from the detritus of South African history. Why was he still confined in the wretched institution in which I had found him? Between 1942 and 1963 alone - his period abroad - he had been arrested five times, deported five times, twice incarcertated for long periods, and eight times refused entry into South Africa. During the 50s and 60s he had regarded himself as a kind of pilgrim, that much was clear. A man with a mission, even if he could never have said exactly where his Mecca lay. Now that everything was long behind him, he remained one of the few among the huge band of exiles who had never been able to come home again, either literally or metaphorically. Sitting next to an old man comprehensively saying his piece, I had felt myself to be endowed with an unwanted perspicacity. No doubt his stories sounded like concoctions to those who knew little or nothing of his background. For him, all he had ever been, all he could ever speak of, was secluded within a domain of glass, isolated, viewable only as if through a lens scored by sharp cracks and flaws. I asked myself if I knew of a better way of trying to apprehend the history of his country. After lunch his thoughts veered off on another tack. "I wanted to have strong children. So I restrained myself from women. I kept myself chaste. No smoking, nothing. Working all the time. No whisky drinking. Milk shakes I drink, Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola. In Egypt we have a special drink from sugarcane, I don't remember what they call it. And pineapples. Water melon. Sweetmelon." He fell silent. I wrote on the pad: "Was there a woman in your life?" He read the question slowly, as if spelling it out letter by letter. It did not seem to dismay him. On the contrary, he set about answering it like a conscientious autobiographer, from the very beginning. "The first woman in my life, I was young, I was underage. She was Portuguese and I used to go with her. She said to me: "What do you like? Do you want to copulate or do you want me to suck you off?" I said to her: "I want to copulate. I want to push." I was very small..." He laughed, relieved and amused at the memory. "I had a girlfriend in Turkey. She was very intelligent. She got me the job in the college as a professor of English. She spoke to the authorities. And in Athens, one of the Greek girls in my church loved me. But she died. A great love. And in Pretoria I went to the social workers' meetings and there was a Dutch girl there, very beautiful. But the preacher of the Gospel, he kept her away from me, he wanted her for himself... In America, too, there was a beautiful girl, an American, and in Germany one of the workers I like... But I could not compete. "My biological mother used to call me "Mimis." She liked me, but I was in love with her sister, Annie. Can you remember Marlene Dietrich?" I nodded. "Aha!" he laughed. He began to sing: "Falling in love again, what am I to do? Falling in looove again. "My father was very strict. He always watched you, in case . . ." He made masturbatory gestures with his hand. "He was an engineer. He sacrificed his life to a perpetual motion machine. And I continued in his footsteps. My brother was also a lathe-turner. But my biological mother, she spoiled my brother. In the morning she gives him eggs, fried eggs, scrambled eggs. He, not me. He was born with one leg first, out of my stepmother. Not with the head. She was screaming all night. It was a breech birth. That's why she is like that." His chin sank towards his chest and he stuck out his lower lip, as if sulking. Then he lifted his head, recalling something important. "She made a big mistake in Lourenço Marques when a Portuguese chemist discovered that I had a tapeworm. He gave me some medicine, an extract, a powerful poison. He said: 'You must bring the species' head. I must study it.' I drink the extract and the following day it started coming out. I went to the toilet and half of it was out, two or three metres. But the chemist had said: 'You must not throw it away. You must bring it to me. I want to study it.' My stepmother said: 'It's out, out.' She put it in the toilet." He mimed the pulling of a toilet chain. "A big mistake! A very big mistake! Two or three metres....I think it's still alive in the sewers, because it doesn't die, it's very strong. And the Portuguese chemist was very angry. He said: 'Why do you throw it away?' But the sewer is still there. I want to study the sewer underneath the old house. I want to go back to the sewer." He gazed at me with amber-coloured eyes. "You must help me." And later, wistfully, after I had taken a photo of him, "I want you to photograph me in front of my house, in front of my property. I want you to help me. It was difficult to imagine how deeply within himself a man like Demitrios would have felt the dilemma of the "baster" - the bastard, the half-blood. How it must have maimed his sense of self-worth, and the hopelessness he had known as a result. Non-whites were generally regarded by the whites as dirty, animal-like, untrustworthy; but the half-breed was the worst, precisely because he was so close to themselves. Throughout his life, Demitrios had claimed that somehwhere in southern Africa there was a woman waiting for him, the love of his youth. Even as a figment of his imagination, however, this ideal figure threatened to produce for him dark-skinned progeny, who would bring to light the concealed, hereditary stigma of his bad blood. He could cross the line, go over, "play white", though always carrying within him the self-estrangement of his dark conscience. Or, once his wanderings over Europe had miserably ended, he could take on the role of the shamed and vengeful Coloured. He would destroy the loud-voiced chief of the white tribe. With or without the help of the tapeworm inside him, he cut off the creature's head. His deed was the direct consequence of sublunary traumas. The tribal sentiments of the Afrikaner were derived in large measure from some of the sentiments that Tsafendas had harboured within himself: a longing to feel truly at home, a search for acknowledgement, a conviction that he had spent too long a time wandering the wilderness. The Afrikaner was ready to maintain his homeland through violence, the violence of the state if need be. His preoccupation with racial purity and unsoiled blood was central to that aim. Which of the two, then, was more truly crazy: Verwoerd or Tsafendas? It was hardly possible to exaggerate the importance of what Demitrios had done, I reflected. The attack on Verwoerd was a proclamation of the end of the doctrine of apartheid, of the idiotic dread of "racial mixing". It presaged the hesitant beginning of integration. Of a mixed-up living together - the very idea that had horrified so many generations of white South Africans. Of the birth of the "rainbow nation" which, in a bout of over-excitement and child-like honesty, Demitrios had called for in 1964. I had never been able to find any words for the feelings which had overwhelmed me on the afternoon of the attack in September 1966. Retrospectively, it now seemed that the power of madness had at that moment shown itself to be equal to the madness of power. The murder was a melancholy manifestation of being, as if nature itself were finally striking the balance between them. On Friday, March 27, I paid my last visit to Demitrios. I took with me a small Greek stringed instrument, a baglamá , in the hope of diverting him. I showed him the baglamá and strummed a little tune on it. "Very interesting instrument," Demitrios said. "Small in size. Delicate sound. I would have liked to have been able to play it myself. Or the piano accordion. The organ. Before that I was interested in the bugle. That was in Middelburg." Then, in a whisper, "Play some more." The baglamá has a piercing but attractive sound; I was glad that he was able to hear it. "Do you play the violin, too? The saxophone? That's what I'd really like to do." The next question came out of the blue. He asked me who was the president of South Africa now. On my little pad I wrote the name "Mandela" and showed it to him. "Nelson Mandela...? I would like to speak to him. He's a very strong man." When I made a few movements with my fists, like a boxer, Demitrios laughed out loud. From the hall behind us a harsh screaming suddenly broke out. If a stone could scream, it would make a noise like that. Then came the sounds of crashing crockery and another loud voice trying to restore order. Demitrios had fallen silent. If I were ever to ask the question, this had to be the moment. "Do you remember Verwoerd?" I scrawled on my pad with sudden awkward fingers, and handed it to him. "I didn't know Hendrik Verwoerd personally." Demitrios sighed. He thought for a moment. "I had never spoken to him before..." The racket in the hall broke out briefly once more. Demitrios moved uneasily in his wheelchair. "I do regret....." he stammered. "I do regret.....," he said again and yet again, for the third time. "I regret..." He took the paper and pencil out of my hand. When he returned the pad to me I saw that he had written four words in untidy block letters. I REGRET WHAT HAPPENED. He began to cry. I took both his shoulders in my hands and shouted as loudly as I could: "Never mind. Other times. Not your fault." "A whole other time," he sobbed. "I am not that kind of person. It was something that happened. It was not in my nature. Besides, I was sick." His striped dressing gown had fallen from his chest. Poor Mimis. In what followed, he placed the blame on the doctors. It was their fault. They should have operated on him. Why hadn't they done it? He pointed to his stomach. Why hadn't they removed the creature in there? Either they could not or they would not do it. "It will not die. I'm helpless against this Dragon-Tapeworm. I cannot do anything. But they won't investigate. Too difficult and very complicated. At night when I sleep I see orgies. All imagination. Visions." Then he told me that, while he'd been working in parliament, he had heard from a woman member of the house that Verwoerd was not an upright human being. It was one of the things, he wanted me to know, that had set him thinking of what had to be done. "She came to me - I found out later she was a member of the United Party - and she said: 'Hendrik Verwoerd is a very immoral person.' You see? When she told me that I went down . . . and that's how it started. She stirred me. She made me angry." Again, he began to weep; then made an effort to compose himself. "I went down to the shopping centre on the Herengracht and I bought a knife. I went inside and I said: 'Give me a knife.' The woman gave me a little knife. I said: 'It's too small. Give me a bigger knife.' When he had fallen silent I wrote a few more words on the pad. "Like a real Cretan," Demitrios read slowly. "Yeah," he said calmly. "Nature, hereditary nature. "It's nature," he said again, with an air of finality. "Human nature." When we said goodbye he pulled me closely to him, embracing me with one of his arms, and pressed, between sobs, a fatherly kiss on my cheek and forehead. Demitrios Tsafendas died on October 7 1999. fields.headline: Hotel Pelirocco, Brighton
fields.trailText: The rooms are individually designed according to your best-kept fantasy of sex, drugs, rock 'n' roll.
fields.body:
Address: 10 Regency Square, Brighton BN1 2FG.
Tel: 01273 327055.
Web address: www.hotelpelirocco.co.uk

First impressions Five-storey Regency splendour.

What are the rooms like? Each individually designed according to your best-kept fantasy of sex, drugs, rock 'n' roll. There's Lenny Beige's Love Palace, Betty Page's Boudoir, Hysteric Glamour, Modrophenia, Hip Hop. I got Jamie Reid's Magic Room. It was a blast, man - John Wayne meets Boots No 7 - and that's before I tackled the complimentary PlayStation.

The bed test Big, comfy, and a bedspread with naughty words on it.

The bathroom test Not as kinky as Betty Page's, but nevertheless comfortable.

The restaurant Multi-purpose bar, breakfast room and lounge. Open from 8am to 4am.

What is there to see within walking distance? Brighton seafront and all its crazy, fun-packed attractions.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? The South Downs. Go walkies up Devil's Dyke.

How much a night? Doubles and twins from £65.

Would you go back? Wild horses couldn't stop me. This place epitomises Brighton - traditional and bohemian.

webTitle: How the dot.com bosses see it

fields.headline: How the dot.com bosses see it
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: What bosses at Amazon.co.uk, lastminute.com, EuropeanInvestor.com, acequote.com and TheStreet.co.uk think of e-banking
fields.body:
Raphael Fuchs

Chief operating officer of EuropeanInvestor.com, an online financial information source for Europe's new technology markets

He has an internet bank account with Citibank and says he has never experienced any problems with it.

Asked what he considers the pluses and minuses of internet banking he says the pluses are convenience: open 24 hours a day, seven days a week; easy access to information and transactions; a great opportunity for banks to offer online value-added services. On the minus front: "Security is still an issue," he says. He reckons that for simple transactions, internet banking will become the norm, but says that for more sophisticated products such as life insurance, "people will still need human advice".

Bryan Levine

Finance director of TheStreet.co.uk, the online financial commentary service

Says he trusts his online bank Coutts & Co absolutely, as it has "fantastic security". The advantages of online banking are numerous: ease of operation, the ability to bank as and when he wants, and "less hassle". He says he appreciates the service for its ability "to give control to my financial affairs".

However, he understands people's reluctance over internet banking and says there are some banks he would not trust to look after his money online. Nevertheless, he reckons that in the future we will see the numbers of people banking online increasing, although at present some are still nervous.

Helga St Blaize

Founder and director of acequote.com, a b2b (business to business) online marketplace for buyers and sellers of IT and telecoms products

Says she nearly took out an online bank account (with Egg) but "other people's frustrations put me off". She adds: "I'm waiting for online banking to improve in the UK to the level it is already at in the US."

She believes that eventually it will be by far the easiest way of banking. "For consumers with busy lifestyles and the ever-dwindling physical presence of banks outside city centres, it will be an essential tool."She reckons web-based banking will become as commonplace as offline banking is now.

However, she says UK banks "have a long way to go" before they can actually make their customers feel secure.

Martha Lane Fox

Co-founder of lastminute.com, probably the highest-profile dot.com of them all

Does bank online but won't say which bank. She lambasts offline banking, saying it is inefficient, and prefers online banking as "you can manage your money when you want and how you want". Online banking is more "transparent" and puts consumers in the driving seat.

She thinks all the fuss about online banking problems is ridiculous and that despite a few blips the system is fundamentally good. She believes you are safer performing transactions over the net than over the phone.

However, she adds, the future of banking does not necessarily rely on the internet, although it will depend on electronic equipment such as mobile phones and the television.

Steve Frazier

Managing director of Amazon.co.uk, the online book, CD and video retailer

Very positive about internet banking - he has two UK and several US accounts - but admits: "You can't get cash out of a computer." He thinks net banking is a very good way to manage your money and, as someone who is constantly travelling, he finds it useful to be able to log on wherever he is.

He has no qualms about security; the time saved and greater convenience outweigh the "incredibly small risk". However, Mr Frazier does not visualise the banking world being taken over completely by the internet. He appreciates that an Amazon customer stuck at an airport may buy a book at a bookshop and feels there is still a place for high street banks.

fields.standfirst:
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip.
You can download it here free.
fields.trailText: Scott Turow's tale of an FBI sting
fields.body:
Personal Injuries
Scott Turow
Running time 3hrs
HarperCollins, £8.99

A bent judiciary should make prime legal thriller material. But this fictional FBI sting to trap a bench of bung-taking judges fatally sags when they are identified at the start. The only mystery left is whether the miniature micriphone bug sewn into the flies of the protagonist - a dodgy lawyer turned by the FBI - will do its stuff. Although it caulks out a diverting relationship between the lawyer and a female agent, this abridegement does the yarn a favour by wrapping it up more quickly. Kerry Shale, one of our busiest American readers, turns in a customarily professional job.

fields.headline: Alloro, London W1
fields.standfirst: Alloro is one of the new breed of Italian restaurants that have cropped up of late. The food may look and taste good - but it is not Italian
fields.trailText: Alloro is one of the new breed of Italian restaurants that have cropped up of late. The food may look and taste good - but it is not Italian
fields.body:
Address: Alloro, London W1

Alloro is okay. Smart new Italian place. Classy, good-taste design. Proficient service. Capable cooking. Interesting wine list. Reasonably priced, by London standards. So why don't I feel happier about it?

You remember the good old days of Italian restaurants, when the warmth of the welcome was in inverse ratio to the quality of the food, when waiters brandished pepper grinders the size of an Apollo rocket, when pollo was always sopressa and when puddings were always zabaglione? Oh, those dear, dead, innocent days. Well, not so dead, perhaps. There are still a few practitioners of those dark arts here and there, purveying the same spurious, bastardised version of Italian cooking and pandering to the snobbery and ignorance of a certain class of English eater, who put a higher price on the theatre of the fawning waiter than on decent food.

At first sight, Alloro is not like one of these at all. The greeting is polite, not in the least smarmy. The floor is wooden, not tiled. The walls are pale olive green, not white. The wine list is peopled with curiosities from Sardinia and Friuli, not the Vernaccia and Valpolicella of old. The food, too, has had something of a leg-up, what with terrina di verdure grigliate con mozzarella di bufala, gnocchi di patate con gallinacci and petto d'anatra arrosto caramellizato al miele con salsa di vino rosso, to mention just a few of the items on the menu when Angostura and I settled in for lunch.

Nothing very surprising about these dishes, you might say. There's nothing very Italian about them, either - and that is the trouble with Alloro, and a raft of new Italian restaurants. The dishes bear the imprint of frenchification or, worse, anglicisation, where sauces, vegetables and garnishes are used to flesh out the bare bones of a dish, thereby creating a complicated gustatory edifice. They may be delicious in their own way, but they are not Italian.

In the course of a recent trip to southern Italy, I was reminded again and again that the essence of Italian food is its simplicity - or single-mindedness, if you prefer. When you order meat, that's what you get: meat. Ask for fish, and fish appears on the plate, with a slice of lemon. No sauce. No gravy. No vegetables, garnishes, condiments. No distractions. This lack of adornment puts huge emphasis on the quality of the ingredient: it stands entirely by its own excellence, or falls for the lack of it.

My first course at Alloro consisted of culatello originale, finocciona, pane carasau and pomodorini secchi. Culatello is cured rump of pork, a speciality of Zibello in Emilia Romagna and one of the most expensive hams to be had. Finocciona is a salame flavoured with fennel, and is characteristic of Tuscany. Pane carasau is Sardinia's answer to Melba toast: very thin and crisp, and very nice when splattered with halves of cherry tomato, which had been partially dried, I would guess, in the oven, there not having been a whole lot of sun in Mayfair recently. There was nothing wrong with any of these elements individually. Indeed, there was a whole lot right with them - silky, subtle culatello; superb, piercing and delicate finocchiona; intense tomatoes with friable bread. The only trouble was having them all on the same plate. It was a kind of Italian fusion food.

The same thoughts occurred with the fillet of John Dory with fried potatoes and lemon, olive oil and basil sauce. The fish was superb, tense and muscular, as John Dory should be when fresh, but all it needed was a little lemon juice and salt. The potatoes would have done nicely served separately, and the basil sauce would have done nicely on another dish (although I can't think of one off hand). Angostura's monkfish wrapped in courgette and cooked on a skewer with tomato salad was the same: monkfish - splendid; courgette - fine; tomatoes - just about okay.

But what about the unadvertised shavings of fennel? And the green sauce? It could have been a dish in any halfway-decent French restaurant with no specific regional culinary allegiance. The extra-virgin olive oil ice cream that came with strawberries in wine was an ingenious conceit, interesting rather than a giant leap forward in gastronomic pleasure.

And that was that. A brace of Bellinis, a bottle of brilliant, floral Vermentino di Capichera from Sardinia, and an unexplained £3.50 surcharge on the monkfish skewer produced a bill of just over £100, of which the food accounted for £48. Come to think of it, that bill would have been the equivalent of dinner at one of those Da Mimmo's and Trattoria Gennaros of beloved memory. As their spiritual descendant, Alloro will probably do very well

fields.headline: The lone hydrangea
fields.standfirst: Derided as 'Granny' plants, hydrangeas bring vital colour to late-summer borders long after other shrubs have given up the ghost
fields.trailText: Derided as 'Granny' plants, hydrangeas bring vital colour to late-summer borders long after other shrubs have given up the ghost
fields.body:
Few colourful shrubs are at their peak of flowering right now. Most that are are white-flowered - don't ask me why - so if you want colourful, ebullient shrubs from late June until the first frosts, hydrangeas are the ones for you. They include whites, but also pink, red, purple, mauve and blue.

Last year, mine were pretty miserable, thanks to an April frost that swiped the young growth. This year, however, they are as good as I have ever seen them, and what a show they make. Hydrangeas make rounded bushes, by and large; sometimes very large, but you can control their size by pruning (a subject I like to discuss in March).

A point to make here is that rounded hydrangeas, all herded together, cry out for something to break them up. The giant reed grass, Arundo donax , is most satisfactory for this purpose, being tall, narrow and bold, with tiers of wide, blue-grey leaves.

In a cool summer, when we are shivering as we did through much of this July, hydrangeas are at their best. They love it - if too hot or dry at the root, they tell you so at once. Their reproachful, wilting looks force you to give them a heavy drenching. By the next morning, they will be radiant, once more. They love plenty of nourishment, too. Heavy mulches should be given in winter, when they are dormant - but not of mushroom compost, which has chalk in it and will turn the foliage yellow.

You can also give them a boost in March, at the start of their growing season, with a dose of Growmore fertiliser. From early summer on, give them no manuring at all, as they need to enter winter with as well-ripened shoots as possible; nothing soft and sappy that will be vulnerable to frost.

If a hydrangea is non-flowering, the chances are that it is never ripening the growth it made the previous summer. Most, but not all, hydran-geas depend on bringing this intact through winter, so as to flower from it the next year. Hydrangeas are consequently none too satisfactory where winters are unduly cold, though some are tough even then. Hydrangea serrata 'Bluebird' (1m), with lacecap-style flowerheads (big pips or florets surround a disc of small, fertile ones), is outstandingly winter-tough, although it can be clobbered by spring frosts.

Most are excellent in maritime areas, which is why our coastal resorts are so full of them - one of the most ebullient is 'Joseph Banks', with huge pale-pink bun-heads on a bush almost as big as the house behind it - or at least that is how it seems from the road in front.

Another don't, or won't, with hydrangeas is chalky or in other ways strongly alkaline soil. Their leaves turn yellow and they look thoroughly unhappy. To an extent, if the soil is only slightly alkaline, you can correct the situation with iron sequestrine. On neutral or slightly alkaline soils, most colourful hydrangeas have pink or red flower; red particularly suits some of the more dwarf-like varieties, such as 'Westfalen' (0.7m), whose rich colour takes everyone by surprise. That is a hortensia, which means that it has bun-headed inflorescences. 'Geoffrey Chadbund' (up to 2m) is a red lacecap.

On acid soils, the same hydrangeas will be purple, mauve or blue. I find the deeper blues too electric. Light blue is more charming, as in the early and long-flowering 'Générale Vicomtesse de Vibraye' (1.5m and generally shortened to 'Vibraye'), which is bun-headed with small pips. When pink, this looks a trifle cheap, I think - on soils that are not too far removed from neutral, you can alter the colour to blue over two growing seasons by applying regular doses of aluminium sulphate from February to June. If your soil is naturally acid, you won't need to bother.

I find 'Hamburg' (1m) a most satisfactory hortensia, on my fairly neutral soil, where it makes big, blowsy buns of deep-pink pips. Where these receive plenty of light, they turn to bronze as they fade; if shaded, they turn green. If you wish to dry them for winter decorations, pick in early autumn, as the pink is changing to reddish bronze (or green), and dry them like that.

Some hydrangeas have a very long flowering season, thanks to their capacity to keep on producing new flowering shoots. The white hortenisa, 'Mme E Mouillére', gets going in late June and often continues into November, if frost holds off. Mid-season, it is worth sprucing up the bush by removing branches that have faded. 'Ayesha' (1.5m and needing shelter) is a long-flowering hortensia, pink on my soil but blue on acid. It is most distinctive for the in-curving margins of the pips, and is often likened to lilac.

The old-fashioned 'Nigra' (1.5m) also has a long season. Of rather lax habit (pruning out of the lowest branches corrects this), it has masses of smallish bun-heads in pink or blue, but also the distinguishing feature of black stems.
