webTitle: Elspeth Gibson is in the vanguard of  new  British fashion designers

fields.headline: Cut and taste
fields.standfirst: Elspeth Gibson is in the vanguard of the new crop of British fashion designers. They have no time for the wacky creations of their predecessors; they just make great clothes for all sizes that are astonishingly glamorous to boot
fields.trailText: Elspeth Gibson is in the vanguard of the new crop of British fashion designers. They have no time for the wacky creations of their predecessors; they just make great clothes for all sizes that are astonishingly glamorous to boot
fields.body:
Elspeth Gibson was planning to work with horses when she grew up, but she ended up designing dresses instead. "I always loved girly things." Femininity, in the old-fashioned, pink-ribbon sense of the word, is hardly a modish trait, but Gibson - all peachy skin and chocolate-button eyes - has made her mark in the fashion world by reinventing girliness.

From Alexander McQueen's bumster trousers to the scraps of cobweb that pass for Julien Macdonald's dresses, the London fashion designers now making headlines are characterised by a harsh, abrasive sexuality: unsettling to look at, almost impossible to wear. Quietly, meanwhile, Gibson has been forging a different path, making clothes that flatter rather than overshadow the wearer.

Winner of the British Fashion Awards' prestigious New Designer of the Year award two years ago and now a regular fixture at London Fashion Week, she has built a flourishing business on defining and perfecting a luxury-meets-casual look that, it seems, women crave. Her clothes are womanly, practical, yet defiantly romantic. They are also deceptively simple: put on one of her knee-length beaded skirts, and watch the fabric and cut work its magic, conjuring a silver-screen slinkiness out of standard-issue hips and thighs.

Gibson herself, 36 and heavily pregnant when we meet - her first child, Evie Scarlett May, has since been born - is similarly deceptive. She has a soft, musical voice and ends almost every sentence with a silly-me giggle or the phrase "isn't it?", so that she appears, in conversation, to be perpetually unsure of herself.

But, like a true romantic heroine, scratch the surface and discover a will of steel. An assistant who fails to silence a ringing telephone is reprimanded with a swift, terse rebuke; later, in a taxi en route to her Knightsbridge shop, Gibson proves herself to be a bossy backseat driver of the first order.

Gibson grew up in the village of East Markham, in Nottinghamshire: her rosy complexion still owes more to the countryside of her childhood than to London, where she has lived for the past 15 years. Her father was an architect, her mother an illustrator, who, among other things, made drawings for Rolls-Royce brochures. As a child, she kept scrapbooks full of pictures that caught her eye, and drew: "the same shape, a girl with a long dress and a pointed hat".

Her two brothers "always wanted to watch football, and I wanted to watch Black Beauty and cartoons. Because I was the only girl, I had to fight for things." Her grandmother, who had grown up with five sisters, took pity on her and bought her a sewing machine when she was eight. "It was one of the old hand-powered ones. I made a lot of long tube skirts in printed fabrics with elasticated waists." Gibson pauses awhile at the memory of such dubious taste. "I'm sure they looked ridiculous."

She divided her affections between the dressing-up box and Pony Club. "In the countryside, horse-riding gives you freedom. Otherwise, your parents have to take you everywhere. I had two horses, so I spent a lot of time looking after them... and because I spent all my time in wellingtons, I liked the idea of everything being so much more glamorous."

The drive apparent in the grown-up Elspeth Gibson doesn't seem to have been much in evidence during her teenage years: "I wasn't too sure what to do... I liked working with horses, but I quite liked the idea of art college, too." Her father was keen for her to decide, and she "ended up" taking a foundation course at Mansfield College of Art and Design, "doing everything from printing to pottery to graphics... but before long I felt very strongly about fashion".

After graduating in 1984, Gibson moved to London. At this point, the career of all too many talented young British fashion designers goes something like this: be proclaimed a genius for outlandish and extravagant degree collection, and enjoy glorious but short-lived love affair with the press, then fail to produce clothes on time or pay attention to maintaining viable business, and go under within four years. The harsh fact is that very few young designers manage to build lasting businesses in their own name. Some get snapped up to design for bigger companies, but many more simply go bust and disappear.

Gibson's path has been refreshingly different. After completing her foundation course, she landed a placement at Zandra Rhodes, and embarked on a 10-year stint designing for high-street stores, including Top Shop, Miss Selfridge and Monix, before launching her own label. "I wanted to find out how to run a business. Designing for the high street, you have to find fabrics that look good but are cheap, and be really careful with how you use them - when you're cutting thousands, every centimetre counts. Designing is the easy side, and the nicest side. The hard bit is keeping a company going season after season."

Elspeth Gibson London was launched in 1995. Success came relatively quickly, but the early days were nerve-racking none the less. "I went from being the head designer for a company [Monix] to working at home alone with a part-time sample machinist. It was very scary. My first collection was about six pieces, and I took them to Liberty, Harvey Nichols and Tokio. Liberty bought a few pieces, and I was over the moon."

Interest began to grow when Gibson showed an early collection on a stand at the London Designers' Exhibition that accompanies London Fashion Week. A stylist at Vogue saw the clothes, loved them, and brought others to meet Gibson; a buzz started. It was at this time, around four years ago, that Gibson met her now close friend, handbag designer Anya Hindmarch. "Everyone was talking about her, so I went to check out her stuff and loved it," says Hindmarch. "Things were going back to being pretty and feminine, and Elspeth was very much at the forefront of that. And she's so lovely, you can't help but adore her."

By 1997, Gibson's star was rising further, helped by the support of British Vogue, whose editor, Alexandra Shulman, declared that "the most commonly bought item in the Vogue offices this season is an Elspeth Gibson skirt... they seem to strike the right balance, looking modern and different without being too extreme".

The following year, Gibson staged her first fashion show, and opened an Elspeth Gibson boutique in Pont Street, Knightsbridge; last year, turnover grew to more than £1 million. She is one of the few young British designers to to be taken seriously in the lucrative US fashion market - Saks Fifth Avenue does good business selling her clothes. "Americans like to look womanly," says Gibson. "They seem to buy the glam side of my collection."

Gibson has an uncommon gift for creating clothes that tread the thin line between pretty and twee, and is far more influential than she is generally given credit for: over the past five years, she has introduced an evening-wear "look" of a fluid beaded or embroidered skirt or dress worn with simple knitwear that has become something of a uniform among a certain set of chic women who want to look gorgeous but would not be seen dead in an "obvious" dress. "You always feel sexy in Elspeth's clothes," says one devotee, "and you never look like you've tried too hard."

Gibson herself is unusually pretty, petite and cherubic rather than tall and skinny, so she can sympathise more than most fashion designers with women's concerns about their bodies. Her clothes flatter and forgive. What is more, many of them actually look better when they have some curves to hug. On the catwalk, however, Gibson's clothes are still modelled by the classic tall, thin girls, and most of her clothes are bought in relatively small sizes.

"I need to sell clothes to make money, so of course I don't just make size 8s. But the funny thing is that when stores come in to buy, they always go for the 8s, 10s, 12s. Most don't even order any size 14s. We sell size 14 in our shop, but we sell two or three times as many size 10s as size 14s."

She is not immune from feeling body-image pressure. Examining the polaroids of her taken by the photographer who is shooting her portrait for this interview, she is worried that she looks fat. "You will mention that I'm pregnant, won't you?"

There is daywear in Gibson's collection - gingham sun dresses, colourful T-shirts - but even the simplest pieces have a luxurious edge borne out of the designer's love of the best fabrics. With fabrics sometimes costing over £200 a metre, Gibson's clothes can be prohibitively priced: £500 is not unusual for a skirt, say. Such luxury requires discipline in other areas: these fabrics are cut in Gibson's Islington studio, where the samples are made. "We can't afford to make mistakes," she says simply - the business is healthy, but it is still small enough for a wasted £200 piece of fabric to constitute a problem.

More affordable is the Sweetpea range for girls aged three to eight, which Gibson designs for Debenhams. "Debenhams have been really good to me" - the store has sponsored Gibson's show for three years - "and I felt we could work together on the childrenswear, because childrenswear really is different. Because it's such small sizes, you can use good-quality fabrics... but I wanted it to be practical, too. I asked all my friends with children about that."

It was soon after designing the first Sweetpea collection that Gibson became pregnant. She asked about the sex of the child because, "with everything in our industry being so changeable, I wanted something that was set". So she knew already she was expecting a girl; she is, by her own admission, "looking forward to dressing her up", but has no intention of encouraging her daughter, now two months old, to follow in her footsteps. "Oh no - I want her to do something totally different. I think she'd be more sensible going into something like the stock market. I'd let her decide but... I wouldn't recommend being a designer. I'd want her to have an easier life."

Today, she is wearing a Paul Smith men's V-neck jumper taken from the wardrobe of her husband, Dominic, who works alongside her in the Islington studio four days a week, running the financial side of the company; on the fifth day, he continues to practise his first profession, dentistry. They met through a friend, at a birthday lunch. "We weren't attracted to each other at all," she says matter-of-factly. "I never thought we'd be together, and he didn't, either. It's funny how things work out. We knew each other for about a year, and then got together."

They now live in north London, a few roads away from where Dominic grew up. Together, they have an air of frightening efficiency. When they decided to have a baby, Dominic worked out that the only practical way they could cope with a baby born this year was if it were to be born in the relative lull between seasons, in May. "Dominic told me last year we had a window of a few weeks in the autumn when hopefully it would happen, and if it didn't we were going to have to wait another six months." Evie happened, right on cue. A very Elspeth Gibson story: practicality with a fairy-tale ending

Her grandmother, who had grown up with five sisters, took pity on her and bought her a sewing machine when she was eight. "It was one of the old hand-powered ones. I made a lot of long tube skirts in printed fabrics with elasticated waists." Gibson pauses awhile at the memory of such dubious taste. "I'm sure they looked ridiculous." She divided her affections between the dressing-up box and Pony Club. "In the countryside, horse-riding gives you freedom. Otherwise, your parents have to take you everywhere. I had two horses, so I spent a lot of time looking after them... and because I spent all my time in wellingtons, I liked the idea of everything being so much more glamorous." The drive apparent in the grown-up Elspeth Gibson doesn't seem to have been much in evidence during her teenage years: "I wasn't too sure what to do... I liked working with horses, but I quite liked the idea of art college, too." Her father was keen for her to decide, and she "ended up" taking a foundation course at Mansfield College of Art and Design, "doing everything from printing to pottery to graphics... but before long I felt very strongly about fashion". After graduating in 1984, Gibson moved to London. At this point, the career of all too many talented young British fashion designers goes something like this: be proclaimed a genius for outlandish and extravagant degree collection, and enjoy glorious but short-lived love affair with the press, then fail to produce clothes on time or pay attention to maintaining viable business, and go under within four years. The harsh fact is that very few young designers manage to build lasting businesses in their own name. Some get snapped up to design for bigger companies, but many more simply go bust and disappear. Gibson's path has been refreshingly different. After completing her foundation course, she landed a placement at Zandra Rhodes, and embarked on a 10-year stint designing for high-street stores, including Top Shop, Miss Selfridge and Monix, before launching her own label. "I wanted to find out how to run a business. Designing for the high street, you have to find fabrics that look good but are cheap, and be really careful with how you use them - when you're cutting thousands, every centimetre counts. Designing is the easy side, and the nicest side. The hard bit is keeping a company going season after season." Elspeth Gibson London was launched in 1995. Success came relatively quickly, but the early days were nerve-racking none the less. "I went from being the head designer for a company [Monix] to working at home alone with a part-time sample machinist. It was very scary. My first collection was about six pieces, and I took them to Liberty, Harvey Nichols and Tokio. Liberty bought a few pieces, and I was over the moon." Interest began to grow when Gibson showed an early collection on a stand at the London Designers' Exhibition that accompanies London Fashion Week. A stylist at Vogue saw the clothes, loved them, and brought others to meet Gibson; a buzz started. It was at this time, around four years ago, that Gibson met her now close friend, handbag designer Anya Hindmarch. "Everyone was talking about her, so I went to check out her stuff and loved it," says Hindmarch. "Things were going back to being pretty and feminine, and Elspeth was very much at the forefront of that. And she's so lovely, you can't help but adore her." By 1997, Gibson's star was rising further, helped by the support of British Vogue, whose editor, Alexandra Shulman, declared that "the most commonly bought item in the Vogue offices this season is an Elspeth Gibson skirt... they seem to strike the right balance, looking modern and different without being too extreme". The following year, Gibson staged her first fashion show, and opened an Elspeth Gibson boutique in Pont Street, Knightsbridge; last year, turnover grew to more than £1 million. She is one of the few young British designers to to be taken seriously in the lucrative US fashion market - Saks Fifth Avenue does good business selling her clothes. "Americans like to look womanly," says Gibson. "They seem to buy the glam side of my collection." Gibson has an uncommon gift for creating clothes that tread the thin line between pretty and twee, and is far more influential than she is generally given credit for: over the past five years, she has introduced an evening-wear "look" of a fluid beaded or embroidered skirt or dress worn with simple knitwear that has become something of a uniform among a certain set of chic women who want to look gorgeous but would not be seen dead in an "obvious" dress. "You always feel sexy in Elspeth's clothes," says one devotee, "and you never look like you've tried too hard." Gibson herself is unusually pretty, petite and cherubic rather than tall and skinny, so she can sympathise more than most fashion designers with women's concerns about their bodies. Her clothes flatter and forgive. What is more, many of them actually look better when they have some curves to hug. On the catwalk, however, Gibson's clothes are still modelled by the classic tall, thin girls, and most of her clothes are bought in relatively small sizes. "I need to sell clothes to make money, so of course I don't just make size 8s. But the funny thing is that when stores come in to buy, they always go for the 8s, 10s, 12s. Most don't even order any size 14s. We sell size 14 in our shop, but we sell two or three times as many size 10s as size 14s." She is not immune from feeling body-image pressure. Examining the polaroids of her taken by the photographer who is shooting her portrait for this interview, she is worried that she looks fat. "You will mention that I'm pregnant, won't you?" There is daywear in Gibson's collection - gingham sun dresses, colourful T-shirts - but even the simplest pieces have a luxurious edge borne out of the designer's love of the best fabrics. With fabrics sometimes costing over £200 a metre, Gibson's clothes can be prohibitively priced: £500 is not unusual for a skirt, say. Such luxury requires discipline in other areas: these fabrics are cut in Gibson's Islington studio, where the samples are made. "We can't afford to make mistakes," she says simply - the business is healthy, but it is still small enough for a wasted £200 piece of fabric to constitute a problem. More affordable is the Sweetpea range for girls aged three to eight, which Gibson designs for Debenhams. "Debenhams have been really good to me" - the store has sponsored Gibson's show for three years - "and I felt we could work together on the childrenswear, because childrenswear really is different. Because it's such small sizes, you can use good-quality fabrics... but I wanted it to be practical, too. I asked all my friends with children about that." It was soon after designing the first Sweetpea collection that Gibson became pregnant. She asked about the sex of the child because, "with everything in our industry being so changeable, I wanted something that was set". So she knew already she was expecting a girl; she is, by her own admission, "looking forward to dressing her up", but has no intention of encouraging her daughter, now two months old, to follow in her footsteps. "Oh no - I want her to do something totally different. I think she'd be more sensible going into something like the stock market. I'd let her decide but... I wouldn't recommend being a designer. I'd want her to have an easier life." Today, she is wearing a Paul Smith men's V-neck jumper taken from the wardrobe of her husband, Dominic, who works alongside her in the Islington studio four days a week, running the financial side of the company; on the fifth day, he continues to practise his first profession, dentistry. They met through a friend, at a birthday lunch. "We weren't attracted to each other at all," she says matter-of-factly. "I never thought we'd be together, and he didn't, either. It's funny how things work out. We knew each other for about a year, and then got together." They now live in north London, a few roads away from where Dominic grew up. Together, they have an air of frightening efficiency. When they decided to have a baby, Dominic worked out that the only practical way they could cope with a baby born this year was if it were to be born in the relative lull between seasons, in May. "Dominic told me last year we had a window of a few weeks in the autumn when hopefully it would happen, and if it didn't we were going to have to wait another six months." Evie happened, right on cue. A very Elspeth Gibson story: practicality with a fairy-tale ending

fields.headline: The unforgiven
fields.standfirst: Interview: Ed Schutlz, chief executive, Smith & Wesson
fields.trailText: Interview: Ed Schutlz, chief executive, Smith & Wesson
fields.body:
People keep sending Ed Shultz teabags - some already used. In the past five months, hundreds of them have been sent to the chief executive of Smith & Wesson in a mailbag otherwise full of abuse.

A used teabag might seem like an odd way to insult the head of a leading handgun manufacturer. But when Shultz broke ranks with the American gun lobby in an agreement to curb the way his company makes and sells firearms, a wave of xenophobia generated by the fact that Smith & Wesson is owned by British conglomerate Tomkins was released.

The gun lobby was able to make a direct link between Britain's decision to ban handguns with what it considered this latest threat to the constitutional right of all Americans to bear arms.

Charlton Heston, the head of the National Rifle Association, thundered: "Smith & Wesson is a good company and a fine, old American name, but they're owned by the Brits. I don't really relish the idea of the Brits telling us how to deal with one part of our Bill of Rights. I thought we settled that in 1776."

Soon after the teabags began arriving - a reference to the Boston Tea Party - and a consumer boycott of Smith & Wesson guns gathered momentum. After nine years as a hate figure for anti-gun campaigners Shultz is still coming to terms with his status as a traitor. "Our opponents are spinning us as somehow a British controlled company. They have projected me as some kind of a British citizen, controlled by the British government," said the 58-year-old native of Iowa. Shultz refuses to discuss his family or to even allude to where he lives. Security at Smith & Wesson's ugly, squat headquarters at Springfield, Massachusetts, is tight.

Into the firefight Tomkins has lobbed the fact that it wants to sell its subsidiary. The group has decided that at a contribution level of 1% to revenues, the troublesome firm is not part of its core business. The decision to rationalise its operations has been welcomed by the City, but few analysts believe finding a buyer in a stagnant industry at the centre of a legal nightmare is going to be easy.

After Tomkins reiterated its desire to divest non-core operations at its results announcement last month, Shultz received a couple of calls from potential buyers. He sent them straight on to merger specialists at the parent company. But sources close to Tomkins say a deal is likely to be some way off. Shultz says that the sale of his company is "not likely to be a number one priority" for Tomkins - which is going through a management as well as corporate reshuffle. Advisers believe its continuing legal woes are likely to deter prospective buyers.

For while Shultz's decision to change the way he makes and sells guns has brought opprobrium from gun owners, it has only helped settle some of the lawsuits Tomkins faces. Many more, from states as well as individuals, are pending. Anti-gun campaigners also believe that the agreement does not go far enough and simply reinforces what the company is already doing.

Language of war

During an interview of almost three hours in his spartan office, Shultz often uses the language of war to describe his predicament. "In first world war terms, we are in no man's land being attacked by both sides," he said. In the accord, reached with federal agencies on behalf of state authorities during March, Smith & Wesson agreed to adopt safety measures such as equipping new guns with trigger locks and exerting greater control over who buys them. The company has also agreed to develop so-called "smart-gun technology" using fingerprints to identify users.

Shultz's defence against his opponents in the gun lobby is twofold. First, he argues that he had no choice. Smith & Wesson, with estimated undisclosed annual sales of about £100m, baulked at the threat of continuing legal costs. Ground-breaking awards against that other pariah industry, tobacco, helped convince Shultz he had done the right thing.

Asked if he had any regrets about signing the pact, Shultz says no very clearly before adding: "It was the only reasonable alternative we had." His second line of defence is that the company had to change to deal with a changing society and new market dynamics. This has been hard for many gun owners to accept. Among the more blood-curdling complaints made via the net is one suggesting some of the new curbs would allow the Clinton administration to collect information about gun owners.

Shultz, a lifetime Republican who can hardly say the word Clinton without curling his lip, describes this as part of the "spin" disseminated by his opponents. He compares the new rules for gun distributors as akin to making sure someone can drive before giving them a car.

There has been "tremendous support from the public" for his stance, he says. "Here in the US, a significant percentage of the voting population agrees with us." He has even received supportive letters from the UK - a fact unlikely to surprise Charlton Heston.

Short and stocky, and wearing a short-sleeved shirt bearing the corporate logo, Shultz is on the defensive when talking about his company. But his speech becomes rapid and philosophical when he discusses the changing nature of the world around him.

Born on a farm in the mid-west just after the US entered the second world war, guns were "a part of life". His father taught him "the rules", such as each round bringing back something to eat or never firing across water. "I grew up hunting and trapping. When you get a skunk in your mink trap, you need a gun." A grandfather of two, Shultz can list all the shootings that have shocked the US and led to calls for stiffer gun laws. An owner of "dozens" of guns, he objects to the way the public thinks a handgun played a part in the Columbine school shooting when 30-year-old shotguns were used. But, he adds, "Boys in the schoolyard used to beat each other up, they did not run each other down after school."

He cites increasing urbanisation, the end of military service and the decline of the traditional family as reasons for decreasing gun sales. While some estimates put the number of guns as high as the number of people in the US, he says the market peaked in 1995 as the gun-owning population stockpiled weapons to head off the threat of new legislation.

Shultz says this changing society has led to the legal and business difficulties which face his industry and others. "People don't smoke and they don't shoot any more and they sit on juries ... Through elected officials they are already changing these things. If we are perceived by the public to be reluctant to do anything they will just vote us out of existence." "This industry can either move forward or stay obsolete. Smith & Wesson is one of the oldest companies in the US, it was started in 1852. It did not survive into its 149th year by failing to adapt to change."

For all his adaptability, Shultz has a passion for gun owning hard to imagine in anyone outside the US. "My guns will never be confiscated in my lifetime, because the last thing I would do is have a shoot-out. I believe that it's an absolute right for me to have them and if they [government forces] went that far I would be willing to give up my life, as I wouldn't want to live here anyway." The industry has always seen Shultz as an outsider. After graduating as an engineer, he spent his early career working in a shop fixtures business and then an office furniture manufacturer before being hired by Tomkins in 1992. Since March, Smith & Wesson has offered discounts and closed its plant for an annual break - both seized upon by the NRA as signs of financial distress. Anecdotal evidence suggests sales have been hit by the boycott, but it is difficult to know to what extent. Shultz, in a rare attempt at humour, says: "Reports of our demise by folks doing the boycott have been exaggerated."

Berretta rumours

When the agreement was signed several industry pundits expected other gun makers to follow suit. Austrian-owned Glock and Italian Berretta were rumoured as potential signatories. Now, nobody expects anything to happen until after the presidential election. The gun lobby has long supported the Republican party. Dick Cheney, the vice-presidential candidate, is rare even among conservative politicians in never having voted for any gun restrictions.

Shultz says even a Bush presidency would not change the way the wind is blowing. "The government cannot stop states or cities, and it certainly cannot stop individuals from bringing their own actions." Cynical about what he calls "spin" on both sides, he says, "At the federal level this is a good political issue because politicians can take a position - and there is virtually nothing they can do about it."

Shultz says he considered taking his first holiday in five years" this month but it "didn't work out". Instead, he expects to continue to add two hours to each working day, replying to the most reasoned or heartfelt correspondence he gets. Asked if he would consider a management buy-out of some kind, he thinks for a while before saying that if he were an investment professional it "would probably be [in] some kind of internet company".

The CV

Born On a hog, or pig, farm in Iowa, in 1941.

Education First studied in a "one-room schoolhouse"; studied engineering at Iowa State University before training to become a registered professional engineer.

Career Began in the construction machinery industry, progressing to outdoor power and recreational equipment; in 1979 joined Lozier Corporation, a store fixtures business of which he eventually became president; in 1989 became president of Hon Company, an office furniture firm; in 1992 , joined Tomkins as president and chief executive of Smith & Wesson Ê there, in 1994 , he was given responsibility for all professional, gardening and leisure businesses in the US .

Family Two children, two grandchildren.

webTitle: New pension deal for same-sex partners

fields.headline: New pension deal for same-sex partners
fields.trailText: A gay financial adviser this month launches a new pension scheme aimed at helping gays and lesbians avoid the discriminatory problems encountered by Ron Strank and partner Roger Fisher - but he admits that it is at best only a partial solution.
fields.body:
A gay financial adviser this month launches a new pension scheme aimed at helping gays and lesbians avoid the discriminatory problems encountered by Ron Strank and partner Roger Fisher - but he admits that it is at best only a partial solution.

Phil Carvosso of Carvosso and Company has designed the Equality pension in which a lesbian or gay man who has a frozen final salary scheme from a former employer transfers into a personal pension, which lets them nominate their partners as the beneficiary if they die. Mr Carvosso says an additional advantage is that the "transfer value" calculated by the former scheme has to include an amount for spouses benefit, which he says adds around 20-30% to the fund value.

"This facility gives control and choice back to the same sex partner. It does away with the high-handed dictatorial stance taken by the trustee and helps bring the gay and lesbian community back in from the cold."

However, the concept of a pension transfer will make many people feel uneasy. The industry is still clearing up - at a cost of £11bn - the mess caused by the transfer of millions of people out of good final salary schemes into poorer personal pensions.

Mr Carvosso insists that no one still working for an employer with a final salary scheme should consider switching. But other financial advisers working in the gay community are sceptical.

Louis Letourneau of Rainbow Finance says: "You have to be extremely careful about recommending a transfer, even if your pension is a 'frozen' one with a former employer. It's difficult to give average figures about spouse's benefit, as this varies from one scheme to another and from one year to another. I don't believe the way to beat the system is to make yourself worse off by going into a personal pension instead. Final salary schemes, even frozen ones, have very good benefits."

fields.bodyText: A gay financial adviser this month launches a new pension scheme aimed at helping gays and lesbians avoid the discriminatory problems encountered by Ron Strank and partner Roger Fisher - but he admits that it is at best only a partial solution. Phil Carvosso of Carvosso and Company has designed the Equality pension in which a lesbian or gay man who has a frozen final salary scheme from a former employer transfers into a personal pension, which lets them nominate their partners as the beneficiary if they die. The industry is still clearing up - at a cost of £11bn - the mess caused by the transfer of millions of people out of good final salary schemes into poorer personal pensions. webTitle: The World Championship debate rumbles on

fields.headline: The World Championship debate rumbles on
fields.trailText: Punter's Point Paul Wilson risks not entirely cricket-related allegory by picking up the ball that is the World Championship debate and running with it.
fields.body:
Having read a number of ideas regarding a Test-match World Cup I have an idea that would work by minimising the disruption to the various scheduling arrangements that already exist between Test-playing nations.

ICC should introduce a trophy which can be given to the World Champions of cricket - until someone wins it off them. I propose that it is decided by a points system similar to that which determines who is the No. 1 tennis player in the world. It might go something like this:

a) A side winning a Test away from home scores 10 points.
b) A side winning a Test at home scores 7 points.
c) A side drawing a Test away from home scores 5 points.
d) A side drawing a Test at home scores 3 points.
e) A side losing any Test scores 0 points.

Each Test side will then have an ongoing points tally, accumulated over the previous 40 Tests they have played. The team with the highest score (this will change on a rolling basis as Tests are played) at any given point will be recognised as the World Champions and will hold the trophy.

I would also introduce a rule that says that each country must play at least seven of the ten Test teams in the previous five-year period, otherwise they are eliminated from the points table.

Think about the possibilities. All Test sides will be obliged to organise matches against each other, bringing a great boost to the smaller Test nations. Existing trophies (like the Ashes) could continue unhindered, and teams will be forced to take a real interest in Test series being played in other parts of the world. Under this system all Test matches count - there is no such thing as a "dead rubber".

If you can see any faults in this idea then let me know. Use your imagination and see how much fun it could be.

Paul Wilson lives in Sydney, Australia. His e-mail address is colinpaulwilson@hotmail.com. To read last week's Punter's Point, in which Andrew Nixon put forward a Test-match World Championship blueprint of his own, click here

fields.headline: Inquiry into 'brutal' prison
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Police were yesterday called in to investigate allegations that warders at the Portland young offenders institute brutalised inmates over a 14-year period, carrying out physical assaults and terrorising teenagers in their charge. Four warders were suspended from duty.
fields.body:
Police were yesterday called in to investigate allegations that warders at the Portland young offenders institute brutalised inmates over a 14-year period, carrying out physical assaults and terrorising teenagers in their charge. Four warders were suspended from duty.

Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, took the decision after receiving a dossier from the penal reform group the Howard League, alleging assaults on 15 inmates, some as young as 15.

The allegations stretch back to 1986 and one teenager claims he was assaulted a fortnight ago at the Dorset jail, which houses, on average, 543 inmates aged 15-21.

Two serving staff members and one former employee have backed up the claims that a systematically violent regime operates at the youth jail.

Prison reformers say the allegations of brutality are the worst levelled against a youth prison in modern times.

In statements seen by the Guardian, inmates claim they were kicked and punched by officers, and two have told of hearing screams echoing through sections of the Victorian jail following beatings being meted out by officers.

The prison service said yesterday that four officers had been suspended over the allegations. Detectives are investigating the claims of six former inmates who say they were assaulted between December 1997 and March 2000 and have begun legal action.

One former prisoner who is willing to give evidence to police, claimed that as a 19-year-old inmate at Portland in 1993 he was assaulted five times. He said: "On arrival to the block [the officer] asked me my name and number, I replied with my name and number and he shouted 'call me fucking sir'."

"With that he hit me over the head with a wooden board, I went down ... [two officers] got one arm each behind my back and bent my wrists to the point of nearly breaking them."

He then says he was ordered to a cell to be strip searched: "The four officers chased me, pushing and saying run faster. I was just frozen with fear ... They were punching me and ground the sole of their boots in my face, calling me names."

The Howard League said that Mr Narey, who has portrayed himself as a reformer, should have acted sooner over the brutality investigations.

In November last year the Guardian reported claims of brutality from an earlier Howard League dossier. However, none of the ex-inmates making the allegations wanted to be named and Mr Narey decided no inquiry was possible.

In March Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, described conditions at Portland as a "moral outrage" and condemned the jail's treatment of young offenders.

In a statement Mr Narey said: "While being confident that the humanity of Portland has been radically improved by the new governor, I remain extremely concerned about the allegations of abuse."

The Howard League, which wants an independent inquiry into Portland, passed their new dossier to Mr Narey at a meeting on Wednesday. He visited the jail on Thursday.

Frances Crook of the Howard League said: "The culture within the prison allowed the assaults to happen and continue for so long. Either senior managers knew the abuse was happening and did nothing or they did not know, which is just as worrying."

One member of staff at Portland said officers had "closed ranks" over the allegations.

Nogah Ofer, a solicitor representing the former inmates who are suing, said the Prison Service still had not grasped the scale of the problem: "They very much see it in terms of some rogue officers; we're saying it's much more systematic. Why do these things go on for years and years when people know about them?"

webTitle: Solskjaer conjures up memories of Barcelona

fields.headline: Solskjaer conjures up memories of Barcelona
fields.standfirst:
Manchester United 1 Solskjaer 90
Real Madrid 0
fields.trailText:
Manchester United 1 Solskjaer 90
Real Madrid 0
fields.body:
Manchester United gained some revenge for their elimination from last season's Champions League at the hands of Real Madrid with a narrow victory over the Spanish side in the Centenary tournament in Munich last night.

And, to knowing looks from the Bayern Munich fans in the crowd of 28,000 at the Olympic stadium, the English champions won the match in familiar fashion, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's 90th-minute goal from a Teddy Sheringham knock-down bringing back memories of United's last-gasp European Cup final triumph over the Germans in Barcelona last year.

The majority of the match was played at a typically slow pre-season pace, with Real choosing to leave many of their international stars, including the new signing Luis Figo, Roberto Carlos and Steve McManaman, on the bench.

The only notable chances of the first half fell to Paul Scholes and the Cameroon international Geremi as the match rarely lived up to its potential. But after the interval the English champions found their feet.

Solskjaer forced Cesar to save at full stretch, and the Real keeper had to tip David Beckham's chip over the bar minutes later. Further chances for Beckham, Ryan Giggs and Scholes came and went before United broke the deadlock.

Raimond van der Gouw's long clearance was flicked on by Sheringham and Solskjaer took the ball on his chest before stabbing it under the advancing Cesar.

Earlier the hosts Bayern beat the Uefa Cup winners Galatasaray, the fourth side participating in the two-day event to mark the German club's 100th anniversary. The Bundesliga champions won 3-1 thanks to goals from Roque Santa Cruz, Samuel Kuffour and Alexander Zickler, to set up a rematch of that night in Barcelona in today's final.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; G Neville, Silvestre, Johnsen, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs (Yorke, 82min); Solskjaer, Sheringham.

Real Madrid (4-4-2): Cesar; Geremi, Campo, Julio Cesar, Karanka; Savio, Solari, Alvarez (Tote, 64), Guti; Morientes (Etoo, 64), Savio (Rivera, 75).

fields.headline: The Coventry City of Europe
fields.standfirst: Even the cream of the Premiership will never be able to compete with a few European clubs, writes  Martin Thorpe
fields.trailText: Even the cream of the Premiership will never be able to compete with a few European clubs, writes Martin Thorpe
fields.body:
Putting aside the question of whether a man who kicks a football for a living is worth a figure equivalent to the gross domestic product of a small country, the £37m that Real Madrid paid Barcelona for Luis Figo dealt another blow to the already battered self-image of British football.

First Manchester United failed to hold on to the European title that many partially sighted patriots had eagerly used as evidence that the Premiership is best. Then Kevin Keegan's England were exposed as not even second best in Euro 2000. Now the Premiership has been handed conclusive proof that not only is it not the best league in the world, it is not even the richest.

United's interest in the Portuguese playmaker ended at the first mention of the fee; arguably the world's richest club could not afford arguably the world's best player. The feeling that the Premiership generally is becoming the Coventry City of European football - ready to wheel and deal and scrimp and save rather than splash the cash - is compellingly reinforced by the figures.

England's top five clubs have spent £69.3m on new arrivals this summer. The Serie A champions Lazio alone have bought players worth more than £70m. Of this summer's 12 most expensive transfer deals, only one involved an England purchaser - Chelsea paying £15m to Atletico Madrid for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink.

Top of the shops was Figo's move from Barcelona, followed closely by Hernan Crespo's £36m-rated cash-plus-player switch from Parma to Lazio. Even at 32, Gabriel Batistuta was valued at £22.5m when he moved from Fiorentina to Roma, while Barcelona picked up Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars for £32m and France's David Trezeguet moved from Monaco to Juventus for £15m. On and on the list goes. But no matter how many players appear on it, the number of English clubs buying them increases only as the fees fall.

"We cannot compete with Barcelona money-wise, that is obvious," admits the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger. "Nor can we compete with Lazio on the same basis."

So why is it that a league that has just sealed a world-record television deal worth more than £1.5bn cannot compete for the world's best players and, with a few exceptions, is prepared to make do with the world's former best players looking for a final big pay day in their dotage?

Well, the Premiership's macho image may not have suffered too much damage. One look at the Italian and Spanish giants who stride across the transfer landscape reveals them to be not so much a group of football clubs as the private playthings of a wealthy few - Agnelli at Juventus, Berlusconi at Milan, Cragnotti at Lazio, Moratti at Internazionale. If the club needs a player, they write a cheque.

The king's ransom that the appropriately named Real paid for Figo was money promised by Florentino Perez in his attempt to be elected the club's new president. Not surprisingly, he won.

But as Peter Kenyon, the new chairman of Manchester United, defiantly points out, his club is not going down that seemingly gold-paved road. "We are not going to compete with the private pockets of some of the European club owners," he insists.

"What we are not going to compete with is the magnanimous benefactor of a Berlusconi or an Agnelli in Italy or a guy who is running for presidency in one of the Spanish clubs and dipping into his personal fortune - that is not what we are about.

"We have to think smarter: how we are going to create that money in order to reinvest in our youth policy, the stadium and players themselves. I know people say that you should speculate to accumulate but it doesn't work that way. Buying 11 players doesn't guarantee you success. That's not the issue. It is not about buying the best all the time. You can't just keep going on and adding players."

Certainly, if Kenyon ran Manchester United, a publicly listed company, with the same disregard for financial prudence as the top men at Real Madrid, reportedly more than £100m in debt, he would have a lot of shareholders asking a lot of questions. The first would probably be: "When are you resigning?"

It is a situation that annoys Wenger. "Clubs should spend what they have. There should be an international control panel to look at transfers. I feel very frustrated that clubs who have a difficult financial situation still go out and buy what they cannot afford."

None of the other top English clubs come anywhere near matching United's buying power, and the underlings of Serie A and La Liga also struggle to keep up with the Joneses of Southern Europe, with their artificially inflated transfer policy.

But the lack of players of the very highest quality does have its downside in the Premiership."It wasn't that Arsenal had a lack of talent or good players," said Petit on leaving Highbury, "but we didn't manage to win the Champions League. At Barcelona I will be alongside the best players in the world. There is more chance of winning the Champions League here than with any other club."

For all its money, the Premiership remains the MG of European football, not the Ferrari.

"I want to win the Italian league," said Batistuta of his move to Roma. "That's why I said no to Manchester United."

Reluctant to pay transfer fees with more noughts than a West Indies scorecard, English clubs are at least, and at last, showing signs that the penny has dropped somewhere.

This past week has been dominated by story after fantastic story about the measures clubs are taking, not to buy the best, but to keep the best. Stratospheric salaries are reportedly about to be offered: David Beckham £80,000 a week; Michael Owen £75,000 a week.

Apparently Middlesbrough have been forced to offer Christian Ziege £50,000 a week to try to prevent his move to Liverpool and Bryan Robson has had to deny reports that he agreed to pay Alen Boksic more than £60,000 a week to entice the Lazio striker to England's unglamorous north.

Maybe it is only a matter of time before Premiership clubs start straining to match the European giants in transfer fees too. The pressure to succeed can never be underestimated.

The biggest spenders

Real Madrid £80m

Lazio £71m

Roma £52m

Barcelona £44m

Internazionale £32m

Deportivo La Coruna £30m

Juventus £28m

Paris St-Germain £27m

Chelsea £24m

Monaco £24m

Milan £22m

All figures approximate

webTitle: Beckham keen to stay a red devil - at a price

fields.headline: Beckham keen to stay a red devil - at a price
fields.trailText: David Beckham wants to stay at Manchester United, but the champions will have to make him the highest-paid player in the history of British football to keep him at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
David Beckham wants to stay at Manchester United, but the champions will have to make him the highest-paid player in the history of British football to keep him at Old Trafford.

Beckham's spokeswoman Caroline McAteer indicated last night that he was willing to resist the financial trappings of a big-money move abroad - provided United's terms were acceptable.

"It's up to Manchester United," she said. "They know how many other clubs would love to have David playing for them so they know what they will have to do [financially] to keep him.

"But as far as David is concerned he has always been Manchester United through and through and nothing has changed whatsoever."

Although Sir Alex Ferguson has gone on record as saying last season's elevation of Roy Keane's wages to £52,000 a week should not be viewed as a precedent, it is clear the United manager will have to break his salary structure for a second time to keep Beckham.

The England midfielder has three years remaining on his £24,000-a-week contract but United's new chief executive Peter Kenyon is anxious to make a statement of the club's intent by negotiating an improved five-year deal with the 25-year-old, possibly worth as much as £80,000 a week.

In an industry where money talks, Beckham is lagging behind not only Keane but several other United players, most notably the deposed goalkeeper Mark Bosnich.

And in the week that Rivaldo finalised the terms of an £80,000-a-week contract at Barcelona, Beckham is also acutely aware that his international status makes him one of the football's most prized - and marketable - assets.

A clutch of leading European clubs would be willing to spend whatever is necessary to lure him away from Old Trafford if there were the slightest hint that United were unwilling to pay the going rate. Barcelona and Milan have already made firm inquiries, with the midfielder generally thought on the continent to be at loggerheads with Ferguson.

But despite their much publicised falling-out last season, Beckham still has a close, if occasionally tense, relationship with his manager and would relish the chance to tie himself to the club he has supported since boyhood.

"He may have grown up on the outskirts of London but he has been obsessed with United all his life," added McAteer. webTitle: Villa reject 'insulting' Chelsea bid for Southgate

fields.headline: Villa reject 'insulting' Chelsea bid for Southgate
fields.trailText: Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis rejected a £5m bid for the England defender Gareth Southgate from Chelsea yesterday, and described their earlier offer of £4m as "an insult".
fields.byline: Adrian Milledge, Daniel Taylor  and Ian Ross
fields.body:
Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis rejected a £5m bid for the England defender Gareth Southgate from Chelsea yesterday, and described their earlier offer of £4m as "an insult".

Chelsea have been the only English club seriously linked with Southgate, and appear to be trying to cash in after Villa admitted they had not received an offer for the 29-year-old since he submitted a transfer request two months ago.

The London club responded to Ellis's outraged rejection of their initial bid by offering £5m, but that too failed to satisfy the Villa chairman.

"The £4m offer was insulting," Ellis said. "We know the kind of figure we're looking for and if we don't get it Gareth will be staying with us.

"He's got three years left on his contract and we've made it clear to him from day one that we don't want him to leave."

Villa's rejection of both bids has not surprised Southgate, who said: "I've heard about the bids but I always knew they were going to be turned down."

Ellis refuses to name a price but is believed to be looking for more than £7m. His chances of getting that suffered another blow on Wednesday when Southgate appeared in the Intertoto Cup against Celta Vigo, making him ineligible to play for Chelsea in the Uefa Cup.

Moreover, Villa may have to settle for less out of economic necessity. The club made a loss on last season of £4.8m and Wednesday's defeat has seen the club's shares hit an all-time low. Valued at more than £11 each at flotation, they now stand at £3.35.

Paulo Wanchope is expected to complete his club-record £4m transfer from West Ham to Manchester City on Monday despite Bradford City's best efforts to gazump the move.

Bradford have matched City's offer and agreed to meet Wanchope's pay demands, but their chairman Geoffrey Richmond believes the chance to team up with George Weah at Maine Road will be too much for the striker to turn down.

"My gut feeling is that our chances are something less than 50-50, the reason being that there is every possibility he will decide to join what is perceived to be a bigger club," said Richmond.

Middlesbrough are waiting to discover whether Alen Boksic's reputation is enough to earn him a work permit.

The Croatian striker needs clearance from the Department for Employment and Education after agreeing a £2.5m transfer from Lazio. And although Boro have been assured there should be no problem obtaining a work permit, Boksic's lack of international action over the past two years means he does not meet the criteria.

If his application were rejected, the club would have to lodge an official appeal arguing that the player's reputation leaves no doubt as to his quality. Last season they used the same route to complete the loan signing of Juninho from Atletico Madrid.

Robbie Fowler's worst fears were realised yesterday when he was told to rest his badly damaged ankle for between four and six weeks, meaning it might be October before he can return for Liverpool.

It seems probable the striker will be forced to sit out the opening eight league games of the season and miss England's World Cup qualifier against Germany in October.

Fowler was flown home from Liverpool's pre-season tour of Northern Ireland yesterday after straining ligaments in his right ankle in an accidental collision with the Glentoran goalkeeper on Thursday.

Newcastle's striker Temuri Ketsbaia will join Wolves for £900,000 on a two-year contract, subject to a medical and a work permit, but Wolves have had a £1m bid for the Nottingham Forest striker Marlon Harewood rejected.

Niall Quinn expects to finish his career at Sunderland after finalising the details of a new three-year contract.

The Leeds forward Harry Kewell may need an operation on a long-standing achilles problem and that would rule him out of the opening month of the season.

webTitle: Football: Jim White on amateur football enthusiasts.

fields.headline: A Herculean day with the Hellenic groundhoppers
fields.trailText: Magnificent news for die-hard masochists everywhere. To mark the start of the Hellenic League season, a groundhoppers' day has been organised, taking in four local derbies in the space of a mere 10 hours.
fields.body:
Magnificent news for die-hard masochists everywhere. To mark the start of the Hellenic League season, a groundhoppers' day has been organised, taking in four local derbies in the space of a mere 10 hours.

On the August bank holiday, fans of football not so much at the base of the pyramid as down in the foundations can revel in the kick and rush. They can start at Penn & Tyler's Green against Chalfont Wasps at 11am, move on to Kidlington against Headington Amateurs at 2pm, join the throng heading for Carterton Town v North Leigh at 5.30 before ending up at Didcot Town v Abingdon United at 7.45pm. All for the paltry outlay of £9.50. A four-match pass can be obtained by sending a cheque and SAE to the league's general secretary, Brian King, at 3 Queen's Road, Carterton, Oxfordshire, OX18 3YF, Tel: 01993 212738. The price includes a programme at every game.

The league is sponsored by the eccentric pop label Cherry Red records, which launched acts such as Everything But The Girl and the Dead Kennedys on an unsuspecting public.

The label's founder, Iain McNay, incidentally, is a Wimbledon supporter. But he will be spurning the Dons' fixture against Preston that day to take advantage of the ludicrously cheap mini-season ticket and anticipates attending every match. Wants to watch some decent football for a change, presumably.

fields.headline: South Africa gives up on 2006
fields.trailText: South Africa has dropped its legal action against Fifa over the award of the 2006 World Cup to Germany, apparently confident of being given the 2010 finals instead.
fields.body:
South Africa has dropped its legal action against Fifa over the award of the 2006 World Cup to Germany, apparently confident of being given the 2010 finals instead.

The South Africans were preparing to take Fifa to the Swiss civil courts after their request for arbitration on the result of last month's vote was rejected on Thursday.

But after consultation with the Confederation of African Football (CAF) they have withdrawn their court action. "For us the case is now closed," said Irvin Khoza, the vice-president of the South African Football Association.

The decision was almost certainly swayed by Fifa's announcement that World Cups will be rotated from 2010. Privately the South Africans are confident their continent will be awarded the 2010 tournament and feel their country has the best chance of being selected.

The remarks yesterday of Uefa's chief executive Gerhard Aigner sounded positive for their cause. He said the Uefa president Lennart Johansson "feels that it is then the turn certainly for Africa" and added: "I think almost everyone in the football world wants this."

South Africa controversially lost the July 6 vote to Germany 12-11 when the New Zealand delegate Charles Dempsey abstained despite being mandated by his federation to support South Africa.

Khoza said the CAF president Issa Hayatou had advised that "for the good of the game it is important for us to shelve the issue". He added: "We think we have to concentrate now on 2010."

webTitle: To be or not to be an Addick

fields.headline: To be or not to be an Addick
fields.standfirst: The women's double winners technically no longer exist, writes  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.trailText: Anyone tuning in for the women's Charity Shield at Craven Cottage tomorrow could be forgiven for being a little confused given that the match is between Arsenal, who by rights should not have qualified, and Charlton Athletic, who do not really exist.
fields.body:
Anyone tuning in for the women's Charity Shield at Craven Cottage tomorrow could be forgiven for being a little confused given that the match is between Arsenal, who by rights should not have qualified, and Charlton Athletic, who do not really exist.

First the simple bit. The north Londoners finished only third in the Premier League last season and therefore the Doncaster Belles, who finished second, should have been playing instead. Curiously though, the Belles were not invited to take part, apparently for "commercial reasons".

And yet Arsenal's opponents tomorrow did not even compete in last season's Premier League; indeed they were only formed in June. For the past six years the Charlton Athletic women's team was in fact Croydon. As Croydon, they did the league and cup double last season for the second time in six years, making them the most successful English women's team in the history of the game.

But on June 9, at the club's annual general meeting, the players dropped a bombshell on the club's committee by announcing that they wanted to become Charlton Athletic and affiliate with the Premiership club.

It was a bit like Manchester United players voting to become Liverpool, against their board's wishes, and summarily moving to Merseyside. The motion was carried by 17 votes to three (plus four abstentions) and Charlton Athletic women's team was born.

"It came as a bit of a shock and I was very disappointed," said the former Croydon chairman Ken Jarvie. "The players said that they wanted better facilities, funding and training but we have been giving them the best. That's why Croydon is the top women's team in the country."

Two weeks after the agm, however, the Football Association dropped its own bombshell. In a letter to the club, football's governing body said that, under the rules, all that had been achieved at the meeting was a change of name - Croydon had merely become Charlton. The club could not affiliate nor have any connection with its Premiership counterpart, while the chairman and the committee would remain the same, as would the club's business address in Croydon.

"It's a strange position to be in," said Jarvie, who is technically now chairman of Charlton Athletic women's team and plans to attend tomorrow's match. "The FA have told the team that they can have no association with Charlton Athletic at the Valley. I find myself as chairman of a club where the players have been disloyal and don't want anything to do with Croydon. They were happy to play under our banner last season; now they say there are major problems with it."

Adding to the sense of farce, the Premier League fixtures for next season have been published with Charlton appearing as Croydon, but it is still unclear whether or not the team will even be allowed to wear the Addicks' red kit in tomorrow's match.

The club's player-manager Debbie Brampton has resigned, admitting that she might have stayed on had the club remained as Croydon, and her former players have demanded an emergency general meeting where a vote will be taken on full-time affiliation with Charlton Athletic. In the meantime, and against FA guidelines, they are using Charlton's facilities and coaches at the club's training ground.

The former Croydon players are following the lead of the BS Kestrels, who were promoted to the Premier League last season and have since affiliated with Sunderland. They claim that they want to join with Charlton in the best interests of the club because the nature of women's football is changing.

The FA has already announced that it wants a professional women's league by 2003. Fulham recently became the first club to have an all-professional women's side, with 16 players offered full-time contracts.

"It's been a bit of farce but we want to affiliate with Charlton for long-term benefit," said the captain Gill Wylie. "It's vital that the game is run more professionally. That does not mean that all women players have to be professional, but we have to look at how we run our game. We have to follow the American model and see how they have done it.

"We are already benefiting from being connected with Charlton. We have good facilities, excellent coaches and have also got a reserve team. Most women's clubs now want to be connected with bigger men's clubs."

"The top clubs are getting more serious. It's not just about a bunch of women forming a club for fun," said Jennifer O'Neill, editor of the women's football magazine On the Ball."We have to ensure that the level of football remains high so that media interest continues and that's why we have to welcome affiliations with men's clubs."

The England midfielder Gemma Hunt added: "The difference is massive. We even get our own kits washed and don't have to pay subs each week. We are attracting better players and this will benefit the development of our club."

webTitle: Injustice as gay couples are denied equal rights

fields.headline: Injustice as gay couples are denied equal rights
fields.standfirst: Millions of people are being penalised for being homosexual or unmarried at the one of most vulnerable points in their lives: when their long-term partner has just died. Lesley Curwen outlines the latest attempts to change Britain's unfair system
fields.trailText: Millions of people are being penalised for being homosexual or unmarried at the one of most vulnerable points in their lives: when their long-term partner has just died. Lesley Curwen outlines the latest attempts to change Britain's unfair system.
fields.body:
On the tube train to Heathrow, a couple of people stole a curious glance at Ron Strank as he talked to me about his lack of financial rights, as a gay man. Three hours later, on the airport train into Centraal Station in Amsterdam, no one even blinked at a similar conversation. It's symptomatic of the difference in attitude in the two capitals. Less obvious is the tangible difference in the financial treatment of individuals who live as couples, outside marriage.

Sixty-seven-year-old Ron and his partner Roger Fisher recently celebrated their 40th anniversary together. Each has an NHS pension, but neither would inherit any benefits from the pension scheme if the other member of the couple dies first. That's because the NHS pension scheme recognises only a spouse as eligible for a survivor's pension, and that means a husband or wife.

None of the UK's public sector pension schemes provides partners' pensions, though a programme being broadcast today on Radio 4 outlines how the situation is now changing for many company pensions. Ron only discovered his predicament after a casual conversation with a friend. "My reaction," he said, "Was one of disbelief, and surprise at myself, because I thought I was fairly sophisticated about these things."

Ron or Roger would also be subject to inheritance tax if one of them dies and leaves the other more than £234,000; married partners who leave money and property to each other are exempt from this tax. Of course, their financial problems don't just affect gay couples. Greater numbers of heterosexual couples are in the same boat, though they do at least have a choice of taking the obvious solution - a walk down the aisle.

Ron and Roger don't have that option. Neither do gay couples in the Netherlands, but there the law takes a very different view of relationships outside marriage. Ron travelled there to see what life is like under such a legal system and to meet a lesbian couple, Jeanette Drost and Jeanine van der Sanden, who live in Haarlem.

They explained to Ron that they had gone to a solicitor to draw up an agreement, recognised under Dutch law. That means that each would be entitled to benefits from the other's pension schemes and, since they could prove they had lived together for five years, they would be subject to a reduced rate of inheritance tax, the same regime that applies to married couples. They were outraged when they heard Ron and Roger had no such protection under British law. "You're paying as much as the next guy or woman, you should get the same rights," says Jeanine. "It's a great injustice."

Jeanette and Jeanine could have taken another route to protect their finances. Since 1998, gay and straight couples in the Netherlands have been able to record their relationships in a register, a process very similar to marriage, but according to Jeanette, "not so romantic". This confers all the legal benefits of marriage. But the two women are waiting for another change in the law. They want to have a white wedding when gay marriage becomes legal in the Netherlands, a move expected next year.

Back in Britain, we took Ron to the public sector union Unison to see Glyn Jenkins, its senior pensions officer. Ron was hoping that there might be changes in sight in the way public sector pension schemes operate. Glyn Jenkins said the NHS scheme is under review and ministers will look at proposals for partners' pensions next year. What shape would reform take in the big public sector schemes for teachers, civil servants and health workers?

It's expected that revised pension schemes might be set up for staff who are still working, which would offer survivors' pensions for unmarried partners. However, the government has hinted it will do so only if members of the schemes bear the extra cost involved, which might mean they would have to pay a larger proportion of their salaries into the pension scheme.

Glyn Jenkins argues that partner's pensions won't cost the public purse any extra because past actuarial assumptions had forecast that the vast majority of us would marry. Glyn estimates that, in fact, 30%-40% of members of these schemes now live outside marriage, meaning that benefits for partners would not bring additional costs.

Would partners' pensions be implemented for retired staff like Ron? Glyn Jenkins admitted that would be a hard battle to fight and win.

Ron was philosophical. But he decided to try one more tack - to see a civil liberties lawyer. He talked to Di Luping at Liberty. She looked at his details and told him Liberty would consider taking on his case for discrimination to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg or here in the UK, under the new Human Rights Act which comes into force in October. But it might take years to come to court and would be unlikely to help Ron and Roger themselves.

Ron was not put off. He concluded the biggest battle was to wake up millions of people, gay and straight, to the financial problems they might meet at the most vulnerable time in their lives.

 Inside Money, Radio 4, 12 noon today, repeated on Monday August 7 at 3pm.

Each has an NHS pension, but neither would inherit any benefits from the pension scheme if the other member of the couple dies first. That's because the NHS pension scheme recognises only a spouse as eligible for a survivor's pension, and that means a husband or wife. None of the UK's public sector pension schemes provides partners' pensions, though a programme being broadcast today on Radio 4 outlines how the situation is now changing for many company pensions. Ron only discovered his predicament after a casual conversation with a friend. "My reaction," he said, "Was one of disbelief, and surprise at myself, because I thought I was fairly sophisticated about these things." Ron or Roger would also be subject to inheritance tax if one of them dies and leaves the other more than £234,000; married partners who leave money and property to each other are exempt from this tax. Of course, their financial problems don't just affect gay couples. Greater numbers of heterosexual couples are in the same boat, though they do at least have a choice of taking the obvious solution - a walk down the aisle. Ron and Roger don't have that option. Neither do gay couples in the Netherlands, but there the law takes a very different view of relationships outside marriage. Ron travelled there to see what life is like under such a legal system and to meet a lesbian couple, Jeanette Drost and Jeanine van der Sanden, who live in Haarlem. They explained to Ron that they had gone to a solicitor to draw up an agreement, recognised under Dutch law. That means that each would be entitled to benefits from the other's pension schemes and, since they could prove they had lived together for five years, they would be subject to a reduced rate of inheritance tax, the same regime that applies to married couples. They were outraged when they heard Ron and Roger had no such protection under British law. "You're paying as much as the next guy or woman, you should get the same rights," says Jeanine. "It's a great injustice." Jeanette and Jeanine could have taken another route to protect their finances. Since 1998, gay and straight couples in the Netherlands have been able to record their relationships in a register, a process very similar to marriage, but according to Jeanette, "not so romantic". This confers all the legal benefits of marriage. But the two women are waiting for another change in the law. They want to have a white wedding when gay marriage becomes legal in the Netherlands, a move expected next year. Back in Britain, we took Ron to the public sector union Unison to see Glyn Jenkins, its senior pensions officer. Ron was hoping that there might be changes in sight in the way public sector pension schemes operate. Glyn Jenkins said the NHS scheme is under review and ministers will look at proposals for partners' pensions next year. What shape would reform take in the big public sector schemes for teachers, civil servants and health workers? It's expected that revised pension schemes might be set up for staff who are still working, which would offer survivors' pensions for unmarried partners. However, the government has hinted it will do so only if members of the schemes bear the extra cost involved, which might mean they would have to pay a larger proportion of their salaries into the pension scheme. Glyn Jenkins argues that partner's pensions won't cost the public purse any extra because past actuarial assumptions had forecast that the vast majority of us would marry. Glyn estimates that, in fact, 30%-40% of members of these schemes now live outside marriage, meaning that benefits for partners would not bring additional costs. Would partners' pensions be implemented for retired staff like Ron? Glyn Jenkins admitted that would be a hard battle to fight and win. Ron was philosophical. But he decided to try one more tack - to see a civil liberties lawyer. He talked to Di Luping at Liberty. She looked at his details and told him Liberty would consider taking on his case for discrimination to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg or here in the UK, under the new Human Rights Act which comes into force in October. But it might take years to come to court and would be unlikely to help Ron and Roger themselves. Ron was not put off. He concluded the biggest battle was to wake up millions of people, gay and straight, to the financial problems they might meet at the most vulnerable time in their lives.  Inside Money, Radio 4, 12 noon today, repeated on Monday August 7 at 3pm.

webTitle: Leader: debate not vigilantism is needed in response to paedophiles

fields.headline: After the vigilantes
fields.standfirst:
There is no easy response to paedophiles
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The scene played out in Portsmouth in the early hours of yesterday morning will have stirred oddly mixed feelings. A first reaction may have been revulsion at the sight of a lynch mob of 150, surrounding the home of a man, overturning and torching a car, apparently demanding his neck. There is something primitive about a baying crowd, driven by a lust for vigilante, string-'em-up justice
fields.body:
The scene played out in Portsmouth in the early hours of yesterday morning will have stirred oddly mixed feelings. A first reaction may have been revulsion at the sight of a lynch mob of 150, surrounding the home of a man, overturning and torching a car, apparently demanding his neck. There is something primitive about a baying crowd, driven by a lust for vigilante, string-'em-up justice. And yet, some may well have understood the crowd's anger: they were furious to discover they have a child molester living among them. Some were parents, anxious for the fate of their children. They saw what happened to Sarah Payne, the eight-year-old girl killed last month, and they do not want their child to be next. In their view, the News of the World had peformed a service with its week-by-week roll-call of paedophiles, warning people of the threat in their midst.

The paper's decision to drop its drive to "name and shame", announced last night, gives us all a chance to reflect on what can be done to reconcile these conflicting emotions. Clearly, random vigilante publishing was not the answer. If its objective was the protection of children, then it simply failed. In fact it served the opposite purpose, driving paedophiles underground, where neither police nor probation services could keep track of them. Already the relevant agencies have told of convicted sex offenders, once under their watch, who have now moved off-radar. That has increased the risk to children, not reduced it. It is only a pity the News of the World took so long to realise it.

There was a second danger posed by naming and shaming. As the police themselves pointed out, it created new criminals and new victims. The new offenders were the torchbearers gathered in Portsmouth yesterday. Some were obviously louts, glad for an excuse to make trouble, but some were people who would otherwise abide by the law, suddenly drawn into an overheated situation. The new class of victims are those people mistakenly branded paedophiles and hounded as a result. Police have had to give protection to at least three men wrongly persecuted as child abusers, all thanks to confusion over the NoW list. It is a relief that this kind of mayhem will not be repeated in tomorrow's paper.

The News of the World insists it has not caved in, but rather "just begun" its campaign to protect children. It wants legislation modelled on America's Megan's Law to be adopted over here, a new Sarah's Law, establishing a public register of sex offenders which anybody could look at. The Payne parents support the idea, but even here we need to proceed carefully. Information on a register could well spark just the kind of vigilantism on display in Portsmouth; it could also become out of date or confused and lead to more cases of mistaken identity. The 43 police forces of England and Wales already have a register and Home Office figures suggest 97% of ex-offenders comply with it. In America, the more public Megan's Law has reportedly achieved a compliance rate of just 85%.

Bolder proposals are also under discussion. One ex-offenders' organisation and some unexpected voices on the left have called for indefinite custody for that category of child molester which seems driven by a near-irresistible urge to abuse children. Chemical castration to remove the impulse is the most extreme solution; permanent confinement for those deemed still to pose a threat is another. Either way, a debate is what is needed now, not a return to vigilantism - whether in Portsmouth or on the pages of the News of the World.
