fields.headline: Hollick to reshape United News
fields.standfirst:
New publishing and internet ventures could see television assets put up for sale
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Lord Hollick yesterday outlined his plans to reshape United News & Media around business publishing, market research, exhibitions and the internet, which may result in the sale of the group's remaining television assets.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick yesterday outlined his plans to reshape United News & Media around business publishing, market research, exhibitions and the internet, which may result in the sale of the group's remaining television assets.

The Labour peer was setting out his stall following the £1.75bn sale of the group's trio of ITV franchises to Granada Media last week.

The trimmed-down company will be clinging to the coat-tails of the FTSE 100 and Lord Hollick said it was now incumbent upon him to explain the value of the company to investors and to begin rebuilding through acquisitions.

Lord Hollick insisted that he would stay with the company despite the loss of its most high-profile assets.

"These are businesses that I have been involved in for 20 years - a lot longer than I was involved with TV - and they are businesses we engage in with a passion. They turn me and everyone else here on," he said. "The noise surrounding the TV assets has tended to crowd other parts of the business out."

United News' shares were marked 8p higher at 833p.

Of the remaining TV assets he said ITN - in which the company has a 20% stake - would likely float next year, giving United News the chance to sell.

Its stake in SDN, the digital channels that carry ONdigital's pay-per-view movie service would be sold to ONdigital once legislation allows.

The group's 35% stake in Channel 5 is expected to be bought by media group RTL, which owns the rest, although Lord Hollick said there had been no offer made so far. He spoke with some sadness for the first time about the failure of the company to win a place at the table in the consolidation of ITV.

United News had its plans to merge with Carlton Communications scuppered by competition authorities.

"It is with some regret that we didn't succeed in securing a leadership in ITV but either you are number one in that game or you are out," he said.

"But we gained a very high price for those assets and I think our shareholders are benefiting enormously."

He reiterated that the Express newspaper titles and the Daily Star are not for sale and claimed never to have met the Barclay Brothers, owners of the Scotsman and Sunday Business and often named as would-be buyers.

The well-worn argument of leveraging the brands online and using the papers for cross promotion were trotted out. The Daily Star may be ailing but Megastar, the newspaper's online version had 13.5m page impressions last month the company said.

The company also disclosed the £19.6m cost of its abandoned merger with Carlton.

United News reported a 14% increase in revenues for the first half of the year to £1.1bn and pre-tax profits flat at £138m.

webTitle: Leader: George Bush Jr still has a lot to prove

fields.headline: The pretend president
fields.standfirst:
Bush still has an awful lot to prove
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Young George W Bush's graduation speech in Philadelphia went as well as the grown-ups could have hoped. With his mum and dad looking proudly on, and with the old Pentagon hand, Dick Cheney, now assigned to loony right perimeter patrol, "Dubya" managed to sound serious for the serious bits, passionate and compassionate when the script demanded it, and even got a few laughs
fields.body:
Young George W Bush's graduation speech in Philadelphia went as well as the grown-ups could have hoped. With his mum and dad looking proudly on, and with the old Pentagon hand, Dick Cheney, now assigned to loony right perimeter patrol, "Dubya" managed to sound serious for the serious bits, passionate and compassionate when the script demanded it, and even got a few laughs. Crucially, he avoided the sort of bloopers that had led some to suggest earlier this year that he was merely the tolerably presentable, silver spoon-sucking, none-too-bright scion of a famous family who was running for president because, well, because his Pa expected him to. As Republicans know, it having been drummed into them remorselessly, this is exactly the sort of negative comment to which it is now deemed smarter not to respond. They were on their best, polite behaviour all week, as if following a route map to the moral high ground.

Bush the Younger steered well clear of mud-slinging on Thursday night, apart from the occasional, cheap chip-shot at Bill Clinton's oval office work experience programme. What he stood for, he declared, was "honour and dignity". Integrity would be good, too. He spoke of a "new era of responsibility" and, poking fun at Mr Clinton, tried hard to portray himself as a man of firm and settled convictions. "I do not need to take your pulse before I know my own mind. I do not reinvent myself at every turn. I am not running in borrowed clothes." Some said Mr Bush looked tense during his speech, even "wooden", a word hitherto exclusively reserved for Al Gore, his Democratic rival. But it was, after all, his first, big national night out on his own. From the look on Barbara Bush's face, her boy had done well and for George that is one opinion that counts. If it had been a cadet school or police academy passing-out parade, he could have done a Tom Cruise and thrown his cap in the air. As it was, he grinned boyishly. That grin may become very familiar. It is not as big as Tony Blair's, but at least it is not frightening like Mr Gore's. With politically incorrect pollsters calculating the "swoon factor" and Mr Bush now bouncing ahead of the Democrat by 6% among women voters and 14% overall, he could be smirking at us for the next eight years. So it appears there is no choice but to take him seriously. And therein lies the problem.

Mr Bush's address, like almost the whole preceding four-day convention, was as substance-free as a rehab clinic. For those who will insist on dwelling on "issues", there were promises to cut taxes, boost literacy, bolster social security and health provision, and tighten anti-abortion laws. Mr Bush reaffirmed his intention to launch upon the world a new generation of tactical and strategic defensive missiles, no matter what the Russians, Chinese (and America's Nato allies) may say. But at the same time, he and other keynote speakers, apparently unaware of the contradiction, railed against the very administration whose economic stewardship has made such lavish spending programmes possible.

They condemned Mr Clinton's lack of foreign policy focus, but said little about how they would handle the real, current challenges of fair trade, debt relief, peacemaking, and multilateral intervention (though they are adamant that US troops will never serve under UN command). While accusing the Democrats of squandering the opportunities presented by almost a decade of prosperity, Mr Bush (and Condoleezza Rice, his likely national security adviser) squandered the chance to reassure allies that they would steady the Republican lurch towards America First neo-isolationism. The nominee, ritually positioning himself as a Washington outsider, pledged to renew bipartisan politics, ignoring the fact that it was the party whose standard he now carries which wilfully smashed congressional consensus in the mid-1990s, culminating in its polarising impeachment vendetta against Mr Clinton.

But to concentrate on policy is to miss the whole thrust of this week's glitzy-tawdry Philadelphia stage performance. It would be like reviewing The Graduate without noticing that Jerry Hall has taken her clothes off. Rehabilitation is indeed the name of the game for a Republican party which drank deep of the politics of division after its 1992 defeat, which over-indulged in the heady iconoclasm of Newt Gingrich and the noxious nationalism of Pat Buchanan, and which got high (but no nearer to God or the electorate) on the prating dogmas of the evangelical Christian right. By patronising ethnic minorities, by groping for women voters, by their sudden discovery of "inclusion", and by their unconvincing charge to the middle ground, the GOP's leaders have sought to make amends, to show that they are now clean, sober, and ready to rule. But slogans, spin and an expedient, platform-imposed unity do not render these 12-step Republicans believable or trustworthy. And the pretend president, George Bush Junior, has yet to show that he is a man of substance.

webTitle: UK air firm linked to sanctions buster for rebels in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: UK air firm linked to sanctions buster
fields.standfirst:
Former Russian partner accused of supplying arms to African rebels

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: A leading British air charter company, which has been flying supplies into Sierra Leone for the UN and the British army, had a two-year business partnership with a Russian named as the principal sanctions buster for rebel forces in both Sierra Leone and Angola.
fields.body:
A leading British air charter company, which has been flying supplies into Sierra Leone for the UN and the British army, had a two-year business partnership with a Russian named as the principal sanctions buster for rebel forces in both Sierra Leone and Angola.

Air Foyle of Luton, Bedfordshire, worked with Victor Bout, a former KGB officer, through its South African agency, Norse Air Charter, from June 1996 until Bout fled the country in May 1998 after the South African authorities suspected him of smuggling.

Run by Christopher Foyle, the nephew of the late bookshop owner, Christina Foyle, Air Foyle said it was taken in by Bout and insisted that it broke no international or national laws.

Bout, along with other sanctions busters, was named in the House of Commons in January by the foreign minister, Peter Hain, who accused him of smuggling arms to Unita in Angola.

Under parliamentary privilege Mr Hain repeated the allegations in June, adding that Bout was also supplying the Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone. Last week Mr Hain added in a written answer: "There can be no excuse for any state to provide support for Bout in his continuing flouting of UN sanctions."

In March the UN committee monitoring Angolan sanctions said that, in exchange for diamonds, Bout's planes had smuggled embargoed supplies to Unita from South African airports and arms from Bulgaria.

Ironically, in the same month, UN Pakistani peacekeepers were flown to East Timor on one of his transporters. A UN spokeswoman said the contract to move the troops had been handled entirely by the Pakistani air force.

Bout's fleet of about 20 ex-Soviet Antonov and Ilyushin aircraft, operating under the name Air Cess, is now based in Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates and registered in various African countries where he has set up associated cargo companies.

Bruce Bird, head of Air Foyle's cargo operations, said: "It is a regrettable feature of doing business with companies and individuals of the former Soviet Union that one is never quite sure what they are up to.

"Victor presented himself to all of us as a reputable business person. I had a lengthy conversation with him in South Africa and he appeared to be a sensible, practical person who understood the business. We were not aware that Bout was under any suspicion until it was reported in the papers."

Bout's operations first attracted suspicion when his Liberian-registered aircraft were based at Ostend airport in Belgium in 1995. He left Ostend in 1997 after a UN and Belgian investigation into allegations that a number of elderly Russian planes were supplying arms to the extremists responsible for the Rwandan genocide.

But by that time he had also set up business in southern Africa and the Gulf.

On June 1 1996 Air Cess registered a joint venture company in South Africa with Norse Air called Pietersberg Aviation Services Systems (Pty) Ltd, trading as Air Pass. Holding 90% of the shares, Bout became a director with Deirdre Ward, owner of Norse Air, which has been Air Foyle's agent for about seven years. Mrs Ward became managing director and took a 10% shareholding.

Bout's large planes gave Norse Air a big boost. In June 1997 it announced that it had been awarded an ungraded air charter licence. In September that year Air Pass was officially launched at a reception in Johannesburg.

"We attended a very enjoyable launch party for Air Pass, which was attended by all and sundry in the SA aviation community including, I believe, government officials and regulators," Mr Bird said.

Mrs Ward at first denied she was anything more than a broker for Bout's aircraft. When presented with the company records, she said she had been managing director of Air Pass for a year. "Victor made the decisions as owner/chairman, and I merely looked after the operation while he was away," she said.

In her first interview with the Guardian, Mrs Ward said: "Bout didn't have an operating licence and we did, and we were short of aeroplanes. We introduced customers to him, mainly mining houses. He was very intelligent, very personable.

"We realised he may have been up to no good elsewhere, but every flight that left here was checked by immigration, customs, the border police, the normal police and a dog called Rex. Nothing illegal ever left on a flight under my control. It was only after he left that I was told Interpol was looking for him."

Air Foyle has been the worldwide sales agent for the Antonov company in Kiev for 10 years. It recently shipped British helicopters to flood-stricken Mozambique and helped Richard Branson to move his Global Explorer balloon to Morocco two years ago. The MoD is one of its principal customers, although it failed this year to secure the contract for the RAF's short-term strategic airlift.

Bout did not reply to the Guardian's fax or email.

Bout's fleet of about 20 ex-Soviet Antonov and Ilyushin aircraft, operating under the name Air Cess, is now based in Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates and registered in various African countries where he has set up associated cargo companies. Bruce Bird, head of Air Foyle's cargo operations, said: "It is a regrettable feature of doing business with companies and individuals of the former Soviet Union that one is never quite sure what they are up to. "Victor presented himself to all of us as a reputable business person. I had a lengthy conversation with him in South Africa and he appeared to be a sensible, practical person who understood the business. We were not aware that Bout was under any suspicion until it was reported in the papers." Bout's operations first attracted suspicion when his Liberian-registered aircraft were based at Ostend airport in Belgium in 1995. He left Ostend in 1997 after a UN and Belgian investigation into allegations that a number of elderly Russian planes were supplying arms to the extremists responsible for the Rwandan genocide. But by that time he had also set up business in southern Africa and the Gulf. On June 1 1996 Air Cess registered a joint venture company in South Africa with Norse Air called Pietersberg Aviation Services Systems (Pty) Ltd, trading as Air Pass. Holding 90% of the shares, Bout became a director with Deirdre Ward, owner of Norse Air, which has been Air Foyle's agent for about seven years. Mrs Ward became managing director and took a 10% shareholding. Bout's large planes gave Norse Air a big boost. In June 1997 it announced that it had been awarded an ungraded air charter licence. In September that year Air Pass was officially launched at a reception in Johannesburg. "We attended a very enjoyable launch party for Air Pass, which was attended by all and sundry in the SA aviation community including, I believe, government officials and regulators," Mr Bird said. Mrs Ward at first denied she was anything more than a broker for Bout's aircraft. When presented with the company records, she said she had been managing director of Air Pass for a year. "Victor made the decisions as owner/chairman, and I merely looked after the operation while he was away," she said. In her first interview with the Guardian, Mrs Ward said: "Bout didn't have an operating licence and we did, and we were short of aeroplanes. We introduced customers to him, mainly mining houses. He was very intelligent, very personable. "We realised he may have been up to no good elsewhere, but every flight that left here was checked by immigration, customs, the border police, the normal police and a dog called Rex. Nothing illegal ever left on a flight under my control. It was only after he left that I was told Interpol was looking for him." Air Foyle has been the worldwide sales agent for the Antonov company in Kiev for 10 years. It recently shipped British helicopters to flood-stricken Mozambique and helped Richard Branson to move his Global Explorer balloon to Morocco two years ago. The MoD is one of its principal customers, although it failed this year to secure the contract for the RAF's short-term strategic airlift. Bout did not reply to the Guardian's fax or email.

webTitle: Local hotels close doors to Somerset mayor

fields.headline: Hotels close doors to merry mayor
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The mayor of a genteel Somerset seaside resort has been barred from her two poshest local hotels.
fields.body:
The mayor of a genteel Somerset seaside resort has been barred from her two poshest local hotels.

Jacquie Richards, a Tory councillor who runs a mobile lavatory firm, admitted having overdone the hospitality at a twinning bash for German visitors, and then carrying on the celebrations around Burnham-on-Sea.

While her party nationally was getting ready to respond to the government's crackdown on drink and violence, Mrs Richards found herself barred from the Royal Clarence and Queen's hotels in the town on the Bristol Channel.

"She and her husband have been banned from all our premises," said Ray Hill, whose company, Newstead Investments, owns the hotels. "At the end of the day we are licensees, and we have to control things, whether you are prime minister or mayor."

Mrs Richards caused the civic stir after attending a reception for twin-town visitors from Fritzlaar last Saturday night, continuing with the festivities at the Royal Clarence with her husband.

Mr Hill said that the couple were marched out by doormen after allegedly abusing staff, but allegedly carried out a repeat performance the following evening, at the Queen's.

"I got them both into the kitchen and asked them to leave," said Mr Hill, "and I'll be writing to the Conservative party about what has happened. When people are in a position where others look up to them, they should be setting an example. I had been willing to forget what happened on Saturday night, but when they came back again and caused more trouble, that was unforgiveable. It was just obnoxious behaviour. They seemed to be picking trouble."

Mrs Richards said: "This is a completely private matter. We were merry, I don't mind admitting that - but the whole thing has been blown completely out of proportion."

Her colleagues, who hold all but one of the council's 18 seats, are expected to discuss the issue, but the deputy mayor, Louise Parkins, said yesterday: "I'm sure there must have been a misunderstanding one way or another."

Mrs Richards was elected to the town council in May 1999, and served a year as deputy mayor before accepting the top job.

Burnham Conservatives hold their monthly meetings at the Queen's hotel.

webTitle: How the sex offenders register works

fields.headline: The register
fields.standfirst:
How it works

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: There are now just over 12,000 people on the Home Office's register of convicted sex offenders. Since its introduction in September 1997, all sex offenders must lodge their name and address with local police within 14 days of being released from prison. This year, more than 97% of offenders complied.
fields.body:
There are now just over 12,000 people on the Home Office's register of convicted sex offenders. Since its introduction in September 1997, all sex offenders must lodge their name and address with local police within 14 days of being released from prison. This year, more than 97% of offenders complied.

Anyone jailed for 30 months or more is required to be on the register for life. Those with sentences of six to 30 months remain on the list for 10 years.

The register is kept on the police national computer and what the officers do with the information is entirely at their discretion. Police have, in the past, disclosed information on an individual basis based on risk assessment. There is a system for limited notification under which headteachers, doctors, youth leaders, sports club managers and others, including landlords, are notified on a confidential basis of the proximity of a local convicted sex offender.

The register holds not just the names of predatory paedophiles but of sex offenders including rapists and minor offenders such as flashers. The list shows that the fear of predatory paedophiles is far more widespread than the threat itself.

Peter Jones, assistant chief probation officer for Essex with responsibility for sex offender programmes, says a probation service typically supervises about 160 sex offenders. Two thirds of these offenders are in prison and about 50 are in the community at any one time.

Mr Jones estimates that of that number there are usually 10 high-risk offenders who take up a disproportionate amount of resources. He says: "A small proportion are snatchers or pouncers and they are the real predatory ones. I would say we are down to about three in that category."

The probation service, police, prison officers and other authorities are involved in risk assessment when an offender is due to be released back into the community.

"I would say that in the last three years we have made great strides in getting joint, cooperative working with other agencies," Mr Jones says. "We inform people on a need-to-know basis. Now, as a result of this campaign, we have offenders ringing us up in panic, some of whom haven't been supervised by us for years and who appear to be leading law-abiding lives."

Three men were jailed for life at the Old Bailey yesterday for battering a suspected paedophile to death.

William O'Kane was subjected to a "ferocious" attack and left dying on his bed in July last year after he was accused of sexual assault by a nine-year-old boy, the court was told.

Patrick Moran, 36, Daniel Greaney, 23,and Vincent Gill, 26, all from Wembley, north London, were convicted of murdering O'Kane.

webTitle: Mr Sloan is far from entertained

fields.headline: Mr Sloan is far from entertained
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Sean Sloan says this week's Barclays blunder has left him feeling a lot less confident about online banking. Mr Sloan, 32, was one of those who logged on to the bank's net service on Monday morning and suddenly found himself staring at another customer's account details, writes Rupert Jones .
fields.body:
Sean Sloan says this week's Barclays blunder has left him feeling a lot less confident about online banking. Mr Sloan, 32, was one of those who logged on to the bank's net service on Monday morning and suddenly found himself staring at another customer's account details, writes Rupert Jones .

"This someone had a business account and a personal account. I could see all the balances, account numbers and sort codes." He was able to see that the person had made a payment the day before for £13,000. The screen also offered a number of options such as transferring funds or making payments.

"I realised Barclays must have made a mistake. The first thing I wanted to do was get out of there - if funds did go missing from this account, I didn't want to be blamed for it. So I got out," says Mr Sloan, of Tottenham, north London, a director of a company called Snowchicken who works from home.

He ran downstairs and phoned Barclays' helpdesk - it was 8.30am. "I told them I was really concerned - if I can see someone else's details, what's stopping someone seeing my details and transferring funds?" He was told someone would phone him back. But despite ringing again, by mid-afternoon he had still heard nothing. When he mentioned the BBC had been round to film him for that night's news, the bank's head of online banking called back and couldn't apologise enough.

He says Barclays should have shut the service down sooner. He adds: "I enjoy online banking - it saves me standing in queues. But this has put doubts in my mind. If it can happen once, what's to stop it happening again?"

The bank says: "Our service is safe. We have not had these problems before. We invest a lot in our security systems and are committed to ensuring this does not happen again."

webTitle: Test tapes fuel cathedral choirs' battle of the sexes

fields.headline: Test tapes fuel cathedral choirs' battle of the sexes
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Research to be outlined at a conference beginning today is likely to fuel the controversy over whether girls should sing in Britain's cathedral choirs.
fields.body:
Research to be outlined at a conference beginning today is likely to fuel the controversy over whether girls should sing in Britain's cathedral choirs.

Some cathedrals, including Salisbury and Winchester, have recruited girls but do not let them sing alongside boys. Others, including Manchester and St Mary's in Edinburgh, have created fully integrated choirs.

The sight of girls wearing surplices and invading choirstalls which for centuries have been hogged by boys has alarmed church music conservatives.

This weekend academics from all over the world will be told that many listeners to tapes can work out whether the treble line is being sung by girls or boys. Most of those tested thought girls "made a very acceptable sound".

David Howard of York University, who has worked on the project with his colleague John Szymanski, said the idea came from finding two CDs of the same material, one with the top line sung by girls and the other by boys, in Wells cathedral's shop.

A series of 20-second snippets was played to 190 listeners, aged between six and 70, who were asked if boys or girls were on top.

Professor Howard said: "62% identified the gender correctly. The results showed that adults did better than children, that girls did better than boys and that everyone could identify boys more regularly than girls."

Most of those questioned liked what they heard which led Prof Howard to conclude that much of the controversy over girls in choirs was based on factors other than the quality of the sound they made.

The research findings indicate that opposition to girls' voices is based not so much on aesthetics as on a deep-rooted conservatism about the role of women in church.

Prof Howard's paper is one of more than 250 to be given at the sixth international conference on music perception and cognition at Keele University, one of Britain's principal centres for the study of music and psychology.

One paper claims there is a scientific base to the "Mozart effect", whose supporters suggest that 10 minutes of a Mozart sonata is better preparation for certain kinds of tests than relaxation instructions or silence.

This may complement other research from Poland which found that background music may impede concentration, findings which could lead to concerned parents confiscating the hi-fis of children who claim they cannot do their homework without a rock serenade.

webTitle: News of the World relents over drive to shame

fields.headline: Paper relents over drive to shame
fields.standfirst:
U-turn follows mob attacks on suspected paedophiles

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The News of the World backed down on its campaign to name and shame paedophiles last night after condemnation from the police, the probation service and the Home Office.
fields.body:
The News of the World backed down on its campaign to name and shame paedophiles last night after condemnation from the police, the probation service and the Home Office.

The newspaper was told that its tactics put children's safety at risk and would prompt paedophiles to go underground.

The u-turn over its controversial promise to name 110,000 sex offenders followed a number of vigilante attacks on alleged offenders and on innocent men misidentified as paedophiles.

The newspaper had used the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne to justify revealing the names and locations of convicted sex offenders. Its campaign was supported by her parents, Michael and Sara, but the couple did not attend yesterday's conference.

The News of the World couched its turnaround in victorious terms saying it had received the backing of a number of agencies for its proposal for "Sarah's law", which would allow parents "controlled access" to the sex offenders' register.

But Chief Constable Tony Butler, the head of the Association of Chief Police Officers, said his organisation and other agencies were "bailing the News of the World out". He said his organisation backed controlled access.

Gill Mackenzie of the Association of Chief Officers of Probation said: "The probation service is really delighted that the naming and shaming campaign has ceased."

Since the newspaper began its campaign almost three weeks ago five men have been targeted by vigilante groups. Iain Armstrong, 49, a father of three from Bradford, Greater Manchester, was attacked in his home after people mistook took him for a paedophile.

On Wednesday Michael Horgan, 55, of Lewisham, south London, became the innocent victim of the campaign group Antimatter, which sent 500 letters to his neighbours.

Victor Terry, 78, from Croydon, south London, was also targeted by Antimatter, which had confused him with a paedophile of the same name. Letters giving his name and address and warning people with children to be on their guard were sent to about 300 households near his home.

The most violent incident occurred on Thursday night, when more than 150 people attacked the Portsmouth flat of Victor Burnett. Rioters hurled stones and overturned and torched a car. Mr Burnett, who was convicted in February 1989 of being part of Britain's biggest known child sex ring - has now disappeared.

Last night Gerald Baker, of Onslow Village, near Guildford, said he had received a malicious letter on July 30 and neighbours were sent a similar letter telling them he had been identified by the paper. But police confirmed he merely had the same name.

The News of the World's editor, Rebekah Wade, was not at last night's press conference but the paper's managing editor, Stuart Kuttner, admitted there had been threats to staff since the campaign began. He said the paper had taken "extensive and lasting security measures".

The National Association Rehabilitation of Offenders welcomed the news that the "folly" was over. Its spokesman Paul Cavadino said: "During the past few weeks, the naming and shaming campaign has contributed to an atmosphere in which lawlessness has flourished, innocent members of the public have been targeted by vigilantes and defenders have gone to ground fearing reprisals.

"In all it has done considerable damage and subjected some unfortunate members of the public to truly terrifying ordeals."

fields.headline: Cyberspace frees Iran's rebel cleric
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: When Iran's leading dissident, Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, was exiled to the desert by the shah 25 years ago, 30,000 followers made the arduous pilgrimage to visit him. When he was imprisoned, his theology students issued underground bulletins containing his latest religious decrees.
fields.body:
When Iran's leading dissident, Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, was exiled to the desert by the shah 25 years ago, 30,000 followers made the arduous pilgrimage to visit him. When he was imprisoned, his theology students issued underground bulletins containing his latest religious decrees.

Now he is under house arrest in the republic he helped to create, confined since 1997 to his home and garden in the holy city of Qom. And he is using modern methods of breakout of his seclusion.

His website offers everything from a portrait of him standing on a scenic hilltop with his cane to his latest declarations on politics and religion.

At www.montazeri.com you can also find photographs of the his office after hardline thugs broke in. Smeared on the wall is a slogan describing him as "a heretic of the age".

The site is entirely in Farsi, and the photos can be difficult to see on some computers. Even so, the counter shows over 18,000 visits since the ayatollah discovered cyberspace a few months ago.

"For nearly three decades, rulers have tried to silence him. But it's impossible," one of his long-standing disciples said.

The ayatollah's sense of irony is apparent on the net. He has included quotes from famous Iranian leaders who once praised him but are now responsible for his house arrest.

"I'm proud that such a person exists in the Islamic republic," reads a quote from Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

"Montazeri is a world class Islamic scholar," adds the former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.

Corresponding with the ayatollah - who was once in line to succeed Ayatollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic republic - is a simple matter.

A follower need only email him to ask his advice on a religious or political issue. One of his sons downloads the questions and groups them according to subject. Then the cleric, who carries the designation of marja-e taqlid, the highest religious authority in Shi'ite Islam, replies.

In conventional terms, Ayatollah Montazeri has been held almost incommunicado since he publicly questioned the religious credentials of Ayatollah Khamenei.

Only relatives are allowed to visit him. Guards are posted around the clock. His latest book, more than 1,000 pages long, is so hot that followers say that those who have copies are afraid to hold them for more than 24 hours.

"Technology has given him the freedom he has been denied for nearly three decades," said one supporter. "We don't think the authorities can pull the plug on his website, because they probably would have done so by now."

He has been ostracised for his views, including his opinion that political parties should be allowed and that the supreme leader should be elected in a national ballot rather than chosen by the assembly of experts, a body dominated by conservative clerics.

He has also criticised the establishment for distorting the constitution, which he helped to draft after the 1979 revolution, to give more power to the clerics and less power to the people.

fields.headline: Perfect way to clean up
fields.standfirst: Jane Frost has gone from selling soap to promoting the top soaps for the BBC. Patrick Collinson talked to her
fields.trailText: Newspaper editors begin careers covering golden weddings on local rags, chief police constables were once bobbies on the beat; for the BBC's head of corporate marketing, Jane Frost, it was trying to sell pink Shield toilet soap to an unconvinced public.
fields.body:
Newspaper editors begin careers covering golden weddings on local rags, chief police constables were once bobbies on the beat; for the BBC's head of corporate marketing, Jane Frost, it was trying to sell pink Shield toilet soap to an unconvinced public.

Ms Frost joined Lever Brothers from Cambridge University in 1978 as a trainee brand manager. "The chairman's wife thought pink was a rather nice colour, but the public didn't. We ended up sending 50 tons of the stuff to Africa, even though it was perfectly good soap."

Not that Ms Frost thinks that the lessons she learnt at Lever were wasted. "You don't get a better training in marketing than working at Lever. Look at Persil; it's been around 75 years and its brand is as strong as ever."

Now she's in charge of exploiting all the potential that is locked up in the BBC brand - which ranks alongside Coca-Cola and Nike as one of the most instantly recognised brands in every corner of the globe. But the switch from selling soap to selling BBC soaps only came after a long slog up the corporate brands ladder, taking in dishwasher liquid and Shell lubricants.

She switched to Shell, becoming head of marketing in the Middle East, in 1985 when her husband accepted a job in Dubai. At first things were tough. "I ran into persistent sexism wherever I went, even within Shell, which at that time refused to give married women the same entitlement to allowances as married men."

But she persevered and eventually won promotion to planning and marketing director for Shell across the whole of the Far East and Australasia. "Marketing is 90% common sense. The basic principles apply the same way in Saudi as in Sainsbury's," she says.

It was in the Middle East that she first tuned into the possibilities offered by the BBC. "All the decision makers listened to it. In marketing terms it meant that you couldn't sell US jelly [jam in British english] because they wanted marmalade instead. If you could have advertised on the BBC it would be worth a fortune."

Should we be worried that Ms Frost's job now is some sort of Birt-inspired plan to bring advertising to the BBC? True, she was headhunted in 1995 during the Birt era to bring Persil-style marketing disciplines to the BBC, and she reports directly to the Director General. But her chief task is to explain what the BBC is about - and help justify why we fork out £104 a year for a TV licence.

Perfect Day - the promotional video aimed at telling viewers what the BBC is about - was her big break. "We wanted to say that the BBC was a unique organisation. That if it disappeared, you'd really be losing something, and it deserves your support. It was about showing that the BBC can put together these stars, with this sort of quality, that it can surprise people and do something they really enjoy."

The project was not without risks. "Nobody had ever asked for a four-minute long promo to run across the BBC," she says. But David Bowie, Elton John and Lou Reed were among the stars who gave their time to the project for a payment of just £250, and in December 1997 it shot to the top of the charts, selling more than 2m copies and raising £2.5m for the Children in Need charity.

"Once we saw it, we all had faith in it and knew it was going to work. It became the anthem of the BBC. It was also wonderful to see other TV channels such as MTV having to carry our promotional video for free," she says. Its success led to the BBC picking up the Superbrand of the Year award in 1998, but Ms Frost admits that the lack of competition from ITV helped.

"It was good when ITV was still a very fragmented business; Granada is a bigger brand than ITV. But ITV is now getting smarter and picking up on our tricks."

Ms Frost's latest task is to market to other broadcasting companies the services of what was once called BBC Resources but which has been hived off and relaunched as BBC Technology Ltd.

"I know the BBC is not thought of as a technology company, but just think, for example, how we put together the Millennium night broadcast. That involved broadcasting from 60 countries. The private sector makes huge promises about what it can deliver, but often fails. What the BBC has is proven expertise. It's quite simple - it has to work or the BBC goes off the air."

fields.headline: Simon Bazalgette
fields.standfirst: Chief executive of Music Choice, Europe's largest digital broadcaster
fields.trailText: When did you first become a manager?
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

At Warwick University. I was part of a turnaround management team for the university radio station in the mid-80s.

What has been your best moment in management?

The best moment is always completing the next deal, such as signing with major music companies or with a satellite TV company like Sky.

What was your greatest mistake?

Playing in a free travellers festival as a member of an aspiring band. It was held in a field in Kent with the stage lighting provided by the headlights of a dilapidated double-decker bus.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Microsoft's deal when IBM let them own the PC operating system.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

The communications manager and her assistant insist on playing S Club 7 - apart from that, they are all great!

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

The top team at Music Choice is 60% male and 40% female, and the staff are pretty much 50/50 at all levels.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Being smart. Persistence is a much more powerful management quality.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

How do you match the expectations raised by instant communication via digital media with what can actually be delivered in the physical world?

What one lesson would you pass on to trainee managers?

Be persistent and take good advice.

Which management guru do you believe in?

I never totally believe in management gurus, but Stephen Covey's 7 Habits of Highly Effective People summarises the common sense in a very useable way.

Who is your management hero?

Seeing the Greg Dyke/Christopher Bland combo in action at LWT in the early 90s was an education.

Who is your favourite politician?

I am a great admirer of Tony Blair's management style, particularly his attempt to develop a clear vision and open communication.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

Come on you Bees, as in Brentford FC.

Apart from your family, what makes you happiest in life?

Music - particularly The Fall.

What annoys you most?

Bad music, or Brentford losing.

How do you relax?

Playing with my three children, or playing piano duets with my wife.

What is your favourite city?

London.

Do you have a favourite website?

Fast'n'Bulbous - it's a music recommendation site by a radio DJ called Uncle Fester.

What is your greatest regret?

Not spending more time as a musician.

What would you really like to have been?

I'd give it all up to be midfielder for Brentford.

webTitle: Leading the field in an e-commerce era

fields.headline: Leading the field in an e-commerce era
fields.standfirst: John Childress attributes recent catastrophic business setbacks to a failure to shed outdated leadership styles and adapt to the new e-world
fields.trailText: What is leadership all about anyway? While the subject - who has it, what is it, and how to develop it - has been researched and hotly debated for years in academia and business, in today's fast-moving and competitive business environment even the old lessons and learnings are turning out to be suspect.
fields.body:
What is leadership all about anyway? While the subject - who has it, what is it, and how to develop it - has been researched and hotly debated for years in academia and business, in today's fast-moving and competitive business environment even the old lessons and learnings are turning out to be suspect.

While the traditional elements of successful leadership success evolved in the industrial age, the internet age requires a new set of characteristics for success. And those not able to adapt often become casualties on the battlefield of the new economy.

While researching my book A Time for Leadership, I interviewed more than 60 European business leaders about their views on the skills required for success in 21st century Europe. I was surprised to find the traditional ingredients - solid chain-of-command communications, clear directions from the top, the CEO has the best perspective, the importance of solid rules and procedures to promote efficiency, and other traditional command-and-control leadership ingredients - taking a back seat to a more holistic leadership approach.

And the importance of corporate culture, a passionate focus on the customer, and the importance of teamwork at all levels seem to take precedence in today's web-driven, high-speed business world.

Here in the UK we have some revealing examples of once-successful leadership skills having passed their sell-by date. Take the recent decline of British Airways under Robert Ayling. Was he a bad leader? Not really, but he seemed an incomplete one. His financial and legal background and understanding of the finer points of the airline industry were excellent. He seemed like an outstanding choice at the time. But obviously not everything was in place.

Mr Ayling's blind spot (and we all have one) was a lack of understanding of the existing corporate culture of British Airways and that the airline business is, above all, a service industry. To alienate the prime givers of service - flight crews, cabin attendants, ground personnel and check-in staff - was simply a lack of understanding of the importance of this internal culture and a lack of passion for the welfare of the customer.

In the old days you could get it half right and still be a successful company. In today's marketplace, where the customer has greater choice and freedom to take their business elsewhere and where internal employees are no longer compelled to just "do what the boss says", Mr Ayling's leadership skills were only half right, and the company, its customers, and shareholders paid the price.

What about Marks & Spencer, once the icon of successful retailing? Was it poor leadership that brought it to a position of "used to be"? Not really. The problem with M&S was its own success.

The leadership of M&S failed to realise that the game was changing faster than they were. They had been held up as a model for aspiring organisations in books like In Search of Excellence by Peters and Waterman, published in the early 80s. Problem is, this is the 21st century and customers and competition are very different.

Senior managers at Marks & Spencer committed probably the biggest failing of leadership. They talked about change, but did not change themselves. Organisations tend to become shadows of their leaders. In other words, people take their clues about what is important to the business from the actual behaviour of the leaders, not their memos or speeches about the need to change.

It was business as usual at the top of the house while they were all talking about the need to change the business. In this case, it was important to change the leadership. If the world is dramatically different due to greater competition, the emergence of e-commerce and the internet and the changing needs of the customer, then it's obvious that the leaders of major companies should be changing as fast as the marketplace is changing.

Here I mean learning additional principles and skills of leadership in a vastly different marketplace. Can old dogs learn new tricks? Certainly, if they open their minds to the excitement of learning they once had as new managers or management trainees many years ago. We can all learn new ways of leading if we have the courage and commitment. That is the real challenge for this decade. Leadership, like beauty, is difficult to define but you know it when you see it.

 John Childress is the author of A Time for Leadership, Global Perspectives from an Accelerated European Market place, published by Leadership Press priced £14.99. Email: john.childress@uk.sdlcg.com

webTitle: The pieces at prices well worth checking

fields.headline: The pieces at prices well worth checking
fields.standfirst: Chess enthusiasts will flock to Sotheby's auction of rare and beautiful sets in September, predicts Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: One of the great managers of Liverpool football club, Bill Shankly, is reported to have said : "Football isn't a matter of life and death. It's far more important than that." Similarly, it seems, with chess. Long before the tantrums of modern chess players hit the headlines the game aroused strong passions.
fields.body:
One of the great managers of Liverpool football club, Bill Shankly, is reported to have said : "Football isn't a matter of life and death. It's far more important than that." Similarly, it seems, with chess. Long before the tantrums of modern chess players hit the headlines the game aroused strong passions.

Luke Honey, chess specialist at London auction house Phillips, likes to relate the story of the Kempleten automaton. Ostensibly a robot, it was the creation of Wolfgang Von Kempleten, an Austrian mechanic and inventor. He toured the royal courts of Europe in the late 18th century with his creation, which was also known as "the Turk". The machine played against Catherine the Great in Russia and Napoleon was said to have been reduced to fury when the robot beat him not once but three times.

The automaton, however, turned out to be a fake. There was a dwarf inside. The device was sold to an American collector and disappeared in a museum fire in 1926.

Chess is a game of great antiquity. It is thought to have started in the 6th century in India, although its origin has also been ascribed to Persia, Russia and China.

From earliest times the sets were a representation of war, devised by a king and his advisers and waged by pawns, the infantry. There have been a great variety of characters and characterisations. Napoleon and his marshals were models for sets, with Napoleon as king, Marshalls Ney and Massena as bishops and the Duke of Wellington the opposing king.

In India sets were made for export from the 18th century onwards. Craftsmen from places like Madras and Jaipur carved and painted ivory and horn figures depicting Indian princes and their forces ranged against East India Company sepoys. These became known as John Company sets.

Chess sets have been made of wood, ivory, pewter, precious metals like gold and silver, porcelain, including sets from Meissen, Doulton and Wedgwood; ebony, amber, ivory, bone, glass and even marble. Chess was always played on a board divided into squares, but by the end of the 15th century the board had become chequered, making play easier.

However, the bewildering array of materials and characters, together with constant rule changes, meant that by the middle of the 19th century it had become such a complex game that even the best players had trouble identifying the pieces. It was only in the 1840s that an English master, Howard Staunton, produced a design for the standard set we know today. These were usually made by the manufacturer John Jacques and became known as Jacques Staunton's.

Chess sets and literature are on sale everywhere, but well-known collections come up at auction only ocasionally. On Monday September 20 Christie's South Kensington is selling the Allen Hofrichter collection. Hofrichter, born in Austria, went to New York as a child. He opened a printing press in 1928 and during the 50s, and having established himself as an successful and innovative publisher, began seriously collecting chess sets as well as paintings and sculpture. The auction features 150 of his sets.

One of the characteristics of chess auctions is that there are very few dealers. They attract mainly collectors and enthusiasts. Nick McElhatton, specialist at Christie's, says: "There are a lot of chess collectors. It is a good field because the entry price is low - a few hundred pounds - and you can go as high as you like. This collection was put together between 1950 and 1970 so it is 30 years old. There will be interest in what was popular then."

The most expensive chess sets are 17th century German ones from Augsburg, made of amber with semi-precious stones. These rarely come on the market but can realise more than £100,000. None appear in this auction, but there are some interesting Indian items.

An Indian ivory John Company chess set dating from the early 19th century, featuring the British and Indian armies, is estimated to fetch £8,000 to £12,000. A Madras polychrome ivory set circa 1810, depicting warring Indian armies, could fetch up to £5,000. From the 20th century, a Royal Doulton pottery set featuring mice is estimated at £4,000 to £6,000.

These estimates, assuming they are met, would not show any great increase compared to, say, five years ago. But there has been great demand for Staunton's. Luke Honey at Phillips says that the bottom end of the market you would have paid £150 for a 19th century boxwood and ebony playing set. Last year they cost around £300. At Christie's a mahogany set is on offer at £800 to £1,200.

Staunton's can go up to £10,000 if made of ivory. But according to Mr Honey, demand for Staunton's has fallen off a little in the past year. "It is a market like everything else, and the great enthusiasm seems to have cooled a bit," he observes.

 For further information telephone Christie's: 020-7581-7611; Phillips: 020-7629-6602.

webTitle: Pressure builds on Yugoslavia to free western 'terrorists'

fields.headline: Pressure builds on Yugoslavia to free western 'terrorists'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia yesterday came under increasing pressure to release eight westerners, including two British police officers, accused of "terrorist actions" in Montenegro.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia yesterday came under increasing pressure to release eight westerners, including two British police officers, accused of "terrorist actions" in Montenegro.

Last night the Foreign Office said Yugoslav authorities had said the two Britons, Det Sgt Adrian Prangnell from Hampshire and Pc John Yore from Cambridgeshire, might be given access to British officials in Belgrade.

But Bob Gordon, Britain's representative in the Yugoslav capital, has been given no assurances about London's other demands - that it should be told where the men are detained, that they should be publicly charged or released, and that they should be allowed to call their families.

An FO spokesman said the decision to parade British citizens on television without any supporting evidence was "absolutely unacceptable".

The arrests are seen as a propaganda exercise in the run-up to federal elections in Serbia and the independence-minded republic of Montenegro on September 24. At its first pre-election rally last weekend, President Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party repeated its line that its opponents were servants of western saboteurs.

Det Sgt Prangnell's girlfriend, Wendy Priston, a fellow Hampshire police officer, yesterday said her partner was "just doing a police job which he thoroughly enjoys". He was a founder of the Cops for Kids charity in Kosovo, which raises money for local orphans, and has organised sponsored runs and discos.

A Hampshire officer said the detective had been involved in community liaison work in an attempt to build a multiracial police force in the province.

Pc Yore was described by a colleague as "a traffic officer for several years and very good at dealing with traumatic situations. He is experienced at keeping a cool head".

The pair were arrested with two Canadians near the Kosovo border after spending a long weekend at the Montenegrin resort of Sveti Stefan. They had been working at a police school in the Serb province run by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

The Canadians - Shaun Going and his nephew, Liam Hill - own Meridian Resources, a construction company operating in Kosovo.

Yugoslav state TV on Thursday showed footage of the four men and a few cables, a map of Kosovo, pocket knives and a pair of pliers, supposedly taken from them. On Monday Yugoslavia announced that four Dutchmen had been arrested in July for allegedly plotting to kill Mr Milosevic.

Benita Ferrero-Waldner, the Austrian foreign minister and current OSCE chair, requested that Yugoslavia grant consular authorities immediate access to the detained men.

The Canadian foreign ministry accused Belgrade of launching a campaign of intimidation against members of the reform movement and foreigners.

Montenegro's pro-western leadership has accused Mr Milosevic of arresting the men in an attempt to provoke a crisis. There is growing fear in western capitals that Mr Milosevic might attempt to topple the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, while the US is engrossed in its presidential election campaign.

The US and Britain are drawing up detailed contingency plans, including the possibility of military action. "It's fair to say that everything is on the table at this stage," a US state department official said.

fields.headline: Lock in a fair deal
fields.standfirst:
You can thwart gazumpers and gazunderers with a preliminary agreement says Richard Colbey

More about house prices
fields.trailText: The experiences related by Elizabeth Langton last week of how she had been gazundered when selling her home to buyers who reduced their offer on dubious pretexts will become increasingly familiar if the much-predicted property crash materialises.
fields.body:
The experiences related by Elizabeth Langton last week of how she had been gazundered when selling her home to buyers who reduced their offer on dubious pretexts will become increasingly familiar if the much-predicted property crash materialises.

The government, supposedly, has proposals in the pipeline to shorten the conveyancing process and reduce the opportunities for people to renege on offers. However, these well-intentioned proposals, which have been under discussion since 1997, are floundering because of the legal difficulties in regulating how individuals enter into private contracts.

Gazundering - and gazumping - can continue because until contracts are exchanged, neither party is legally bound to do anything. An offer - whether by prospective buyer or seller - is normally binding in honour only. People who would never do anything dishonourable for the sake of a small sum can quickly lose their scruples when they realise there is a saving of thousands of pounds, perhaps the equivalent of several months' tax-free salary, to be had.

But it is possible for buyers and sellers to protect themselves by insisting on a preliminary agreement, sometimes called a "lock out", as soon as an offer is made. The simplest form requires both buyer and seller to pay a deposit - typically around 2% of the agreed price - to be held jointly by their respective solicitors. If either reneges on the deal they will then forfeit that deposit.

The agreement under which the deposit is paid can specify the circumstances in which withdrawing from the sale or attempting to renegotiate the price is permitted. A survey showing substantial defects would obviously justify the buyer pulling out. The purchasers might also make their buying the house conditional upon obtaining a suitable mortgage offer.

However, where buyers have claimed that they already had such an offer, their asking for such a provision to be included would be suspicious, to say the least.

If the sellers do not complete the sale because they accept a higher offer from another source, it is clear that they will lose the deposit. The possibility of losing a deposit may also be a significant disincentive to buyers considering withdrawing their original offer and replacing it with a lower one.

If the sellers are desperate enough to accept that lower offer, they will probably also agree that the deposit isn't forfeited. However, if the sellers stand firm, the buyers face losing a house, which they presumably want to buy, as well as the deposit.

This form of agreement is sometimes varied to one - a true lock out - that prohibits the seller from offering the property to anyone other than the buyer for a specified period. This, though, doesn't provide the seller with any protection if the buyer later withdraws. Despite their having been approved by the Court of Appeal, some conveyancing solicitors are reluctant to use any form of preliminary agreement. Solicitors who dismiss their use completely, though, are likely to be doing so because they lack the technical skills to draw up an effective agreement.

Such agreements do make the process more complicated and time-consuming than it usually is, which can lead to the solicitor charging, justifiably, higher fees. Anyone entering into a house buying transaction in good faith may feel that is a small price to pay for the assurance that they cannot be cheated with impunity.

If the other party declines to make such an agreement, that could be because they are, as Elizabeth Langton suspected her buyers may have been, planning from the beginning to renege on their offer.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: In the lair of India's asthmatic bandit king

fields.headline: In the lair of India's asthmatic bandit king
fields.standfirst:
Fears grow for health of film star kidnapped by notorious outlaw

Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: Somewhere in the dense rolling forests of southern India a 72-year-old matinee idol with high blood pressure and weak knees was preparing last night to spend his fifth night in the hideaway of a deadly but asthmatic fugitive.
fields.body:
Somewhere in the dense rolling forests of southern India a 72-year-old matinee idol with high blood pressure and weak knees was preparing last night to spend his fifth night in the hideaway of a deadly but asthmatic fugitive.

In a recorded statement smuggled out of the forest and broadcast yesterday, the actor Rajkumar said he was being well treated by Veerappan, India's most notorious outlaw.

He added that the bandit king, who is wanted for more than 130 murders, was looking after him "like a brother", but urged the government to give in swiftly to his demands.

The message, delivered to officials on an audio cassette, was the first word from Rajkumar since he was abducted on Sunday from his isolated farmhouse in the village of Gajanur in Tamil Nadu, close to the border with Karnataka. Three male relatives were also seized.

Until then Veerappan had been lying low. It was rumoured that, at 60, he was tired, mildly depressed and generally fed up with his fugitive existence.

After almost 15 years of hiding in the impenetrable Satyamangalam forest, where he presides over a vast sandalwood and ivory smuggling empire, he is keen to cut a deal with the authorities, sources suggest.

On Wednesday a Tamil magazine editor set off into the jungle as an official emissary to ascertain the outlaw's demands. RR Gopal and three colleagues who accompanied him have been hampered by torrential rain and have yet to re-emerge.

Mr Gopal has met Veerappan twice in the past to secure the release of kidnap victims. Before he left on Wednesday he described how, on his last encounter with Veerappan in 1997, he was led by one of his henchmen through a series of checkpoints before reaching "a high point, with a drop of dizzying proportions".

"Suddenly a person materialised with a levelled rifle... and the person who was accompanying me had to yell, saying not to shoot. Anyway, he then lowered his gun and led me to his chief."

Veerappan was "shrewd and intelligent", he recalled. He was also said to be a master of junglecraft who could tell when a bird was flying out of fear.

The camp was tidy and well-appointed. Mr Gopal said he was astonished when, on his arrival, the bandit presented him with a clean toothbrush and toothpaste. He was given food supplied by sympathetic villagers.

Every morning Veerappan would ceremonially bless his weapons. He listened without fail to the BBC Tamil news, Mr Gopal said.

On Monday, in an attempt to smooth future negotiations, government officials called off 500 policeman who had begun a half-hearted search of the 2,300 square miles of mountainous forest where Veerappan and his followers live.

Over the last 10 years the army has tried several times to flush him out, but the bandit has stayed one step ahead.

Rajkumar's abduction has convulsed India for the past week and provoked rioting in the actor's native Karnataka. Tamil newspaper offices have been pelted with stones, schools closed and bus services suspended. At least one fan has committed suicide. With 210 films to his credit, Rajkumar is revered more as an icon in his home state than as a mere celebrity.

His kidnapping is the audacious climax to Veerappan's delinquent career, which began as a teenager when he shot his first elephant. He later set up his own poaching gang, killing more than 3,000 tuskers, and branched out into sandalwood smuggling.

At first villagers regarded him as a heroic figure, but that reputation faded as the number of his victims grew. He was last arrested in 1986, only to escape, killing four policeman and a forest official as they slept.

Three years ago he tried to secure an amnesty from the government, agreeing to give himself up in return for a maximum two-year jail sentence. But the deal fell through and Veerappan disappeared.

As part of the failed agreement he stipulated that a film should be made of his life. In fact a Hindi movie, Jungle, which is loosely based on his exploits, is currently playing to packed cinema houses across India.

Last night an Indian cameraman, Richard Mohan, who went to interview Veerappan in 1998 and was held captive for three days, said the biggest danger to Rajkumar's life was from the jungle terrain and climate.

He recalled how Veerappan's party would sleep through the day and walk three to six miles in the night.

"Even for a youngster like me it was a killing experience. I wonder how Rajkumar, who is 72, will be able to cope."

From poaching to mass murder

1955 Teenage Veerappan shoots dead his first elephant and becomes the protege of infamous southern Indian poacher Xavier Gounder

1955-80 Kills 3,000 elephants and breaks away from his mentor

1983-85 Murders three forest guards from the state of Karnataka

1990 Military task force set up to end his reign of terror. The operation fails

1991 Karnataka deputy conservator of forest beheaded by his gang

1993 Kills 15 police informers and seven Tamil Nadu security officials

1994 Kidnaps senior police inspector and six others. Veerappan's brother Arjunan arrested. Inspector escapes. Arjunan dies in custody

1997 Kidnaps 10 Karnataka forest officials who are released after 44 days following the mediation of Tamil magazine editor RR Gopal

2000 Abducts Rajkumar, one of Indian cinema's most venerable stars, and three male relatives, from the actor's farmhouse

How it all adds up

All in all Veerappan has:

 Killed 138 people, including 32 police officers and 10 forest officials

Slaughtered more than 3,000 elephants

Smuggled 40,000 kgs (88,000lbs) of ivory and looted sandalwood worth £15m

webTitle: High level of turnover for Tate & Lyle

fields.headline: Not so sweet on Tate
fields.trailText: Shares in the sugar and starches company Tate & Lyle may have closed unchanged at 300p yesterday, but it was not the price dealers were keeping an eye on.
fields.body:
Shares in the sugar and starches company Tate & Lyle may have closed unchanged at 300p yesterday, but it was not the price dealers were keeping an eye on.

Around 6% of the company shares changed hands, after several large lines of stock were placed at 293p, a 7p discount on Thursday night's closing price.

Dealers suggested the volume was related to a disgruntled institution deciding to cut its holding in Tate & Lyle after last week's profit warning - its second in four months. A spokesman for Tate & Lyle refused to comment on the high level of turnover.

The finger of suspicion immediately pointed at US mutual funds Franklin Resources and Capital Group.

Even though the stock is trading well below the 12-month high of 480p reached in November, yesterday's actions ought to give investors something to chew over.

fields.headline: Nycomed Amersham
fields.trailText: Nycomed Amersham is likely to break its silence on Monday over the potential sale of its life-sciences arm, which has been hanging in the air as a possibility since February.
fields.body:
Nycomed Amersham is likely to break its silence on Monday over the potential sale of its life-sciences arm, which has been hanging in the air as a possibility since February.

Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, or APB, is about as sexy as the new economy gets, positioned on the cusp of computer technology and gene-bashing. It makes hi-tech machines that biotech companies use to sequence genes, typically costing $200,000 (£133,000) each.

Nycomed owns 55% of APB - the other 45% is held by Pharmacia & Upjohn, which cannot sell for two years under its recent merger with the genetically modified foods company Monsanto. Nycomed is keen to keep management control of the business, so its favoured path is to spin off just a 10% stake, on Nasdaq.

There is a feeling that despite its expertise, APB punches below its weight - the likes of Perkin-Elmer and Celera are more visible because of their public listing. A part float would allow APB to offer share options for important scientific staff and mean the company could issue equity for future acquisitions.

Valuations of APB have so far fluctuated between $1.5bn and $3.5bn, but all these are on the conservative side. In the United States, Perkin-Elmer and Celera trade on more than 10 times revenue, which would give APB a price tage of more than $5bn.

It is conceivable, therefore, that Nycomed could scoop a cool $500m simply by spinning off 10%.

Nycomed's shares have been edging up ahead of its results on Monday - they rose 21p to 698p yesterday, giving the group a market capitalisation of £4.5bn.

The remaining imaging business is a decent prospect, with products such as iodine seeds for detecting cancer. Proceeds from the spin-off will provide money for acquisitions, allowing Nycomed to expand in a rapidly growing industry. The shares are worth a look.

fields.headline: Telewest triggers tug-of-war
fields.trailText: An interesting two-way tussle was developing yesterday over embattled cable company Telewest. Stephen Scruton, the HSBC analyst who triggered the recent massive slide in the cable operator's share price with his revelation that the rollout of its digital TV service had been delayed for three months, was once again out bashing the stock.
fields.body:
An interesting two-way tussle was developing yesterday over embattled cable company Telewest. Stephen Scruton, the HSBC analyst who triggered the recent massive slide in the cable operator's share price with his revelation that the rollout of its digital TV service had been delayed for three months, was once again out bashing the stock.

Repeating his "sell" advice, Mr Scruton also cut his target price on Telewest to 120p from 140p, citing Thursday's "poor" figures and the company's long-term prospects.

While Mr Scruton accepts that cable will be the best route into the home, he claims this is a less than economic business. He prefers business focused cable operators such as Energis (up 5p at 490p).

But on the other side of the City, Deutsche Bank analyst Mike Williams was out telling clients that Telewest shares were worth 300p and at current levels represent a "buy".

Mr Williams sees digital broadband cable as a "new dawn for the industry". Sure BSkyB is six months ahead of the game, he says, but the game is only just beginning.

At the end of the trading session, Mr Williams appeared to have come out on top, with Telewest shares closing 4.25p stronger at 160p. But given Thursday's hammering - Telewest shares fell 11% - dealers said the move could just as easily have been a dead-cat bounce.

The wider market generally enjoyed a positive day. Although closing off its best, the FTSE 100 index rose 46.4 points 6,363.5, led by resurgent technology and telecom stocks, which had so badly undermined on Thursday, and supported by a tame US employment report.

Volume was a modest 1.2b shares by the official 4.30pm close reflecting the fact that it is holiday season.

Vodafone Group, up 14.5p to 285.5p, led the telecoms sector higher, closely followed by Colt Telecom, 86p better at £20.40, Cable & Wireless, 35p stronger at £11.45 and Marconi, 28p higher at £10.00.

In the hi-tech sector, chip designer ARM Holdings bounced back, putting on 39p to 670p in the wake of an upbeat industry report. According to the Semiconductor Industry Association, worldwide sales of semiconductors reached a record $16.6bn (£11bn) in June, a rise of 48% on the same period last year. The news helped optical chip specialist Bookham Technology, which settled at £39.69, a gain of 339p.

Still, the new economy jitters had not completely vanished. Emap, the publisher of lad magazine FHM, dipped 22p to £11.34 after a broker called into questions the prospects for traditional media companies in the digital world.

In the current climate Deutsche Bank thinks investors want evidence of payback from new media ventures before they invest.

With such evidence hard if not impossible to find, Deutsche believes Emap shares are going nowhere and has downgraded the stock to "market perform" from "buy".

The retail sector was stuck in the doldrums after the latest figures from the British Retail Consortium confirmed what most people already knew - that fierce competition is keeping prices under pressure. Next dipped 0.5p to 653.5p, Boots eased 1p to 489p, Dixons was 19.75p lower at 260p and Marks & Spencer was unchanged at 216p.

Friendly words from broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney helped Millennium & Copthorne Hotels end the day 31p better at 457p. SSSB upgraded its target price on the stock 450p, from 425p previously, citing the buoyant London hotel market.
