fields.headline: Barclays
fields.standfirst: Bank with big PR problems and big profits
fields.trailText: The self-proclaimed big bank for the big world started life small in the east of England in the early 1700s. What powered its rise in the next 300 years were the Quakers. But it was only for alphabetical reasons that the bank, which this week reported a near doubling of its half-year profits to £1.8bn, became known as Barclays.
fields.body:
The self-proclaimed big bank for the big world started life small in the east of England in the early 1700s. What powered its rise in the next 300 years were the Quakers. But it was only for alphabetical reasons that the bank, which this week reported a near doubling of its half-year profits to £1.8bn, became known as Barclays.

Legend has it that the name was chosen because two directors with the name Barclay sat on the board and alphabetically came before Bassetts, the next in line. Well into the 1970s the bank was still managed by relatives of the founding Quaker families - the Barclay, Bevan, Birkbeck, Gurney, Pease, Tritton and Tuke, many of whose names were known in their own right for their financial prowess.

Most of the family ties have now been lost - largely because the bank started to bring in outsiders to help it out of a string of sticky patches - although, by coincidence, John Varley, who runs the bank's retail banking operations, is married to a member of the founding Pease family.

It has just pulled through its latest period of management uncertainly after spending much of last year without a chief executive when Martin Taylor, an outsider who was not a banker either, departed suddenly after a boardroom row. In what became a comedy of errors, his replacement, former US marine Michael O'Neill, failed to turn up for work on health grounds.

Eventually, Irish Canadian Matt Barrett took the helm in October, just as the bank began to lurch from one controversy to another.

First the bank caused outcry about plans, now dropped, to charge rivals' customers £1 to withdraw money from hole-in-the-wall machines. Then the bank closed 171 branches, at the same time embarking on an advertising campaign proclaiming its size. Actor Sir Anthony Hopkins was dragged in to the ensuing row when it emerged the Welsh-born star featured on television screens at a time when the branch in his home area was on the closure list.

Damage limitation

Then it emerged that Mr Barrett, the big bank's new chief executive, had a big pay deal too - worth 30 times his £850,000 basic salary. This week, just days before revealing its stunning profits rise, the bank suffered a glitch on its on-line bank - where it also proclaims to be the biggest - when a handful of customers were able to access other people's accounts.

But, while a series of public relations disasters could be expected to inflict damage on a brand, in its half-yearly profits figures the bank claimed evidence to the contrary. Instead of mass defections by customers, the bank insisted it was selling more products to its existing customers as well as pulling in new ones off the street.

The spread eagle logo, softened last year to try to lose its brutal image, is still doing the trick, so the bank said.

The motif itself, like the name of the bank itself, was an accident. Its association with Barclays can be traced back to 1728 when John Freame - his son-in-law was John Barclay - moved to a new premises in London's Lombard Street above which hung a huge black eagle sign.

These were the days when few people could read or write so pictorial images, like the eagle, were important to attract customers. Even as Mr Freame and his son-in-law's business flourished - his name was added to the partnership in the 1730s - and they moved to various premises on Lombard Street above which pictorial images such as a bible and three crowns hung, it was the spread eagle which became synonymous with the bank.

The three crowns were added to the logo 200 years later, though, when the bank wanted to register an emblem for Barclays, which took its name in 1896 when 20 private banks merged.

It was known as the Quaker Bank though the early part of the 20th century because of its founders' roots. The three largest banks out of the 20 which formed Barclays were the long-winded Barclay, Bevan, Tritton, Ransom, Bouverle and Company of London; the Norwich and East Anglian-based Gurney group of banks; and the Jonathan Backhouse and Company of Darlington.

More corporate action in 1918 - when Barclays merged with the London, Provincial and South Western - propelled the bank to become one of the "big five". Then in 1969, it bought Martins, the last of the main banks not to be headquartered in London, which bulked up its size even further.

Out of Africa

Not content with expansion at home, the bank roved overseas in the 1920s and struck strong roots in Africa, which later left the bank saddled with criticism in the 1980s and reviled by student activists.

Barclays also had ill-fated plans to be a major investment bank, embarrassingly bungling the development of BZW, which was disbanded three years ago and is now known as Barclays Capital.

An acquisition in 1995 helped the bank become a major player in fund management industry when it bought California-based Wells Fargo investment management in 1995. Now part of Barclays Global Investors, it one of the world's biggest so-called index-tracking firms.

Domestically, Barclays tussles with its rivals HSBC, Lloyds TSB and NatWest, to claim the title of the biggest banker to companies and private individuals alike.

But unlike NatWest, this year taken over by Royal Bank of Scotland, and Midland, now consumed into the HSBC brand, the Barclays name is still surviving. Mr Barrett has not ruled out making acquisitions to expand the bank further but he might want to make sure he moves first to ensure the Barclays brand survives another 300 years.

The Fax:

Likes to claim to be a pace-setter in banking. Barclays launched the first credit card - the Barclaycard - and installed the first cash machine in the country Advertising started on TV in 1968 when Barclaycard featured a bikini-clad girl out shopping. In 1978, Eric Sykes starred in ads using a cash machine with the catch line: "We're open even when we're closed" The 1980s catch line was: "Do you sometimes think the bigger the bank gets the smaller your problems will seem to them?"; now of course it's the "big bank for the big world"

webTitle: Unilever in shake-up after drop in profits

fields.headline: Unilever in shake-up after drop in profits
fields.standfirst: Speculation mounts on firm splitting up
fields.trailText: Unilever is shaking up its top management to form two global divisions - food and personal care - in an attempt to cope with tumbling prices and shrinking profits in consumer markets worldwide.
fields.body:
Unilever is shaking up its top management to form two global divisions - food and personal care - in an attempt to cope with tumbling prices and shrinking profits in consumer markets worldwide.

News of the reorganisation followed a 9% fall in half-year pre-tax profits to £1.88bn. It triggered renewed speculation that the company could eventually split itself up.

Unilever said the change was to improve coordination of its global brands - which include Dove soap, Birds Eye frozen foods and Persil washing powder.

Unlike its international rivals, Unilever presently manages these division on a regional basis, with only long-term overall strategy decided centrally.

A spokesman said: "It's all about brands - we want a much tighter alignment between strategy and operations, to help us innovate and grow."

The company's finance director, Patrick Cescau, will take charge of food manufacturing from January, while Keki Dadiseth who was recently promoted to the board after running the group's operations in India will oversee household goods and personal care.

Strategy director Rudy Markham will replace Mr Cescau as finance director, while Alexander Kemner, who is head of food, will retire next year.

The company brushed aside suggestions that the move could foreshadow a demerger. The company spokesman said: "This is not a precursor to splitting Unilever up."

It is part of chief executive Niall FitzGerald's Path to Growth strategy, which is centred around slashing the group's 1,600 different product names to just 300 or 400 "power brands".

Food and cosmetics manufacturers have been squeezed in recent years by extremely tough competition among retailers, which many analysts believe has been triggered by a combination of e-commerce and the "Wal-Mart effect", as superstores with much lower margin undercut their smaller rivals.

Savvas Savouri, an analyst at Commerzbank, said: "This is a reactive, rather than a proactive move. Prices are drifting downwards and firms think they can reorganise their way out of difficulties."

Unilever's shares, which touched 700p two years ago, edged up 5.75p to 431.75p in trading yesterday.

The industry has been shaken by profits warnings from a number of US companies, including the household goods group Procter & Gamble and the food company McBride.

Unilever's first-half earnings were hit by a £376m restructuring charge. Turnover edged up 2% to £20.6bn helped by steady progress in North America, despite lower sales in Europe due to lower vegetable oil prices.

Many observers believe that Unilever will eventually split its food division from its household and personal goods operations. Mr FitzGerald has said he has no "theological" objection to a demerger, if his three-year restructuring plan fails to pay off.

Analyst David Lang of Investec Henderson Crosthwaite said: "I don't see a demerger happening at the moment. But it could easily happen eventually - you can still see a fault line down the middle of the business."

webTitle: Joan Collins shares TV beauty tips

fields.headline: Joan Collins shares TV beauty tips
fields.trailText: Joan Collins has been given shares in return for publicising Channel Health, a health and lifestyle television company that plans to float on the AIM next week with a £20m valuation.
fields.body:
Joan Collins has been given shares in return for publicising Channel Health, a health and lifestyle television company that plans to float on the AIM next week with a £20m valuation.

Ms Collins has received an undisclosed holding in the company in return for sharing health and beauty tips with viewers through six one-hour documentary style programmes called "Joan Collins - My Secrets".

Channel Health has been aired on BSkyB's digital service since last month and is aimed at affluent young mums who tend to look after the health concerns for the entire family, according to founder Joanne Sawicki.

"Joan is a great asset because she does normal things like drink, smoke and eat chocolate but in moderation. We want people to take a fun approach to looking after themselves."

Broker Beeson Gregroy says the listing should raise £5.1m net of expenses to help fund new programming and the development of the channelhealth.net website.

Channel Health's content will be targeted at the growing number of people who are becoming concerned about living a healthy lifestyle. Discovery Health already broadcasts on Sky Digital while Granada and Flextech are thought to be bidding for funds from the Department of Health to set up a public health channel.

Ms Sawicki dismissed suggestions that Channel Health looked similar to Clickmango.com, the Joanna Lumley fronted health and lifestyle web company that recently announced it was closing down, or that it would fall victim to the lethargy that has afflicted shares in listed health information companies in the United States. "We're nothing like them," she said.

Channel Health's revenues will come from broadcasting contracts, content licensing, premium rate telephone information lines, e-commerce and, from next year, subscription fees.

fields.headline: Swiss banks agree $1.25bn Holocaust deal
fields.trailText: Switzerland's two biggest banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, yesterday approved a $1.25bn settlement with victims of the Holocaust.
fields.body:
Switzerland's two biggest banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, yesterday approved a $1.25bn settlement with victims of the Holocaust.

The agreement, reached after a legal process that began in 1996, is designed to settle charges that Swiss banks prevented survivors withdrawing money deposited before the second world war.

A Credit Suisse Group spokesman said lawyers for his bank and UBS would go to the New York offices of District Judge Edward Korman on Friday to accept the deal formally.

Four Swiss insurers - Baloise, Helvetia Patria, Rentenanstalt/Swiss Life and reinsurance group Swiss Re - are adding $50m to the settlement amid claims some life insurance policies of survivors had not been honoured.

An important amendment wants banks to agree to recommendations of the so-called Volcker Commission.

The panel, chaired by former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker, scrutinised Swiss bank accounts for over three years in a hunt for assets of Holocaust victims and proposed that banks publish 4.1m accounts of possible victims.

Swiss banking regulators have so far allowed banks to set up a database of 46,000 accounts. Another amendment calls on Swiss companies who used forced labourers to come forward and hand over documents to special master Judah Gribetz, who will set up a distribution list for the settlement money to help find the people or their heirs.

Estimates of the number of people involved vary. One study of companies in the German town of Singen, just over the Swiss border in the east, puts the number there at 2,500.

Food group Nestle said its Maggi unit used forced labour in Singen, while engineers Georg Fischer and aluminium producers Alusuisse have also come forward.

Life sciences groups Novartis and Roche have said their subsidiaries used a small number of prisoners of war, but paid them a wage equal to other workers.

fields.headline: Vodafone leads in German auction
fields.trailText: Vodafone, the world's biggest mobile phone company, yesterday led the bidding in Germany's auction of third-generation mobile phone licences as it jostled with other operators to stitch up a network of such deals across Europe.
fields.body:
Vodafone, the world's biggest mobile phone company, yesterday led the bidding in Germany's auction of third-generation mobile phone licences as it jostled with other operators to stitch up a network of such deals across Europe.

Vodafone is competing with other telecoms groups such as Deutsche Telekom and Hutchison Whampoa to become the major player in 3G mobile on the continent.

Each European country is selling capacity via beauty contests or auctions that will allow mobile phone operators to offer 3G technology.

However, there was speculation yesterday that Deutsche Telekom's strategy to gain a foothold in the lucrative Italian market, which has 35m mobile users, may have been dealt a blow.

Sources said Italian telecom's group Tiscali was likely to choose Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa as its preferred international partner in a consortium to bid for licences rather than Deutsche Telekom.

Italy is expected to begin its auction of third-generation spectrum from August 24 and France, Switzerland and Belgium are expected to follow.

The bidding in the German auction passed $4.5bn (£3bn) yesterday. The auction surpassed the total $2.42bn raised in the Dutch auction last month but is still substantially short of the £22.5bn raised by Britain's 3G licence sale in April.

webTitle: Notebook: In global marketing, size really does matter

fields.headline: In global marketing, size really does matter
fields.standfirst: But even at the top it's not easy
fields.trailText: Life is tough for sprawling, old-economy, bricks-and-mortar consumer goods manufacturers such as Unilever. Prices and margins have been sliding for several years and there is increasing pressure to do something - anything - to turn things around.
fields.body:
Life is tough for sprawling, old-economy, bricks-and-mortar consumer goods manufacturers such as Unilever. Prices and margins have been sliding for several years and there is increasing pressure to do something - anything - to turn things around.

One way to get breathing space from anxious investors is to announce a reorganisation, preferably throwing in a liberal sprinkling of terms such as "global brands", "alignment strategy" and "interface with consumers". Yesterday's move from Unilever appears just such a ploy, amounting to a game of boardroom musical chairs in which everybody still ends up with a seat. To be fair the shake-up is partly prompted by Unilever's recent takeover of Bestfoods, which gave it more presence in the southern hemisphere. This area has traditionally been run by Unilever on a regional basis, and the firm is keen to take a more co-ordinated approach in each of its product areas.

However, the changes will do little to help chairman Niall FitzGerald overcome the industry's underlying problems - the growth of e-commerce and increasingly frantic competition between retailers. The growth of the all-in-one hypermarket has made life tough for household goods manufacturers - Sam Walton, the chairman of Wal-Mart, has a lot to answer for with his aggressive price-cutting strategies.

The world is heading towards a situation of having just a few huge food corporations. Unilever is anxious to be one of the leaders, alongside players such as General Mills and Nabisco. Size matters a great deal in marketing brands internationally but even at the top, life is not going to be easy.

Dirty old United

It is the old cocktail party test. Ask yourself what people's reactions would be if you told them you ran three of the ITV franchises. Now imagine the shuffling gait of the same crowd as you detail your interests in trade magazines, market research and the Daily Star. Glamourous they are not.

Lord Hollick, however, still managed to enthuse his way through the presentation yesterday of the reshaped United News & Media group.

CMP, the renamed Miller Freeman business publishing division, enjoyed a 19% hike in operating profits to £73m in the first half, while United's PR Newswire in the United States showed a 42% increase to £21m.

The disposal programme of mature businesses outlined in November and now pretty much complete has helped underlying revenue growth to rise from 5% to 9%. Lord Hollick also argues, reasonably enough, that after the ITV sale United will no longer suffer through being seen by some investors as a dirty old conglomerate. In the medium term, United shareholders have also done well from the franchise sale, even if Lord Hollick's party conversation has not.

His most immediate difficulty will be conveying what is actually left in the group, much of which is shrouded in jargon and difficult to grasp. The continued investment in online services, which in the first half lost £42m, will also be of concern for doubters despite Lord Hollick's insistence that the group is taking a "hard headed" approach to the internet. If he truly wants to shake off the conglomerate tag, then the newspaper division and consumer publishing still sit uneasily. The Daily Express and Daily Star now appear even more conspicuous in the United line-up than they did before the ITV sales.

Cruickshank 55

In what might be the first sign that married life is softening Gordon Brown, the banks were able to utter a sigh of relief after the government's response to the controversial Cruickshank review.

There are no heavyhanded measures to make life easier for customers to move their current accounts. Paycom, the new regulator for the payments system, is to be "consulted on" before being launched on an industry which hates regulation. Rumours this week suggesting a windfall tax was on its way also proved wild. But a close reading of the response to the 55 Cruickshank recommendations tells a different story. Paycom will happen at some point, with the government "committed to the introduction of primary legislation".

On the subject of compulsory changes on moving accounts, it is clear that these are only lacking since the banks themselves have used the time since the publication of the Cruickshank report to show that things can be improved.

The banks are at last working on automating the transfer of direct debit instructions - regarded as a serious deterrent to moving bank accounts - while the Link cash machine network has opened its doors to new, non-bank providers. The banks themselves have ditched charges, in the most part, for withdrawing cash.

In short, the simple threat of action is producing real results.

fields.headline: Bombardier swoops
fields.standfirst: Adtranz sold for £500m
fields.trailText: Bombardier, the Canadian transportation and aerospace group, paid £500m yesterday to buy train-maker Adtranz from DaimlerChrysler in a deal that underlines the growing consolidation in the transport industry.
fields.body:
Bombardier, the Canadian transportation and aerospace group, paid £500m yesterday to buy train-maker Adtranz from DaimlerChrysler in a deal that underlines the growing consolidation in the transport industry. DaimlerChrysler chairman Juergen Schrempp had wanted to sell off the Adtranz division to concentrate more on the company's core automobile business, adding "Bombardier is the best choice to bring Adtranz into the future."

Adtranz employs 22,000 but the deal is not likely to affect its UK workforce which is mainly based in the Midlands. DaimlerChrysler will reap about €900m (£545m) from the sale via tax savings effects. Manfred Bischoff, chairman of the train maker's supervisory board, said Bombardier would take over Adtranz' debts and losses.

The train-making industry at home and abroad is in the middle of a boom and Bombardier said that the proceeds from the planned sale of Adtranz's fixed installations and signalling business would cut the net purchase price. Both companies said that the sale -subject to the approval of Daimler's supervisory board - would positively affect DaimlerChrysler's earnings.

fields.headline: Rio Tinto wins North deal
fields.trailText: Rio Tinto won the battle for iron ore producer North yesterday after it raised its takeover bid to $1.75bn (£1.16bn), ousting the rival South African bidder Anglo American.
fields.body:
Rio Tinto won the battle for iron ore producer North yesterday after it raised its takeover bid to $1.75bn (£1.16bn), ousting the rival South African bidder Anglo American.

North, based in Australia, accepted British-owned mining group Rio Tinto's offer of £1.84 for each share, which was 25% higher than its initial hostile bid. Anglo American had offered £1.65 apiece for North but said yesterday that any higher offer could hurt its profits and would fail to enhance value for its shareholders.

North's board recommended that shareholders accept Rio Tinto's offer and create the world's second biggest iron ore producer behind Brazil's Cia Vale do Rio Doce. Rio already had a 14.5% stake in North and required more than 50% for its bid to be successful.

Sir Robert Wilson, Rio Tinto chairman, said: "From the outset Rio Tinto has focused on the capital and operating synergies available with our acquisition of North. We believe we are the logical acquirer of North."

Shares in Rio Tinto were up 17p to £10.55.

North is attractive to Rio Tinto and Anglo American because of the strong growth in the global steel industry which has expanded by 11% this year. Japanese steel mills are the primary customers for iron ore producers.

The consolidation of North's Australian operations into Rio Tinto's will reduce the Japanese steel mills' bargaining position in export contracts as they had previously played each of the Australian iron ore producers against each other to get the best deals.

Rio Tinto, however, has paid the price for its increased offer to North shareholders.

It will only achieve half its expected cost savings, which analysts predicted were as much as £156m on its original offer.

Rio Tinto was in talks with BHP last year for both companies to put their iron assets into a joint venture. But this was abandoned after each company failed to reach agreement on its structure.

Rio, which has interests in iron ore, industrial minerals, copper, aluminium, energy and gold, is known for its emphasis on cost cutting.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Hi-tech firm speaks out
fields.body:
Hi-tech firm speaks out

Sun Microsystems president Ed Zander said yesterday that he was happy to let the European Commission deal with allegations that Microsoft was abusing its power but added that no company was above the law.

The EC said on Thursday that it had sent Microsoft a "statement of objections" over claims that it was abusing its power in the personal computer market to gain an edge in the global server market.

Sun Microsystems also said yesterday that it would create an additional 275 engineering jobs as it doubles the size of its software development centre in Dublin over the next three years.

The move will bring total employment at the site to 600 and make the Irish centre one of the company's largest software development operations outside the US.

Car numbers on the increase

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said yesterday that it had raised its forecast for new car registrations this year by 25,000 to 2.225m.

"The new car market is healthy, with an array of attractive deals and new models on offer and, now that uncertainty has been removed on the pricing issue, the year ahead looks very bright," SMMT chief executive Christopher Macgowan said.

Discounts on domain names

Magic Moments Internet yesterday announced a low cost domain name registration facility service, called 123-reg.co.uk, which allows customers to order and manage their own domain name and email services online.

The service has been developed by WebFusion, the company that Magic Moments acquired in May, and is aimed at customers with a requirement to register many names as part of their business.

Guinness goes to strike ballot

The union representing workers at Guinness Ireland said yesterday it would press ahead with a strike ballot after talks to prevent 300 job losses ended without success.

The Services Industrial Professional Technical Union had urged Guinness, owned by Britain's Diageo, to suspend the decision to cut jobs at two plants in the town of Dundalk. The vote takes place on Tuesday but no strike date has been set.

Coca Cola protests

A group of former and current black Coca-Cola workers said yesterday they would disrupt the drinks company's tentative settlement of a racial discrimination lawsuit if details of the deal were not revealed soon. The workers stood outside the company's headquarters in Atlanta and protested that terms of the settlement had remained secret.

Two months ago, Coca-Cola tentatively settled the 1999 suit that accused it of discriminating against blacks in pay, promotions and performance reviews. An American court has, however, ordered that details of the deal remain sealed until October.

EU looks at post proposals

The European Commission has invited comments under its merger regulations on new joint ventures involving Britain's Post Office, TNT Post Group and Singapore Post Private.

fields.headline: Chief constable faces leak investigation
fields.trailText: A chief constable is to be investigated over allegations that he deliberately leaked details of a scathing government adviser's report on one of his own high profile detectives.
fields.body:
A chief constable is to be investigated over allegations that he deliberately leaked details of a scathing government adviser's report on one of his own high profile detectives.

Barry Shaw of Cleveland police was named by a staff whistleblower who claims that contemptuous criticism of Ray Mallon's "zero tolerance" policing scheme was given to the press.

The allegations, made under the protection of the new Public Interest Disclosure Act by a civilian employee of the force, say that the chief constable approved of the leak, in spite of his repeated position that background to the controversy over Mr Mallon must remain confidential for the police inquiry - named Operation Lancet - to be "scrupulously fair".

Mr Shaw, who will continue his normal duties during the new inquiry, has strongly denied any connection with the leak, which effectively wrecked a media conference by Mr Mallon in June, shortly after he was cleared of criminal behaviour over the use of police informants when a superintendent in Middlesbrough.

The new inquiry will see the third independent senior officer in as many years investigate Cleveland police force.

The Daily Express published long extracts from a dossier by Treasury counsel - QCs who advise the government on the likelihood of successful prosecutions - which condemned Mr Mallon's administration as "woeful and chaotic" and described his version of the American zero tolerance policy as showing "complete indifference" to the law.

The decision to investigate the claims was made by an emergency meeting of Cleveland police authority, which has asked South Yorkshire chief constable Michael Hedges to lead the inquiry.

The authority rejected calls for the suspension of Mr Shaw, which would only be within its powers if leaving him in post would inhibit the investigation or was otherwise in the public interest.

The inquiry, Operation Lancet, was initially launched in 1997 by the then chief constable of Warwickshire, Andrew Timson, who resigned two years later when he was faced with unrelated allegations against him from within his own force. He was succeeded in 1999 by Lloyd Clarke, deputy chief constable of West Yorkshire, who wrapped up the main inquiry last autumn.

The background to Operation Lancet goes back much further, however, to the collapse of a drugs trial on Teesside, which left a legacy of suspicion about the way informers were handled in parts of the Cleveland service.

Mr Shaw, who is 59 and a former Merchant Navy officer and Glasgow beat constable, told the Guardian last month that he believed there were officers in Cleveland who should be in jail and others who should be dismissed.

He said then: "If I can't sleep easily at night over probity in my force, no one in Cleveland can."

Mr Mallon, who is 45 and was courted by Labour and Conservative politicians during the last general election campaign as a figurehead of tough policing, has called for a public inquiry into the Lancet affair.

He denounced "dirty tricks" after the leak in June and has demanded repeatedly that he should be reinstated. He is still suspended pending disciplinary hearings over Lancet's central informant allegations, which could take at least another year.

Mr Shaw said last night that the inquiry was welcome and would receive full co-operation.

He said: "It is a difficult time but the force should not be diverted from the excellent work officers and support staff are doing in tackling crime and anti-social behaviour on our streets."

webTitle: Tom Paulin: Republicanism in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Republicans left, right and centre
fields.standfirst:
In Ireland, unionists have nowhere to go but monarchism

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Even when the Queen Mother isn't having a birthday, people in England increasingly use the word "republican" to define their political views. At the same time, I think of the term as embracing both the left and the right of centre, and so, properly speaking, being a term which belongs to culture rather than to politics.
fields.body:
Even when the Queen Mother isn't having a birthday, people in England increasingly use the word "republican" to define their political views. At the same time, I think of the term as embracing both the left and the right of centre, and so, properly speaking, being a term which belongs to culture rather than to politics.

Margaret Thatcher was classically republican and iconoclastic in her attitudes, had an uneasy relationship with the Queen, and represented values which resemble those of the Republican party in the United States. It is, I think, sentimental and inaccurate to believe that the republican cast of mind is naturally left of centre.

In the north of Ireland, the term is taken to mean "a supporter of Sinn Fein/IRA", and when using the term you have to be careful, if you don't support those organisations, to make your lack of support clear. The effect is slightly cumbrous, though.

The alternative is to call yourself a nationalist, but the problem with the term "nationalist" is that it carries a heavy weight of ethnic and religious identification. It asks you to bow down to a force which Yeats addresses as "master of the still stars and of the burning door". The murky, violent energy in the term "nationalist" makes it a tricky label, and it is only slightly offset by the qualifying adjective "constitutional".

The problem with the term "republican" is that the combined efforts of Conor Cruise O'Brien and Sinn Fein/IRA have made it synonymous in many people's minds with political terrorism and violence. This means that many people on the unionist side have nowhere to go both ideologically and imaginatively except monarchism.

It also means that as unionists don't in general get accused of supporting loyalist terrorism, there is a certain sense in which they think they are occupying a moral high ground. Their gun-running efforts in 1912 are celebrated by ATQ Stewart in The Ulster Crisis, but there is not the same connection made between unionism and armed terrorism.

It would be best if the two ideological principles - unionism and republicanism - could be debated as principles detached from historical emotion and the baggage that goes with it. Unionism has to be seen - and respected - as a cult which finds little echo in the hearts and minds of the majority of the British people. The Oxford undergraduates I teach know nothing of English history, let alone anything about Irish history. This means that as a set of values and principles, unionism is becoming more and more detached from what it terms the "mainland".

At the time of the referendum on the Good Friday agreement, I was in the Belfast office of the Progressive Unionist party - pride of place was given to a slightly smoky-looking 1950s photograph of Elizabeth II. It had an archaic look, as if the party's loyalty was not to the current monarch but to an ideal image of her far in the past.

As a republican, I naturally think that this image has to be swept away and replaced with new images and insignia, but then I recognise that republicanism has always been short of female images, that indeed it prefers symbols and letters to images (part of its protestant inheritance no doubt). I also remember an encounter with a politician I greatly admired, the late Paddy Devlin - Paddy became hugely angry when I unwisely broached the need for there to be new images and insignia in the north of Ireland. Like the word "republican", this was a loaded issue - it had guns and Semtex in it. Although I don't think this is the case, it could be argued that republicans need to consider how deeply images of the crown and monarch are embedded in the unionist imagination. The idea of the crown in parliament, which is the foundation of British constitutional democracy, is the result of the Glorious Revolution, as it is known, of 1688. Many republicans in Britain see the Williamite revolution as a great liberating event - which it was in Britain, if not Ireland. Indeed, I've come to realise that a famous novel by one of William of Orange's most famous supporters, Daniel Defoe, is a coded myth of that revolution. Robinson Crusoe is a version of the island republic with a king at its head. Crusoe's goat skins are his robes of state.

Although the loyalist identification with the British monarch has always reminded me of another tropical island - it's in the New Hebrides, where the natives worship a framed photograph of the Duke of Edinburgh (it is the only place where he is popular) - I'm beginning to recognise that this is a more than slightly patronising view. Those of us who believe that Ireland should become a 32-county republic need to take seriously the idea that part of that republic's eclectic imagery could be images of the young Queen Elizabeth.

It might seem surreal, but it would also be an image for compromise and tolerance. I can even see Robert McCartney and Conor Cruise O'Brien taking their caps off in awkward reverence.

The Oxford undergraduates I teach know nothing of English history, let alone anything about Irish history. This means that as a set of values and principles, unionism is becoming more and more detached from what it terms the "mainland". At the time of the referendum on the Good Friday agreement, I was in the Belfast office of the Progressive Unionist party - pride of place was given to a slightly smoky-looking 1950s photograph of Elizabeth II. It had an archaic look, as if the party's loyalty was not to the current monarch but to an ideal image of her far in the past. As a republican, I naturally think that this image has to be swept away and replaced with new images and insignia, but then I recognise that republicanism has always been short of female images, that indeed it prefers symbols and letters to images (part of its protestant inheritance no doubt). I also remember an encounter with a politician I greatly admired, the late Paddy Devlin - Paddy became hugely angry when I unwisely broached the need for there to be new images and insignia in the north of Ireland. Like the word "republican", this was a loaded issue - it had guns and Semtex in it. Although I don't think this is the case, it could be argued that republicans need to consider how deeply images of the crown and monarch are embedded in the unionist imagination. The idea of the crown in parliament, which is the foundation of British constitutional democracy, is the result of the Glorious Revolution, as it is known, of 1688. Many republicans in Britain see the Williamite revolution as a great liberating event - which it was in Britain, if not Ireland. Indeed, I've come to realise that a famous novel by one of William of Orange's most famous supporters, Daniel Defoe, is a coded myth of that revolution. Robinson Crusoe is a version of the island republic with a king at its head. Crusoe's goat skins are his robes of state. Although the loyalist identification with the British monarch has always reminded me of another tropical island - it's in the New Hebrides, where the natives worship a framed photograph of the Duke of Edinburgh (it is the only place where he is popular) - I'm beginning to recognise that this is a more than slightly patronising view. Those of us who believe that Ireland should become a 32-county republic need to take seriously the idea that part of that republic's eclectic imagery could be images of the young Queen Elizabeth. It might seem surreal, but it would also be an image for compromise and tolerance. I can even see Robert McCartney and Conor Cruise O'Brien taking their caps off in awkward reverence.

webTitle: MoD holds talks on privatising Trident base

fields.headline: MoD holds talks on privatising Trident base
fields.standfirst: Government accused of putting profits before national security in plans to hand over running of Faslane to private company
fields.trailText: The government was accused yesterday of putting profits before safety and national security after it emerged that the Ministry of Defence has been holding talks with a private company over the running of the Trident nuclear submarine base on the Clyde.
fields.body:
The government was accused yesterday of putting profits before safety and national security after it emerged that the Ministry of Defence has been holding talks with a private company over the running of the Trident nuclear submarine base on the Clyde.

The discussions follow a review of naval bases across the UK which concluded that they were operating at almost 45% over capacity.

Discussions are under way with Babcock Rosyth Defence, owners of Rosyth dockyard, about the handling of key services at the Faslane base, home to four Trident nuclear submarines.

Talks are also taking place with Devonport Management in Plymouth and Fleet Support in Portsmouth.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, said yesterday that the government could save up to £150m as a result of the discussions.

"We already have high level security work conducted by private companies and we have the very highest security and safety standards," Mr Hoon said.

"This is a very early stage in the process. These kinds of arrangements already exist in the shipyards and it is something we are looking to extend. There is significant overcapacity in warship repair and maintenance across the UK."

Almost all the 8,000 workers at Faslane are employed by the MoD.

Dennis Richmond, head of Babcock facilities management, said in a statement that operational ship and submarine work were included in their proposal. "We envisage handling nuclear work such as checks, tests and maintenance of the submarines' reactor plant," he said.

The company, which operates the Rosyth naval base in Fife, said a contract could be signed next year, with Babcock assuming control at Faslane by 2002.

The MoD insists that there is no question of the armed guarding of the facility being handed over to the private sector. It says there is already private sector involvement in building and refitting the nuclear submarine fleet and that safety and security would always be paramount.

But unions and opposition politicians expressed concerns about the implications of the move. Officials say up to 3,000 jobs could be at risk, 1,000 of them at Faslane, if the proposals go ahead.

Alan Grey, convener for the Institute of Professionals, Managers and Specialists, said he would request a meeting with Mr Hoon to discuss why Babcock Rosyth Defence was given more information about the talks than workers at the base.

"This government came in saying they would not follow the previous administration's line of private good, public bad. In practice, they appear to have come with the belief that the public sector is a bad thing," he said.

Jack Dromey, national organiser for the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "Our message is do not rush to a private sector judgment, do not make the mistakes of the Tories.

"You cannot now say thanks for your past loyalty, flexibility, your reward is the sack for some and privatisation for others. Post Paddington, safety and security must come before the interests of private shareholders."

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said he was "deeply concerned" about the security implications of the possible privatisation.

"This decision may seriously affect our national security and our armed forces' technical security," he warned.

Mr Duncan Smith said the decision was motivated by a desire to cut costs.

He added: "Yet again, this Labour government is putting cutting costs before the security of our armed forces."

A Scottish National party spokesman said that it had huge concerns about "plans to privatise Britain's nuclear weapons".

He said the SNP wanted to see nuclear weapons scrapped, not handed over to a private company devoted to putting profit before safety.

fields.headline: 'Groovy gang' drug police jailed
fields.standfirst:
Disgraced detectives from elite crime squad seized drugs and recycled them for their own profit

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A police corruption trial that detailed widespread drug dealing between officers in an elite crime squad and leading figures in the underworld ended yesterday with three disgraced detectives being jailed.
fields.body:
A police corruption trial that detailed widespread drug dealing between officers in an elite crime squad and leading figures in the underworld ended yesterday with three disgraced detectives being jailed.

Det Con Thomas Kingston, 42, Det Con Thomas Reynolds, 40, and Det Sgt Terance O'Connell, 43, all members of 9 regional crime squad based at East Dulwich, south London, should have been at the forefront of the fight against drugs crime. Instead, they called themselves "the groovy gang" and for five years were part of a conspiracy to recycle drugs they seized in raids for their own profit, the Old Bailey heard.

Kingston and Reynolds were jailed for three and a half years each after they were convicted of conspiracy to supply £7,500 of amphetamine sulphate.

O'Connell was jailed for two years for perverting the course of justice by trying to cover up for his two colleagues. He was cleared of conspiracy to supply.

Two other members of the squad, Robert Clark and Christopher Drury, were jailed in February for their involvement in the scam, but their convictions could not be published before the end of the trial for legal reasons. Clark, the ringleader of the group, was sentenced to 12 years. Drury received 11 years.

Evidence presented at the two trials showed the detectives were involved in lucrative double-dealing.

Their corrupt activities were exposed when a drug dealer, Evelyn Fleckney, who was having an affair with Clark, turned supergrass, and another officer in the squad, Det Con Neil Putnam, gave evidence against his colleagues after "wrestling with his conscience", the court heard.

Fleckney, a powerful drug baroness, described how she became a police informer in the early 1990s. She and Clark became lovers, staying in £200-a-night hotels - signing in under the name Bart Simpson - going on holidays to the Canary Islands and exchanging expensive gifts.

They even attended police functions together.

However, their relationship was also a business one.

Fleckney, who was known as "the chairman of the board", fed Clark information on major drugs shipments. Part of any drugs seized by the squad were stolen by Clark and recycled by Fleckney through her network of dealers. The profits were shared among the detectives involved.

Orlando Pownall, who prosecuted in both trials, said: "This had the effect of returning to the streets the very drugs that Clark was entrusted to seize. Those from whom they 'stole' could hardly be described as victims and would be unlikely to complain on arrest."

The corrupt activities were in full swing in September 1991 when Putnam joined the squad. That month Fleckney told Clark a large quantity of cannabis resin was being dropped from a light aircraft over the village of Nutting in East Sussex.

Putnam was present as officers from the squad seized the drugs and made arrests. A few days later, Clark handed Putnam £300, the first of several payments.

"He knew it was a corrupt payment, but did not realise precisely what it was for," said Mr Pownall.

In the second trial, Putnam described how the police were tipped off that a quantity of amphetamine was being delivered to an address in Clapham, south-west London, in July 1995.

Kingston and O'Connell were among officers who went to the scene. They took two of the six packets they found and put them in a carrier bag.

Putnam, who was there as an exhibits officer, was asked by Kingston to take the bag to Reynolds, who was off duty.

"Reynolds arranged for the drugs to be sold and a few weeks later gave Putnam £500, his share of the proceeds," said Mr Pownall.

Sentencing Kingston and Reynolds yesterday, Judge David Paget QC said: "You have been convicted of what is a very grave offence."

Suspicions about the squad and rumours of the relationship between Fleckney and Clark persisted throughout the 1990s, but nothing could be proved.

However, Fleckney turned supergrass after she was convicted in March 1998 of conspiracy to supply ecstasy, cocaine and cannabis and jailed for 15 years.

At the time of her arrest, she was controlling a multimillion international drugs distribution network.

She boasted: "There are not many dealers like me. I could have a million pills if I wanted. I could have had 100,000 delivered yesterday."

Putnam, who was described as a devout Christian, was then questioned by Scotland Yard's complaints investigation bureau and decided to give evidence against his colleagues. Both he and Fleckney pleaded guilty to a number of drug-related offences in November last year.

Putnam was jailed in February for three years 11 months, but is now free.

Fleckney was sentenced to four and a half years for her involvement with the detectives. The sentence runs concurrently with her 15-year term.

The Old Bailey heard that the officers in the squad "became a rule unto themselves", Mr Pownall said.

"There was no supervision and through the lack of supervision there grew a sense of arrogance, a feeling that they were untouchable."

The judge in the first trial, Mr Justice Blofeld, condemned the lack of supervision from senior officers, although he praised CIB for its investigation.

fields.headline: 30 arrested for 'witchcraft' killings
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: Police in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh yesterday arrested 30 people accused of involvement in the gruesome killing of four women and a man they suspected of witchcraft.
fields.body:
Police in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh yesterday arrested 30 people accused of involvement in the gruesome killing of four women and a man they suspected of witchcraft.

A police statement said that all the key accused were being held and raids were being made to arrest others.

Earlier this week a mob of about 200 villagers stormed the homes of the five people, whom they suspected of practising black magic.

The victims were dragged to the square in the village of Timmapur, beaten up, and then tied to a tree before being doused with kerosene and burned alive.

The mob violence followed the death of two villagers, one a mentally ill woman, in the past week, which triggered fears of witchcraft in the village.

Police officials said that they had appealed to the public not to believe in black magic or sorcery, and not to resort to violence if they suspected such activities.

fields.headline: Planners rediscover the high street
fields.trailText: The high street, undermined and emptied by the unrelenting growth of out-of-town shopping complexes for two decades, is back in fashion.
fields.body:
The high street, undermined and emptied by the unrelenting growth of out-of-town shopping complexes for two decades, is back in fashion.

Forecasts for retailing this year show that town and city centres are likely to account for 94% of major retail projects during 2000 - a reversal of the trend in 1998/99.

As ministers plan measures to help the high street revival - and, perhaps, gradually seal the fate of the much-criticised greenfield mall - a retail analyst, CB Hillier Parker, forecast that this century could see major investment in cities. However, it cautioned that the big developers, major global players, could take investments to Europe and further afield if planners stopped further out-of-town growth.

In 1998 and 1999, which saw two huge shopping complexes open at Trafford, in Greater Manchester, and at Bluewater, near Dartford in Kent, town centre shops amounted to 37% and 45% respectively of retail projects. Over half of projects were out-of-town sites.

Over the past year city centre shopping developments either completed or in the pipeline are approaching the £2bn mark, and exceeding the expectations of developers.

The planning minister, Nick Raynsford, said yesterday that planning guidelines to curb out-of-town developments, introduced by the last government and strengthened by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, were bearing fruit.

"This has been like turning round a supertanker," he said. "It is only now we are seeing the results of a policy change made by John Gummer [the Tory environment secretary] after the Tories spent their first 15 years in office encouraging out-of-town development: huge swaths took place in the 1980s and early 1990s.

"There is no question that a number of major retailers are now looking actively at new town centre locations," he said. "There is a big new interest in town centres ... you've seen a dramatic change to what was forecast a year ago with Wal-Mart's arrival [the US giant that took over Asda, and was expected to lead a move back to greenfield sites]. I am very optimistic. Retailers are increasingly confident."

He labelled Bluewater, opened last year but approved in the mid-1990s, "the last big dinosaur of the old era ... we won't see any more of them." For good measure, he also said he was fed up being held up, both on official business and on pleasure, by traffic jams on both sides of the Thames created by the shopping complex.

Measures to speed the high street revival are being considered by the government. Legislation to create town improvement zones could be introduced to underpin informal city centre public-private partnerships around the country. The zones would give councils statutory backing to create joint companies with large retailers and businesses to manage city centres and other commercial districts.

Town halls might be allowed to retain a proportion of revenue raised from council tax and business rates to put into the zones or into special urban improvement areas, using public money to lever in hundreds of millions from business. The public-private companies could manage roads, oversee car parks, employ town centre wardens, and help plan public transport, while providing other services.

The environment department appears cautiously confident the Treasury will prove sympathetic and include the plans in Gordon Brown's autumn pre-budget statement. Further measures will be outlined in a white paper.

Privately some developers believe the tide will turn against out-of-town centres - dominated by seven huge complexes, from Gateshead's MetroCentre, to Meadowhall in Sheffield, and Lakeside in Essex - because shoppers are fed-up with traffic gridlock at weekends and evenings.

New centres, such as the £250m Oracle at Reading, Berkshire, are leading the way. Incorporating two large stores and 80 shops, it draws 500,000 shoppers a week, well ahead of projections. Other centres are under way at Southampton, Solihull in the West Midlands, and Uxbridge, west London.

Birmingham is preparing for the biggest retail revival of all. Two centres costing £800m are under construction: the progressive demolition of the infamous Bullring centre, to be replaced by a modern complex; and the Martineau Place scheme nearby. A new indoor market is due for Christmas.

Birmingham has felt threatened by the Merry Hill shopping centre at Dudley, which opened in 1989. Two years ago its owners failed to have it redesignated as the new town centre for the area.

Dudley has been seen as a case study for how a town can die when a shopping complex is built on its doorstep. Marks & Spencer and Sainsbury's, for instance, left the high street for Merry Hill - although Dudley's town centre manager, Sean Nethercott, said it had since been reborn as a smaller shopping area.

However, in its latest development plan Dudley council told the government it favoured creating a new town embracing Merry Hill, an adjoining waterfront office and leisure area, and the nearby town of Brierly Hill. It plans 1,100 new homes.

webTitle: Childminders condemn proposal to let them smack children

fields.headline: Childminders condemn proposal to let them smack children
fields.trailText: Childminders yesterday criticised a government proposal to allow them to smack children and babies in their care.
fields.body:
Childminders yesterday criticised a government proposal to allow them to smack children and babies in their care.

New regulations on childcare planned by the Department for Education and Employment would allow childminders to smack children in their homes if parents gave permission. But physical punishment would remain forbidden in day nurseries, playgroups, children's centres and creches.

Childminders said they did not want the right to smack, and condemned the government for putting children at risk of abuse.

The National Childminding Association (NCMA), whose 40,000 members are against smacking said its telephone lines were jammed yesterday with parents and professionals complaining about the proposals.

Gill Haynes, chief executive, said: "We are appalled that the government has ignored our advice. These standards are supposed to be about providing safe quality care for children wherever they are, but smacking babies can never be acceptable in any childcare setting.

"A recent consultation document published by the Department of Health showed that most people believe children under two should never be smacked by parents, let alone by a professional childcare worker.

"Childminding is the most used form of day care for children. Why should it have different standards to other forms of care?"

Ms Haynes said the government had misunderstood the purpose of regulation, and the proposals contradicted national occupational standards.

Childminders often cared for children from different families at the same time, she said, and even if a childminder did agree to physical punishment it would be difficult to enforce different rules for individual children.

The regulations will standardise daycare for children and are expected to come into force next year. Currently each local authority has different standards.

A department spokeswoman said childminders who worked in their own homes were different from carers in other settings.

"Rather than the government telling people what they can and cannot do in their own homes, these proposals mean that with the permission of parents childminders will be allowed to agree to smack children," she said.

"This is not the government encouraging childminders or parents to smack children; it is giving them a choice about how children are disciplined."

Gaby Shenton, acting director of the child safety charity Kidscape, said: "These proposals are an indictment of the government's attitude to children. Smacking is not acceptable.

"Children are the most vulnerable people in society, but they are not being protected by the government. We have a women's minister and a disability minister. But we do not have a children's minister when one is clearly needed."

The NCMA yesterday was planning to draw up a children's health charter in protest.

The Foundation for Cot Death said the proposal would endanger babies, as smoking around them substantially increased the risk of cot death.

fields.bodyText: Childminders yesterday criticised a government proposal to allow them to smack children and babies in their care. New regulations on childcare planned by the Department for Education and Employment would allow childminders to smack children in their homes if parents gave permission. But physical punishment would remain forbidden in day nurseries, playgroups, children's centres and creches. Childminders said they did not want the right to smack, and condemned the government for putting children at risk of abuse. The National Childminding Association (NCMA), whose 40,000 members are against smacking said its telephone lines were jammed yesterday with parents and professionals complaining about the proposals. Gill Haynes, chief executive, said: "We are appalled that the government has ignored our advice. These standards are supposed to be about providing safe quality care for children wherever they are, but smacking babies can never be acceptable in any childcare setting. "A recent consultation document published by the Department of Health showed that most people believe children under two should never be smacked by parents, let alone by a professional childcare worker. "Childminding is the most used form of day care for children. Why should it have different standards to other forms of care?" fields.headline: Blairism, noun: very difficult to define
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The trouble with lexicography is that it is a scrupulous, honourable art. You must not be manipulative, biased or subjective. It is, in fact, spin-doctoring in reverse.
fields.body:
The trouble with lexicography is that it is a scrupulous, honourable art. You must not be manipulative, biased or subjective. It is, in fact, spin-doctoring in reverse.

Which is why scholars working on the New Penguin English Dictionary have just taken an unprecedented two months to find a printable definition of one little word: Blairism.

After marathon meetings and untypically heated arguments, they accomplished the task. This week they sent the agreed definition to the printers. The dictionary is to be published at the end of the month.

It was, however, a close-run thing. "Dictionary writers are usually placid creatures," Ruth Killick, a spokeswoman for Penguin Press, said yesterday, "But the thunderstorms of June and July were nothing to the storms in our editorial office."

Nigel Wilcockson, the dictionary's editor, said: "We went through no less than five different definitions before we finally reached agreement. I've not seen such controversy since the heady days of political correctness in the 1990s."

The first 16 words were no problem: "Blairism, noun: the policies associated with Tony Blair, British Labour leader and prime minister from 1997... "

But almost every word suggested for the rest of the sentence proved to be dynamite. The first draft was "... especially regarded as a highly modified or modernised form of traditional socialist thinking intended to appeal to a wider electorate".

"Modernised" was weeded out as a matter of spin rather than fact. "Intended to appeal" was felt to be opinionated.

The next stab was "... characterised by the absence of a fundamental underlying ideology and close attention to prevailing public opinion".

This was passionately championed by some but outvoted as "tempting but too strong" - and rather nastier than a dictionary should be.

The third, more pro-Blair draft - "... characterised by a modified and inclusive form of traditional socialism" - also bit the dust. "Inclusive" was felt to be a matter of opinion and "a bit too strong".

The fourth draft has been lost among other screwed-up bits of paper but the editors eventually agreed. The final nine words of the definition will read: "... especially regarded as a modified form of traditional socialism".

Slightly tame, perhaps, but likely to stand the test of objectivity for a reader in 100 years' time. "Some might say that the lexicographers were simply doing their best to hit a moving target," Ms Killick said.

webTitle: John Hardy on Christianity and homosexuality

fields.headline: God's children, straight and gay
fields.standfirst:
More about section 28
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: What has made the recent debate on the proposed repeal of clause 28 so extraordinary is that it is hard to envisage it taking place in any other European country.
fields.body:
What has made the recent debate on the proposed repeal of clause 28 so extraordinary is that it is hard to envisage it taking place in any other European country. The Anglo-Saxon mind apparently encounters peculiar difficulties in coming to terms with the human condition, especially in matters of sexuality.

Many of the debate's protagonists have drawn on what they believe to be a reservoir of Christian concern for ethics and education. I suggest that this belief, held by many who think of themselves as good, practising Christians, could hardly be further from the truth. The arguments set forth by these would-be defenders of the faith have little, if anything, to do with a viable form of ethics or education, and nothing to do with Christianity.

What they do tell of is a profound, one might almost say pathological, nostalgia for a tribal, or feudal, past, whose values for a society such as our own are utterly redundant. The fallacy underlying this essentially anti-Christian creed is that whatever is best and most virtuous must have been set down long ago, either in scripture or by tradition - but certainly in stone.

Here a distinction has to be made; there is a world of difference between tradition and traditionalism. In Christianity, tradition - under the guidance of the Holy Spirit - is ongoing and contingent upon man's capacity to understand. Hence, Jesus's words of warning: "Many things I could tell you, but you would not understand," however, "I shall be with you always... and my Spirit will guide you into all truth." That truth, significantly present in Christ, will - if we listen and respond - "make us free".

Traditionalism, on the other hand, is a refusal to accept that deal and, despite voluble claims to gospel fidelity, a refusal to take the warnings of Christ seriously. Hence, what was once "understood" - and, according to Christ, not fully understood - is regarded as final.

What limited the understanding of even Jesus's closest friends was, of course, their conditioning. Racially and self-consciously they were rooted in the salvation story of a small semitic tribe. Traditionalist morality is rooted in that same tribal mentality, and thus belongs to a time when the nation of Israel was struggling for survival in a hostile desert environment.

Resources were scarce and had to be secured by force. Hence, numbers were all important, in particular the number of young males. The tribe had to maintain a strong fighting force, and its central ethic was geared to that end. Procreation, being a sociopolitical imperative, received the highest sanction - that of Jehovah, Lord of Hosts.

The need and justification for such a specific ethic has long disappeared. Our lives could hardly be further removed from those of our Old Testament forebears, and it is simply foolish to imagine that we can be guided by the same norms to which they clung.

If we are to mature, as the spiritual life demands, we must recognise that what Christ "told" his hearers, and a fortiori the legal and ethical considerations of ancient Israel, was provisional, contingent upon the historical, psychological and intellectual limitations of his hearers. Christ did not destroy the Law, but did try to transform and, where possible, supersede it, for he knew that the fathers of Israel did what they did because they had to. To be faithful to Christ, we must do likewise.

Those who find this conflicts with their scriptural understanding might reflect that, according to scripture, the Law delivered to Moses was itself conditional. It was a concession to the incomp- rehension of the children of Israel. God's original dispensation, we are told, was smashed to pieces by an enraged Moses.

The implications of this are that we must accept, as Christ himself accepted, our humanity - and this entails, as in the gospel, a commitment to men and women whose humanity is rich, diverse and, yes, sometimes downright annoying.

We know that between four and 10% of humanity is fundamentally homoerotic. Equally, we know that this tendency is natural, ie whatever its etiology, it is not a consequence of nurture, persuasion or promotion. As Christians, we must therefore conclude that homosexuality - given its prevalence and endurance - is an essential aspect of the imago dei .

Consequently, it has not merely to be accepted, tolerated or respected but caringly tutored - so that gay men and women can grow, and help others to grow, into "the fullness of the stature of Christ". Within a Christian understanding, such education is the right of every child, whatever its sexual orientation.

To those who advocate "an acceptance of the homosexual, but not his or her homosexuality", one can only commend the words of Christ, as reported in the Gospel of Thomas: "If you bring forth what is within you, what you have will save you. If you do not... what is within [will] kill you."

 John Hardy is a lecturer and spiritual director. His work as a priest is directed towards a radical form of ecumenism

webTitle: Laughing all the way to the bottle bank

fields.headline: Laughing all the way to the bottle bank
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A new tin shed appeared in my backyard the other day, a futile effort by the landlord and the middle-class tenants in our block to ward off the ubiquitous bin scavenger.
fields.body:
A new tin shed appeared in my backyard the other day, a futile effort by the landlord and the middle-class tenants in our block to ward off the ubiquitous bin scavenger.

Morning, noon, and night the rubbish-raiders rake through the household rubbish for anything that can be eaten, drunk, or converted into a few kopecks. It's a measure of the poverty in the city that the scavengers include not only elderly vagrants and street urchins, but prim old women, clean and neatly dressed.

The landlord's compassion has its limits, however. In an attempt to tidy things up and deter the raiders, the refuse bins were padlocked overnight in a metal shed. But within days the doors of the shed were hanging off their hinges and rubbish was strewn across the yard.

You can barely dump your black plastic bag in the bin before the rubbish regulars pounce. The most coveted prize is empties. The kids rush off to the grocer's, where they get a rouble (about 2p) a bottle. The desperate old men ransack the empties for dregs of beer, wine or something stronger.

But while the indigent bottle-collectors make a handful of kopecks, the brains behind Moscow firm Intellekt are playing for bigger stakes.

According to Rospatent, the official patents authority, Intellekt can lay claim to a payment for each of the millions of bottles circulating in Russia. Exploiting Russia's market mayhem and the lack of the standard legal and commercial instruments that underpin a "normal" free economy, the clever dicks at Intellekt filed a patent application for glass vessels.

There is still no patent law in Russia, but there is a patent office. The trick is to submit your application in highfalutin language accompanied by complicated drawings and explanations. Or you can try bribing someone at the patent office.

In Intellekt's case, the common bottle was presented as a seemingly complex conical container. The fine print went into the geometric detail of convex and concave, and the relative thickness of the glass at various points.The patent was granted.

Intellekt claims that any old beer bottle fits the description. Short of a court ruling otherwise, Intellekt is probably right.

The past few years have seen a colossal beer boom in Moscow. That spells reasonable pickings for the armies of poor people hunting the empties. But it represents far richer pickings for Intellekt, which has written to all the big breweries demanding 0.5% of their profits as royalties for the use of patented glass vessels.
