webTitle: Child sex offenders comment on the naming and shaming campaign

fields.headline: Inside the minds of Britain's most reviled
fields.standfirst:
Three offenders insist that it is children who are put in danger when paedophiles are exposed

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: James was offered a false passport the other day. And a dodgy driver's licence. His mate said it wouldn't be a problem. All he would have to do was dye his hair.
fields.body:
James was offered a false passport the other day. And a dodgy driver's licence. His mate said it wouldn't be a problem. All he would have to do was dye his hair.

James is a high-risk sex offender. Since the News of the World naming and shaming campaign began almost three weeks ago, James has lived in fear of being identified. He has refused the passport but knows it is available, should he need to disappear quickly.

James - not his real name - is 34 and is adamant he is not a paedophile now but concedes that he was for a very long time. He abused a number of boys, one as young as six, whom he had befriended. He was released on licence from prison in July 1998 and, he claims, has not reoffended.

Young and attractive, willing to help build treehouses or give boys rides on bikes, James was able to draw children to him easily. What began as flashing escalated into serious sexual abuse. Since he was 18 he has served three sentences for his assaults.

These days, James has a job. He lives near London and has friends. He also has the odd minder. Because he is classed as a high risk, he is visited by officers from a police paedophile unit and is the subject of surveillance - sometimes covert, sometimes overt. He also has a very sceptical probation officer. Because he is classed as high risk he was interviewed by officers investigating the murder of Sarah Payne.

James is talking the talk and walking the walk. The jargon of therapy sits well with him - he was a "groomer" and he "owns" his crimes. He has done a few treatment programmes and has achieved a superconfidence from the belief that he has made himself better. His eyes dart around nervously at first but as he recounts details of his crimes he pins your eyes down, watching for a twitch of disgust.

Like most other sex offenders, James opened the last two editions of the News of the World with trepidation. Had he been named, he would almost certainly have lost his job. Speaking before the newspaper's announcement yesterday that it was suspending its campaign, he said he was prepared to "give a kicking" to anyone who "grassed" him and sent his name to the paper.

Since the campaign began, agencies working with offenders have warned that vigilante attacks will lead to serious offenders going underground. Without controls and with an increase in stress, the paedophile is much more likely to reoffend. Some probation officers have reported that one or two of their supervisees have disappeared.

James says the threat of exposure does not tempt him to go to ground but he did do so before: easily. When police were looking for him after his last offence he went to the Netherlands, where he used prison contacts and hooked up with a paedophile ring. He was caught and extradited and sentenced to eight years' imprisonment, of which he served five.

James knows networks of paedophiles at home and abroad. He used to let them have videos of his offences. He maintains that it took him three years in prison before he stopped associating with them but he could get back in touch any time. James believes he knows the workings of their minds.

Quite calmly, he says: "The impact [of the outing campaign] is pretty simple, really. These guys will go on the run - they are not going to stand around waiting for a kicking or have their windows put in or firebombed. They will say to themselves, 'I am on the run now and I have a list of 20 to 30 paedophiles.' What's to stop them all getting together and all going underground or abroad?

"They are going to feel a lot safer than being alone. They will think, 'Well, we are wanted by society, our picture is going to be in the paper. OK, well I will go and snatch a kid off the street.' They are facing a life sentence anyway."

James points out that most prolific sex offenders have a network they have built up of many hundreds of people, a network that can be relied on quickly: for disappearance or pleasure.

"I do know of a lot of paedophiles that aren't on the registers at the moment that have disappeared. I know two of the people who were outed last Sunday and they told me years ago that if they were ever outed they would disappear.

"The public wants to know that their children are safe but the way their children are going to be safe is to let the professionals deal with this situation. If they continue with this they are going to end up getting some kid killed."

Clive

Like James, Clive does not fit the stereotype of the paedophile. He is trendily dressed in jeans, sweatshirt, chunky shoes. He is clean and bright. Like James, he does not look how a paedophile is supposed to look.

The panic over the murder of Sarah Payne has caused us to misuse labels, to forget that only a tiny proportion of the 110,000 men regarded as convicted sex offenders fall into the category of predatory paedophiles who abduct children. Most are minor offenders or, like Clive, have abused members of their own family. Clive, 42, was convicted of indecent assault against his girlfriend's little sister. During the course of the police investigation it emerged that he had also abused his own sisters, offences that began when he was nine. Clive was given a four and a half year sentence of which he served three years, and is now on licence until January 2002.

Like James, Clive believes he has stopped offending. He went through the sex offenders' treatment programme in prison and claims that he now avoids stressful situations, which he has identified as leading to his previous pattern of offending. He says: "I am absolutely certain that I won't reoffend. I am a different person from what I used to be. I read a lot of books on Buddhism, shamanism and philosophies and that helps me. I am more educated now and know what's wrong."

Clive produces pages of A4 on which he has written lengthy notes about the News of the World campaign. He lists the effects of naming and shaming: "shopping will be difficult", and "socialising will be virtually non-existent". But, importantly, he says the campaign has increased stress levels, depression and fear and lowered self-esteem; all factors that can combine to trigger reoffending.

Clive has met many paedophiles who are untouched by their offences and fears their reaction to outing. "Most sex offenders will not endanger their own life," he says. "The risk of reoffending increases if prison is the only alternative means of safety. If you have nowhere else to go and you know prison is the only place you can go, then you may as well reoffend.

"Those that have not been convicted or caught may use alternative, more severe means in gaining a victim so as not to get caught. The most severe means is obviously murder. There's very few sex offenders I would say that are high risk, but the ones that are high risk are capable."

He believes disclosure only reinforces the idea that offenders can never be allowed to change, thus giving them a justification for their behaviour. He thinks children who threaten to expose known sex offenders may be at risk.

Clive is, of course, also worried for himself. His girlfriend has not told her family about his past. "She would have a lot to answer to," he says. "She thinks that her brother will actually beat her up. She's certainly incredibly scared.

"I can understand people's point of view, why they don't want me to come out or mix with them. I think the way forward is to accept that I must have a second chance. If I fail again then fair enough, give me life."

John

Forty-nine-year-old John knows what it is like to be exposed. He has been beaten up on a number of occasions, verbally abused and taken for the serious sex offender that justice decided he was not.

John is on two years' probation for indecent assault. He says that on two occasions he put his hand on a boy's bottom and on his back and he was eventually prosecuted for it. He denies any further assault but admits he is not sure what might have happened. The court considered it a minor offence but his local community did not.

John fears wider exposure, not for himself but for his family. And he is also worried about the effect any disclosure would have on his victim. "It wasn't a serious offence but it was still an offence and the victim needs protecting," he says.

"Given what happened I can understand people's anger but this isn't the answer. As far as I am concerned they are using a child's death to make money."

All names have been changed.

Since the campaign began, agencies working with offenders have warned that vigilante attacks will lead to serious offenders going underground. Without controls and with an increase in stress, the paedophile is much more likely to reoffend. Some probation officers have reported that one or two of their supervisees have disappeared. James says the threat of exposure does not tempt him to go to ground but he did do so before: easily. When police were looking for him after his last offence he went to the Netherlands, where he used prison contacts and hooked up with a paedophile ring. He was caught and extradited and sentenced to eight years' imprisonment, of which he served five. James knows networks of paedophiles at home and abroad. He used to let them have videos of his offences. He maintains that it took him three years in prison before he stopped associating with them but he could get back in touch any time. James believes he knows the workings of their minds. Quite calmly, he says: "The impact [of the outing campaign] is pretty simple, really. These guys will go on the run - they are not going to stand around waiting for a kicking or have their windows put in or firebombed. They will say to themselves, 'I am on the run now and I have a list of 20 to 30 paedophiles.' What's to stop them all getting together and all going underground or abroad? "They are going to feel a lot safer than being alone. They will think, 'Well, we are wanted by society, our picture is going to be in the paper. OK, well I will go and snatch a kid off the street.' They are facing a life sentence anyway." James points out that most prolific sex offenders have a network they have built up of many hundreds of people, a network that can be relied on quickly: for disappearance or pleasure. "I do know of a lot of paedophiles that aren't on the registers at the moment that have disappeared. I know two of the people who were outed last Sunday and they told me years ago that if they were ever outed they would disappear. "The public wants to know that their children are safe but the way their children are going to be safe is to let the professionals deal with this situation. If they continue with this they are going to end up getting some kid killed." Clive Like James, Clive does not fit the stereotype of the paedophile. He is trendily dressed in jeans, sweatshirt, chunky shoes. He is clean and bright. Like James, he does not look how a paedophile is supposed to look. The panic over the murder of Sarah Payne has caused us to misuse labels, to forget that only a tiny proportion of the 110,000 men regarded as convicted sex offenders fall into the category of predatory paedophiles who abduct children. Most are minor offenders or, like Clive, have abused members of their own family. Clive, 42, was convicted of indecent assault against his girlfriend's little sister. During the course of the police investigation it emerged that he had also abused his own sisters, offences that began when he was nine. Clive was given a four and a half year sentence of which he served three years, and is now on licence until January 2002. Like James, Clive believes he has stopped offending. He went through the sex offenders' treatment programme in prison and claims that he now avoids stressful situations, which he has identified as leading to his previous pattern of offending. He says: "I am absolutely certain that I won't reoffend. I am a different person from what I used to be. I read a lot of books on Buddhism, shamanism and philosophies and that helps me. I am more educated now and know what's wrong." Clive produces pages of A4 on which he has written lengthy notes about the News of the World campaign. He lists the effects of naming and shaming: "shopping will be difficult", and "socialising will be virtually non-existent". But, importantly, he says the campaign has increased stress levels, depression and fear and lowered self-esteem; all factors that can combine to trigger reoffending. Clive has met many paedophiles who are untouched by their offences and fears their reaction to outing. "Most sex offenders will not endanger their own life," he says. "The risk of reoffending increases if prison is the only alternative means of safety. If you have nowhere else to go and you know prison is the only place you can go, then you may as well reoffend. "Those that have not been convicted or caught may use alternative, more severe means in gaining a victim so as not to get caught. The most severe means is obviously murder. There's very few sex offenders I would say that are high risk, but the ones that are high risk are capable." He believes disclosure only reinforces the idea that offenders can never be allowed to change, thus giving them a justification for their behaviour. He thinks children who threaten to expose known sex offenders may be at risk. Clive is, of course, also worried for himself. His girlfriend has not told her family about his past. "She would have a lot to answer to," he says. "She thinks that her brother will actually beat her up. She's certainly incredibly scared. "I can understand people's point of view, why they don't want me to come out or mix with them. I think the way forward is to accept that I must have a second chance. If I fail again then fair enough, give me life." John Forty-nine-year-old John knows what it is like to be exposed. He has been beaten up on a number of occasions, verbally abused and taken for the serious sex offender that justice decided he was not. John is on two years' probation for indecent assault. He says that on two occasions he put his hand on a boy's bottom and on his back and he was eventually prosecuted for it. He denies any further assault but admits he is not sure what might have happened. The court considered it a minor offence but his local community did not. John fears wider exposure, not for himself but for his family. And he is also worried about the effect any disclosure would have on his victim. "It wasn't a serious offence but it was still an offence and the victim needs protecting," he says. "Given what happened I can understand people's anger but this isn't the answer. As far as I am concerned they are using a child's death to make money." All names have been changed.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Visit the Cock Beek as it winds its way past the housing estates of East Leeds and you will be struck by the sheer numbers of bicycle frames, pushchairs and bed frames dumped down its steep banks.
fields.body:
West Yorkshire

Visit the Cock Beek as it winds its way past the housing estates of East Leeds and you will be struck by the sheer numbers of bicycle frames, pushchairs and bed frames dumped down its steep banks. Pick it up further downstream, after it has trickled through the heavily manicured grounds of Garforth Golf Course, and you will find it snaking through open farmland, lined with ash and alder, bordered by pasture or crops. Here and there, pockets of wetland survive, where meadowsweet, flag iris and water dropwort abound.

In the village of Aberford, close by the county boundary with North Yorkshire, it becomes a shallow watercourse, the bottom covered with fine shingle. Small trout bask in the sunlight and grey wagtails flutter up from bankside rocks to catch mosquitoes and midges hovering above the water. A few days ago I watched a group of children hunting for bullheads beneath the larger stones, shrieking with delight each time they imagined one had been caught, only to peer in frustration into a plastic jar full of nothing but cloudy water.

Water voles were my quarry. West Yorkshire Ecology, a unit funded by the five local authorities in the county, has commissioned a substantial survey for this fast disappearing small rodent. Sadly, along the whole 10 kilometres of the Cock Beek which I visited, not one trace of water vole did I find. They used to be there, 20 or 30 years ago. Local landowners recalled seeing them; one even admitted shooting them with an air rifle as a boy. Today they are gone, not because of shooting but through predation by mink. There were plenty of their tracks and signs, paw prints left in the soft mud at the water's edge. Another victim of this escaped and released alien seems to be the moorhen. Very, very few were to be seen.

Despite the lack of water voles, there were lighter moments. A roan Shire mare looked down upon me as I waded thigh-deep in the beck below its enclosure. If horses are able to give quizzical looks, this one certainly did.

webTitle: Israeli designers go weak for Arab chic

fields.headline: Israeli designers go weak for Arab chic
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The first time Shimon Cohen held a length of Damascus silk in his hands, the bright, striped fabric that is prized throughout the Arab world was a revelation.
fields.body:
The first time Shimon Cohen held a length of Damascus silk in his hands, the bright, striped fabric that is prized throughout the Arab world was a revelation.

"When I touched the brocade, I felt it was heavy with time," he said. "It spoke to me inside."

And so the first wave of a new trend reached Shenken Street, the habitat of stylish Tel Avivians, which is cluttered with boutiques and cafes and serves as the launching pad for many fashions.

This summer Mr Cohen and a handful of other Israeli designers have penetrated a cultural barrier, plundering the markets of East Jerusalem and towns under Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank for cloth, beads, and T-shirts emblazoned with Arab film stars and calligraphy.

Their small, tentative and confused homage to indigenous culture is rare in Israel where "Arab taste" is generally considered a term of abuse.

It signals increasing curiosity among Israelis towards their former enemies, the Palestinians, and greater cultural assertion by the Second Israel - the immigrants from Middle Eastern countries.

In recent months, for example, there has been a small trickle of Jewish Israelis returning to West Bank towns to shop.

To Mr Cohen, a French-trained designer who sells long dresses with Damascus silk panels in his shop on Shenken Street, the interest in traditional Arab textiles was as much about self-discovery as appreciation of the Palestinian other.

Born in Haifa of Moroccan immigrants, Mr Cohen, 35, spent his childhood in an agony of embarrassment, compounded by his parents speaking Arabic at home and playing Arabic records.

"I wanted to be Israeli," he said. "When I was 15 years old to be a Moroccan was not so good."

But when he grew up he came back to his roots.

"Suddenly I felt something inside me wake up. Because inside, I am an Arab. I speak the language, and I grew up eating from an Arab kitchen."

Recent students of the Shenkar College of Engineering and Design, Israel's top fashion training institute, have created Arabic-inspired collections and the college had its first Israeli Arab graduate this year.

The current guide to Tel Aviv nightclubs is emblazoned with lines of Arabic type. But the cover designer admits that the writing, which makes no sense in translation, was chosen only for its graphic appeal.

"A day in pyjamas, a day in the kitchen," it reads.

The Israeli designs have yet to penetrate the mainstream or win followers in Arab East Jerusalem or in areas ruled by the Palestinian Authority.

There the younger generation dresses as it has for years: in jeans and T-shirts, or, for the more traditional women, headscarves and long tunics.

And while Mr Cohen is expansive on his love of Arabic music, textiles and architecture, the appreciation does not extend towards a greater understanding of the Palestinians and their political aspirations.

"It is not Saddam Hussein I think about when I make a dress," he said.

"It is not because I like Arabs. I am doing it because I like the colours, and I like the wonderful Syrian brocades."

But Hani Mourad, director of the Institute of Fashion and Textile Design near Bethlehem, the only such college in Palestinian-ruled areas, does not take offence at cultural borrowing.

"It may be 1,001 nights, but at least you really have to like something to copy it," he said.

"Politically, it is a nice statement that they are calling it Arabic. Maybe one day they will call it Palestinian."

For veterans of the tiny Israeli fashion scene, the latest trend for Arab-influenced design is a tiny bubble waiting to be popped. They remember the 60s and 70s when loose-fitting kaftans made in Israel were snapped up by New York boutiques.

Israeli designers plundered liberally in those days, scouring Arab markets for beads, cloth and keffiyehs, and employing Palestinian seamstresses expert in traditional embroidery, according to Tamara Yuval-Jones, a designer from that period who now teaches at the Shenkar college .

But with modern Israel intent on modelling itself on western Europe and north America, the fashion designers turned west again in what Ms Yuval-Jones argued was partly the result of a lack of confidence in a new nation.

"Usually a provincial sign of taste is that they want what they see in Paris or Milan," she said.

"Most of the designers here want fabrics from Paris or Italy, and they are not interested in fabrics that they can find just around the corner."

But the turbulent politics of the region also intervened to inhibit appreciation of indigenous culture.

"Unfortunately," she said, "there is not a big love here between Jews and Arabs."

fields.headline: Kobie Coetsee
fields.standfirst: Afrikaner leader who foresaw the collapse of apartheid and met Mandela in jail
fields.trailText: The former South African minister of justice Kobie Coetsee, who has died of a heart attack aged 69, opened a door in the wall of blind prejudice on which apartheid was built by initiating official contact with the imprisoned Nelson Mandela.
fields.body:
The former South African minister of justice Kobie Coetsee, who has died of a heart attack aged 69, opened a door in the wall of blind prejudice on which apartheid was built by initiating official contact with the imprisoned Nelson Mandela.

He showed great moral courage in 1985, when the reform programme of his mentor, President PW Botha, lay in ruins and an untrammelled police force fought to regain control of the turbulent black townships. After five years as minister of justice and prisons, at the apex of racist oppression, Coetsee decided to take up a challenge from Mrs Winnie Mandela, then still married to the internally exiled hero of the black majority, and a formidable beacon of resistance in her own right: to meet his most famous prisoner.

By this time, Mandela had already been moved from the notorious penal colony on Robben Island, off Cape Town, to Pollsmoor jail, in the Cape Province. The meeting at the prison so impressed Coetsee that he soon went back for more, even though the world's most famous detainee had established moral ascendancy over his chief jailer.

Coetsee, whose original motive was to neutralise Mandela by offering him freedom in exchange for a public renunciation of violence, was among the first Afrikaner nationalist politicians to grasp the truth that white minority rule really was doomed, however often Botha might say "adapt or die" - a policy that was really always intended to preserve rather than abolish apartheid.

In 1989, four years after the historic first encounter, Coetsee managed to engineer a secret meeting between Mandela and the president himself. Botha, a Hendrik Verwoerd without the vision - and South Africa's most repressive white ruler - was not impressed, and a brief exchange foundered on Botha's total intransigence.

That August, the pragmatic tendency in the ruling National party, which included Coetsee and FW de Klerk and was terrified by damaging American economic sanctions against apartheid, found the courage and strength to oust Botha. Six months later, Mandela walked free from Pollsmoor, the expectations heaped on his elderly shoulders by all races as high as his moral standing.

Coetsee himself was born at Ladybrand, in the Afrikaner heartland of the Orange Free State. His family was steeped in Boer resistance to domination, British or black. Both his grandfathers led troops in the Boer war that engaged the British empire at the turn of the last century. One of them, CR Swart, became the first president of Verwoerd's republic of South Africa in 1961.

Coetsee's parents were rural Afrikaners, totally committed to the National party, which came to power in the white-dominated elections of 1948 - and stayed there until Mandela's African National Congress won power in 1994. After studying law at the University of the Orange Free State, the young Coetsee became active in local politics, marrying the daughter of another Afrikaner family, Helena "Ena" Malan, in 1956.

He won the Bloemfontein West constituency in the whites-only election of 1968. When Botha became prime minister in 1978, he made Coetsee deputy minister of defence (Botha's old department and his favourite). Two years later, Coetsee was promoted to the cabinet as minister of justice, with prisons added to his responsibilities.

As such, he was blamed for the mounting detention without trial of opponents of apartheid, as the Botha regime struggled against internal and external resistance. This understandably overshadowed changes introduced by Coetsee, liberal in their context, to the laws of rape, domestic violence and divorce.

Botha changed the constitution in 1983, elevating himself to the post of executive state president and inaugurating what proved to be apartheid's vicious and brutal last stand. Six years later, with the economy prostrate, de Klerk, significantly assisted by Coetsee, took over. The latter told Winnie Mandela over tea and cakes that her husband would soon be free.

It was only to be expected that Coetsee would take a leading role in the ensuing, extremely fraught, negotiations between the National party leadership and the ANC, which led, initially, to power-sharing in an uneasy transitional government, and then to outright ANC rule after the first elections under universal franchise.

During the talks, Coetsee, while always committed to the fair rule of law, showed apprehension about the prospect of instant majority rule, fearing that the volk from which he came would simply be swept aside. At one stage, he thought de Klerk was making dangerous concessions and tried to resign from his cabinet post. But as a fair man, he could not deny the majority's rights, and was persuaded to stay on.

After the 1994 election, he was appointed president of the new South African senate, an acknowledgement from all sides of his decent role. Troubled by ill-health, he retired in 1998 to his farm in the Orange Free State to pursue, all too briefly, his hobbies of shooting and fishing.

He leaves his wife, three daughters and two sons.

Dan van der Vat

Hendrik Jacobus 'Kobie' Coetsee, politician, born April 19 1931; died 29 July 2000

fields.headline: Freed Shankill bomber regrets 'accident'
fields.standfirst:
Survivor of blast that took 10 lives says he never intended to kill 'innocent people' but accepts he is now a loyalist target

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Shankill Road bomber, Sean Kelly, today ends his seven-year silence on one of the worst atrocities in 30 years of violence in Northern Ireland, claiming the IRA's murder of nine Protestant shoppers in the loyalist heartland of west Belfast was an accident.
fields.body:
The Shankill Road bomber, Sean Kelly, today ends his seven-year silence on one of the worst atrocities in 30 years of violence in Northern Ireland, claiming the IRA's murder of nine Protestant shoppers in the loyalist heartland of west Belfast was an accident.

Kelly, 28, who calls himself an ordinary guy caught up in the conflict, admits in a newspaper interview that he will be a target for loyalists for the rest of his life. But he is keen to stay in his native Ardoyne in north Belfast, and wants to do community work.

Kelly, whose accomplice Thomas Begley, 23, was killed in the October 1993 attack, tells the North Belfast News: "The fact innocent people died is something I will have to live with for the rest of my life. While we did go out to kill the leadership of the UDA, we never intended for innocent people to die. It happened, and I have to accept that the families of those people who were killed in the explosion will never forgive me. But it honestly was an accident and if I could do anything to change what happened, believe me I would do it."

The IRA intended to kill Johnny Adair, the Ulster Freedom Fighters' leader, believing his team would be holding a meeting upstairs from Frizzell's fish shop on the Shankill Road at the time of the attack. An 11-second fuse was apparently meant to detonate the bomb as they ran past after a warning was shouted.

But the targets were instead at a nearby cafe, and, in the reckless operation, the bomb exploded before shoppers could get out. Begley, posing as a fish salesman, was bending over the bomb as it ignited early, and was blown to pieces. Kelly, also in white overalls, was at the door. One rescuer who was unaware who he was recalled him trying to walk off as he was dug from the rubble, scarcely conscious. His release sparked rare unity among rival loyalist groups. Graffiti close to his home reads: "S. Kelly. We can wait. UVF-UFF."

Kelly, who lost the sight of his left eye and power in his left arm in the explosion, says: "I just want to get on with my life like everyone else that got out of jail. But I would be fooling myself if I thought that loyalists would not try to kill me at some time or another."

He was one of 86 convicted terrrorists freed eight days ago as the early release scheme, a key plank of the Good Friday agreement, reached its climax. Among the 428 prisoners to benefit are 143 life sentence prisoners.

The jubilant scenes which greeted the mass release from the Maze prison have exacerbated unionist disenchantment with the agreement. Several pundits believe unionist backing for it has dropped from around 55% in May 1998 to less than 40% now, suggesting serious problems lie ahead for the political process.

Kelly tells the predominantly nationalist weekly paper: "I know that there are those people who will say that I have no right to talk about victims. But everyone has suffered, including those of us who have been to jail.

"I lost my close friend Thomas Begley that day. Like the other people who died in the bomb, he was a mother's son too.

"I do not want to see any more people dying or getting injured. I not want to see any more young men and women rotting away in jail for years."

Kelly, expected to attend a function in the Ardoyne last night to mark his release, continues: "I have supported the peace process since the beginning, and am fully behind the Sinn Fein leadership who have helped bring the peace process about.

"It wasn't because we wanted out of jail early. It is because we realised better than anyone that a settlement had to be found if this conflict was going to be brought to an end some day. I hope that day has now come."

Kelly, 28, who calls himself an ordinary guy caught up in the conflict, admits in a newspaper interview that he will be a target for loyalists for the rest of his life. But he is keen to stay in his native Ardoyne in north Belfast, and wants to do community work. Kelly, whose accomplice Thomas Begley, 23, was killed in the October 1993 attack, tells the North Belfast News: "The fact innocent people died is something I will have to live with for the rest of my life. While we did go out to kill the leadership of the UDA, we never intended for innocent people to die. The IRA intended to kill Johnny Adair, the Ulster Freedom Fighters' leader, believing his team would be holding a meeting upstairs from Frizzell's fish shop on the Shankill Road at the time of the attack. fields.headline: Francisco Javier Sáenz de Oiza
fields.standfirst: Iconoclastic architect whose buildings reinvigorated the cities of post-Franco Spain

fields.body:
Driving into Madrid from Barajas international airport, the Spanish capital is heralded by an extraordinary monument. In the summer heat haze it is hard, until you get close, to work out what exactly this Brobdingnagian structure is. One of Don Quixote's giants? An overgrown Spanish oak? A freak outcrop of vertiginous rock, its peak neon-lit by a cinematic billboard at night?

As you inch nearer, you finally work it out. This is the Torres Blancas building, a huge organic-style apartment block, designed in 1961 and completed in 1968 by the architect Francisco Javier Sáenz de Oiza, who has died of cancer, aged 81. With his Banco de Bilbao, it remains the most distinctive modern building in Madrid.

Sáenz de Oiza was one of a small number of energetic practitioners who reinvigorated Spanish architecture in the 1950s and 1960s, after the deep sleep of dull neo-classicism dutifully trotted out by architects after Franco's seizure of power in 1939. Along with José Coderch, Oriol Bohigas and Alejandro de la Sota, he brought, at first, a highly rational geometric modernism, and then an inconoclastic "organicist" architecture, into what had become the stale, dry mix of Francoist design.

Architects, however, were far freer to express new ideas under the fascists than writers and film-makers. It is worth noting that, when Sáenz de Oiza began work on the radical Torres Blancas in 1961, Luis Buñuel's Viridiana, which had just won a prize in Venice, was banned by Franco's censors; the liberal newspaper, Madrid, was closed as he started on the design of the distinctive Banco de Bilbao (the BBV building today) 10 years later.

Because architecture is not a literal art, its practioners have often been able to experiment under the nose of dictators, whose own taste has tended to be for a grandiose, yet formal, neo-classicism.

The Torres Blancas building was, however, Sáenz de Oiza's most extreme and expressive design. He was noted for his rational and sometimes monumental housing, beginning in Madrid at the end of the 1940s, and for his later attempt to reconcile the naturalness of Frank Lloyd Wright with the geometric logic and precision of Mies van der Rohe.

This process began at the time of the last of the Congrès Internationaux d'Architecture Moderne (CIAM) meetings in the 1950s. Here, Team X, a group of young international architects that Sáenz de Oiza associated with, won the day with a campaign for a more human, modern architecture than the clinical white approach that emerged in the 1920s with Le Corbusier and Mies.

This approach can be seen in the Ciudad Blanca tourist housing of 1961-3, which Sáenz de Oiza designed, on the coast at Alcudia, Majorca. Although quite severe looking, the white concrete apartments form a modern landscape that sets up a man-made dialogue with the seascape they intrude upon.

The search for a balance between the natural and the man-made in architectural design was to lead Sáenz de Oiza up several alleyways in his career, more or less successfully. He looked for inspiration, at various times and in various of his own projects, in the design and ideas not just of Wright and Mies, but also of the American-Finnish architect Eero Saarinen, the Finn Jorn Utzon and the Estonian-American Louis Kahn, all of whom designed highly expressive buildings that took modern architecture a long way from Le Corbusier's "machines for living in".

Saarinen's most outlandish building was the TWA terminal, in the guise of birds' wings at John F Kennedy airport, New York; Utzon's was the unforgettable Sydney Opera House; and Kahn's, the Bangladeshi parliament building in Dacca. In fact, one of Sáenz de Oiza's latest designs, the Torretriana regional government building in Seville (1989-97), is a homage to Kahn.

Unsure perhaps of his identity as an architect, or perhaps just a modest man, Sáenz de Oiza often said, "I'm really a very bad architect." He was heard to say this during his brief acceptance speech when presented with the Prince of Asturias Prize in 1993, one of many awards that came his way during the last 20 years of his life. More likely, however, it was a case of Sáenz de Oiza being continually dissatisfied with his work - it was harder for architects to find their feet as confidently in Franco's Spain as it was in democratic Europe and the United States.

However, there was no lack of work. Franco's Spain was often quite successful from a strictly economic point of view. Between 1950 and 1970, the population of Madrid rose from about 2m to 4m people. New buildings were needed as never before. Sáenz de Oiza was one of the architects who did well during this boom, and has left his mark on the city - with the Torres Blancas and the great rounded Banco de Bilbao Tower of 1971-81, on Paseo de la Castellana, Madrid's main thoroughfare.

After Franco's death in 1975, public sector architecture throughout Spain enjoyed a boom as the regions regained increasing levels of autonomy and new administrative and civic buildings were needed or wanted.

Born in Navarra, Sáenz de Oiza trained in Madrid, and spent most of his career in the Castillian capital. In the early 1980s, he became director of the Madrid School of Architecture where, a lively and talkative man who could criticise without causing offence, he was popular with students.

As part of the post-Franco establishment, he designed the Spanish embassy in Brussels, along with such other public monuments as the Public University of Navarra, Pamplona, and the delightful remodelling of an old palacio in Las Palmas, Gran Canaria, into the Atlantic Centre of Modern Art (1988-89). This showed in another guise how the architect was always trying to reconcile one architectural approach with another.

Mostly he got it right, although there are some designs - such as the broad-shouldered social housing complex (1986-90) on the edge of Madrid's M-30 express ring road - that lack every last spore of the organic quality he sought, and expressed so dramatically in the Torres Blancas.

Saenz de Oiza is survived by his wife and their seven children, four of them architects who frequently collaborated with their father.

Jonathan Glancey

Francisco Javier Sáenz de Oiza, architect, born October 12 1918; died July 18 2000

webTitle: Mark Lawson: The naming and shaming debate

fields.headline: After Sarah
fields.standfirst: Let's face it: killing or castration is the only alternative to the sex offenders' register
fields.trailText: Let's face it: killing or castration is the only alternative to the sex offenders' register
fields.body:
As the Sydney Olympics approaches, it is a good week to remember the biggest loser of the 1996 games in Atlanta. Richard Jewell was the security guard accused by the media of planting the bomb which exploded in the city. He was subsequently proved to be innocent, but too late for his reputation or peace of mind and residence.

Jewell's story is a powerful modern fable. A recent book revealed that President Clinton keeps in his Oval Office desk a "Richard Jewell file", containing cuttings about a case which he believes to demonstrate the potentially lethal irresponsibility of the media. As "naming and shaming" is directed against British paedophiles - and mobs storm the homes of those thought to be a threat to children - perhaps the editor of the News of the World and all residents' associations should put a Richard Jewell file in their desks. The newspaper's immediate campaign may have gone away - yesterday's belated common sense perhaps reflecting the Murdoch empire's unease at being in opposition to both police and the NSPCC - but the issue and public anger remain.

The history of witch-hunts - whether against satanists or communists - generally does discredit to the hunters. But this explosion of anger, in which newspaper editors and citizens have become self-declared special constables, is a significant public moment and its roots should be explored. In brutal terms, the public reaction to the Sarah Payne case is a freak result of the time it took to find her body. If the murder had been discovered within hours - allowing no press conferences, no family appeals, no motorway service station sightings - the terrible grief of those who loved her would have been no less, but there would have been minimal impact on those who didn't know her. She would have stayed in the public's mind for about as long as the victims of plane crashes.

The young girl's iconic power derives from the fortnight in which it was necessary for the police and her family to maintain the possibility that she was alive. The News of the World's behaviour on the last two weekends seems obviously reprehensible to many. But the mob was also brought to the door in part by the hysterical, sentimental and religiose coverage of the child's absence and death. People - in a compressed version of the Diana phenomenon - were given time to think they knew her.

Another trigger to the listing of paedophiles is the fact that secrecy - and its civilian equivalent, privacy - have become luxuries in most areas of culture. The former head of MI5 (the second to be named in parliament) is about to publish her memoirs. Tax returns and Number 10 memos turn up in newspaper offices. Suspects in murder investigations - including a man twice arrested in the Sarah Payne case - are now routinely named by the media, where once they would have been only "a 41-year-old man". Even the BBC, after long resistance, now names those in the interrogation room despite the risk - read the Richard Jewell file - that they will be released without charge.

In this age of openness, what justification could there be, the argument runs, for convicted paedophiles alone to be allowed to keep the blinds down? The pressure for exposure increases with the mounting evidence of past cases in which establishment bodies - the Roman Catholic church, children's homes, schools - have sheltered known sex offenders and even directed them towards a fresh supply of young flesh.

In this way, the naming and shaming crisis is a continuation of the Tony Martin story. In both cases, there is a dangerous gulf between judicial judgment and public perception of the issues. Already unpopular for sending Norfolk farmers to prison for defending their property, courts and police are now perceived to be secreting sex offenders in the house next door.

But crucial to the vigilante reaction is the nature of the crime. It is possible to make the case for the rehabilitation of terrorists or murderers without the instant assumption that you personally wish to plant bombs or wield knives. But any sympathy to paedophiles is taken as a sexual confession. Irritating as it may be to probation officers who work with sex offenders, this prejudice is logical. Terrorism may be justified by politics and murder by passion or provocation. Paedophilia is the only major crime in which there is no possibility of extenuating circumstances.

And yet what is to be done with the criminals? Would the News of the World's readers pay the taxes to keep paedophiles jailed for ever? Could they tolerate the level of executions which would be the only alternative? And so the only option is the maintenance of offenders at private addresses known to the police and their probation officers.

The problem here is that the ancient principle of Nimby (not in my back yard) becomes understandably universal. The traditional liberal-baiting question during debates on the possible release of Myra Hindley is: would you let her babysit your children? Any yes is purely rhetorical. In the same way, the liberal position on sex offenders is that they should live under police supervision in someone else's village. Now that this rat is out of the bag, it is hard to see how the police and courts can trap it again.

The debate about naming and shaming exactly apes that over capital punishment. In both cases, substantial and legitimate moral horror over criminal acts leads to a call for terrible remedies. Indeed, vigilante attacks on the homes of named paedophiles or those who may sound confusingly like them are a citizen-driven form of capital punishment. If the current mood sustains, the killing of a paedophile by the public seems almost inevitable.

But - though supported by millions of citizens and many newspapers - the death penalty is kept off the statute books by the one unanswerable and non-politically partisan argument against it. What if you get the wrong person? The same applies to naming and shaming, in which there are already cases in which the wrong man has been got by both the News of the World and vigilantes.

While there is some rough justice in a Blairite minister being caught between populism and common sense, Jack Straw faces over paedophilia a delicate and terrible judgment. Although no one would wish it, a false attack with awful consequences is his best hope of lifting the mood of deranged recrimination which has followed Sarah Payne's murder.

Without that, the future for known paedophiles is chemical castration, longer prison terms, or nonce safe-houses maintained at great police expense and time. All the home secretary can do when the public waves the Sarah Payne memorial book is to raise the Richard Jewell file against it. But, at the moment, it is only one of those volumes that the public wants to read.

webTitle: Farm seizures start with widow's eviction

fields.headline: Farm seizures start with widow's eviction
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean government has begun its long-promised mass expropriation of white-owned land for redistribution to millions of black peasants with the seizure of the first farms without compensation.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Centenary  and Chris McGreal  in Harare
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean government has begun its long-promised mass expropriation of white-owned land for redistribution to millions of black peasants with the seizure of the first farms without compensation.

The confiscation of Viewfield Farm in Centenary, an hour's drive from Harare, comes after months of confrontation and violence as President Robert Mugabe vowed to take much of Zimbabwe's fertile land out of the hands of a few thousand white farmers.

Although hundreds of farms have already been illegally occupied by war veterans and their supporters, and several white families forced to flee their homes, Viewfield is the first to be taken by the government after being legally designated for confiscation.

An official messenger served the elderly owner, April Davies, with the papers authorising its seizure. She has 90 days to vacate her house. Her 34 black farm labourers and their families have also been ordered off the property.

The government bussed 47 families, described by local officials as "land starved", to the 1,300-hectare (3,200-acre) tobacco and maize farm. They were allowed to peg out 28 hectares each.

The government says another two dozen farms in the area will be resettled within days and it will use the army to move 500,000 families on to expropriated farms in the coming months.

It described those given land on Viewfield Farm as widows, war veterans and villagers on communal land. Locals say the families were chosen for their loyalty to Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party.

The Mashonaland provincial governor, Elliot Manyika, who handed over the land, said: "This is the start of an ongoing exercise to resettle the people before the onset of the rains.

"We want them to prepare the land and produce to feed the nation. Infrastructure will follow when we have finished putting the people on the land," he said to the cheers of the new owners.

But by Mr Manyika's own admission, the 47 families have no tools or skill in using the farm's equipment, raising serious doubts that they will fulfil his exhortation.

Critics warn that wholesale seizure of commercial farms will wreck Zimbabwe's agricultural production and an already battered economy. The finance minister, Simba Makoni, admits that the economy is in "deep crisis" and imposed a sharp devaluation and a block on new public spending in an attempt to revive it.

The government is also scrambling to fend off looming American sanctions aimed at blocking all international finance and US aid to Zimbabwe because of the illegal land seizures and political violence.

White farmers have taken the government to the supreme court, arguing that the land seizures amount to unconstitutional racial discrimination.

In his court application, David Hasluck, the director of the Commercial Farmers Union, concedes that whites dominate land ownership but adds that the confiscations amount to "an assault upon the white farming community, the rape of their properties and the deprivation of their livelihoods".

Mrs Davies's farm was invaded by "war veterans" in March. Within weeks her husband Douglas died of a heart attack. She blames the stress of the land seizure. After the confiscation order was served, Mrs Davies went to Harare to stay with her daughter. She refuses to speak to the press.

Although Mr Mugabe has vowed repeatedly that his government will not pay a penny for the soil he says was originally stolen from blacks by British colonists, the government is legally obliged to compensate Mrs Davies for her house and farm buildings. But the two sides have not even begun to discuss an amount and the farmers union doubts she will see any money soon.

The confiscation of Viewfield Farm in Centenary, an hour's drive from Harare, comes after months of confrontation and violence as President Robert Mugabe vowed to take much of Zimbabwe's fertile land out of the hands of a few thousand white farmers. Although hundreds of farms have already been illegally occupied by war veterans and their supporters, and several white families forced to flee their homes, Viewfield is the first to be taken by the government after being legally designated for confiscation. An official messenger served the elderly owner, April Davies, with the papers authorising its seizure. She has 90 days to vacate her house. Her 34 black farm labourers and their families have also been ordered off the property. The government bussed 47 families, described by local officials as "land starved", to the 1,300-hectare (3,200-acre) tobacco and maize farm. They were allowed to peg out 28 hectares each. The government says another two dozen farms in the area will be resettled within days and it will use the army to move 500,000 families on to expropriated farms in the coming months. It described those given land on Viewfield Farm as widows, war veterans and villagers on communal land. Locals say the families were chosen for their loyalty to Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party. The Mashonaland provincial governor, Elliot Manyika, who handed over the land, said: "This is the start of an ongoing exercise to resettle the people before the onset of the rains. "We want them to prepare the land and produce to feed the nation. Infrastructure will follow when we have finished putting the people on the land," he said to the cheers of the new owners. But by Mr Manyika's own admission, the 47 families have no tools or skill in using the farm's equipment, raising serious doubts that they will fulfil his exhortation. Critics warn that wholesale seizure of commercial farms will wreck Zimbabwe's agricultural production and an already battered economy. The finance minister, Simba Makoni, admits that the economy is in "deep crisis" and imposed a sharp devaluation and a block on new public spending in an attempt to revive it. The government is also scrambling to fend off looming American sanctions aimed at blocking all international finance and US aid to Zimbabwe because of the illegal land seizures and political violence. White farmers have taken the government to the supreme court, arguing that the land seizures amount to unconstitutional racial discrimination. In his court application, David Hasluck, the director of the Commercial Farmers Union, concedes that whites dominate land ownership but adds that the confiscations amount to "an assault upon the white farming community, the rape of their properties and the deprivation of their livelihoods". Mrs Davies's farm was invaded by "war veterans" in March. Within weeks her husband Douglas died of a heart attack. She blames the stress of the land seizure. After the confiscation order was served, Mrs Davies went to Harare to stay with her daughter. She refuses to speak to the press. Although Mr Mugabe has vowed repeatedly that his government will not pay a penny for the soil he says was originally stolen from blacks by British colonists, the government is legally obliged to compensate Mrs Davies for her house and farm buildings. But the two sides have not even begun to discuss an amount and the farmers union doubts she will see any money soon.

webTitle: Letters: The talent to be radical by design

fields.headline: The talent to be radical by design
fields.trailText: Your article (French town stung by mosquito report, July 25) makes passing and completely ill-informed reference to the Centre Georges Pompidou, in particular relating to its recent refurbishment.
fields.body:
Your article (French town stung by mosquito report, July 25) makes passing and completely ill-informed reference to the Centre Georges Pompidou, in particular relating to its recent refurbishment. You claim the building was "so hi-tech it had to be almost dismantled before it could be repainted ..."

In fact the building's inherent flexibility assisted rather than hampered the recent refurbishment, which extended far beyond a new lick of paint. The brief called for a reconfigured foyer area, revised exhibition lay-out, adding 50% more gallery space, new escalators, providing direct access to the public research library, and the construction of a new restaurant.

More than 7m people pass through the Pompidou Centre each year - indeed it is the building's immense popularity which necessitated the refurbishment programme in the first place.
Richard Rogers,
London

Diana Rowntree's obituary of Sir Leslie Martin (August 2) contained the sweeping assertion that Martin was "not an able talent spotter". In January 1957 Martin - along with Eero Saarinen - was a member of the Sydney Opera House competition jury. And, in the words of the jury chairman Ingham Ashworth, "the oft repeated story [that Saarinen alone was responsible for selecting Jørn Utzon's outstanding design] is complete nonsense".

There is no truth at all in the statement that Utzon's entry was picked out of a reject pile. In fact, Martin was initially particularly interested in Utzon's submission. Subsequently, Martin was in part responsible for selecting Ove Arup as lead engineer for the project. Martin's recognition of the strength and sheer brilliance of Utzon's radical design suggests that contrary to Rowntree's assertion, he was rather a good talent spotter.
Christopher Thompson, Hørsholm,
Denmark

fields.headline: Our record in Burma
fields.trailText: The suggestion that our pipeline in Burma was constructed using forced labour is totally false (UK firm linked to Burma slavery, July 27). Premier Oil does not condone forced labour or human rights abuses.
fields.body:
The suggestion that our pipeline in Burma was constructed using forced labour is totally false (UK firm linked to Burma slavery, July 27). Premier Oil does not condone forced labour or human rights abuses. We have clearly stated and demonstrated our support for fundamental human rights (see our website: www.premier-oil.com. )

Premier has regularly raised allegations of forced labour, when brought to our attention, with the authorities in Burma. There is a clear recognition that we will continue to highlight such allegations and insist they be fully investigated. Although we do not have the capacity to verify allegations, we have shown we do not shy away from the commitment we have made: to promote and protect human rights within our legitimate sphere of influence.

Fighting between different groups has been going on for many years. The longstanding (since 1947) Karen-Burmese conflict is one of the principal conflicts remaining and is focused in the Tenasserim area. Premier's pipeline area is reported as being the whole of Tenasserim, when in fact, our sphere of influence is relatively small: 40 x 10 miles. Within this area we can influence what is going on; outside, we cannot.

Premier's policy of constructive engagement incorporates a strong community development element - an estimated 1m people will benefit from programmes over the next five years. We have commissioned a rigorous external social audit of our business to understand how we are performing as a responsible company; the results will be published next year. We do not believe that sanctions will positively influence the situation in Burma. Over time, integration into the global economy is more likely to bring about change.
Charles Jamieson,
Chief executive, Premier Oil

fields.headline: Poor show
fields.trailText: When I read Lyn Gardner's piece on Mark Rylance (King of the Globe, G2, August 2), my reaction was "Oh yeah?" I admire Rylance's enthusiasm and dedication, but to any theatre-lover the Globe can only be seen as an anachronism and tourist attraction
fields.body:
When I read Lyn Gardner's piece on Mark Rylance (King of the Globe, G2, August 2), my reaction was "Oh yeah?" I admire Rylance's enthusiasm and dedication, but to any theatre-lover the Globe can only be seen as an anachronism and tourist attraction (it was the dream-child of an American, not an English, actor).

We don't go to the cinema to see reproductions of DW Griffiths's work, and even some 40s and 50s black-and-white films now seem artless in the extreme, so what is the point of trying to recreate a 500-year-old theatrical experience? Joan Littlewood must be turning in her grave.
Helena Newton,
Ilford, Essex

fields.headline: Penis envy
fields.trailText: William Leith (Privates on parade, G2, August 3) might be amused by the "size matters" ads, but as a well-endowed male I am not. The current debate on penis size has revealed an incredible amount of ignorance among women.
fields.body:
William Leith (Privates on parade, G2, August 3) might be amused by the "size matters" ads, but as a well-endowed male I am not. The current debate on penis size has revealed an incredible amount of ignorance among women. About 90% seem to think that if it hangs down there there like an overgrown salami it will also be massive when erect. This misconception is also being passed on to teenage boys. Let's get one thing straight. When it's cold, wet etc, most male members can shrivel to almost nothing. This is normal and not cause for concern/amusement. I'm glad I'm not a teenager.
Paul Morrison,
Peterborough, Cambs

A whole page on the phallus in the women's section. Perhaps I'm simply not grasping the point.
Liz Fremantle,
London

webTitle: Pepped up Bush stalks the swing states

fields.headline: Pepped up Bush stalks the swing states
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush took his re-energised Republican presidential campaign straight to the battleground states of the American midwest yesterday, aiming to add to his formidable poll lead over the Democrat Al Gore in the wake of this week's made-for-television Republican convention in Philadelphia.
fields.body:
George W Bush took his re-energised Republican presidential campaign straight to the battleground states of the American midwest yesterday, aiming to add to his formidable poll lead over the Democrat Al Gore in the wake of this week's made-for-television Republican convention in Philadelphia.

Just hours after the razzmatazz that followed his 52-minute acceptance speech on Thursday night, Mr Bush flew to Pittsburgh with his running-mate Dick Cheney to start a three-day swoop through Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Illinois: four traditional swing states which may hold the key to the White House once again on November 7.

"We're in for a tough campaign, but we know it and we're ready," he told party leaders at a breakfast rally before leaving Philadelphia. "As we depart the city of brotherly love, we depart with a good feeling in our heart."

Though no politician ever admits feeling anything but good about his election prospects, Mr Bush has a better claim than most right now. Even before the convention, the latest Gallup poll showed him with an 11-point lead over Mr Gore.

Day-by-day tracking polls in convention week also suggested a strong swing to Mr Bush by independents and women, the two groups of voters who were the principal targets of the relentless four-day "compassionate conservatism" showcase in Philadelphia.

As Mr Bush flew out in search of post-convention "bounce", Mr Gore got back into the action with a speech to firefighters in Chicago after spending this week on a seaside holiday in North Carolina. Mr Gore will announce his vice-presidential running-mate in Nashville on Tuesday, before travelling to the Democratic convention, which opens in Los Angeles on August 14.

These are crucial days for Mr Gore, who must regain the initiative from the increasingly upbeat Republicans, who left Philadelphia yesterday confident that their candidate is leading his party back to the White House after eight years on the political sidelines.

Mr Bush chose not to use his convention speech for the fire-and-brimstone Clinton-bashing which delights Republican activists but alienates less narrow-minded voters.

"For eight years, the Clinton-Gore administration has coasted through prosperity," he told his audience. "Our current president embodied the potential of a generation. So many talents. So much charm. Such great skill. But in the end, to what end? So much promise, to no great purpose."

He took noticeable pains to present himself as a healer rather than an avenger - and he even went out of his way to acknowledge his own misspent youth. He believed in forgiveness, he said, "because I have needed it."

But he chided the Democrats for neglecting the military, the schools and the elderly - the Republican strategists' three main policy battlegrounds.

While careful to play to the uncommitted television audience - especially female and minority voters - Mr Bush also gave conservatives a lot of what they wanted.

He pledged himself to a round of tax cuts, to the deployment of a national missile defence, to parental power in schools, to no new gun laws, and - potentially the most controversial of all - to supporting a ban on late-term, or "partial birth" abortions.

Conspicuously absent from his speech was any but the most perfunctory mention of world affairs.

Nor did he say anything much about environmental issues, and he did not mention his pro-big-business agenda, even though he is committed to a range of measures which will lift many legal restrains from his party's biggest corporate backers.

Party people

Bush family

Supplanting the Kennedys as America's premier political dynasty, there were starring cameos from George Sr, family matriarch Barbara, wife Laura, daughters Barbara and Jenna, brother Jeb, nephews George P and Pierce. Sixty-two Bushes attended on the final night.

Newt Gingrich

The forgotten man of the Republican revolution spent the week posing for endless snaps with delegates, telling anyone who would listen that his conservative ideas were intact in the Republican election programme.

Condoleezza Rice

The Russia expert consolidated her position as Bush's principal foreign policy adviser with a speech in primetime on Tuesday. One of dozens of African-Americans who were showcased.

Karl Rove

Mastermind behind the convention's touchy-feely makeover, and the enforcer who made sure the word "impeachment" was never heard in public.

Party poopers

Henry Hyde

A hero to the conservative right, Hyde and his fellow Clinton impeachers were kept out of sight and hearing for the week. Not a word was heard from Dick Armey, Jesse Helms, Tom DeLay or Dan Burton either.

Dan Quayle

Who? Tuesday night's roll-call of the party's former heavyweights lacked two conspicuous names: Richard Nixon and the man who couldn't spell potato.

Bill Clinton

Nobody mentioned him until Cheney took off the gloves on Wednesday. If there's one thing worse than being impeached, it's being ignored.

webTitle: Cheney linked to oil loans funding

fields.headline: Cheney linked to oil loans funding
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A research group has linked Dick Cheney, the Republican party's prospective vice-president, with an increase in government-backed loans which helped his oil company do business in politically sensitive parts of the world.
fields.body:
A research group has linked Dick Cheney, the Republican party's prospective vice-president, with an increase in government-backed loans which helped his oil company do business in politically sensitive parts of the world.

The report by the Centre for Public Integrity, a non-partisan research group, points out that Halliburton, the Dallas-based company headed by Mr Cheney, has benefited from government contracts or guaranteed loans worth at least $3.8bn (£2.54bn) during his five-year stewardship.

Knut Royce, a senior fellow at the centre and co-author of the report, linked the increase in government support with the company's increased political contributions during that time. "Halliburton clearly had support in part because it had been very generous over the years in giving money to the Republicans," he said.

Halliburton gave $1.2m (£800,000) to candidates and parties while Mr Cheney was chairman, compared with $534,750 in the five years before his arrival. The $3.8bn awarded to the company since he joined in 1995 is compared with $1.3bn in the five previous years.

About $2.3bn in US government contracts was awarded to Halliburton in the past five years, almost double the level of the previous five years. But the centre made it clear that Mr Cheney had not been accused of wrongdoing. "It's simply a question of business as usual," Mr Royce said. "That's one of the [downfalls] of the system."

webTitle: Gay who lost heart for the Tory fight

fields.headline: Gay who lost heart for the Tory fight
fields.standfirst:
As the section 28 rhetoric grew uglier Massow knew he had to make the break and join Labour

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: As the section 28 rhetoric grew uglier Massow knew he had to make the break and join Labour
fields.body:
Read the profiles of Ivan Massow and you would assume you were about to meet the high priest of high camp. It is all "flamboyant gay millionaire", the former male model who once posed naked (with boyfriend) to promote his insurance company, the strikingly handsome Tory boy and newly-appointed chairman of the Institute of Contemporary Arts who would warn interviewers they would find no skeletons in his closet - "just dust and a few old Judy Garland records".

Read Massow's own words and you would get the same impression: screaming queen. This, after all, is the man who told Guardian readers of his relief that it was George Robertson rather than Michael Portillo who had won the top job at Nato: "To have lost Mr Portillo would have been to have lost a very good looking man from English politics. This is a loss that the general public, I feel, would simply not tolerate."

Yet this is not the man you meet. In his first interview since defecting from the Tories to Labour Massow is not the loud, vain performer of media stereotype. Instead, he pitches up in a VW Polo, wearing dark jeans and a fairly grubby, navy polo shirt - even though he knows he is going to be photographed. It is Classic FM on the car radio, not songs from the shows.

His speech is halting and, if anything, unconfident. He is shy, too - refusing to show off his striking new home, an originally Jacobean manor house in Frome, Somerset. ("My partner's there right now, and he doesn't want to do it.")

At his side, as if for protection, is a minder from Millbank. It is the senior press officer Lance Price, who turns out to be the first Labour official Massow contacted to discuss his possible conversion. The result of all this is to make Massow look very different from the showy homo of media imagination. He is more thoughtful, more complicated than that. And the same is true of his political switch. Some have dismissed it as a flash in the pan gesture from a fly by night politico, a man who was a Conservative candidate for the London mayoralty one minute, a drop out from the race the next. But that impression would be wrong, too.

Journey

Ask Massow when his journey towards Labour began and he gives an answer measured not in weeks or months, but years. "It started an awfully long time ago," he says, by now sitting in a corner table in a pub in Westbury, a safe distance from his pile in Frome. "My family was quite Conservative," he says, by which he means John Massow, the kindly bachelor who took him off the hands of social services a few years after young Ivan's own family had violently broken down.

The young Massow felt the same way as his adoptive father, who had been busy teaching the working class boy middle class politics, as well as middle class manners. Even though he was just 11, he remembers his impression of the last Labour government: hyper inflation and a sense of crisis. How did he pick all that up? "From delivering papers every morning."

The Tory message made sense to him. He joined his local Young Conservatives, becoming chairman by the time he was 14 - the youngest in the country. "I was like something out of a comic, that kid who everyone beats up at school."

An invited economist explained how it could all work and not a single person around the table - including William Hague - understood it. The policy would have required a Conservative government to cut taxes even in a recession, when tax revenues are down and benefit payments are up. "That's when I started to lose faith in what we were saying. I thought we were trying to score cheap points with policies we hadn't thought through - which is what I thought Labour had done before the election." There were two other blows to come. Massow still harboured his adolescent ambition to be an MP. No matter that he was a high flyer, in regular email contact with Michael Portillo, summoned to talk strategy with the leader, the formal selection process found Massow fit only to be classed "D1" - not on the official candidates' list, but "deferred". It meant he had to get more experience before he was deemed fit to seek a Tory parliamentary nomination. He would have to go on a special training weekend. "Can you imagine? There were role plays, including how to handle a television interview - and I'd been on Question Time the week before!"

They wanted someone with "contemporary, metropolitan values" and Massow fitted the bill perfectly. In the end, Steve Norris re-entered the race - saving the party from having to choose from a field of "scary" Tory baronesses, says Massow - and he was "unbelievably relieved" not to have to go through with it.

But the rarity of a liberal Tory such as Norris touched on the second, much larger problem. Massow had seen his mission within the Tory party as akin to that of Dorothy and the Tin Man in the Wizard of Oz: to give it a heart (the Judy Garland analogy is his).

"I decided to come out in the Spectator - as a socially inclusive Conservative." He told Hague, Portillo and others in private what he was writing in public: that the Tories had to find a kinder, more tolerant language if they were to speak to a country that was changing. He urged them to drop their defence of section 28, which bars the promotion of homosexuality in schools. Massow even submitted a Dorothy-like paper to Hague, whose title was a variation on the Tin Man's catchphrase: "If I only had a heart."

He thought Hague would understand. "He had voted for [age] 16 on the age of consent, he had been to the Notting Hill carnival and when I talked about all this stuff in private he seemed to agree with me." But then Massow would see the leader on his feet in the House of Commons, "using the issue of section 28 so divisively, and the rhetoric got more and more unpleasant... he wasn't the person I knew."

Losing battle

Massow realised he was fighting a losing battle. He would be invited to speak at a Tory dinner, squaring off against Ann Widdecombe, and the diners would side with her.

A gay friend would seek a parliamentary seat only to be rebuffed, again and again: apparently no Tory association was ready to accept an openly gay MP. Finally, Massow was at the Tory knees up known as the Blue Ball when Hague addressed the partygoers on the merits of section 28: Massow walked out in disgust.

He talked about his growing sense of defeat with a friend he won't name in the Labour party. He suggested Massow get in touch with Lance Price, formerly a BBC political correspondent now at Labour headquarters.

They met last week and shortly afterward Massow arranged to see his most senior Labour contact, the culture secretary, Chris Smith. That impressed Massow: having been ignored in his own party, here was a Labour cabinet minister with an open door (Smith did not know in advance what Massow wanted to discuss).

Contrary to reports this week, the Conservative party did not make any last-minute offer to stay. That is because Massow did not give them the chance: he knew that if they had advance warning of his switch, they would get their version out before his. Instead he sent an elliptical email to his chum in the leader's office, Nicholas Gleave, which mentioned a sense of "not belonging" anymore. All he got were soothing noises about a future "chat with William".

He was not offered a hurried peerage. Instead, it seems, that offer had been dangled, codedly, several times before - so often, in fact, that Massow had become highly doubtful that it would ever happen. The Tories had talked about Massow as a Conservative Waheed Alli, the young, gay, media peer who sits with Labour. But he was not keen to provide a "cool, inclusive" fig leaf for a party that he believed was neither cool nor inclusive.

Labour did not offer him anything either. They made it clear he would have to pay his dues, that he certainly would not find a seat in time for the next general election. He has told them he wants to work on social exclusion, hence the meeting with the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, on Wednesday. He had no meeting with Tony Blair and only met Alastair Campbell for the first time on Wednesday.

So now it is time for a new persona for this gay Jay Gatsby, the invented man who had three different surnames by the time he was 12.

He may still be only 32, but this week saw the end of a political journey that lasted nearly two decades - and the beginning of another one that may go all the way, even over the rainbow.

webTitle: Catholic priesthood is becoming mainly gay, US theologian claims

fields.headline: Catholic priesthood is becoming mainly gay, US theologian claims
fields.trailText: A book which claims that the priesthood is becoming a gay profession has divided the 60m US Roman Catholics and led to calls for the priest who wrote it to be thrown out of his post as rector of one of America's leading seminaries.
fields.body:
A book which claims that the priesthood is becoming a gay profession has divided the 60m US Roman Catholics and led to calls for the priest who wrote it to be thrown out of his post as rector of one of America's leading seminaries.

What has added insult to injury is that the author of The Changing Face of the Priesthood, Donald Cozzens, 61, cannot be dismissed as a crank or a radical. He is president-rector and professor of pastoral theology at St Mary Seminary and Graduate School of Theology in Cleveland, Ohio, and has a doctorate in psychology.

"One thing seems clear: the image of the priesthood once captured in the gentle pastoring of a Father O'Malley in The Bells of St Mary no longer holds," he says, referring to Bing Crosby's Oscar-winning role as a saintly inner-city priest in a 40s' film series.

His book claims that seminaries are becoming "significantly gay". About 20,000 of the country's 32,000 priests have left the clergy to get married in recent years, and many of those who remain are gay (more than half in some estimates), he claims.

The revelation, in an otherwise sober religious work, could not have come at a worse time for the Vatican, which has significantly hardened its attitude to gays. Recently the Pope denounced a gay pride march in Rome.

Fr Cozzens writes: "The priesthood of the 21st century will likely be perceived as a predominantly gay profession.

"Vicars of priests and seminary administrators who have been around a while speak among themselves of the disproportionate number of gay men that populate our seminaries and presbyterates.

"Studies find that approximately half of American priests and seminarians are homosexually oriented... the percentage appears to be highest among priests under 40."

In Britain, where the head of the Catholic church in Scotland, Cardinal Thomas Winning, has led the campaign against the repeal of Clause 28, a spokeswoman said no similar surveys had been done.

There have been calls for the book to be banned and complaints from the parents of some trainee priests. But it is a case of bolting the stable door after the horse has fled, since the book has already sold out its initial print run of 20,000 copies, making it a best seller for its publisher, the Liturgical Press.

Dean Hoge, a sociologist and specialist on the priesthood at the Catholic University of America, said: "It is the most important book on Catholic priests... for years. These topics are being talked about openly by the laity and the academic research community, but they are not being talked about openly by the Catholic leadership; and that's a tragic situation, because these are real problems and should be discussed."
