fields.headline: A birthday greeting from Lilibet
fields.standfirst:
Message from the Queen begins a 'quiet' day for the Queen Mother as crowds pay tribute to a celebrated centenarian

Special report: the Queen Mother at 100
fields.trailText: The nation's most celebrated centenarian enjoyed a quiet day with family and friends yesterday: up late, visit from the postman, picked up by grandson and driven round the corner for lunch at her daughter's.
fields.body:
The nation's most celebrated centenarian enjoyed a quiet day with family and friends yesterday: up late, visit from the postman, picked up by grandson and driven round the corner for lunch at her daughter's.

Being the Queen Mother, she was accompanied by two military bands and a mounted cavalry escort from the Blues and Royals, and received a 41 gun salute.

Waving to acknowledge the greetings of a crowd in the Mall, the first member of the royal family to reach her 100th birthday looked in robust and cheerful good health.

As the sun came out, and the time for her parade approached, numbers swelled to fill the area in front of Buckingham Palace to respectable if not ecstatic dimensions, probably in excess of 30,000. Many were tourists from abroad, pleased to see the daily spectacle of changing the guard supplemented by a royal pageant.

When the Queen Mother appeared on the balcony of the Buckingham Palace, accompanied by her daughters and then gradually the rest of the royal family, while the band of the Coldstream Guards below played Happy Birthday, there was a surge of cheering and applause.

The first public appearance came at mid-morning outside the Queen Mother's residence, Clarence House, with the arrival of the royal postman, Tony Nicholls. Moments earlier he had driven self-consciously up the Mall in his little red van in the wake of the gun carriages of the Royal Horse Artillery and a troop of Life Guards.

The card from the Queen he delivered was the same she sends all centenarians (including 11 others who had birthdays yesterday), but it had a personalised message. The Queen Mother handed the envelope to an equerry, Captain William de Rouet, with a request for him to use his sword as a letter opener.

Proving that - like the rest of us - the Queen has difficulty finding something novel to write in birthday cards, it read: "On your 100th birthday all the family join with me in sending you our loving best wishes for this special day." But it was signed with the pet name by which the Queen, herself 74, was known as a child, Lilibet.

For the short journey up the Mall, the Queen Mother was joined by her grandson, the Prince of Wales, in an open-topped landau, drawn by four grey horses and decorated in her racing colours. Back at Clarence House, five ladies in waiting were deputed for an hour to continue to accept gifts and cards.

The procession wound down into the Mall, past the Victoria Memorial with its statue of a world-weary queen who still had five months to live when the Queen Mother was born. As the carriage drew through the main gates of Buckingham Palace the waiting band struck up the national anthem.

Then, in the hiatus after the party disappeared inside, the police formed up like defenders in front of a goal mouth, to protect the open gates from the surging crowd, while in the courtyard the band surreally moved into a medley including the Grandstand theme and Blaydon Races.

Right on cue, the ageing trouper appeared to acknowledge the cheers. Down in the crowd, the sentiment was that she was wonderful. Myra Roger, her daughter Ruth Franton and grand daughters Jennifer and Kirsty, up for the day from Beaconsfield in Buckinghamshire, were enjoying every moment.

"It's a momentous historical occasion," said Myra. "She represents old fashioned virtue - the epitome of the royal family. She's not changed for the worst, has she?" Further along, Sally Marchant from Carshalton in south London, and her sister Maureen Boyd, home on holiday from Australia, reckoned they knew the secret of the Queen Mother's success: "She's a great figurehead for royalty, isn't she? I think she advises quietly behind the scenes, don't you? She keeps them in line."

Katie Miller, aged seven, of Chorleywood in Hertfordshire, thought the Queen Mother looked lovely. "I don't think she looks 100. I think she looks more like 82. I want to come back when the Queen's 100," she said.

The band in the courtyard played on, Jerusalem and Who's Your Lady Friend? Over the heads of the departing crowd came the sound of street vendors making a last effort: "Any more for flags?"

fields.headline: Niger rig hostages 'will be freed'
fields.trailText: Armed Ijaw youths who stormed two Shell oil platforms in the Niger delta demanding jobs for the local community repeated their promises yesterday to release their 165 hostages, including five Britons.
fields.body:
Armed Ijaw youths who stormed two Shell oil platforms in the Niger delta demanding jobs for the local community repeated their promises yesterday to release their 165 hostages, including five Britons.

Royal Dutch/Shell admitted that there had been a breakdown in communication with the Ijaws' representatives but remained confident that the local and expatriate staff employed by service contractors on the platforms would be freed by the weekend.

The Ijaws have refused to leave until their representatives returned to confirm details of the deal. The representatives were said to be making their way to the rigs - in mangrove swamps, 60 miles north-east of Port Harcourt - to call off the siege.

The Ijaws, like other tribes in the Niger river delta, have been stepping up their calls for a fairer distribution of Nigeria's oil wealth. Since November there have been half a dozen attacks on gas plants and pumping facilities.

The latest crisis began on Monday when more than 50 youths stormed the Malad Bay 70 and Malad Bay 75 drilling platforms. At least 145 Nigerians, seven US citizens, five Britons and a number of Australians and Lebanese were held hostage. They were said to be safe. The Britons have not been identified.

"The only constraint is that they cannot leave the living quarters or the rigs," a Shell spokesman said. The captive workers are employed by Mallard Bay and the NGN Catering Company.

The seizure of the rigs is the latest in a series of hostage dramas. In November militants kidnapped six oil workers from a Shell helicopter. They freed them after talks, but seven policemen were later killed. President Olusegun Obasanjo sent army units who ransacked the town of Odi hunting for the kidnappers.

Earlier this year youths stormed a gas plant near the southern port of Warri, abducting 32 workers and two soldiers. In April 40 French workers were seized but released unharmed. Last month two Chinese oil workers were freed.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Metal clue to Concorde crash

A 40cm thin metal strip not belonging to Air France's doomed Concorde was found on the runway after the plane took off from Paris last week, France's accident investigation bureau said yesterday.

The bureau, which is now certain that the fire on the jet did not start in the engines, said one shred of tyre from the plane had a "substantial cut" in it. Reuters, Paris

Marine accused of sex assault

A US marine has been brought before a military court accused of indecently assaulting a 14-year-old girl as she slept in her home on the Japanese island of Okinawa .

Lance Corporal Kenny Titcomb, 19, could be imprisoned for up to seven and a half years if found guilty. Reuters, Tokyo

German tourist dead in Kashmir

The body of a German tourist abducted in Kashmir last month by suspected Islamic militants has been found by an Indian police search party.

It is believed that Harfurth Rolf, who was found in a glacier 175 miles south-east of Srinagar, had been shot. AP, Srinagar

fields.headline: Missile system targeted
fields.trailText: Your report on the US missile defence system (Britain's critical missile dilemma, August 2) does not mention a major reason for opposition, which is that the possession of such a system could encourage the possessor to consider the option of a first strike
fields.body:
Your report on the US missile defence system (Britain's critical missile dilemma, August 2) does not mention a major reason for opposition, which is that the possession of such a system could encourage the possessor to consider the option of a first strike. If a country is suddenly attacked by many missiles with multiple, independently targeted warheads and decoys, it is highly unlikely that any anti-missile system could shoot down all of them.

On the other hand, if such an attack were launched, it is likely that a few missile sites would survive and a small number of missiles would be launched in retaliation. If the country which launched the first strike had an anti-missile system, it is possible it could cope successfully with the small number of retaliatory missiles. For this reason, an anti-missile system could break the nuclear stalemate.
Prof Patrick Wall,
London
p.wall@umds.ac.uk

The US attitude towards national missile defence scares me rigid. A recommendation from US defense secretary William Cohen to begin the next phase of this project is expected any day. The aim is to have the first 100 missiles in place - and pointed at China - by 2005. Unsurprisingly, this prospect is making China, Russia, India and a lot of other states extremely nervous. In the not too distant future, the US could be in a position to launch a nuclear strike against an opponent whilst hoping to protect itself from retaliation.

The next phase of America's national missile defence system includes updating Fylingdales. This ballistic missile tracking station in north Yorkshire is the means by which the United States keeps its eye on the whole of the northern hemisphere. (Pine Gap in Australia keeps a lookout in the south).

The government might want to fudge the issue of Fylingdales as long as possible, but as your coverage rightly points out, there is serious and growing concern about it doing so - including from government supporters. There is even a chance of this being aired at the Labour party conference next month. A resolution cir culating among activists calls for "a clear commitment that neither Fylingdales, Menwith Hill nor any other facilities in this country will be used in the development of the US national missile defence system".
Carol Turner,
Labour CND

The government says it won't give a decision on Fylingdales until the US makes a formal request. Tony Blair must know that if he made it clear now that he would not permit such a US early-warning station, this would have a strong influence on the US decision to go ahead or not, Clinton being able to drop the project for "totally unrelated reasons".

Once the US government has made a formal request, it will have committed itself to the project and will move heaven and earth, and Tony Blair, to implement it. If he has any convictions about the rights and wrongs of NMD, he would jump at this chance to influence the result.
WP Keppler,
Wembley, Middx
wpkeppler@netscapeonline.co.uk

Richard Norton-Taylor recalls the long protest by women at Greenham Common, clearly expecting something similar will happen if the Americans attempt to build a new "star wars" base in the UK. This is perfectly correct. Women have also organised protests at the US spy station at Menwith Hill for years now. We have gained masses of invaluable information and experience and are more than ready to take on any new military base the US might wish to visit upon us.
Lesley Boulton,
Sheffield
lesan@cwcom.net

webTitle: Woman jailed for five years for throwing her six-year-old son to his death

fields.headline: Woman jailed for five years for throwing her six-year-old son to his death
fields.trailText: A mother who threw her six-year-old son to his death from the balcony of their 14th floor flat was jailed for five years yesterday.
fields.body:
A mother who threw her six-year-old son to his death from the balcony of their 14th floor flat was jailed for five years yesterday.

Allison Campbell, 26, from Glasgow, who had alcohol and drug problems, picked up Derek after waking him and his brother with warnings of a fire and threw him from their tower block home on October 27 last year.

The boy, described by neighbours as "a little angel", was heard to shout: "Mum, don't do that" before he was dropped over the edge.

At the high court in Edinburgh yesterday, Campbell wept as she was sentenced.

She had originally been charged with murder, but the crown accepted her plea of guilty to culpable homicide on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

She had spent several months under assessment at Scotland's state hospital in Carstairs, but yesterday the judge, Lord Penrose, accepted medical reports which said there was no reason for her to continue hospital treatment. The court heard that she had had depression and a history of drink and drug abuse.

The court had been told that Derek and his brother, aged nine, had been wakened by their mother's shouts in the early hours and had run to her.

Campbell picked up Derek and pushed him through safety netting on the balcony. Police were alerted by neighbours, who heard screaming and shouting and then saw the boy hit the ground. Attempts were made to resuscitate him. He was pronounced dead in hospital. When police arrived at the flat they found two fires in bedding in the house.

Donald Findlay QC, defending, told the judge that when Campbell was first taken to the state hospital she was "very plainly significantly disturbed".

webTitle: Secret aid for forced marriage victims

fields.headline: Secret aid for forced marriage victims
fields.trailText: Women who are forced to marry against their will are to be provided with a credit card-sized help sheet that can be hidden on their body when they are taken abroad. This is one of a number of measures to deal with the problem put forward by the Home Office and Foreign Office yesterday.
fields.body:
Women who are forced to marry against their will are to be provided with a credit card-sized help sheet that can be hidden on their body when they are taken abroad. This is one of a number of measures to deal with the problem put forward by the Home Office and Foreign Office yesterday.

The announcement comes after reports of more than 1,000 British girls, many in their teens, being tricked by families into visiting the Indian sub-continent only to discover they had been sent there to marry a stranger.

The small help cards, designed to be hidden under clothing, will carry the numbers of consulates, police and charities who can help the victim overseas. They will be available in doctors' surgeries, advice centres and the Foreign Office and its consulates.

The plan, launched by Home Office and Foreign Office junior ministers Mike O'Brien and Lady Scotland, follows a working party report into the problem of forced marriages which was published in June.

The group heard of cases which ranged from "loving manipulation" exerted by close family members to more extreme cases involving threatening behaviour, violence, abduction, imprisonment, rape and even murder.

Other suggested measures include improving liaison between British and overseas police forces, collation of forced marriage cases to provide reliable data, and training for consulate staff to help them deal with victims.

Last night Hannana Siddiqui of the Southall Black Sisters women's group said the plan did not go far enough.

The organisation had resigned from the Home Office working party, saying the recommendation that women in some cases should be prepared to accept mediation could force vulnerable women back into abusive situations. "Obviously we welcome the fact that the government is making positive statements to address this problem. But the latest move doesn't really seem to tackle the domestic situation and focuses on the foreign one.

"The government has still not tackled the issue on the front line such as offering legal aid, money for safe houses and more services and rights to these women."

Lady Scotland said the "abhorrence" felt by the government at forced marriages was shared by religious leaders from all denominations. But the issue was very complex. "What we are doing is weaving threads together to build a safety net in this country before the victim is sent abroad and continue it when they are overseas."

Forced marriages are a small percentage of the arranged marriages which take place every year in Britain.

The government plan also puts forward the possibility of interviewing both members of a newly married couple on the point of entry into Britain to see if consent has been freely given by both sides.

Mr O'Brien said this would have had to be enforced carefully to avoid it being regarded as an extra immigration control. He said: "If we interview everyone in all mixed marriage situations this would be extremely bureaucratic.

"If we were to go down this route there would be the concern that it would be an extra kind of immigration control. Putting extra consular staff in particular areas overseas would also not solve the problem. What it is about is getting into the mindset of a small minority of parents in Britain who feel they can force their children into marriage against their will. I am optimistic we can win this fight."

The plan will now be open to consultation.

webTitle: Runaway daughter escaped family with backing of police

fields.headline: Runaway daughter escaped family with backing of police
fields.trailText: Hina, a 22-year-old arts worker, fled her home years six years ago after her family tried to trick her into travelling to Pakistan for a forced marriage at 16.
fields.body:
Hina, a 22-year-old arts worker, fled her home years six years ago after her family tried to trick her into travelling to Pakistan for a forced marriage at 16.

Having already seen her brothers and sisters trapped in the same way, the offer of a chance to meet relatives she had never seen immediately rang alarm bells.

Six years on, her family are still trying to track her down and punish her for bringing shame on the family name. She has not seen her siblings or parents since her escape.

"I wish they would disown me because that would mean I could stop being on the run," she said. "But they are still lurking out there trying to get at me.

"At the age of 14 I was forced into an engagement. At 16 I was about to be taken abroad to Pakistan via Saudi Arabia but I escaped.

"It was one of these common cases where the visit was on the pretext of meeting family members but having seen it happen so often to others it was obviously a trick.

"Once there I would be trapped into marrying a stranger with no chance of escape. In Pakistan women cannot go anywhere without a chaperone, so it would have been impossible to get away. I would have had no allies within the family. Although I grew up in London, I was brought up under very strict Islamic rules. It has made me rebel against it. "

Hina contacted authorities including police and social services in advance, warning that her family would pull out all the stops to find her. Still at school, she knew she would not be able to escape without support.

She fled her home during the night. Her parents immediately contacted police, filing a missing person's report. But because they were forewarned, detectives refused to divulge Hina's whereabouts to her family.

"Even through mediation with social services, my family still threatened me if I didn't go back. Although I translated their threats to the police officers and social workers, they didn't believe I was really being threatened because they didn't hear the threats first hand.

"My father said he wanted to punish me and my mother accused me of making her ill because I have ruined the family's reputation."

Hina believes the government is still unaware of the true dangers facing women like her. "But if they put into practice what they are promising, we may see a difference."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Huntsmen face trial

Three hunt stewards with the Quorn foxhounds, with which the Prince of Wales has ridden, were yesterday committed for trial at Leicester crown court on charges including assault against hunt saboteurs.

The charges follow trouble at a hunt at Wymeswold near Loughborough in March.

Woman 'died from vCJD'

An inquest on a 30-year-old mother of two who may have died of the human form of mad cow disease was opened and adjourned until December in Blackburn, Lancashire, yesterday.

A postmortem was being carried out on Anita Maria Bradshaw, who died in hospital after suffering from what was thought to be new variant Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease.

Mother on murder charge

A mother charged with the murder of a newborn baby was yesterday remanded in custody until August 11 by Doncaster magistrates.

Alison Johnson, 34, a cleaner, was charged after the girl's body was discovered in an outbuilding at her home in Rossington, near Doncaster.

Few job seekers seek training

Only 16% of job seekers are training to improve their career prospects even though 76% think increasing their skills would help them find more rewarding employment, a survey showed yesterday.

Job dissatisfaction affects around half of full and part time workers, the NOP poll for career advice website StepStone found.

webTitle: Britain faces 2 days with no leader

fields.headline: Britain faces 2 days with no leader
fields.trailText: Britain will be left technically leaderless when Tony Blair takes his family on holiday to Tuscany today, 48 hours before the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, returns from Cyprus.
fields.body:
Britain will be left technically leaderless when Tony Blair takes his family on holiday to Tuscany today, 48 hours before the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, returns from Cyprus.

With the chancellor, Gordon Brown, presumed to be honeymooning across the Atlantic on Cape Cod, the remote chance of a nuclear first strike by one of Britain's historic enemies would theoretically leave the country without strategic direction.

But Downing Street officials emphasised last night that wherever Mr Blair is, he is "the prime minister, always the prime minister". He is only two hours from home and is in constant contact. Across Whitehall at Mr Prescott's office, they said much the same.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, and Jack Straw, the home secretary, are on leave, but may well be somewhere in Britain if an emergency breaks. Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, is out of the country.

For the third successive year Mr Blair, his wife, Cherie, and four children will be staying at the 50-room Tuscan palazzo on the estate of Prince Girolamo Strozzi and his wife, Irina, until mid-August, before moving to the home in Gascony, south-west France, of high court judge Sir David Keene for the sixth successive year.

As usual he will travel by RAF jet and be available for inter-government lunches in both venues and - after a change of heart - will give the stalking paparazzi a photo-call soon after his arrival in Italy.

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, is believed to be in Majorca, while the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is walking in Turkey.

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, is in the south of France.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, is heading to the US. But Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is too busy to leave his base in the north-east.

fields.headline: Mid-life change
fields.standfirst: L-plate comics quit bank for West End
fields.trailText: The Monty Python sketch about the accountant who ran away to join the circus has come close to life. Two bank managers from Chipping Norton, with no stage experience, have sunk their savings into hiring a West End theatre to launch their comedy careers.
fields.body:
The Monty Python sketch about the accountant who ran away to join the circus has come close to life. Two bank managers from Chipping Norton, with no stage experience, have sunk their savings into hiring a West End theatre to launch their comedy careers.

Tim Lyon and Ken Norman, sensible, middle-aged, Morris Minor-driving chaps from the Cotswolds, took singing and tap dancing lessons before taking the next "perfectly logical step" of booking Her Majesty's Theatre, where Phantom of the Opera plays to nearly 1,200 people, for one night only.

So far - despite the added attractions of Essex's leading comedy folk singer, Tony Wian, and the boys and girls from Chipping Norton school's "top-notch" production of Guys 'n' Dolls - they have sold only 250 tickets.

But neither Tim, 48, nor Ken, 38, who took voluntary redundancy from NatWest last year, are discouraged. Buoyed by a card from their hero, Ronnie Barker, wishing them "the breast of duck", they are dreaming of their own television show to fill what they see as a public yearning for "good clean, family fun and nice comedians ... tap-dancing vicars, singing vergers, funny songs about TV vets, that sort of thing.

Tim has never seen a comedian performing live: "I've seen lots on TV though. People have always told me I look like John Cleese or Rowan Atkinson or Michael Barrymore. One day it would be nice if they said I look like me."

Tim, whose employers often told him that he was "too funny for corporate credit analysis", said he had never felt more happy or fulfilled. "It feels great to make such a good bad investment."

Even so, coming up with original songs and scripts - and keeping them clean - has not been easy. "We tried to be squeaky clean, but we just couldn't do it. The terrible thing about double entendres is that they just keep coming up, as it were."

Central TV would not allow them to sing one of their songs, What Shall We Do With Randy Mandy? on its six o'clock news. "They said it was too risque to be sung before watershed."

But their spirits were soon lifted when Ronnie Barker offered his old material for free. "Every time I thought I had come up with a great idea for a sketch, Ken would remind me that the Two Ronnies had done it before. Ronnie really is the master."

Barker, who ran an antique shop near their Oxfordshire homes for a time, tried to talk the pair out of making such a "mad West End debut". They would lose their shirts. " 'You're utterly crazy, barking mad,' he told us," said Tim.

By that stage, however, they were well beyond taking a few aspirins and letting it pass. "It all started during a chat over coffee when we realised the bank was closing the training centre we worked in," said Tim. "We just clicked, and we thought what the hell."

Their big night will cost them around £20,000, and Tim said his redundancy money will have run out by September. Ken is going through a divorce, but Tim's wife and daughter have been very supportive.

"No matter what happens, this has been a great year," said Tim. "We hope something will come out of it, but even if it doesn't we will be better trainers. We have learned so many new skills from this."

 Norman and Lyon play Her Majesty's Theatre, Haymarket, London W1, on Sunday, August 13 at 7pm. For tickets call 020 7494 5430. Their website is www.newtricks.co.uk

fields.headline: The last word on Embryos
fields.standfirst:
The egg it is the source of all
'Tis everyone's ancestral hall
Clarence Day
fields.trailText: There were strong hints this week that the government will shortly permit "therapeutic cloning" using human embryos, which involves producing embryos in the laboratory so that stem cells can be harvested from them.
fields.body:
There were strong hints this week that the government will shortly permit "therapeutic cloning" using human embryos, which involves producing embryos in the laboratory so that stem cells can be harvested from them. (These are the fundamental building blocks of the body.) Aptly called pluripotent, stem cells are able to diversify into all the different organs and tissues of the human frame, so they can be used to cure many diseases - Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, Huntington's Chorea, diabetes, cancer and heart conditions - and will eventually heal injuries such as burns. The medical potential is immense. On one estimate, more than 100m people world-wide may benefit.

Embryologists finally learned how to isolate and culture stem cells in 1998 after years of research. They insert human genetic material into an egg, which is then prompted to develop into an embryo in a laboratory dish, producing stem cells.

Apart from the developmental plasticity of the cells, a great advantage is that they are perfectly matched immunologically to the individual who needs them, for they derive from that person's own body. As a single example shows, the advantage is obvious: there will be no more heartbreaking searches for matching bone marrow donors for children with leukaemia.

Predictably, Christian charity finds the idea repugnant. Because the original research was conducted on embryonic stem cells taken from aborted foetuses and embryos left over from fertility treatments, religious groups opposed to abortion and in vitro conception were extremely hostile to it. In their view an embryo is human life, and as such is sacrosanct. In America religious groups condemned the decision to permit stem cell research as "government sponsorship and funding of experiments in which living human embryos are dissected and killed". But given the promise of the technique to alleviate human suffering, religious objections seem not merely uncharitable but obtuse and confused.

Religionists must suppose that whatever supernatural agency created the world also created human intelligence. But they seem to think that the results of applying it to anything other than reading (and uncritically accepting) ancient religious literature is sinful. Does this mean that the deity made a mistake, or is she playing us a trick? If not, and providence endowed us with intelligence competent to discover therapeutic cloning, what is the objection to using it for the benefit of humanity?

The haste with which religionists invoke the sanctity of human life in embryos is remarkably absent when it comes to war, capital punishment, the gun lobby, the armaments industry and its exports to conflicts in the third world, and - by way of their opposition to contraception - overpopulation and its attendant evils of poverty, disease, ignorance and crime. Equally repugnant is their preparedness to allow human disease and pain to continue whenever a medical treatment conflicts with their interpretation of a 2000-year-old text.

The objectors are also factually confused. There is no question of stem cells having to be "harvested" from aborted foetuses, because ova - flushed away in billions of menses every year - can be secured by other means, as in fertilisation procedures. Soon adult stem cells may be used, or even reprogrammed, to do the work. The religious premise is that an embryo is a human being; but an embryo - from the Greek "embryon" meaning "unformed" - is a small aggregation of cells, no more a person than is the skin grazed off your knee when playing football.

A Turkish proverb says "today's egg is better than tomorrow's hen," but embryology suggests that we can amend it to "today's egg can make today's hen better." There are plenty of sufferers not in a position to wait for tomorrow: for them therapeutic cloning cannot come soon enough.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart's Diary: The DJ's progress

fields.headline: The DJ's progress: or a radio downfall in six scenes
fields.trailText: The BBC board of governors has upheld a complaint against my old sparring partner Chris Moyles, the Radio 1 disc jockey, for making sexually explicit remarks on his Saturday morning show.
fields.body:
The BBC board of governors has upheld a complaint against my old sparring partner Chris Moyles, the Radio 1 disc jockey, for making sexually explicit remarks on his Saturday morning show. He must be absolutely thrilled. It's one of those rites of passage in a DJ's life, like a civil servant collecting a CBE. But judging by the standard career path of DJs, this could be the highlight of his entire working life.

You could do a series of Hogarth etchings depicting the life trajectory of a Radio 1 DJ (this does not refer to Mr Moyles personally). No 1 would show our man graduating from in-store deejaying to hospital radio, where he would be fired for making inappropriate jokes about colostomy bags. In No 2, he gets a job on Radio Droitwich, and is nearly sacked for being rude about a local councillor. ("I wouldn't say she's fat, mate, but if she sat on yer knee yer legs would go through the floor.")

No 3 is success. He has his show tape accepted by the BBC, and is given the late-night Sunday slot. By No 4 he is promoted to the breakfast show where he has a chance to demonstrate his cutting-edge humour ("Blimey, you should see the tits on her!"). He is denounced by the Mail for being filthy and by the Guardian for being boring. In No 5 a new controller arrives and, with poorly disguised glee, sacks him. He begs for a transfer to Radio 2, but is told they only take talent these days.

In the last engraving, he is doing the 2-6am shift on Radio Wrexham, which he combines with daytime cabbing. We see him pathetically grateful to perform the opening of a new Spar mini-mart, taking the fee in groceries.

 The world's greatest advertising industry, as our lads style themselves, is never more risible than when trying to impart a sexy image to something dreary. There's a series of posters for a fluid called Lambrini Bianco. Each depicts a trio of raunchy lasses overcome with merriment. In one, a woman announces: "I treat all my men with a firm hand," as she grasps the bottle in explicit fashion. We know just what she means, and the message is rammed home at the bottom of the ad: "Girls just want to have fun."

What makes this pathetic is that the drink is "slightly sparkling perry". I suppose we're meant to imagine one of these funsters saying "Come on back to my place, lad, and get some fizzy pear juice down yer neck," but I can't imagine it. You might as well market Horlicks as an aphrodisiac. I expect they will soon.

 Another seemingly annual ritual is the Which? magazine report on motorway service stations. Inspectors declare themselves repelled and disgusted by the fish and chips and stringy chicken, as if they expected any different. What we do is consult the Good Pub Guide as we drive along, and make a detour to somewhere which promises decent food and, we hope, takes children.

Last weekend we were on the A12, virtually a motorway at its southern end, and went half a mile off the road to Kelvedon, a pretty little town, where we ate in the handsome garden of The Sun. The food was good, the welcome warm, the beer cold, and the whole pleasing break cost £17 for four people, around two-thirds of what we'd have paid for dreck in a service area.

I had high hopes of a website, 5minutesaway.co.uk, which lists food outlets, accommodation and petrol stations according to which motorway exit they're near. It is fairly useful, though seems to list a lot of McDonalds, KFCs and Harvesters, none of which strike me as being much better than a Road Chef or Granada. (If a waitresses like those you see in the ads asks, "Have you visited a Harvester before?" just reply, "Surely no one ever comes twice?".)

 We were on the A12 heading for the Suffolk coast where we spent the weekend with our friend Christopher Matthew and his family. Chris writes a lot of books. He lavishes care on them, gets very excited when the publishers tell him he's going have a huge hit, and then waits for something to go wrong. Often it's because the editor has moved, or the publisher has sold up and the incomer has no interest in the work.

But then a year ago he knocked off, fairly quickly, a book called Now We Are Sixty, which is a pastiche of the AA Milne verses in Now We Are Six. It's a sharp take on modern life ("They're changing sex at Buckingham Palace"), produced by John Murray. Thanks to arduous proselytising by Chris (and some help from Hatchard's bookshop) it's taken off. The book keeps going in and out of the best-seller lists, and has sold 60,000 copies so far. I'm now starting work on Fifty Is Fun, Those Fabulous Forties and Seventy Can Be Sexy!

 At one point we visited Southwold. Now that some British seaside resorts, such as Rock in Cornwall, have become intensely fashionable, Southwold, with its elegant balconied houses, gorgeous Swan hotel and well-trimmed greens, is very chic indeed. One of the handsome but tiny beach huts will cost you £30,000, enough to buy a family home in some parts of the country. We called in at Adnam's wine warehouse where the tasting area is a sort of permanent cocktail party. People were cheerily greeting their friends, and saying, "just a top-up of that very pleasant South African chardonnay, if you don't mind..."

 On the way home we stopped at Cambridge. With millions coming in from Microsoft and vast new labs springing up around the city, the place is booming. House prices there match the more expensive parts of London. And the sleepy train I used to take past Audley End and Saffron Walden has been replaced by a twice-hourly rocket to King's Cross, while the latest university league table gives it a score of 96%, more than 10 points higher than the No 2, Imperial College in London.

Poor old Oxford (in some subjects, such as English and French, roughly twice as many people apply to Cambridge as to Oxford) is stuck at No 3, barely ahead of York. Oxford is trying to catch up, but its rigid college system and unwillingness to change mean that it has a long way to go.

 We all wish Gordon Brown and Sarah Macauley well, though I hope she manages to change some of his habits. When I was political editor of the Observer, and he was shadow chancellor, it was quite common to receive a call from him at 10pm on a Saturday night. "Hello, Gordon here. I've been running some of the Treasury figures through my computer, and I've been amazed to find a 7.4 billion shortfall..." You wanted to yell down the phone: "Gordon, it's Saturday night. You shouldn't be working. Go out and have some fun." Hopefully he now will.

webTitle: The readers' editor on his Sisyphean labour

fields.headline: Beetlemania
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... his Sisyphean labour
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... his Sisyphean labour
fields.body:
A recent email from a reader began, "Dear Sir, Madam, With reference to the July 24 edition of the Guardian, I would like to point out [that] ... this particular edition is numbered 47858. This is, however, erroneous, as this was the number of the July 22 edition - both editions now carry the same edition number.

"I consider this to be a very serious mistake, the more so while this is not the first time this very mistake is made. You may recall that I sent you a similar letter on September 28, 1971 - I was then promised that this would not happen again."

I sent the following reply: "Thank you for your email pointing out a serious anomaly in the recent numbering of Guardian editions. I took the opportunity to draw your letter to the attention of the senior editorial staff of the Guardian at the editor's meeting this morning where I read it aloud. I am sure greater efforts will be made in future."

The editor's meeting, it would be true to say, broke up on hearing this complaint and, rather unusually, several journalists expressed the hope that it would feature prominently in the following day's corrections. It did not do that because I came to the conclusion that it was a carefully contrived hoax, rather cunningly arranged with a mistake both in the language ("while") and the dating of the last letter of complaint (1971). These were clearly designed to suggest, once I had begun to suspect its authenticity, that it had come from a journalist on the Guardian.

Authentic or not, it wonderfully represented a tone of voice with which I have become quite familiar, the relentless monotone of the compulsive pedant. There is something of the pedant in all of us, of course. In you and me it is present as a perfectly healthy ingredient of a balanced personality. But in the others . . . Happily they represent only a minority in the total who call - about 18,000 of you since the office opened in 1997.

Readers of the Guardian who write to complain often add a message of sympathy and encouragement. Mr Seagroatt of Liverpool wrote recently, "The apparent insouciance with which you carry out the labours of Sisyphus is admirable." (Thank you for the perceptive "apparent".) Even Private Eye was moved to suggest that perhaps no one since Sisyphus had undertaken such an impossible task as the one I have.

Sisyphus, if I may remind you, was in Greek mythology the king of Corinth whose punishment in Hades was to roll a huge stone up a hill only for it to roll down, causing him to start all over again, and so on and on (I recommend britannica.com for more details).

Here is something I happened to be reading, quite coincidentally, which describes this aspect of my task perfectly: "Now begins a Sisyphean labour. The ball, that enormous burden, is painfully hoisted, step by step . . . to a certain height, always backwards . . . An ill-advised movement frustrates all this toil; the ball rolls down dragging the bearer with it . . . He begins over again with indefatigable obstinacy. Ten times, 20 times, he will attempt the hopeless ascent . . ."

This is a description of a creature with which, on a bad day, I can readily identify, the dung beetle as observed by the naturalist Jean-Henri Fabre.

Readers also encourage us to continue with this toil of owning up and correcting by pointing out now and again that errors in newspapers range widely through time and space. Margaret Manuell, browsing through the archives of the Tamworth Herald, unearthed the following in the issue of December 25, 1880:

A correction: It will be almost unnecessary to inform our readers that the words "awful and honorable life" which occurred in the notice of Mr Stretton's death in our last, should read "useful and honourable life".

My correspondent added, "An ill-chosen word and a spelling mistake. The Guardian couldn't have done it better."

The following, from the Canberra Times of July 6, this year, was also drawn to my attention:

Correction: The late Edythe Butler, BEM, was incorrectly referred to as "Edy the Butler" in About Town on Tuesday. This was a subeditor's error.

Ah. That's it, blame the subs. Although, perhaps we should indeed blame them for the variations in the spelling of a Californian place name in G2 this week. It should have been Stevens Creek, a title never bestowed upon it in the piece, in which it appeared variously as Stephen's Creek, Steven's Creek, and, wait for it, Jacob's Creek, a name usually associated with an Australian wine. As a reader said in an email from California, "Best put the bottle down and check the copy!"

 Ian Mayes is now away; his column will resume in September. Elaine Showalter will write in this space until then. Jean-Henri Fabre's description of the dung beetle is taken from Insect Lives: Stories of Mystery and Romance from a Hidden World by Erich Hoyt and Ted Schultz (Mainstream). Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

I took the opportunity to draw your letter to the attention of the senior editorial staff of the Guardian at the editor's meeting this morning where I read it aloud. I am sure greater efforts will be made in future." The editor's meeting, it would be true to say, broke up on hearing this complaint and, rather unusually, several journalists expressed the hope that it would feature prominently in the following day's corrections. It did not do that because I came to the conclusion that it was a carefully contrived hoax, rather cunningly arranged with a mistake both in the language ("while") and the dating of the last letter of complaint (1971). These were clearly designed to suggest, once I had begun to suspect its authenticity, that it had come from a journalist on the Guardian. Authentic or not, it wonderfully represented a tone of voice with which I have become quite familiar, the relentless monotone of the compulsive pedant. There is something of the pedant in all of us, of course. In you and me it is present as a perfectly healthy ingredient of a balanced personality. But in the others . . . Happily they represent only a minority in the total who call - about 18,000 of you since the office opened in 1997. Readers of the Guardian who write to complain often add a message of sympathy and encouragement. Mr Seagroatt of Liverpool wrote recently, "The apparent insouciance with which you carry out the labours of Sisyphus is admirable." (Thank you for the perceptive "apparent".) Even Private Eye was moved to suggest that perhaps no one since Sisyphus had undertaken such an impossible task as the one I have. Sisyphus, if I may remind you, was in Greek mythology the king of Corinth whose punishment in Hades was to roll a huge stone up a hill only for it to roll down, causing him to start all over again, and so on and on (I recommend britannica.com for more details). Here is something I happened to be reading, quite coincidentally, which describes this aspect of my task perfectly: "Now begins a Sisyphean labour. The ball, that enormous burden, is painfully hoisted, step by step . . . to a certain height, always backwards . . . An ill-advised movement frustrates all this toil; the ball rolls down dragging the bearer with it . . . He begins over again with indefatigable obstinacy. Ten times, 20 times, he will attempt the hopeless ascent . . ." This is a description of a creature with which, on a bad day, I can readily identify, the dung beetle as observed by the naturalist Jean-Henri Fabre. Readers also encourage us to continue with this toil of owning up and correcting by pointing out now and again that errors in newspapers range widely through time and space. Margaret Manuell, browsing through the archives of the Tamworth Herald, unearthed the following in the issue of December 25, 1880: A correction: It will be almost unnecessary to inform our readers that the words "awful and honorable life" which occurred in the notice of Mr Stretton's death in our last, should read "useful and honourable life". My correspondent added, "An ill-chosen word and a spelling mistake. The Guardian couldn't have done it better." The following, from the Canberra Times of July 6, this year, was also drawn to my attention: Correction: The late Edythe Butler, BEM, was incorrectly referred to as "Edy the Butler" in About Town on Tuesday. This was a subeditor's error. Ah. That's it, blame the subs. Although, perhaps we should indeed blame them for the variations in the spelling of a Californian place name in G2 this week. It should have been Stevens Creek, a title never bestowed upon it in the piece, in which it appeared variously as Stephen's Creek, Steven's Creek, and, wait for it, Jacob's Creek, a name usually associated with an Australian wine. As a reader said in an email from California, "Best put the bottle down and check the copy!"  Ian Mayes is now away; his column will resume in September. Elaine Showalter will write in this space until then. Jean-Henri Fabre's description of the dung beetle is taken from Insect Lives: Stories of Mystery and Romance from a Hidden World by Erich Hoyt and Ted Schultz (Mainstream). Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. webTitle: Theatre reviews: The Pirates of Penzance, Regent's Park Open Air Theatre and Pageant, the Vaudeville Theatre

fields.headline: Is camp becoming a drag?
fields.standfirst: Mincing policemen, cross-dressing beauty contestants - London's stages are awash with the over-the-top and the effeminate.  Michael Billington  doesn't think he can take much more.
fields.trailText: August is a month for camping, not least in London theatre. In the excellent Pirates of Penzance in Regent's Park, the police are treated as fairy-footed rozzers led by the spryly twinkling Stephen Matthews. And Pageant, a spoof American beauty contest which has just moved from the King's Head to the Vaudeville, is played by men in drag and is camper than the proverbial Chloe.
fields.body:
August is a month for camping, not least in London theatre. In the excellent Pirates of Penzance in Regent's Park, the police are treated as fairy-footed rozzers led by the spryly twinkling Stephen Matthews. And Pageant, a spoof American beauty contest which has just moved from the King's Head to the Vaudeville, is played by men in drag and is camper than the proverbial Chloe.

"Camp" itself is a multi-coloured word. According to my Shorter Oxford Dictionary, its origins are unknown. But we all recognise it when we see it.

Any definition of high camp would include Oscar Wilde, much of Noel Coward, the musicals of Sandy Wilson, the novels of Ronald Firbank and EF Benson, and Vincent Price's horror movies. Examples of low camp would be the Carry On movies, Round the Horne, Larry Grayson, and Frankie Howerd. Indeed, it was the last who once provided a memorable negative definition. Glancing furtively at his prim lady pianist, he gossipingly confided that she was so out of touch she thought Richard Dimbleby was camp.

What is fascinating is how camp has spread far beyond the gay community. The exchanges of Jules and Sandy on Round the Horne have become part of comic folklore. "Did you drag yourselves up on deck?" they were famously asked after a violent sea storm. To which the response was: "No, just sweaters and jeans."

Straight entertainers, for generations, have also used the armoury of camp. George Robey dolled himself up as Queen Victoria; Max Miller sported dazzling rainbow-coloured suits; Barry Humphries has transformed Melbourne's Edna Everage from a dowdy suburbanite into a glittering superstar dame with a talent to abuse.

But camp, as Pageant currently proves, has its limitations. It thrives best when its form of epicene exaggeration has a hetero counterpoint. Jules and Sandy were funny precisely because they were quizzed by Kenneth Horne, who seemed innocently oblivious to their riotous double-entendres. Kenneth Williams and Charles Hawtrey could wince and mince through the Carry On movies because they were offset by the roguish earthiness of Sid James and Barbara Windsor.

Even in a show like Regent's Park's Pirates of Penzance the campy cavortings of the cops contrast with the four-square Englishness of Paul Bradley's Major-General. Camp, at its best, is about contradiction: a classic example is George Melly, who hymns love and lust while arrayed like Solomon in all his glory.

The reason that Pageant - conceived, I'm delighted to note, by Robert Longbottom - palls after a while is that, having struck camp, it has nowhere much to go. It parodies the tacky vacuity of beauty pageants by casting men as the rival contestants. It also creates a mock-suspense by getting audience members to vote for the winning queen. On the first night the prize rightly went to Leon Maurice-Jones, who, as Miss Industrial North-East, shows an astonishing capacity to do cartwheels and play the accordion while on roller-skates.

But I suspect the show would be much funnier if it were compered by a po-faced straightman; instead it has Lionel Blair, who, with his spangled hair and salmon pink evening dress, seems in complicity with the very world outside which he supposedly stands.

Undeniably Pageant has some very funny moments: many of the best come from the toothy, horse-faced Miles Western, who plays Miss West Coast as a dippy, spaced-out creature who seems to have descended from another planet. At one point, as he seeks to demonstrate a new line in strap-on deodorants, he almost strangles himself in his choker and is reduced to suppressed sneezes by the intoxicating odours. I laughed but I was mainly intrigued by the audience, who were reduced to paralysed hysteria. There was something exaggeratingly self-perpetuating about the laughter, suggesting that camp itself is contagious.

Pageant, which is directed and co-written by Bill Russell, is a perfectly amiable off-Broadway show. But two thoughts strike me. It is the fifth American import I have seen in the past two weeks, suggesting that we are rapidly turning into a cultural colony of the US. But it also exploits to the full a strong element of camp: what Penelope Gilliatt once dubbed "the charm of the bad". While spoofing beauty contests, the show clearly delights in their tasteless decor, their absurd pretensions, their innate chauvinist competitiveness.

But to me there is limited fun to be had from wallowing in the awfulness of the second-rate: on such evenings, I find myself yearning for an unironed reality and the oxygen of authentic passion. Camp is undeniably a part of theatre, but if it becomes the whole part then you get hermetic enervation. Better, I'd have thought, the grim reality of the kitchen sink than the self-delighting mockery of sinking kitsch.

Pageant is at the Vaudeville Theatre, London WC2 (020-7836 9987), till November 26. The Pirates of Penzance is at the Regent's Park Open Air Theatre, London NW1 (020-7486 2431), from August 17 to 23, and August 29 to September 5.

webTitle: Gig review: the Montgolfier Brothers at the Notting Hill Arts Club, London

fields.headline: Time to go home
fields.trailText: Gig review: the Montgolfier Brothers at the Notting Hill Arts Club, London
fields.body:
It's one thing to be an experimental duo aligning looped drums with unworldly guitars. It's another to be playing in a cellar - in this case at the Notting Hill Arts Club in London - that squashes all the beauty of your sound and the pain of your lyrics. But such is the plight of the Montgolfier Brothers.

As Roger Quigley leans forward, one leg bent, shoulders hunched - hands tightly gripping both microphone stand and cigarette, and a music stand of lyrics before him - it's clear he's about to divulge the secrets of his soul. But the first uttering of Ghost sees all his good intentions lost against the guitars of fellow band member Mark Tranmer and helping hand Otto, and the constant chit-chat of revellers at the bar. It wasn't meant to be like this.

The Montgolfier Brothers are appropriately named after French siblings who were big in the ballooning world, and their music conjures up images of wide-open spaces, air and light, drawing comparisons with both Badly Drawn Boy and the Cocteau Twins.

And while three guitars and a backing track could be seen to be over-zealous, and in the wrong hands would be painful, this is nothing if not delicate: more Segovia than Slayer. As Between Two Points chimes and ripples calmly, Quigley sings in a voice that's endearing rather than impressive.

Which applies to Quigley and Tranmer themselves. They are gifted musicians and their instrumental tracks, especially Can't Get Through, linger in the mind, but they are not adept at the art of showmanship.

Quigley alternates between crouching down, staring at the floor and playing the guitar with his back turned to the audience. And the others don't try any harder, looking at their instruments for inspiration. The Montgolfier Brothers obviously take their music seriously, but with so little interaction or even eye-contact with the crowd, you start wondering why we should care.

It's then that Quigley chooses to acknowledge we're here. "We've got an experiment," he says, "and we're going to use you as guinea pigs." The song, Prestwich Choir, is the highlight of the set, as Quigley jumps on to a waiting drum kit and slowly, methodically, builds a rhythm that swells in force and intensity. It's the highlight of the night, a fantastic example of sublime talent.

But it's also dispassionate and controlled - like the man says, an experiment. And it serves to show that some bands should just stay at home and be content to win fans with their records. The Montgolfier Brothers and their majestic melodies aren't made for the live experience. It's a feast better served at home.

webTitle: Opera review: Siegfried and Götterdämmerung, Jürgen Flimm's new production at Wagner's own theatre in Bayreuth.

fields.headline: Vicious cycle
fields.standfirst: Bayreuth's latest take on the Ring fills  Tom Service  with wonder and despair
fields.trailText: Bayreuth's latest take on the Ring fills Tom Service with wonder and despair.
fields.body:
The second half of Wagner's Ring cycle, in the operas Siegfried and Götterdämmerung, tells of the doomed lives and loves of Siegfried and Brünnhilde, archetypal figures of heroism. But even in the dragon-slaying, wife-winning exploits of the young Siegfried, there is little sense of untrammelled joy in Jürgen Flimm's new production at Wagner's own theatre in Bayreuth. When Siegfried kills Fafner (the giant who transformed himself into a dragon to protect the gold he won in the first work of the cycle, Das Rheingold), Siegfried's sword lays waste to an entire ecosystem. As the smoke clears from Fafner's carcass - a metal and flesh homunculus like one of David Cronenberg's nightmarish visions - Erich Wonder's sets reveal a scorched wasteland. Decay - environmental and ethical - has set in.

But Wolfgang Schmidt's Siegfried is blissfully unaware of this rot. From the moment we meet him, he is an arrogant brat who delights in using his strength to humiliate the dwarf Mime, his ageing, thieving guardian. Siegfried is no hero, just an overgrown boy. Like Flimm's portrayal of the gods in Das Rheingold, Siegfried is profoundly, fallibly flawed. Schmidt's singing of the part has a winning openness but his enthusiasm occasionally spills over into a clumsiness of intonation and articulation.

When Siegfried frees Brünnhilde from her enchanted sleep in the third act of the opera, he is forced to confront, for the first time, someone over whom he has no power. Their duet is one of the most vocally and intellectually taxing in the operatic repertoire, especially at conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli's slow tempos. Although blusteringly powerful, the combination of Gabriele Schnaut's Brünnhilde and Schmidt's Siegfried does not create the same momentum as their orchestral underpinning. Indeed, the outstanding moments of this Siegfried involve Alan Titus's Wotan. In the snowy remnants of the set from the end of Das Rheingold, Wotan, the king of the gods, movingly finds a kind of reconciliation, albeit a masochistic one, when the mortal hero Siegfried's sword breaks his spear confirming the end of the gods and the independence of Siegfried.

By the time of the final opera of the cycle, Götterdämmerung, the wastes of the landscapes in Siegfried have been transformed into a seething, industrial heartland from which every vestige of nature has been eradicated. The undoubted leader of this rotten renewal is Hagen, son of the dwarf Alberich, whose theft of power-bestowing gold from the Rhinemaidens began the entire story of the Ring. Wonder has made the Gibichung Hall a gleaming, triple-tiered waiting-room, from which Hagen, and his half-brother and sister Gunther and Gutrune, plan their world domination.

John Tomlinson's Hagen orchestrates his pursuit of power with conspiratorial vehemence. As magnificently strong vocally as he is broodingly brilliant as an actor, Tomlinson gives the most complete performance of this Ring. His Hagen is a dark reflection of Titus's Wotan, but Hagen's lust is hollow, empty and pretentious. In the hellish airport-lounge of Wonder's sets, Hagen inhabits a world of pure surface, a mere frame for his unquenchable bitterness.

Hagen is the most significant mirroring in a Götterdämmerung that is suffused with reminiscences and doppelgangers. Siegfried is murdered by Hagen where Fafner's geometric skeleton lies, becoming an outsider where he was once triumphant. Brünnhilde's climactic immolation scene - in which Schnaut finds her most convincing and sensitive singing - is played out against situations and scenery from the whole cycle. Wonder's symbolism careers finally towards the interchangeable surfaces of a series of backdrops. The end of the gods, in this staging, is the collapse of the imagery on to a point of total emptiness. But the final gesture of the production is of a warrior (Brünnhilde, perhaps?) alone on the vastness of the Bayreuth stage - an enigmatic vision of isolation and an unattainable heroic ideal.

Over the course of all four operas of the Ring cycle, Flimm and Wonder make Wagner's epic speak with a directness that is contemporary and mythological. Allied to Sinopoli's liquid, lucid conducting, this Ring is rigorously focused on the human allegories at the heart of the story. The cycle's continuing relevance could scarcely find more compelling expression.

fields.headline: Round and round the houses
fields.standfirst: He's a Home Counties boy who flays the middle-classes from his base in Yorkshire, a shy man whose inner turmoil comes out in his plays, a comic writer of world renown - yet the critics are divided about his reputation.  Simon Fanshawe on a very modern Molière
fields.trailText: The Guardian Profile: Alan Ayckbourn
fields.body:
Alan Ayckbourn was explaining how his plays become hits to a man who runs amusement arcade slot machines in Scarborough . First, they're tried out in the resort's theatre, next they transfer to the West End, "then, if I'm lucky, they go to America or Holland or wherever. And each place they go, I get paid."

The slot machine man, "a bit of a wide boy," Ayckbourn admits admiringly, was intrigued - "but how do you get the actual money?" There was no mystery, said the playwright, with his usual anxious modesty, "the theatre collects a percentage and just sends it to my agent". The slot-machine man bellowed, "they just hand over the money? That's fucking brilliant. I have to empty these machines myself, every day. 'Ere, George!" And Ayckbourn had to describe the whole system to George again.

During rehearsals for his 54th and 55th plays, the linked House/Garden, Ayckbourn said: "Suddenly I've got credibility in Scarborough - for this scam. And I've managed to explain what I am doing there now: I am running an international racket." And he laughs, not his guffaw, but his other one - the funny internal sort of gurgle, an almost private sign of some personal satisfaction.

It's a revealing tale. In the theatre world Ayckbourn is decisively a man of the people. His friends say he feels it is important to be accepted by ordinary people with ordinary jobs for doing something real. So his plays are designed to be immediately accessible. Nothing matters to him more than getting the audience in. It always has. It was a ground rule imparted by his mentor, Stephen Joseph, after whom Ayckbourn's theatre-in-the-round in Scarborough is named. He was the wild and inspiring son of Michael Joseph the publisher and Hermione Baddeley, the great revue comedienne of the 30s and 40s. Joseph's brief to the then 20-year- old actor was "to write plays that would fill the theatre". He's been doing that for 30 years. But Ayckbourn adds now: "They also had to be worthy of my peers and colleagues who were sharing the dressing room with me in Scarborough. They'd mostly come a long way up from London and made quite big cuts in their living standards to do so. If I'd given them tacky seaside stuff they'd say, 'Look, I could have been doing telly.'"

You should do more of this.'"

He always says that most of his plays are located "somewhere north of Reading". They are all sharply aware of their place in the pecking order and most of them are determined to change it to the disadvantage of others. He watches us inflict awful cruelty on each other, more often than not during the family rituals of birthdays, Christmasses, meals, funerals and marriages. [However] I am probably guilty of tidying up the world a bit because things tend to happen rather quicker in plays than in the real world. Although Robert Maxwell did fall overboard."

Your life became more and more about those months at school because you came home and you knew no-one. Women were a bit strange, too, because you didn't see them much."

And I was very angry that anyone allowed me to make that sort of vow. It wasn't an easy thing to walk away."

Eventually he did, after about six years, although he didn't get divorced for another 35. He married his long-time personal assistant, Heather Stoney, in 1997. Legend has it that, with a knighthood possible, he waited until the honour was bestowed so that he could divorce and then remarry: that way there would be two Lady Ayckbourns. He doesn't demur.

You just feel with him that you could chat about any women's problems. He's in no way not butch, but I can natter on to him like I would to a girlfriend." Ayckbourn constructs a company around him, and people work with him again and again - Glossop, the designer for 14 years; Michael Gambon, his star actor for 20.

But Scarborough gives him more than control. It gives him a regular audience which allows him to practise theatre in a community where he belongs. He has, in the way of those who are rootless in childhood, zealously adopted this Yorkshire seaside resort as home. And it colours his view of what theatre is and why it matters. "I strongly believe - I'm a regionalist of course - that theatre is the forum where we discuss ideas and also ourselves. And we do it in a way that you cannot do in the movies, which are one-sided arguments made by someone a million miles away, purveyed by people who are 17 times your size. Which is just nothing like watching Hamlet die a few feet in front of you."

In an eight-month season, the theatre produces one new show of his a year - said to be gestated for months but actually written at great speed in just four weeks - and as much new writing as it can risk at the box office. It seeks out new work by writers who wish to reach a wider public, the people Ayckbourn describes as the ones who believe they're not theatregoers.

For this the theatre gets £450,000 a year from Yorkshire Arts, £53,000 from North Yorkshire Council, and £207,000 from Scarborough Council. Despite the theatre also earning £650,000 in commercial income, the town has wobbled in its commitment. In 1997 there was the celebrated "luvvies versus lavvies" dispute when the redoubtable philistinism of the British reared up in the form of a local councillor who said that the theatre grant would mean closing the town's 22 public lavatories. The headline writers could hardly believe their luck. The local paper was full of inarticulate praise for the public conveniences as a major Scarborough attraction, and Ayckbourn lost his rag. "If you happen to be teetotal in this town, then God help you - because there is little else to do apart from get drunk and buy shoes," he wrote. The council later relented.

For all the ongoing debate about the best way of keeping theatre alive, in his book it comes down to one thing: "I have been out to lunch with successive arts minis ters who say, 'OK, Alan, tell us what the problem is'. And I say, 'money'. And they say 'Apart from that'. It's nothing to do with anything but money. I feel like a man in a house with no roof, the rain pouring in, and people offering money to build a conservatory. I just want some roofing tiles."

They have seen every play and their verdict is that "he is getting even funnier". "I was just staggered," he says, starting the kind of knowing commentary on the writing that can only come from an intense involvement in the whole body of work.

Ayckbourn is richer than he admits. His agents put the royalties alone at "well over a million a year". Ayckbourn says "a million a year? I wish it was. I work in theatre, you know, I don't do movies." But he also gives a lot to his theatre. It is a matter of record that he has worked as artistic director without drawing a salary for 30 years, and that he pays for a casting director. But, according to friends, he also donates a considerable amount of his royalties to the Stephen Joseph and he bought the lease on the current building for an estimated £200,000, in partnership with Charles McCarthy, the UK chairman of McCain's chips, and Lord Down, both great local supporters of the theatre. Some estimate that his personal contribution to the bid for National Lottery funding which enabled them to buy and open the new building in 1996 was about £400,000.

Ayckbourn is not only part of a great but now-fragile tradition of regional civic theatre, but also of the stream of English dramatists from Shakespeare through the Restoration to the Kitchen Sink, although perhaps not yet including the smack and sodomy kids of Shopping And Fucking and Blasted. But he grew up in theatre's changing landscape. Emerging as an actor just after 1956 when Osborne, Pinter and Wesker were beginning to get established, he also had the advantage of playing Coward and Rattigan in weekly repertory. It is clear that he feels part of both movements but ultimately he decided on a commitment to popular work and to write plays which he says "are simply about people".

It is that which, out of snobbery, prevents some people taking him seriously.Peter Hall says that there "is still some feeling that if a play is commercial it somehow doesn't belong in the subsidised theatre and that we should be doing plays about distant indigenous tribes in loose poetic rhyme". If you want a reputation of significance, that's a fatal error. And it's compounded if you not only choose to write comedies but produce one a year - and then in the provinces. Yet, as a writer in English, Ayckbourn is second only to Shakespeare in terms of the number of times his plays are produced around the world. Every year in Britain there are 25 to 30 professional productions of Ayckbourn, and his work goes around the world, with translations in 34 languages. Later this year the National Theatre of Taiwan in Taipei will revive its hugely successful national tour of Communicating Doors in Cantonese. The German theatre critic Gerhard Stadelmaier called Ayckbourn, whose popularity in Germany almost tops that in Britain, "the Molière of the middle classes".

Critics, however, are divided about his reputation. Is he just a "pretty farceur" - a populist boulevard writer churning out commercial comedy hits based on theatrical trickery, and a writer with no sustainable claim on posterity? Or does a body of work which contains Relatively Speaking, Absurd Person Singular, The Norman Conquests, Absent Friends, Bedroom Farce and A Chorus Of Disapproval, make him "one of our most serious dramatists, comparable with Pinter, Hare and Stoppard", as Michael Billington described him?

The two new plays are about the deceptive nature of reality; they show people from different angles, so certain things appear funny until you see them from a different perspective. Ayckbourn is reluctant to intellectualise, but will admit that his work has some kind of philosophical impact. But he has a horror that people will draw back from going to his shows if they feel they're going to be preached at.

He saw this happen to one of his contemporaries, Harold Pinter, early on in his career. Ayckbourn says, "to me, he wrote wonderful plays. But they became so studied, so interpreted that you couldn't walk near them without having a BA." Analysis clouded the theatrical experience, and even Pinter himself resisted that. In his early days as an actor, Ayckbourn was once directed by Pinter in one of Pinter's own plays. As he was feeling his way into the part, he asked the playwright, "Where does this guy come from?" Pinter replied: "Mind your own fucking business."

Despite the critics' snobbery it is clear that he is one of the nation's most intuitive chroniclers, particularly foreshadowing what would come to fruition in the 80s with the decline of the professional classes before the advance of thrusting opportunists. As Hall says, "He has an acute social sense of what it was like to live in England in the last half of the 20th century. And for that, as much as any dramatist, he is required reading".

Educated: Haileybury, Herts. Married: 1959 Christine Roland (two sons, Steven, Philip), dissolved; October 1997 Heather Stoney.
Career:
1957 actor, Theatre-in- the-Round, Scarborough; 1962-70 BBC radio drama producer, Leeds; 1971- artistic director, Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough; director, National Theatre 1986-7. Some plays: 1959 The Square Cat, 1965 Relatively Speaking, 1972 Absurd Person Singular, 1973 The Norman Conquests, 1977 Bedroom Farce, 1979 Joking Apart, 1982 Way Upstream, 1985 A Chorus Of Disapproval, 1987 A Small Family Business, 1996 Communicating Doors, 1998 Things We Do For Love, 2000 House/Garden.
Honours: 1987 CBE; 1997 knighted.
