Ian Grundy and Bob Harris, who run the guesthouse, Interludes, whose clients come just to see the plays, say, "Scarborough can't buy the kind of publicity Alan brings". They have seen every play and their verdict is that "he is getting even funnier". Bob Watson, a retired local English teacher, was a reluctant convert, chaperoning his wife and daughter under protest to his first Ayckbourn, Confusions, in the early 70s. "I was just staggered," he says, starting the kind of knowing commentary on the writing that can only come from an intense involvement in the whole body of work. Ayckbourn is richer than he admits. His agents put the royalties alone at "well over a million a year". Ayckbourn says "a million a year? I wish it was. I work in theatre, you know, I don't do movies." But he also gives a lot to his theatre. It is a matter of record that he has worked as artistic director without drawing a salary for 30 years, and that he pays for a casting director. But, according to friends, he also donates a considerable amount of his royalties to the Stephen Joseph and he bought the lease on the current building for an estimated £200,000, in partnership with Charles McCarthy, the UK chairman of McCain's chips, and Lord Down, both great local supporters of the theatre. Some estimate that his personal contribution to the bid for National Lottery funding which enabled them to buy and open the new building in 1996 was about £400,000. Ayckbourn is not only part of a great but now-fragile tradition of regional civic theatre, but also of the stream of English dramatists from Shakespeare through the Restoration to the Kitchen Sink, although perhaps not yet including the smack and sodomy kids of Shopping And Fucking and Blasted. But he grew up in theatre's changing landscape. Emerging as an actor just after 1956 when Osborne, Pinter and Wesker were beginning to get established, he also had the advantage of playing Coward and Rattigan in weekly repertory. It is clear that he feels part of both movements but ultimately he decided on a commitment to popular work and to write plays which he says "are simply about people". It is that which, out of snobbery, prevents some people taking him seriously.Peter Hall says that there "is still some feeling that if a play is commercial it somehow doesn't belong in the subsidised theatre and that we should be doing plays about distant indigenous tribes in loose poetic rhyme". If you want a reputation of significance, that's a fatal error. And it's compounded if you not only choose to write comedies but produce one a year - and then in the provinces. Yet, as a writer in English, Ayckbourn is second only to Shakespeare in terms of the number of times his plays are produced around the world. Every year in Britain there are 25 to 30 professional productions of Ayckbourn, and his work goes around the world, with translations in 34 languages. Later this year the National Theatre of Taiwan in Taipei will revive its hugely successful national tour of Communicating Doors in Cantonese. The German theatre critic Gerhard Stadelmaier called Ayckbourn, whose popularity in Germany almost tops that in Britain, "the Molière of the middle classes". Critics, however, are divided about his reputation. Is he just a "pretty farceur" - a populist boulevard writer churning out commercial comedy hits based on theatrical trickery, and a writer with no sustainable claim on posterity? Or does a body of work which contains Relatively Speaking, Absurd Person Singular, The Norman Conquests, Absent Friends, Bedroom Farce and A Chorus Of Disapproval, make him "one of our most serious dramatists, comparable with Pinter, Hare and Stoppard", as Michael Billington described him? The two new plays are about the deceptive nature of reality; they show people from different angles, so certain things appear funny until you see them from a different perspective. Ayckbourn is reluctant to intellectualise, but will admit that his work has some kind of philosophical impact. But he has a horror that people will draw back from going to his shows if they feel they're going to be preached at. He saw this happen to one of his contemporaries, Harold Pinter, early on in his career. Ayckbourn says, "to me, he wrote wonderful plays. But they became so studied, so interpreted that you couldn't walk near them without having a BA." Analysis clouded the theatrical experience, and even Pinter himself resisted that. In his early days as an actor, Ayckbourn was once directed by Pinter in one of Pinter's own plays. As he was feeling his way into the part, he asked the playwright, "Where does this guy come from?" Pinter replied: "Mind your own fucking business." Despite the critics' snobbery it is clear that he is one of the nation's most intuitive chroniclers, particularly foreshadowing what would come to fruition in the 80s with the decline of the professional classes before the advance of thrusting opportunists. As Hall says, "He has an acute social sense of what it was like to live in England in the last half of the 20th century. And for that, as much as any dramatist, he is required reading".  House/Garden open at the National Theatre, Upper Ground, London SE1 on August 9 Life at a glance - Alan Ayckbourn Born: April 12 1939, Hampstead, London Educated: Haileybury, Herts. Married: 1959 Christine Roland (two sons, Steven, Philip), dissolved; October 1997 Heather Stoney. Career: 1957 actor, Theatre-in- the-Round, Scarborough; 1962-70 BBC radio drama producer, Leeds; 1971- artistic director, Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough; director, National Theatre 1986-7. Some plays: 1959 The Square Cat, 1965 Relatively Speaking, 1972 Absurd Person Singular, 1973 The Norman Conquests, 1977 Bedroom Farce, 1979 Joking Apart, 1982 Way Upstream, 1985 A Chorus Of Disapproval, 1987 A Small Family Business, 1996 Communicating Doors, 1998 Things We Do For Love, 2000 House/Garden. Honours: 1987 CBE; 1997 knighted.

webTitle: Julie Burchill: Both sides of the argument

fields.headline: Both sides of the argument
fields.standfirst: What is the effect on the developing world if its brightest people are welcomed as fodder for the west's many-mawed corporate monster?
fields.trailText: What is the effect on the developing world if its brightest people are welcomed as fodder for the west's many-mawed corporate monster?
fields.body:
When I was young, I was very partisan. Everything, with me, was for or against - Blue Peter vs Magpie, Bowie vs Bolan. I put a lot of it down to growing up in a city with two football teams. If you've got one (Brighton, say, or Torquay), then you're united, and if you've got loads (London), they kind of cancel each other out. But if it's the either/or example of Bristol City and Bristol Rovers (and, similarly, in Manchester, Liverpool and Glasgow), it encourages an antagonistic mentality.

At my junior school, knowing the lyrics to The Red, Red Robin (City) when you should have known the lyrics to Goodnight, Irene was the difference between living your life as a social pariah or living it as a sidekick of the gods. (It says so much about the superiority of Bristol Rovers that only they had the imagination to take their anthem from the old blues legend, Leadbelly.)

On the home front, and until I was at least 10 years old, I thought that "Capitalist!" was literally a swear word, such was the vehemence with which my dad yelled it at the TV screen. On many a night I was awoken from my childish truckle bed to be carried downstairs to watch the latest victories of the Viet Cong. Thus I grew up unable not to feel strongly about the slightest of Issues, and could be driven to white-knuckle rage by those bovine types who would say, when asked to choose between, for example, spring and autumn, "Oh, you can't really choose, can you, because it's like comparing apples and oranges." But why can't you compare apples and oranges - why can apples be compared only with other apples?

By 18, my lack of ability to see the other chap's POV had me marching behind an SWP banner against the National Front and penning vicious pieces in the NME about the rash of nihilist punks, such as Howard Devoto (I know this is getting boring now, but hang on in there), who refused to nail their colours to the mast with self-adoring songs such as Shot By Both Sides. Shot by both sides? As if anyone would bother.

My fiercely partisan view of the world lasted until I was well into my thirties. When I was courting my ex-girlfriend, I once broke up with her - though admittedly only for a day - when she refused to agree with me that if Adolf Hitler had lived he should have been put to death. It was an incredibly hedonistic, pleasurable affair, too, so you can imagine how strange and surreal it must have seemed, suddenly interrupting our idyllic sunny afternoon sessions with bouts of interrogation about her preferred method of punishment for the world 's major dead war criminals.

But now, in my forties, I actually appear to have started seeing both sides of loads of arguments. Take the proposed repeal on public sex for homosexuals. No one wants to be on the same side as a bunch of joyless Daily Mail curtain-twitchers, but doesn't demanding the right to use public conveniences for one's private pleasure seem rather selfish, almost crypto-Thatcherite? There is no such thing as society, just my own spontaneous sexual fancies. Most of us manage to wait until we get home. Why not gay men?

Then there's the euro, and imperial measures. I certainly don't want to live in a world of bland euro-portions, where high streets from Hounslow to Hamburg to the Hague, all look and sound the same, but I can't help thinking that the very people who are asking us to get hot under the collar (measured in inches, natch) about our national identity and sovereignty are the very same people - the Daily Mail again, Mrs T, the Spectator - who have spent the past 50 years crawling so far up the fundament of the US that only the soles of their feet are now visible. It seems highly unlikely that the EU could wreak anything like the havoc on the political, social and cultural life of this country that the US has done, so why all the panic and purity suddenly?

Similarly, the sight of the G8 summit, at a cost of £500 million - including, for some reason, a £4-million replica of Bill Clinton's home in Arkansas - was repellent but, on the other hand, what sort of message about independence and putting their own house in order does it send to the developing world if we keep treating it like a ditzy wife who has run up a huge credit-card bill, pranged the company car and still expects to get away with it scot-free? These countries did, after all, clamour for independence and autonomy, which seems hardly compatible with such indulgence.

Then there's economic immigration - and before you get your recycled Biros out, I'm obviously not referring to people who flee in fear for their lives, but rather to those people who come here in pursuit of a better lifestyle. No one wants to see people dying in the backs of vans - but what is the long-term effect on the already weak developing world if its fittest, brightest and most able people are welcomed into the west as yet more fodder for our many-mawed corporate monster? Surely it would be far better for everyone if those people with skills stayed at home and used them for the betterment of their own struggling countries.

Yet I know that, if I was one of these same people, I would be over here like a shot. This is, after all is said and done, the best country out of a bad bunch, and I would certainly never want to live anywhere else. So it seems a bit phoney of me to be against any sort of immigration. (Just as phoney, in fact, as those knee-jerk liberals who are always running England down, but then, when it comes to immigration, seem to change their minds completely and maintain that a man's life isn't worth living unless he can live it on this sceptred Isle.)

The immediate effect on my day-to-day life of seeing both sides of an argument is that I feel a good deal more relaxed and tranquil, but also, if the truth be told, only half alive. That's not to say I'm not happier. It's just that I do miss the adrenaline rush that fierce, blinding hatred of the other side invariably provided, and I'm sure that's why a lot of people go in for hate on a regular basis. Hate, like love, stirs up certain pleasurable chemicals in us that become addictive. Meanwhile, I'm going to kick back and enjoy the summer scraps from my vantage point, and dream of the day when I'm back in the fray once more.

fields.headline: Named, shamed
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Sinbad has been getting it in the neck lately from everyone in Brookside (Channel 4). Or in what passes for his neck, as Sinbad is built on the same flowing lines as a walnut whip or Private Doberman in Bilko. Sinbad is a natural phenomenon, like the clouds of the sky or the waves of the sea. There are no straight lines in him.

After nearly 16 years playing Sinbad, Michael Starke is leaving the soap to have a stab at playing Hamlet or polo. Such dereliction can bring out the beast in the most domesticated TV company. Patrick Duffy, who played Bobby Ewing, once said: "I asked Dallas to let me leave with dignity and they hit me with a car." So Sinbad, the noblest scouser of them all, is now accused of being a paedophile and taunted remorselessly by people whose morals would make a ferret suck its teeth. Barred by Beverley, Merseyside's foremost slapper. Shunned by Susannah, who bounds buoyantly from man to man. Hounded by Kitty, a truant from the Twilight Home for the Tiresome. As Bev's barmaid said: "Just think about it. Sin and Bad: you can tell by his name, can't you?"

Sinbad is a window cleaner who used to clean a porthole in the middle of the pane, ignoring the corners. That is the worst thing he ever did.

At the moment he is rolling around the close like a lost hub cap. No one in Brookside ever goes far. Usually they move in with another odd lot a few doors down. In Sinbad's case, the Corkhills. But life there is so rough that intermittently even the Corkhills move out. As Jackie Corkhill said to Sinbad in a striking understatement: "This 'asn't been an 'appy 'ouse." What with Jimmy being a manic depressive and Lindsey thinking she is a lesbian, Jackie's hair is looking like a hayfield atharvest, tied in random sheaves. This week, bravely swimming against the popular tide, Rachel asked Sinbad to be godfather at the christening of her baby, Beth. If you want animated dialogue and a large audience, you cannot beat a sacred occasion like a wedding or a christening. The excellent acoustics of the church bounced the argument about. "He's making a mockery of the whole thing!" "I'm going to 'ave me say!" "What's all the shouting about?" "Tell 'im to sling 'is 'ook!" The baby was the quietest one there. It ended with Sinbad, auditioning perhaps for King Lear, apostrophising the uncaring heavens: "Strike me down dead now! Kill me!"

In one of those curious soap quirks, Coronation Street (ITV) had a christening too. For those of you who have not been paying attention, 13-year-old Sarah Louise Platt had a baby, Bethany, and this week the Platts decided, as they put it, to get Bethany done. The godmothers were Sarah's best friend, Candice, and Hayley, who strictly speaking is a man. Coronation Street often seems to have a tap root in panto and at the height of the festivities Candice's mother appeared in a puff of smoke, like the bad fairy. She spoke her mind: "You should be ashamed if you think you've got something to celebrate!" Life at the Platts is like sitting between the cymbals during one of Beethoven's noisier bits, and this set them off fortissimo: "We'll have something else to celebrate soon when you go!" Pausing only to chew the vicar's ear ("You're not fit to wear that dog collar!"), Candice's mother left in a marked manner. Just as the missing godfather arrived in a police car, having been caught shoplifting.

Talking of godfather... in Coronation Street a huge and hairy passenger squeezed into Steve McDonald's minicab, addressed him affably as "Sunshine" and threatened him with an early death if he testified in court. Homicidal yetis may be par for the course when minicabbing, but the whiskery one added one riveting word. " Capice? "

Capice? In Coronation Street? I haven't felt so shaken since an Italian nurse produced a syringe and said her name was Borgia.

fields.headline: Woke up this morning...
fields.standfirst: ... and told some gags. Billy Jenkins proves the blues can be a laughing matter
fields.trailText: Billy Jenkins proves the blues can be a laughing matter
fields.body:
Picture this: on a small stage draped in blue and red curtains sit five pale men in dark suits. They play the blues. Summertime Blues is a weird slice of music-theatre from Billy Jenkins and the Blues Collective. Funny and musicianly, it runs every Wednesday this month at the tiny Blue Elephant theatre in Camberwell, south-east London.

Full of knowing references, deliberate anti-climaxes and musical jokes, it's the kind of show that could drive some people up the wall. But it worked for the first-night audience because Jenkins uses the blues idiom as a cast-iron structure from which he can dangle his interests and obsessions.

His colleagues have just the right combination of musical virtuosity and self-effacement. The back line comprises drummer Mike Pickering and bass guitarist Thad Kelly (also one third of the superb Orquestra Mahatma). Dylan Bates plays electric violin through a variety of effects pedals, and second guitarist Rick Bolton squeezes exquisite solos between equally skilful rhythm parts. One of the treats of a small space like this is enjoying the details of sound and performance at close quarters.

Watching the leader is something else, though. He's a gifted guitarist, but there's an awkwardness, an impatient bloody-mindedness, about the way he attacks the instrument. There are the rapid, spiky runs that almost race ahead; the randomly placed discords with odd ringing tones; the sour, abrasive timbre; the unexpected leaps into George Benson pastiche or catchy "smooth jazz" chords. All this is accompanied by his familiar gawkiness: his body jerks, his shirt-tails come loose, his head and neck twitch like a robot bebopper.

Jenkins has been doing this for so long that he is entirely comfortable with his discomfort, and the Blues Collective are a well-drilled extension of his contradictory, likable personality. He's a thinker, a flamboyant theorist and an articulate and argumentative letter-writer who is always ready to challenge the showbiz status quo. One of his promotional badges showed a dollar sign with a line through it in the manner of a no-smoking sign; his latest slogan, plastered over his website (www.billyjenkins.com) is "music not business".

His CV includes a stretch in alternative comedy clubs (as part of Trimmer and Jenkins) and his comic timing is as quirkily effective as his groove. His deployment of his musicians can be clever and sensitive, but he uses musical stereotypes as a source of gags, walking over to chat to Bolton during Kelly's unaccompanied solo; making exaggerated yawning gestures after asking Pickering to list the dimensions of his drum kit; miming blissed-out dope-smoking while Bates plays a psychedelic electric violin solo. And Bolton's solos are a constant delight - to us and Jenkins - with the added bonus that in a yellow spotlight he's the spit of Homer Simpson.

The blues are a rich seam that is unlikely to run out, and they provide Jenkins with a repertoire that runs from Willie Dixon's Spoonful via First Day in Hell (a Jenkins original about nursery school) to Bye Bye Blues (with audience participation). It's a universal language: at one point, while blowing into a harmonica, Jenkins holds up fingers to indicate which of the chords, I, IV or V, he wants the band to move to. He can shout "Let's do it in A flat" and the band swerve into the key without a murmur. Then he preaches his Blues Prayer ("Forgive us this day our three passing chords/Lead us not into The Temptations"), concluding with "Oh yeah" instead of "Amen".

Jenkins has found a missing link between comedy improv and music improv: very British, and full of music and good humour.

Summertime Blues is at the Blue Elephant, 59a Bethwin Road, London SE5 (020-7701 0100), every Wednesday till August 30.

His deployment of his musicians can be clever and sensitive, but he uses musical stereotypes as a source of gags, walking over to chat to Bolton during Kelly's unaccompanied solo; making exaggerated yawning gestures after asking Pickering to list the dimensions of his drum kit; miming blissed-out dope-smoking while Bates plays a psychedelic electric violin solo. And Bolton's solos are a constant delight - to us and Jenkins - with the added bonus that in a yellow spotlight he's the spit of Homer Simpson. The blues are a rich seam that is unlikely to run out, and they provide Jenkins with a repertoire that runs from Willie Dixon's Spoonful via First Day in Hell (a Jenkins original about nursery school) to Bye Bye Blues (with audience participation). It's a universal language: at one point, while blowing into a harmonica, Jenkins holds up fingers to indicate which of the chords, I, IV or V, he wants the band to move to. Jenkins has found a missing link between comedy improv and music improv: very British, and full of music and good humour. Summertime Blues is at the Blue Elephant, 59a Bethwin Road, London SE5 (020-7701 0100), every Wednesday till August 30.

webTitle: John and Katya Berger see the old Lisbon in the new

fields.headline: The long sunset
fields.trailText: John Berger and Katya Berger Andreadakis see the old Lisbon in the new
fields.byline: John Berger  and Katya Berger Andreadakis
fields.body:
We have come to Lisbon to check out a portrait painted more than five centuries ago whose "likeness" perhaps still applies, still rings true. A portrait of the city itself in six panels.

After the customs at the airport, we spot, amongst all the people who have come to meet travellers they don't know and so are holding up names written on pieces of cardboard, a man who is in the painting. His name has long since been forgotten, yet he's easy for us to recognise because he looks like Pasolini. His face has the same expression of desire and foreboding. In the painting he's standing at the very top of the fourth panel. At the airport he notices us - he misses very little - yet he makes no sign. The simple fact of his being there was the sign. He had come to reassure us, who had travelled so far, that the others, his companions, were awaiting us.

The painting, with its six wooden panels, shows the dignitaries and people of Lisbon revering their patron saint, Vincent. The people are life-size. It was painted in the 1460s by Nuno Gonçalves for the cathedral. Then it was lost, and refound in 1882 in the monastery of São Vincente de Fora. Today it is in the Museum of Antique Art.

We go to the church of São Vincente de Fora on Palm Sunday. A small crowd of elderly women with their grandchildren, carrying bouquets of reeds, laurel, rosemary, carnations, are waiting to be blessed. Standing by the high altar before he says Mass, the young priest - he has almost the air of an adolescent - takes off his glasses and carefully, between finger and thumb, cleans them on his crimson robe. When he places them back on his nose, he can see very clearly and he surveys the congregation without either harshness or indulgence, without pathos or rhetoric. Could it be that an unwritten city law here is: do not exaggerate, for life itself is already exaggerated? The painting seems to propose this, but we do not yet know why.

A young woman modulating her voice so that it suggests, in the immense church, the horizon outside, sings an oratorio as if it were a fado . It is often said that Lisbon is the city of la saudade , which is usually translated as nostalgia, and that fados are the popular songs of this mood.

There would be good reasons here for being nostalgic. In the 15th century, having opened up the trade routes to west Africa, India, China and Brazil, Lisbon was one of the richest capitals in Europe, importing diamonds, gold and spices. An example: 120 tons of cloves per annum!

Walking along a narrow street of the Alfama district in a squall of Atlantic rain, we came upon a pungent smell of cinnamon and red pepper: the last traces of a past wealth left in poor dishes.

In the same narrow street we enter a small cafe, the size of a caravan, where we drink beer and are offered beans to nibble. Besides the two of us, there are five men who are clearly habitués. One of them, a widower in his 70s, is telling stories about life's exaggerations. He is wearing a new flat cap on the very top of his head, which underlines the worn-ness of his face. He is called Sebastiao. In the painting he's a bishop - just below Pasolini - and there in the painting he doubts whether his long homilies have ever been believed, and this doubt constitutes the sadness of his sincerity.

Lisbon was once a city of great navigators, over-armed crusaders, unsparing merchants, wealthy slave-traders - 16th century records show that, during just three years, some 400,000 souls suffered, in Portuguese boats, the "Middle Crossing" from West Africa to Brazil. In 1775, Lisbon was destroyed by tidal waves and an earthquake which continued for days. Experts calculate that another earthquake is overdue.

Nevertheless, nostalgia is the wrong word. Vienna is, par excellence, the city of a nostalgia for past glory. And its nostalgia is suffocating. Lisbon is buffeted by too many winds.

On a traffic island near the Garden of The Martyrs we each place a lit candle in a makeshift metal tent, the size of a baby's pram, where 100 or more other candles touch each other as they flicker and burn, protected as they are from the wind. A city as tilted and open towards an ocean as this one cannot be nostalgic. Lisbon is, however, the most westerly city of the continent, and so the nearest to the sunset.

The western Atlantic coasts of Europe, from the highlands in Scotland, passing by Donegal in Ireland, Land's End in England, Brittany in France, Galicia in Spain, all speak of and evoke dreams about a departure westwards and about the millions who departed - of whom the sunset is a reminder every evening of the departed, who were lost at sea, or who discovered new continents of experience.

Remembering the past in the present tense, yes; nostalgia, no. This is a fine distinction, yet in portraits, fine distinctions are crucial. Of course, there's no tilted city to be seen in the painting. There are simply 58 people standing in a kind of Flemish painted portrait-box. (Van Eyck, who influenced Goncalves, visited Lisbon in the 1420s). The martyr St Vincent, who is in the foreground, is represented twice. A few of those who are honouring him have been identified: the King Alfonso V, his uncle Henry the Navigator, who set up a school for mariners and invented a compass, the archbishop. The others - fishermen with their nets, monks, a doctor, an architect, a Jew, a scribe, the ambitious and the modest of every kind, all 50 of them have become anonymous. Each face is highly individual, yet they share something. And what the 50 faces have in common, what perhaps makes them a single city, is a certain stance towards life. How to get close to examine that stance?

We are in one of the famous yellow trams - they are as famous as San Francisco's cable cars, for they have been much filmed during recent years. Maybe with A Streetcar Named Desire, they are the only other trams which have become stars.

The drivers drive like sailors, as if all the while they were hauling ropes and tying knots rather than operating wheels and levers. Behind the driver, the passengers sit or stand - many of them are women (unfortunately, there are no ordinary women in the painting) with a familial calm, as if they were each sitting at home or standing on their own landing.

Herculano, young and from the country, is standing beside the driver; he works on a cork plantation undressing the trunks of oak trees; already he accepts what he's going to get in life. So much and no more. In the painting he's in the top row, third from the right.

This tram is a room running on rails between other rooms. It climbs, shudders, turns on a staircase, goes downstairs, makes a noise like a knife being sharpened in the kitchen, waits, starts again, passing between shops, doorways, bedrooms, living rooms with TVs, birdcages, a dog with his paws on the windowsill, closets which have been locked for years with the key lost, and all the while, as it lurches on its journey, it almost touches the first-storey open windows or the street doors - leaving in the street only enough space for those who know how to flatten themselves suddenly against a wall. Could it be that this capacity of flattening oneself, even when fat, has something to do with the stance we are trying to get close to? Portugal, too, is a narrow country flattened between the mass of Europe and the ocean.

We return to the painting and its unusual perspective. It plays like the city does, the city with its seven steep hills, its three funiculars, its steps, its little cast iron tower of Santa Justa, owned by the tramway company, where the lift just takes people up and down: it plays with eye levels. In the foreground, you look steeply down on the painted parquet floor on which 10 figures are kneeling. And when you look at all the citizens standing in the two back rows with their faces just as large as those in the foreground, you are looking up at them from way below. What is unusual is that, although these citizens are purported to be standing further away on the same floor as the chief protagonists, they seem to be standing, flattened against a wall, on a balcony which protrudes forwards.

They are, as it were, upstairs overlooking everything which is not in the picture, and no two are looking in the same direction. Standing on their narrow ledge of Portugal and, taking one thing at a time, they appear to be contemplating everything without a trace of rhetoric or exaggeration.

In a poem about his own life, seen after his own death, Fernando Pessoa wrote:

I understood that things are real and all
different from each other;
I understood it with the eyes, never with thinking.

In the Baixa district, where Pessoa worked in a bank, a long-distance race is taking place. The circuit goes repeatedly around several blocks of smart shops, banks, travel agencies. The trams and traffic have to wait or stop. Nobody shows the slightest impatience. One thing at a time on this Sunday morning.

There are several hundred runners, including a few women. Many of the men are over 50. They run well, steadily, encouraging one another, their long strides beating out a rhythm on the cobbles between the tramlines on the streets.

No bravura. No overt competitiveness. It is already for all the runners a victory rather than a race. We notice a face stretched by effort into a kind of smile which acknowledges his own name, Costa, and everything that has and is happening to Costa! Then we see a similar smile on the faces of Madalena, Joachim, Luiz.

This is not a city which fucks itself up. No, it's a city that waits, knowing that the brief moment to fuck will come.

A young man in the fifth panel - he may be the Marquis of Montenor - is probably thinking about death.

We take a tram to the Cemetery of Pleasures. The sign indicating the tram's destination is simply Prazeres (Pleasures). Like almost every site in Lisbon, the cemetery is on a hill. The graveyard streets are lined with tall cypresses. The tombs, called jazigos (lying-in places) are little stone residences. A typical jazigo has a metal door with two windows and lace curtains inside. We peer through the lace and see on either side of the door three tiers for coffins with counterpanes, rugs, photos, pillows, flowers, a Madonna, a teddy bear, a toy tram. In one there may have been an empty birdcage. What we cannot see is whether the doors have handles on the inside.

The man in the office by the cemetery gate has the face of a sailor. Come to think of it, the jazigos are the size of small ship's cabins. In response to a visitor's question he is bent over a map. Like many calm people, he has a strong neck. We recognise him: second row from the top in the second panel - a fisherman at that time.

Now we are in the Praça da Allegria, the Square of Joy. A small public garden with elms, palms and jacaranda trees. On the grass chickens peck for worms. There is a flowery plaque celebrating Alfredo Keill, who wrote the Portuguese national anthem. An old woman with an umbrella is sitting very still on a park bench. We think she's watching one of the chickens. Then she gets to her feet, turns, and walks, using her umbrella as a stick, towards us. As she walks she laughs. She stops in front of us, still smiling.

There's something you shouldn't forget, she says, in fact you should know it, and it's this: the dead don't stay where they are buried.

We nod.

I have to go now to watch the sunset, like I do every evening, she adds.

We follow her at a distance up the hill.

Lisbon is a city which forgives many of life's cruelties.

Remembering the past, it perhaps displays a certain indulgence. Remembering it for a second time, it regains control of itself. Remembering the past for a third time, it waits to see what is going to happen next.

webTitle: Dulcie Domum: Why can't all men be like this?

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Why can't all men be like this?
fields.standfirst: 'Wow! Use of word  poignant  in opening remark.'
fields.trailText: 'Wow! Use of word  poignant  in opening remark.'
fields.body:
Whole family invited to gay barbecue by Jonathan and Roy, who bought my country cottage. Great Aunt Elspeth and Harriet both up for it, but ex-Spouse declares wild horses will not drag him there. He can't face any jokes about bangers, and assumes he will be the object of sexual harassment. Inform him that no gay man in his right mind would give him a second look, and that his only hope of harassment now is from large, lonely, desperate reptiles.

He changes his mind when he realises it might mean a decent supper for once, and when we are welcomed with kisses all round, he even acquiesces in a token embrace - closing his eyes and thinking of char-grilled tuna.

"I love gay men!" whispers Harriet. "If I was a man I'd be gay! I think I'm gay, anyway - although I do fancy Jamie on EastEnders." My recollection of Jamie on EastEnders is of a youth so slender and girlish that Shakespeare's company would have snapped him up for Rosalind.

"We hired the tents, Dulcie!" Jonathan gazes proudly around the garden. They have turned my wilderness into a twinkling paradise, complete with eastern awnings, tassels and little flags. "Very Agincourt," I smile. "Perfect example of English Camp," remarks ex-Spouse. Jonathan looks pleased, and goes off ranting, "And Gentlemen of England now a-bed." Fairy lights are strung from the trees, but forbid ex-Spouse to make any flippant references to them.

Aunt Elspeth is considerately offered a seat next to the Chiminea, where she gossips with a benign old gentleman with long hair and earrings. He turns out to be Jonathan's dad, and shares Elspeth's passion for Rhum and Eigg. (The islands, not the beverage.) Harriet dances on what used to be my patio, but is now a tropical deck, with two men whose hair is wreathed with vine-leaves. Ex-Spouse hovers next to the barbecue and tries to look saturnine and distinguished. Despite all that fuss about coming, I can see he secretly wants them all to fancy him just the same. The sad thing is that I think only his aunt fancies him, these days.

"Are you Dulcie?" Turn to see extraordinarily handsome man - a sort of healthy version of Chopin - behind whose left shoulder the moon is rising portentously. "This used to be your cottage, didn't it? Isn't it a bit poignant coming back like this?" Wow! Sensitivity to my feelings, use of the word poignant in opening remark - why can't all men be like this? Assure him that cottage is so far removed from the dismal hovel it was in my time, that it is now so chic, so sparkling, so adored, that I feel it has, in some sense, come out.

A gay man will install an atrium, plant a parterre, do a deck with bamboo and hammocks, and envisage an orchard with medieval jousting tents in the time it takes an average husband to be asked 299 times to put up a shelf - about 18 months. Chopin gallantly assures me there is something to be said also for dismal hovels, indeed, as a landscape painter he prefers neglect and ruin.

A landscape painter! Not a product manager, not a corporate IT strategist, but a landscape painter. Immensely reassured by the thought that though I have lost my youthful beauty, I can still offer a pleasing prospect as a neglected and ruined landscape. We talk of holidays. Fred (Chopin's real name - spooky or what?) confesses he is destined for Barcelona. Reveal that I was hoping to expose my daughter to Italy, but that I am too broke.

"Oh!" cries Fred, "but I have a house near Sanfatucchio - you can stay there for as long as you like." For the rest of the evening I am inwardly humming "last train to Sanfatucchio".

On the way home, reveal I have accepted Umbrian hospitality for the last week of the hols. Aunt Elspeth is celebrating an invitation from Jonathan's dad to play bridge, and Harriet has decided to marry a gay man and have children by IVF.

"And what," I enquire of the silent Ex, "Did you come away with?"

"Irritable bowel syndrome, if you really must know," he growls. "Sodding evil draught up my arse all evening." Console him with the thought that it could have been a lot worse.

Fred (Chopin's real name - spooky or what?) confesses he is destined for Barcelona. Reveal that I was hoping to expose my daughter to Italy, but that I am too broke. "Oh!" cries Fred, "but I have a house near Sanfatucchio - you can stay there for as long as you like." For the rest of the evening I am inwardly humming "last train to Sanfatucchio". On the way home, reveal I have accepted Umbrian hospitality for the last week of the hols. Aunt Elspeth is celebrating an invitation from Jonathan's dad to play bridge, and Harriet has decided to marry a gay man and have children by IVF. "And what," I enquire of the silent Ex, "Did you come away with?" "Irritable bowel syndrome, if you really must know," he growls. "Sodding evil draught up my arse all evening." Console him with the thought that it could have been a lot worse.

fields.headline: Over 60
fields.standfirst: Instead of exploiting the yearning of 60-year-olds to be thought self-sufficient, the Government urges them to think of themselves as helpless
fields.trailText: Instead of exploiting the yearning of 60-year-olds to be thought self-sufficient, the Government urges them to think of themselves as helpless
fields.body:
When I reached the age of 60 at the beginning of the year, I didn't feel that this was a great event. Insofar as the passing of the decades has made any impression on me at all, I think that the most unsettling moment was when I turned 30. It meant that my youth had gone forever and that I couldn't pretend otherwise. Turning 40 obviously meant that I could no longer deny middle age, but I wasn't trying to deny it, anyway, so that didn't bother me. And as people live longer and longer (eg, the Queen Mother who, as you may have heard, was 100 years old yesterday), middle age has expanded to occupy a huge chunk of one's life.

So I turned 50 and then 60 without thinking there had been any change in my enduring status as a middle-aged man. It did not occur to me that I might have become old, and although I am now possibly less agile and more forgetful than I used to be, and although my hair is practically white and my digestive system less efficient, the thought still does not occur to me. Or at least it would not occur to me if the Government were not so determined to convince me that I have in fact passed through some age barrier from which there is no turning back.

Since becoming 60, although I now work harder and earn more money than I have ever done before, I have already been offered cheap rail travel and cheap winter fuel in recognition of my age and frailty. Worse than that, when I got to the front of a queue to buy an entrance ticket to the Natural History Museum the other day, I was waved away on the grounds that I looked too old to have to pay for one. That was hurtful, but it also made me wonder why the Natural History Museum felt it shouldn't ask people over 60 to buy a ticket even though it clearly needs their money.

The nation is supposedly facing a crisis caused by an impending glut of old people. There will be too few people in work to pay for the welfare of those in retirement, it is claimed. Radical action is required to deal with this impending disaster. Yet the Government, instead of exploiting the yearning of 60-year-olds to be thought of as vigorous and self-sufficient by telling them to brace up and get on their bikes, urges them to think of themselves as old and helpless and in need of financial support. This is complete madness on the Government's part.

The crisis has been exacerbated by the ageism that has taken root in our society over the past few decades. Most companies and public bodies now insist that employees should retire at 65, if not earlier, however well they are doing their jobs. Even the Pope, who is allowed to carry on until he dies, demands that his bishops offer him their resignations when they are 75. Why should it matter how old a bishop is? The older, the better, I would have thought.

As a freelance journalist, I have a very inadequate pension provision, and this has begun to worry me. Last week I went to my bank to consult a pensions expert about this. Was there still anything I could do to avoid destitution in my old age? In response, she kept asking me a disconcerting and unanswerable question: "When do you want to retire?" I could reply only that I had no idea. I suppose I will go on writing for newspapers as long as I feel able to do so, and as long as there remains a newspaper that is prepared to print what I write. I will also presumably write less, and therefore earn less, as I get older and lazier. Like the Queen Mother, I will probably cut down my commitments a bit when I get to 100, but, like her, too, I don't suppose I will exactly retire.

All this brings me to Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester. At the age of 98, she has just become the first member of the Royal Family in this nation's history formally to retire. The announcement was made this week by her son, the Duke of Gloucester, who offered good reasons for her decision.

She had, he said, "become increasingly forgetful, which greatly reduces her ability to communicate in the way she would wish", he said. "For this reason, my mother no longer feels confident in carrying out official engagements away from Kensington Palace or in coping with the clamour of social gatherings." In practice, this will not make a great difference to anything. Princess Alice's last official engagement outside her home was a visit in 1995 to the Ladies' Guild of the St John Ophthalmic Hospital. But she has set a disturbing precedent.

fields.headline: Spadework
fields.trailText: Plant of the week
fields.body:
Plant of the week

Lilium candidum (the Madonna lily) is a classic white lily with a heavenly scent. Like most other lilies, it likes partial shade and a deep root run in humus-rich soil; this one is prolific, producing between five to 20 blooms per plant in early to mid-summer.

Now to late summer is the time to plant the bulbs, so they have a chance to grow a first rosette of leaves and a root system before winter sets in. Readers can order three bulbs for £8.99 (inc UK p&p), or buy six and get three more free for £17.99. Call 0870 8701361 for delivery in September.

Time to...

Lift and store tulip and hyacinth bulbs, chucking out any that look diseased or damaged, and hang them where mice can't reach. An airy, dry place is preferable, as damp tends to start bulbs into life again.

My regeneration
There's still a chance to catch the pilot Edinburgh Temporary Garden festival, which runs until Monday. Three under-used sites in the city - among them the forecourt of the social-work department and the secret garden at the Royal Botanic Gardens - have been transformed by artists Adrian Wiszniewski, Lumir Soukup and Les Arts'griculteurs. For details, visit www.johnrogan.freeuk.com (or contact lumirsoukup@hotmail.com ).

Hoe down
This onion hoe, with a graduated 12cm blade, is good for weeding close to plants. It costs £17.85 via the Organic Gardening Catalogue - call 01932 253666, or mail to chaseorg@aol.com; a handle (not included in price) can be attached if you wish.

fields.headline: How to navigate
fields.trailText: During the second world war, all road signs were removed to confuse German invaders. In fact, half those missing in action in the war were people who had trouble getting home and had to pretend they'd always intended to re-settle in Swindon.
fields.body:
During the second world war, all road signs were removed to confuse German invaders. In fact, half those missing in action in the war were people who had trouble getting home and had to pretend they'd always intended to re-settle in Swindon.

Navigation is not easy, even with road signs. Many marriages falter shortly after someone says, "I'll drive, you navigate'. Men believe that all women lack the essential DNA for navigation. They've watched their partners veer aimlessly all over shopping centres with no clear sense of purpose or direction, and they fear that this will be the same on major roads.

Most people have a big road atlas in the car. The reason they are so big and floppy is in the interests of safety; when a man says to a woman, "The blue one's a motorway not a river", he is a split-second away from getting a 1998 Motorists' Atlas full in the face.

You can tell a good navigator by their anticipation. Ideally, you'll get, "In half a mile, take the turning on your left marked A420". Any instruction that starts with "We should have..." is not good. If you're married to this kind of navigator, it's wise not to let them near Ordnance Survey maps unless you enjoy a nice country walk trying to follow the "path" of a line of pylons.

Inevitably, on a long journey in unfamiliar territory, a wrong turn will be made. If a woman takes a wrong turn, this is because she has the direction-finding capacity of an old shopping trolley. If a man takes a wrong turning, it's because it's an ingenious short-cut. It may be a special kind of short-cut that seems to be longer than a long-cut, but this shouldn't be mentioned until you both have grandchildren and life has lost some of its intensity.

Women have advanced psychological weapons for use with navigation. For example, if they take a wrong turn, it is actually the man's fault, because he passed up the opportunity for correcting her at the appropriate moment. When men get their directional knickers twisted, they often drop into the silent rally-driver-from-hell mode, where they think that they will be able to make up for a colossal map-reading error by driving like a loony for half-an-hour.

One useful tip in navigation is that there are no sets of identical villages in this country. When you've just gone through the same village twice, it means that she took the wrong turning, his short-cut was a circle and someone is in line for the 1998 Motorists' Atlas treatment.

fields.headline: The Questionnaire...Julia Morris
fields.standfirst: Julia Morris was born in Sydney, Australia, in 1968, and began her career as a stand-up comic. She spent seven years working in Australian television, but her show at last year's Melbourne International Comedy Festival was such a success that she took it to the Edinburgh Fringe. She is performing at Edinburgh again this year, and features in the Channel 4 documentary series about the festival, Edinburgh Or Bust! She lives in London.
fields.trailText: Julia Morris was born in Sydney, Australia, in 1968, and began her career as a stand-up comic.
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?

To be the kind of 50s housewife depicted in early sitcoms.

What is your greatest fear?

That Prince Charles will fall in love with me.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

I talk too much, too fast - every man's nightmare.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?

Chauvinism.

What is your greatest extravagance?

Sale time: I feel like I'm losing money if I don't spend!

What makes you depressed?

Spending all my money.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

My hooters could be bigger.

What is your most unappealing habit?

Phoning boys.

What is your favourite book?

A boyfriend's bank book.

What is your favourite fantasy?

Turquoise water, sun shining and snogging handsome blokes.

Do you believe in monogamy?

I wish boys did.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?

Lionel Ritchie, when I was nine.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?

It's not that I didn't mean it. Well . . .

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

'Looks like that ceiling could do with another coat.'

What is your greatest regret?

Not auditioning for the Spice Girls.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?

The quality of my single life.

What would your motto be?

Always acknowledge, never approach.

What keeps you awake at night?

Excellent television - so I sleep well.

How would you like to die?

Young enough to know what's going on but old enough to know time's up!

Do you believe in life after death?

Yes, I like white clothes.

How would you like to be remembered?

Fondly and often.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

Hear everything, reveal nothing.

webTitle: The knowledge: Bone up on lamb chops

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Bone up on lamb chops
fields.trailText:
The subject

Any cut of lamb that is thin and tender enough to be cooked in a frying pan or grill, or, at this time of year - slaver slaver slaver - over open coals. If you eat meat, chances are you love lamb chops.
fields.body:
The subject

Any cut of lamb that is thin and tender enough to be cooked in a frying pan or grill, or, at this time of year - slaver slaver slaver - over open coals. If you eat meat, chances are you love lamb chops.

The basics

Take a side of lamb and count down from the neck end. You soon come to the six to eight cutlets: bingo! Next door, six to eight loin chops: bingo again! Moving right along to the chump, which is really part of the leg, but is often butchered as a trio or quartet of chops: final bingo! The Knowledge awards a demi-bingo to the shoulder, which can be cut into chops of irregular appearance but outstanding flavour, and zero-bingo to the leg. If you are ever offered leg 'chops', spurn them - they do not cook well.

The details

Chops on parade: cutlets - generally thin, with a long rib bone (little meat but tremendous gnawing potential) and a small nugget of devastatingly succulent 'eye' meat. Chops on parade: loin chops - eye meat larger, rib replaced by 'tail' or 'flap ', the curlicue of meat/connective tissue/fat running from loin to breast. Don't accept more than two inches of tail meat; why pay top price for marginal pleasure?

Chops on parade: chumps - the odd man out; if not kept with the leg (which fetches top prices), they're usually cut on the thick side with a small section of bone, and premium flavour. NB All these items can be cooked as 'double chops' (tricky), all can be used as a roasting joint (easy), but all are at their best on the barbie - high heat, short cooking time. Aim for well-browned outside, medium-rare inside. A minute's rest after cooking will do them good.

Where to buy

Ordinary supermarket lamb tends to be better than supermarket beef or pork, but a good butcher is really your lamb- chop man of the hour.

The easy way out

This is it.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: White wine
fields.body:
White wine, a passionate wine lover once remarked to me, can aspire only to the level of Gilbert & Sullivan, and lacks the complexity and ambition of red, which can be Wagnerian, he argued. I continued to sip the decent drop of stuff that he was generously providing, a Barolo, but when the bottle was exhausted I ventured the view that I infinitely preferred sitting through The Pirates Of Penzance to enduring Parsifal and he looked disgusted. He didn't open a second bottle.

It is true, of course, that red wine is deeper and richer than white, since it uses the skins of the grapes for colour and chemical extraction (most important, the tannins), whereas white only flirts with the skins. But, in spite of this, I still regard riesling as great a grape as any red, apart from syrah and nebbiolo. Chardonnay, too, can achieve startling levels of dramatic intrigue, in the form it sometimes achieves in California, Australia, Chile and, uniquely (but rarely), in Burgundy.

All this is by way of introducing this week's column, which is exclusively white. Let us open with Argento Chardonnay 1999, from Argentina. It packs in melons, ripe pineapples, pears, raisins and delicate acids to great effect. Fine, frolicsome, cheap and so cheerfully complex that you smile as you sip - and it is a sipping wine, such is its provocative, if soft, style. You can find it at Tesco, though not all branches (call 0800 505555 for details), it costs £4.99 and rates 17 points out of 20.

At Bottoms Up and Wine Rack, there are a pair of exquisite 17-point New Zealanders. Te Mata Estate Chardonnay 1999 (£8.49) has the old-fashioned vegetality of the Montrachet variety and the limpid acids of the Kiwi kind. The marriage is superb: angular, classy, finely wrought and outstandingly, compactly balanced. Church Road Reserve Chardonnay 1998 (£11.99) delivers extreme elegance and controlled fruitiness, which impact on the tastebuds subtly yet thrillingly, then the marvellous texture becomes apparent, then the rich, dramatic finish.

Thresher and Victoria Wine also boast two 17-point Kiwis. Montana Reserve Chardonnay 1999 (£7.99) is intense yet sublime, offering creamily rich fruit that manages to come across potently without being too ripe or blatant. A delicious blend of smoky melon and fine acids, it has elegance, elongation, and ease of effect. With Church Road Chardonnay 1998 (£8.99), there is an old European undertow to the fruit, fine and agricultural, but, in its overall polish and aplomb, it is on another planet from many of the three-times-more-expensive white burgundies with which we might odorously compare it.

Thresher and Victoria Wine (along with Majestic and certain Safeway branches - 01622 712926 for details) also have two further NZ wines, both rating 16.5 points. 'In the Black' Chardonnay 1998 (£5.99) presents a wonderful clash of baked melon/pineapple with fresh lemon acids. Oyster Bay Chardonnay 1999 (£6.99) is sleekly fruity, with an almost lazy manner to it, exposing layers of supple fruit and crisp acids.

Last at Thresher and Victoria Wine, a superb Soave: Zenato Soave Classico 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99) is possibly the classiest specimen of its kind - rich, controlled, stylishly acidic, beautifully textured, very finely wrought, and remarkably stylish and subtle.

At Unwins, there is a quartet of attractive whites, two from Australia, two from Chile. The latter are Valdivieso Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99) and Concha y Toro Gewürztraminer 1999 (16 points, £4.49). The chardonnay parades gorgeously chewable fruit, all vegetal and ripe but bold and polished on the finish.

The gewürz has the clichéd spicy richness and rosy-edged fruit, but also something extra, more exotic and slightly rogueish on the finish. This is a terrific wine for oriental nosh. The Aussies are Woodvale Semillon/ Chardonnay 1999 (15 points, £3.99), which is a bargain bowl of understated, never OTT, fruit; and Grant Burge Late Harvest Muscat 1997 (16 points, £4.99), which is menthol-undertoned, pineappley, very rich and half-sweet. It makes a wholly different aperitif, and works with rich Chinese food such as duck pancakes with plum sauce.

The marriage is superb: angular, classy, finely wrought and outstandingly, compactly balanced. Church Road Reserve Chardonnay 1998 (£11.99) delivers extreme elegance and controlled fruitiness, which impact on the tastebuds subtly yet thrillingly, then the marvellous texture becomes apparent, then the rich, dramatic finish. Thresher and Victoria Wine also boast two 17-point Kiwis. Montana Reserve Chardonnay 1999 (£7.99) is intense yet sublime, offering creamily rich fruit that manages to come across potently without being too ripe or blatant. A delicious blend of smoky melon and fine acids, it has elegance, elongation, and ease of effect. With Church Road Chardonnay 1998 (£8.99), there is an old European undertow to the fruit, fine and agricultural, but, in its overall polish and aplomb, it is on another planet from many of the three-times-more-expensive white burgundies with which we might odorously compare it. Thresher and Victoria Wine (along with Majestic and certain Safeway branches - 01622 712926 for details) also have two further NZ wines, both rating 16.5 points. 'In the Black' Chardonnay 1998 (£5.99) presents a wonderful clash of baked melon/pineapple with fresh lemon acids. Oyster Bay Chardonnay 1999 (£6.99) is sleekly fruity, with an almost lazy manner to it, exposing layers of supple fruit and crisp acids. Last at Thresher and Victoria Wine, a superb Soave: Zenato Soave Classico 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99) is possibly the classiest specimen of its kind - rich, controlled, stylishly acidic, beautifully textured, very finely wrought, and remarkably stylish and subtle. At Unwins, there is a quartet of attractive whites, two from Australia, two from Chile. The latter are Valdivieso Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99) and Concha y Toro Gewürztraminer 1999 (16 points, £4.49). The chardonnay parades gorgeously chewable fruit, all vegetal and ripe but bold and polished on the finish. The gewürz has the clichéd spicy richness and rosy-edged fruit, but also something extra, more exotic and slightly rogueish on the finish. This is a terrific wine for oriental nosh. The Aussies are Woodvale Semillon/ Chardonnay 1999 (15 points, £3.99), which is a bargain bowl of understated, never OTT, fruit; and Grant Burge Late Harvest Muscat 1997 (16 points, £4.99), which is menthol-undertoned, pineappley, very rich and half-sweet. It makes a wholly different aperitif, and works with rich Chinese food such as duck pancakes with plum sauce.

fields.headline: Make mine a...
fields.standfirst: Pisco
fields.trailText: Pisco
fields.body:
Pisco is a strong south American brandy found in Chile and Peru. On its own, it tastes a bit oily, but mix it with fresh lime juice and sugar syrup (2 1/2 shots of Pisco, 1 shot of lime, 1/2 shot of sugar syrup, plus a dash of egg white) to make a Pisco Sour, and it is truly magic. (Actually, what the Chileans use, you might like to drop into the conversation, is a small green lemon, but limes are our nearest equivalent.)

Most of the Pisco that reaches these shores is Chilean, and comes from a designated Pisco 'zone' on the edge of the Atacama desert. So who drinks it (apart from elderly dictators)? Well, it is extremely popular with Chilean wine-makers, who quaff it at the end of a long, hard day pumping out the merlot, but has yet to take off over here, possibly because of the success of caipirinha, that other South American cocktail based on strong liqueur and lime juice. But give it a try. It's easier to pronounce and equally delicious. (Oddbins sells Capel Pisco from £9.99.)

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: 'Tanya, how could you! You promised your readers... Your family name...' My mother amazed me. 'You're a funny one to talk! Have you forgotten your own episodes with the financial advisor, the salmon poacher or the medium, let alone all the others?' I shrieked back.
fields.body:
'Tanya, how could you! You promised your readers... Your family name...' My mother amazed me. 'You're a funny one to talk! Have you forgotten your own episodes with the financial advisor, the salmon poacher or the medium, let alone all the others?' I shrieked back.

'I was abandoned by your errant father. Ever since, I've tried to find a haven in the storm. But you must maintain a line of conduct according to your rank,' Mum said haughtily, in her best Lady Of The Bedchamber manner.

'Your father may have run away with a hussy who sold patchwork Levi's (circa 1975) at Jean Machine, but your bloodline is magnificent.'

Could it be that my mother, a Daily Mail reader, is being swept away by the tidal wave of Royal Centenary euphoria? She made an operatic grand exit before I could ask for an explanation, so I checked www.genealogy.com. I was amazed to discover that I'm directly descended from William Mallbank (Millbank), baron of Nantwich in Cheshire, who also acquired lands in Lancashire and Dorset.

Although the connection might well be disputed, the site maintains that I am linked to the Seigneur de Brecey, a munificent benefactor of the Abbey of Longues.

My God! The Millbanks may have helped conquer England in 1066, and yet I have a much more powerful personal connection with the Queen Mother (www.royal.gov.uk/family/mother): she devoted her life to a stammering, diffident, trauma-ridden husband; I still have a soft spot for Migraine Alan.

www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk

webTitle: How best to bless a new house?

fields.headline: This blessed plot
fields.standfirst: A visit from a priest, offerings to the gods, or scripture pinned to the doorway: how best to bless a new house?
fields.trailText: A visit from a priest, offerings to the gods, or scripture pinned to the doorway: how best to bless a new house?
fields.body:
It takes more than a house-warming to make a place truly your own. Some settle for just moving in their belongings or the most cursory lick of paint. Others go for the full redecoration, with maybe a wall knocked down for good measure. But for many a formal blessing is the only way to round off the whole stressful process of moving home - after all, there is no way of telling what bad omens, spirits or karma have been left behind.

"The place I lived in before used to have this really bad energy in my bedroom," says Khushbir Sekhon, 33, director of the Asian Fostering Bureau. "I used to have a recurring feeling just as I was falling asleep that there was someone in the room, and sometimes I would feel them on top of me and I'd have trouble breathing. It was a really horrible presence. When I moved, I felt that I took that energy with me to the next flat."

So, when Khushbir bought her first two-bedroom house four years ago, in Stratford, east London, she "was keen to have it cleansed of any negative energy".

Khushbir, who is a Sikh, claims not to be religious, more "spiritual". She was keen in this instance to seek advice from an older Hindu for an appropriate ceremony, and so she turned to her friend, Neeta. Neeta consulted her mother, who referred to a religious calendar and thereby determined an appropriate date for the ceremony that had the correct planetary influences. "It's really important for me to have some guidance from elders - otherwise all these customs and rituals would be gone," says Khushbir.

However, the set date and time fell months before Khushbir's was due to move in, when the previous residents, a white couple with a dog, were still living there. "So I rang them up and said that I needed to come round at this time and explained that this is what we do to bless a house before we move into it," she says. "I think they found it a bit bizarre - they weren't quite sure what we were doing - but they allowed us to do it."

To ensure that the house would be prosperous, Khushbir and Neeta made offerings to the gods of fresh coconut, mung daal, rice, fruit, betel nut and a brass pot of water. They burned incense sticks and said a prayer both to Sikh Guru Nanak and the Hindu god Ganesh.

Neeta's nine-year-old daughter, Puravi, conducted the ceremony, because children are regarded as both innocent and auspicious. Fruit and Indian sweets were shared with the previous residents, and the remaining offerings were left as permanent features in the house.

Ideally, these should have been situated by the kitchen sink, the part of the house that faces sunrise in the east... but: "We placed the tray by the front window, " admits Khushbir. "It was the most appropriate place we could find in the circumstances, and our primary concern was that the dog couldn't get to it. Later, you're supposed to move [the offerings] up into the attic, but I can't get to mine, so I place the tray on top of my cupboard."

As a precautionary measure, to ward off any undesirable intentions or karma that may be brought to the house by visitors, fresh chillies and limes are threaded together and hung on the front doorway. Statues of Hindu gods live both in the kitchen and the bedroom. "I don't believe in coincidences," says Khushbir, "but I've never had that nightmare in this house."

While Khushbir's ceremony was a one-off, a blessing - or Ayiasmo - is a regular affair for Greek Orthodox care worker, Elena Sideri-Costa. "I first got the house blessed a week after I moved in," says Elena, 49, who lives in Palmers Green, north London. "I invited the local priest, family and friends," she says. "The priest bought an icon, and we lit candles and burnt frankincense. We prayed together for about 20 minutes and then the priest sprinkled holy water with basil leaves around the house - the purpose being that, if there are any bad omens or any kind of evil, it will go away. It's a new start, a new life, a clean start in a new house.

"It's not just a blessing for when you buy a house - sometimes people do it every year, or if there has been any bad fortune in their lives. If ever I feel a bit down, I will call my local priest and get an Ayiasmo performed. So far, I have had it done every couple of years."

Ayiasmos are followed by a celebration. Dancing is a must. "After your house has been full of family and friends of all ages all having a wonderful time, the house feels lighter and better," says Elena. That is what I like most about them: it is a way of getting a whole community together."

Throughout her house, there is an abundance of silver- and gold-plated religious icons. The front living room is a haven in which a corner is devoted to prayer and ritual. One entire corner of the room is filled with pictures of Saint Constantine, Mary, Jesus and Saint Helena that have been passed down through the family.

As she prays, Elena regularly burns frankincense, and olive leaves and oil. "We believe that the olive tree is holy, because Jesus used to rest under them. We believe that with the rising smoke our prayers reach the heavens."

While Elena displays icons and religious pictures around her home, Flora Michael, 98, who lives in a Jewish Care residential home, keeps a Mezuzah on her bedroom door. This is a piece of parchment with Hebrew passages from Deuteronomy written on it, and should be put up by a boy over the age of 13 (regarded as an adult) or a rabbi within 30 days of moving into a house. A prayer of consecration is usually said at the same time.

The verses in the Mezuzah consist of the first two paragraphs of the Shema, a central prayer of Judaism that requires all Jews to practise its laws. Jewish homes are required to adorn doorways (except those of the toilet and bathrooms) with them.

Since it has become impractical to have parchment alone hanging from doors, small boxes made from metal, wood or even glass are now used to protect them. For Flora, who lives in Friern Barnet, north London, the Mezuzah is a form of identification as well as a reminder of her Jewishness. "They are on every Jewish bedroom door here. They're expensive but beautiful; the very religious men kiss them."

Mezuzahs are regularly checked by a Jewish official, known as a Kashrut, who examines them to see if the Hebrew print quality and passages are correct.

Many elderly of the faith go to live with Jewish Care because they are unable to perform the rites and rituals that they would like to within their own homes. Many of these take place beneath the dazzling, blue stained-glass windows of the synagogue on the ground floor, or in the communal areas - where volunteers help the frail to light candles just before sunset on Friday, bringing in the sabbath.

"We light two candles on a table and we have wine to make a kiddush, a sweet kosher wine," says Flora. Food is prepared before the sabbath - kitchens are separated in colour codes of blue and red, to keep milk and meat apart as Jewish law prescribes - so that the whole day can be spent doing simple things such as eating, singing, praying, studying or just talking. A home from home

fields.headline: Ice and easy does it
fields.standfirst: Sorbets are not for refreshing the tastebuds, but are genuine flavour sensations in their own right
fields.trailText: Sorbets are not for refreshing the tastebuds, but are genuine flavour sensations in their own right
fields.body:
It was a perfect pudding, without unholy embellishment of any kind: a small cloud of pavlova with three spoonfuls of intensely-flavoured sorbets - raspberry, blackcurrant and redcurrant - each finished with a flick of barely whipped cream. The sorbets were of a perfect consistency, having that slight density they get an hour or so after churning that adds substance to the clear, penetrating flavour of the fruit. The pavlova was crisp without, like the crust on a fall of snow, giving way to a soft and yielding froth below. The comma of cream provided a gentle foil. It was simple, beautiful, magical.

That elegant construct of a pudding - half Phillip Johnson, half Philippe Starck - at Campanile, the hot-shot restaurant on La Brea, Los Angeles, was an epiphany in my experience of ices, a landmark in the memory bank, and one to set beside the soothing balm of the fig, peach and almond combo in Florence that I wrote about last week.

In this day of the super-rich, artery-clogging, commercial ice cream, the lighter, subtler, more intense pleasures of the sorbet tend to get passed over, yet their history is longer and, if anything, richer than that of its cream and egg yolk brother. Tradition has it that the Chinese and Arabs started it all off when they used snow to chill fruit juices, and for once there might be some substance to tradition. According to students of ice history, the first mention of what is known as endothermic effect, using saltpetre and cold water to make ice, comes in the Kitab Uyan al-Anba fi Tabaqat al-Atibba, by Ibn Abu Usaybi, an Arab medical historian in the 13th century.

There are serious technical differences between sherbet, deriving from the Arabic sharbat - "syrups, pastes, powders, lemonades and other fruit juices, sweetened and diluted with water in the Turkish fashion, and regarded primarily as healthful, sustaining, restorative beverages", as the peerless Elizabeth David puts it, which were sometimes mixed with snow or ice - and sorbet, which derives from the Italian sorbire, meaning "to sip". When sorbet became the frozen ice that we know and love today, however, is a bit confused, to say the least.

There has been a long-standing connection based on trade and conquest (not necessarily in that order) between Sicily and North Africa, and between North Africa, Sicily and southern Italy, and it seems likely that this is how knowledge of these most desirable summer coolers percolated ever northwards. There are establishments in Messina, Palermo and various other Sicilian towns that specialise in one of the three great branches of ice science to this day.

Although water ices - aka eaux glacés, eaux d'Italie or acque gelate - were known and appreciated in Paris, Naples, Florence and Spain in the 1660s, it was only when a Sicilian, Francisco Procopio, opened the Cafe Procope in Paris to sell sorbets and sherbets in or around 1690 that they really took off. So successful was it that within 60 years there were 250 other such establishments plying for trade. Iced creams didn't get much of a look in until a bit later.

However, we will not concern ourselves with sherbets and historical debate here, but stick to the glory of the sorbet, which has the great advantage - for the restaurant chef and the happy home cook alike - of being simple and inexpensive to make. Using fruits in season when they are cheap and plentiful justifies the expense of the machine (or sorbetière). The summer yields gluts of berries, currants and other fruits, and cordials and purées can be frozen to make sorbets aplenty with ease and speed.

There's no reason to stop in the summer, either. Sorbets made from pears or the myriad variety of plums are just as delicious, and aid the consumption of autumn game with pleasant ease. Come winter, when the citrus fruits are at their peak, clementines, oranges, limes and lemons all make sumptuous sorbets, ready to pretty a Christmas table splendidly.

So to hell with the ready-made, joyless muck that crowd the supermarket freezer cabinets and masquerade as a treat, when in truth they are full of rubbish and have barely a trace of the flavour advertised. Take a leaf from the life of Signor Procope, and make your own.

RASPBERRY SORBET
Very good with strawberries, too - and blackberries, come to that, as long as they are full and ripe, and therefore need no cooking.

700g very fresh, ripe raspberries

115g caster sugar

2 very fresh egg whites

3 dssp lemon juice

Carefully pick over the berries, then put them into a food processor and render to a purée. Pass the purée through a fine sieve and stir in the sugar, dissolving it completely. Stir in the lemon juice. In a very clean bowl, whisk the whites until they are stiff, then fold them into the raspberry mixture. Churn in a machine according to manufacturer's instructions. This sorbet is at its best eaten within a few hours of churning.

ORANGE SORBET

Needless to say, this approach may be used for all the citrus fruits, although the quantity of sugar may have to be increased or reduced depending on the acidity of the fruit. It is worth pointing out that the norm used to be to rub cubes of loaf sugar over the zest of the fruit, to absorb the flavour and oil. It is a labour of love, but the result is truly exceptional.

150g caster sugar

300 ml water

Juice of 1 lemon

Rind of 2 oranges

500ml orange juice

Put the caster sugar, pared rind and water (a still mineral water is good here) into a stainless-steel pan and bring to a boil. Boil for four to five minutes, then remove from the heat and leave to cool. When the syrup is cool, add the orange and lemon juices, pour into an ice-cream machine and churn according to manufacturer's instructions.

MELON SORBET
This is a great favourite of mine, and goes straight on to the restaurant's menu the moment the first melons of the year appear. As for the quantities listed, I would normally buy two melons and make lots.

900g ripe Charentais melon

190g caster sugar

3 tbsp lemon juice

Peel the melon carefully. Scoop out the seeds and push them through a sieve, saving any bits and juice that comes through. Cut the melon flesh into pieces, and render to a purée with the reserved seed juice, sugar and lemon juice. Push the purée through a sieve also. Churn according to manufacturer's instructions.

PERSIMMON SORBET
If persimmons are hard to get hold of, by all means use Sharon fruit instead (it's much the same thing, to tell the truth), but substitute a third of the weight with fully ripe apricots.

1 kg of persimmons

180g icing sugar

1-2 lemons

Scoop out the flesh of the fruit and whizz it in a liquidiser, along with the sugar and lemon juice (if the machine gets too full, do this in a couple of batches). Push the resulting pulp through a conical sieve, adding a spoonful or two of water if the mixture is over thick. Churn in a machine according to the instructions.

TOMATO SORBET
No, this is not a joke, but a rather nice idea from Lindsey Bareham's Big Red Tomato Book, which is just out in paperback (Penguin, £8.99).

1 kg very ripe tomatoes

15mg tomato purée

tsp salt

15g icing sugar

10 drops Tabasco

30ml vodka

1 tbsp fresh lemon juice

Chill a bowl in the freezer. Core the tomatoes, then blanch them in boiling water for 15-20 seconds. Remove from the water, peel, de-seed and chop roughly.

Liquidise the tomato flesh, then add the tomato purée, salt, sugar, Tabasco, vodka and lemon juice, and mix well (add more salt, if required). The more bold among you may wish to add a splash of Worcestershire sauce, some horseradish and a dash or two extra of vodka. Churn the sorbet mix, then transfer to the chilled bowl in the freezer

TECHNICAL TIPS
 Sorbets can be made with either fruit purée and syrup or fruit purée, syrup and raw egg white. Eggs whites are added to stabilise those sorbets that melt rather quickly, or to lighten those that tend to go rather dense because there is not enough pectin or fibre in the fruit used. If you do use egg whites, get pasteurised ones, if you can; otherwise, use only very fresh, free-range, organic eggs.

 It is worth keeping a jar or bottle of syrup in the fridge during the peak sorbet season, so that you can easily make them fresh every day or so. The syrup will keep happily in the fridge for up to two weeks.

 The ratio of sugar to water required to make the classic simple syrup is 1:1 (ie, 500g sugar + 500ml water = 800ml syrup; or 1kg sugar + 1 litre water = 1,600ml syrup).

 You can use granulated or caster sugar. Just heat until the sugar crystals are melted, cool and then pour into a sterilised container. You can make syrup simply by mixing sugar and water. This takes longer, so it is advisable here to use the finer caster sugar, which dissolves easier.

 You can make sorbets without an ice-cream machine or sorbetière. Just decant your sorbet mixture into a plastic container and palce it in the coldest part of the freezer. Check it after 1-1 hours - there should be a rim of ice crystals forming round the edge of the containers with soft slush in the middle. Beat for a few seconds with a whisk, electric beater or in a food processor, until you have a uniform slush, and put the container back in the freezer. Do this a couple more times at 1-1 hour intervals until the right texture is reached.
