fields.bodyText: It was a perfect pudding, without unholy embellishment of any kind: a small cloud of pavlova with three spoonfuls of intensely-flavoured sorbets - raspberry, blackcurrant and redcurrant - each finished with a flick of barely whipped cream. The sorbets were of a perfect consistency, having that slight density they get an hour or so after churning that adds substance to the clear, penetrating flavour of the fruit. The pavlova was crisp without, like the crust on a fall of snow, giving way to a soft and yielding froth below. The comma of cream provided a gentle foil. It was simple, beautiful, magical. That elegant construct of a pudding - half Phillip Johnson, half Philippe Starck - at Campanile, the hot-shot restaurant on La Brea, Los Angeles, was an epiphany in my experience of ices, a landmark in the memory bank, and one to set beside the soothing balm of the fig, peach and almond combo in Florence that I wrote about last week. In this day of the super-rich, artery-clogging, commercial ice cream, the lighter, subtler, more intense pleasures of the sorbet tend to get passed over, yet their history is longer and, if anything, richer than that of its cream and egg yolk brother. Tradition has it that the Chinese and Arabs started it all off when they used snow to chill fruit juices, and for once there might be some substance to tradition. According to students of ice history, the first mention of what is known as endothermic effect, using saltpetre and cold water to make ice, comes in the Kitab Uyan al-Anba fi Tabaqat al-Atibba, by Ibn Abu Usaybi, an Arab medical historian in the 13th century. There are serious technical differences between sherbet, deriving from the Arabic sharbat - "syrups, pastes, powders, lemonades and other fruit juices, sweetened and diluted with water in the Turkish fashion, and regarded primarily as healthful, sustaining, restorative beverages", as the peerless Elizabeth David puts it, which were sometimes mixed with snow or ice - and sorbet, which derives from the Italian sorbire, meaning "to sip". When sorbet became the frozen ice that we know and love today, however, is a bit confused, to say the least. There has been a long-standing connection based on trade and conquest (not necessarily in that order) between Sicily and North Africa, and between North Africa, Sicily and southern Italy, and it seems likely that this is how knowledge of these most desirable summer coolers percolated ever northwards. There are establishments in Messina, Palermo and various other Sicilian towns that specialise in one of the three great branches of ice science to this day. Although water ices - aka eaux glacés, eaux d'Italie or acque gelate - were known and appreciated in Paris, Naples, Florence and Spain in the 1660s, it was only when a Sicilian, Francisco Procopio, opened the Cafe Procope in Paris to sell sorbets and sherbets in or around 1690 that they really took off. So successful was it that within 60 years there were 250 other such establishments plying for trade. Iced creams didn't get much of a look in until a bit later. However, we will not concern ourselves with sherbets and historical debate here, but stick to the glory of the sorbet, which has the great advantage - for the restaurant chef and the happy home cook alike - of being simple and inexpensive to make. Using fruits in season when they are cheap and plentiful justifies the expense of the machine (or sorbetière). The summer yields gluts of berries, currants and other fruits, and cordials and purées can be frozen to make sorbets aplenty with ease and speed. There's no reason to stop in the summer, either. Sorbets made from pears or the myriad variety of plums are just as delicious, and aid the consumption of autumn game with pleasant ease. Come winter, when the citrus fruits are at their peak, clementines, oranges, limes and lemons all make sumptuous sorbets, ready to pretty a Christmas table splendidly. So to hell with the ready-made, joyless muck that crowd the supermarket freezer cabinets and masquerade as a treat, when in truth they are full of rubbish and have barely a trace of the flavour advertised. Take a leaf from the life of Signor Procope, and make your own. RASPBERRY SORBET Very good with strawberries, too - and blackberries, come to that, as long as they are full and ripe, and therefore need no cooking. 700g very fresh, ripe raspberries 115g caster sugar 2 very fresh egg whites 3 dssp lemon juice Carefully pick over the berries, then put them into a food processor and render to a purée. Pass the purée through a fine sieve and stir in the sugar, dissolving it completely. Stir in the lemon juice. In a very clean bowl, whisk the whites until they are stiff, then fold them into the raspberry mixture. Churn in a machine according to manufacturer's instructions. This sorbet is at its best eaten within a few hours of churning. ORANGE SORBET Needless to say, this approach may be used for all the citrus fruits, although the quantity of sugar may have to be increased or reduced depending on the acidity of the fruit. It is worth pointing out that the norm used to be to rub cubes of loaf sugar over the zest of the fruit, to absorb the flavour and oil. It is a labour of love, but the result is truly exceptional. 150g caster sugar 300 ml water Juice of 1 lemon Rind of 2 oranges 500ml orange juice Put the caster sugar, pared rind and water (a still mineral water is good here) into a stainless-steel pan and bring to a boil. Boil for four to five minutes, then remove from the heat and leave to cool. When the syrup is cool, add the orange and lemon juices, pour into an ice-cream machine and churn according to manufacturer's instructions. MELON SORBET This is a great favourite of mine, and goes straight on to the restaurant's menu the moment the first melons of the year appear. As for the quantities listed, I would normally buy two melons and make lots. 900g ripe Charentais melon 190g caster sugar 3 tbsp lemon juice Peel the melon carefully. Scoop out the seeds and push them through a sieve, saving any bits and juice that comes through. Cut the melon flesh into pieces, and render to a purée with the reserved seed juice, sugar and lemon juice. Push the purée through a sieve also. Churn according to manufacturer's instructions. PERSIMMON SORBET If persimmons are hard to get hold of, by all means use Sharon fruit instead (it's much the same thing, to tell the truth), but substitute a third of the weight with fully ripe apricots. 1 kg of persimmons 180g icing sugar 1-2 lemons Scoop out the flesh of the fruit and whizz it in a liquidiser, along with the sugar and lemon juice (if the machine gets too full, do this in a couple of batches). Push the resulting pulp through a conical sieve, adding a spoonful or two of water if the mixture is over thick. Churn in a machine according to the instructions. TOMATO SORBET No, this is not a joke, but a rather nice idea from Lindsey Bareham's Big Red Tomato Book, which is just out in paperback (Penguin, £8.99). 1 kg very ripe tomatoes 15mg tomato purée tsp salt 15g icing sugar 10 drops Tabasco 30ml vodka 1 tbsp fresh lemon juice Chill a bowl in the freezer. Core the tomatoes, then blanch them in boiling water for 15-20 seconds. Remove from the water, peel, de-seed and chop roughly. Liquidise the tomato flesh, then add the tomato purée, salt, sugar, Tabasco, vodka and lemon juice, and mix well (add more salt, if required). The more bold among you may wish to add a splash of Worcestershire sauce, some horseradish and a dash or two extra of vodka. Churn the sorbet mix, then transfer to the chilled bowl in the freezer TECHNICAL TIPS  Sorbets can be made with either fruit purée and syrup or fruit purée, syrup and raw egg white. Eggs whites are added to stabilise those sorbets that melt rather quickly, or to lighten those that tend to go rather dense because there is not enough pectin or fibre in the fruit used. If you do use egg whites, get pasteurised ones, if you can; otherwise, use only very fresh, free-range, organic eggs.  It is worth keeping a jar or bottle of syrup in the fridge during the peak sorbet season, so that you can easily make them fresh every day or so. The syrup will keep happily in the fridge for up to two weeks.  The ratio of sugar to water required to make the classic simple syrup is 1:1 (ie, 500g sugar + 500ml water = 800ml syrup; or 1kg sugar + 1 litre water = 1,600ml syrup).  You can use granulated or caster sugar. Just heat until the sugar crystals are melted, cool and then pour into a sterilised container. You can make syrup simply by mixing sugar and water. This takes longer, so it is advisable here to use the finer caster sugar, which dissolves easier.  You can make sorbets without an ice-cream machine or sorbetière. Just decant your sorbet mixture into a plastic container and palce it in the coldest part of the freezer. Check it after 1-1 hours - there should be a rim of ice crystals forming round the edge of the containers with soft slush in the middle. Beat for a few seconds with a whisk, electric beater or in a food processor, until you have a uniform slush, and put the container back in the freezer. Do this a couple more times at 1-1 hour intervals until the right texture is reached.  Sorbets that contain alcohol take longer to freeze.  Sorbets are best eaten within a few hours of being made. They will keep in the freezer indefinitely, but the freshness of flavour soon goes, so it is better to make them in small quantities and often. Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.standfirst: Letters on Captain Corelli
fields.trailText: Letters on Captain Corelli
fields.body:
As somebody who read Captain Corelli's Mandolin because 'everybody else was', I was interested to learn that the people of Cephalonia and the real-life Corelli have turned against the novel (A Greek Myth, July 29). The irony is that, in attempting to illustrate the moral equivalence of fascism and communism, Louis de Bernières' tramples over the truth in 'ideological' fashion.

The result is a falsification of the partisans' resistance. One ideology from that era that he does not seek to dispel, however, is that of national character: surrounding the slushy love story at the heart of the book is a series of stereotypes - emotional Italians, clinical Germans, stiff-upper-lipped Brits, truculent Yugoslavs and murderous Greeks - that are milked for all they are worth. The success of the novel reveals their continuing appeal.

Dr Sam Pryke
Aigburth, Liverpool

De Bernières can be criticised in the way the Italian Marxist Antonio Gramsci analysed novelists in the Prison Notebooks. What needs and aspirations do historical novels fulfil, and why do they have such wide appeal? Gramsci also examined the ideological content of novels by unveiling the intellectual conservatism and flaccid social criticism at their heart, something that Seumas Milne's article tackles superbly.

It is worth considering, too, de Bernières' wider social function as a writer. His three earlier novels, all set in Latin America, contain similar 'barbarians' and disparaging portrayals of people in other parts of the world.

Adam David Morton
Llanilar, Aberystwyth

De Bernières should know that no resistance movement could survive without support from the overwhelming majority of the people. This the Greek partisans had, and his caricature of them as inhumane beasts is unbelievable and, for me, ruined what is a very enjoyable and well-written novel.

John Green
Cnwch Coch, Aberystwyth

I was astonished by the quoted comment from the Captain Corelli film's producer that 'the argument about politics and the civil war is as dull as ditchwater'. To me, the real story sounds much more interesting than the novel - just as humanly dramatic and politically engaging. It is pathetic that so little regard for the truth appears to come into the telling of so many film stories.

Thom Osborn
London N7

The events in Greece at the end of the second world war were a defining moment in history. At Yalta, Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin drew a line across Europe, defining spheres of influence. In order to stop Greece having a left-wing government, the British occupation force persecuted the resistance forces and reinstated the Nazi-collaborators in power.

This not only led to the civil war, but gave Stalin a role model as to what should be done in the parts of eastern Europe on his side of the line. De Bernières is just the latest revisionist to attempt to rewrite history.

Martin Davidson
London NW7

Much of Captain Corelli is written from the women's viewpoint, yet your piece had no interviews with female comtemporaries of the partisans. An honest account by women might give a different slant on the wartime activities of the fiercely-proud men who obviously feel so slighted by the story.

Maggie Hazel
Birmingham

Email your letters to: weekend@theguardian.com

webTitle: Inspired Walsh shines through the gloom

fields.headline: Inspired Walsh shines through the gloom
fields.trailText: Prior to this third Test, Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose had bowled 152 overs in the series against England, of which 65 were maidens. They had conceded 275 runs and taken 24 wickets at 11.45 runs apiece.
fields.body:
Prior to this third Test, Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose had bowled 152 overs in the series against England, of which 65 were maidens. They had conceded 275 runs and taken 24 wickets at 11.45 runs apiece.

The other West Indian bowlers had sent down 90.1 overs and England had scored 325 off them, with only 21 maidens produced and 12 wickets taken at a cost of 27.08 runs per wicket.

That pattern repeated itself on day two here, with Walsh and Ambrose continuing in their parsimonious mode. Ambrose was containing but Walsh once again also found the inspiration to summon up that penetrative edge needed to pick up three wickets. It took his tally to 470 as he continues to improve his own record, and at one stage he had bowled seven consecutive overs and taken three wickets without conceding a run.

It was another display of high-quality bowling from the 37-year-old Jamaican. That he was able to summon up his enthusiasm and this type of performance in his 120th Test was no simple achievement. Could this be due to the obvious delight he still finds in playing? This was evident after he had taken his third wicket, Graham Thorpe, after which he grinned from ear to ear and almost danced into a celebratory huddle with team-mates.

Should he play the remaining matches here he will surpass Sir Vivian Richards as the West Indian who has played the most Tests. It is another record to add to his most wickets, most ducks and most not-outs. He must qualify for most effort as well, even if this is a joint award with those other players who have always given their all.

There has been much discussion on whether Walsh can go on long enough to get 500 Test wickets. On this proof of his continued excellence, why not? There is certainly no one waiting in the wings to challenge his position.

It must be a reflection on West Indian cricket that no one is challenging him and must be one of the greatest concerns, along with the brittle nature of the batting and yesterday's indifferent fielding.

It will also be of concern to Walsh, because he is a team man. This is a depressing period for West Indies on this tour but nothing can detract from Walsh's contribution. He may be a team man but one must suspect that his decision to continue may well hinge on the output of his present colleagues and his ability to bear the load.

webTitle: Nowhere for men in charge  to hide as cover is blown

fields.headline: Nowhere for men in charge  to hide as cover is blown
fields.trailText: "The covering of the playing area at Test matches in this country varies from the good - Edgbaston, Lord's - to, frankly, the diabolical. Old Trafford on Thursday was poor" : Mike Selvey
fields.body:
Personally I find it embarrassing. No, not the sycophantic Jenny Bond's apparent belief that she is actually a member of the royal family, which is bad enough (John Prescott could probably carpet the House of Commons with her clothing allowance). Actually it is something more vital, the covering of the playing area at Test matches in this country, which varies from the good - Edgbaston, Lord's - to, frankly, the diabolical. Old Trafford on Thursday was poor.

The technology of covering has been little changed since Victoria was on the throne and WG was considering a Gillette contract. Certainly Edgbaston has had its Brumbrella - the piece of North Sea oil pipeline with synchronised motors at either end and its plastic sheet that rolls out across the ground - for years and, more recently, Lord's has cranked up its hovercover (considered cutting edge, incidentally, at a time when the cross-Channel hovercraft has been deemed redundant) and there have been inflatable domes, not least at Old Trafford.

But essentially the process worldwide still involves wheeling on a series of interlinking raised covers for the pitch itself, and then dragging tarpaulins and plastic sheets over other parts of the ground. It is a bit like trying to improve on the mac and umbrella. Where can you go?

Well, you make a better mac and a more efficient umbrella, and if there is rain about you make sure you do not leave them in the hall cupboard. On the first day of an important high-profile Test match, Old Trafford failed the public.

The quagmire that resulted from the downpour shortly after lunch was understandable up to a point, although perhaps the umpires ought to have been pre-emptive and allowed the ground staff on earlier - inform the public immediately and they would understand - and there was no excuse for failing to cover the bare ends on the pitch at the edge of the square, despite the assertion of the groundsman Peter Marron that he was always going to stick a coconut mat on it when play resumed. But the fact that play did not even start until midday as a result of overnight rain was less excusable.

How can such a situation arise? Both Edgbaston and Lord's cover pretty much the entire playing area prior to the game, so why not Old Trafford? Is it perhaps a question of spheres of influence or wrong priorities?

If Lancashire have the financial acumen to build a hotel on the ground and run a flourishing banqueting business then would the cost of investing in something a bit more state of the art than plastic sheets dragged on to the ground (hard to do anyway, according to Marron, when they themselves get wet) be so hideous? Hiring suitable equipment costs around £12,000 apparently, and if Lancashire are not prepared to do that then the England and Wales Cricket Board ought to meet the cost. Terry Blake, the ECB marketing manager, certainly agrees that something more ingenious, which can cover quickly but which allows water dispersal without saturating the outfield, needs developing, but the public and players deserve even the basics done better.

Yet only in the matter of mopping-up have there been advances. Once, this consisted of forking the soil until surface water disappeared and then using sacking to mop up the rest. It recalls the famous occasion at the Oval in 1968 when the outfield was flooded, the crowd helped in the drying process and Derek Underwood bowled England to a victory that had seemed beyond them.

In Rawalpindi during the 1987 World Cup we were treated to the sight of a fellow removing surface water from the covers by cupping his hands, scooping at the puddles and transferring as much as he could to a bucket, which is as low-tech as it gets, short of using a drinking straw. Other solutions abroad, particularly in the Caribbean, have involved using the downdraught from helicopters to blow-dry the ground, and employing petrol to set the surface alight, which is spectacular at least.

Now, although the fork-and-blot method is still in evidence, the Whales, motorised squeegees that can soak up gallons at a time and then discharge them into the drains beyond the boundary, have come into their own and have clawed back countless hours that might otherwise have been lost.

Maybe the obvious solution comes from Graham Gooch's lateral thinking, however. Grow your turf cricket square by all means, he says, but why not use synthetic turf, with proper drainage, for the remainder of the ground? A few carpet burns for the diving fielders would be a small price to pay for the goodwill, and think of the saving in two-stroke for the mowers.

fields.headline: Royal flush beats two aces
fields.trailText: Even in the orderly world of Alec Stewart, this was going some. A hundred in his 100th Test on the day of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday. Not forgetting the statutory 100 press-ups before breakfast. He does like to keep life organised.
fields.body:
Even in the orderly world of Alec Stewart, this was going some. A hundred in his 100th Test on the day of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday. Not forgetting the statutory 100 press-ups before breakfast. He does like to keep life organised.

To contemplate a hundred was achievement enough in a series where, before Stewart and Marcus Trescothick rallied with such conviction, no England player had even passed 50. To make a hundred brought an ovation of rare passion.

"They seemed to stand on their feet for ever," Stewart said, and thanked Manchester for its kindness. An uncompromising competitor he might be, but no modern player has more respect for the game's traditions and demands.

When Stewart arrived at the crease with militaristic bearing, it was 17 for three and 41 England wickets had fallen in this series for 648 runs. Michael Atherton's 100th Test had yielded only a single on his home ground. Nasser Hussain had imagined a monster in a routinely rising ball. Graham Thorpe had been so conned, first ball, by Courtney Walsh's artful slower one that night might have fallen all around him.

Less than three hours later, as Stewart offered all corners of the ground his perfectly drilled 21-bat salute, such statistics belonged to a different world. This became an innings of zero tolerance, a clean-up campaign against a summer of batting crimes.

Sir Colin Cowdrey, recovering from a stroke in Kent, was the only other Englishman to mark his 100th Test with a century, and even he did not do it on the Queen Mother's birthday. Stewart, a committed royalist, blushed at the thought. "She's been brilliant. I'm very proud of the royal family; it all tied in very nicely," he said. As did the fact that his father, Micky, and mother, Sheila, were in the crowd.

Stewart radiated vitality. His gear gleamed so white and pristine that had the sun ever emerged there would have been a danger of the Test being suspended because Trescothick was being dazzled by the reflection. After tea he struck the ball with the crisp crunch of a man biting a freshly picked apple, his drives zinging through the off side as if scrubbing it clean.

He is in the midst of a truly remarkable run which might have brought him four successive England hundreds, had he not flashed impulsively at Heath Streak on 97 and been caught behind in the final of the NatWest series at Lord's.

There was even an appropriate batting partner. Alongside Stewart in his 100th Test stood Trescothick, in his first. It might have served as a discourse on the natural order of things and the constant need for renewal, and emphasised the remarkable impression that Stewart is actually growing younger.

Trescothick remained utterly calm. To recognise that Walsh and Curtly Ambrose offered a new challenge was one thing; to be stuck for 45 minutes on nought and be entirely unflustered was further testimony to his pedigree.

fields.headline: Hollioake prolongs Lancashire's distress
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 310 & 227-4dec
Lancashire 120 & 19-0
fields.trailText:
Surrey 310 & 227-4dec
Lancashire 120 & 19-0
fields.body:
Surrey's captain Adam Hollioake seems an affable chap but his performance here yesterday suggested that he could teach the Marquis de Sade a thing or two about inflicting mental suffering.

It was sadistic enough to score 310 after being 12 for three, and then to bowl out Lancashire, their most serious championship rivals, for 120. But his surprising decision not to enforce the follow-on had little logic to it, unless it was done purely to prolong Lancashire's distress.

Being picky, Hollioake probably got it wrong. On the principle that you should generally do what the opposition would least like, he should have asked the Lancashire batsmen to try again. The match might have been wrapped up by now.

He could hardly reason that his bowlers were tired after disposing of Lancashire in just 39.1 overs, even though Alex Tudor had bowled 15 overs for his career-best seven for 48.

Hollioake will also end up with free range all over his face if the weatherman is proved wrong and it rains all day today. But when Surrey romp over the winning line today, as they should, it will make very little difference.

Hollioake might argue that Lancashire are psychologically damaged beyond repair after the pre-declaration mauling they took from the Surrey batsmen in the final session. Perhaps Surrey were determined to inflict some awful torture following their heavy defeat against the same opposition in the recent NatWest Trophy quarter-final.

Lancashire, set 418 for victory when Surrey declared at 227 for four, were given eight overs batting and finished on 19 without loss. They need an implausible 399 more.

Lancashire seemed to go into the match under the impression that Michael Atherton was not playing at Old Trafford. Their captain, John Crawley, is their only opening batsman here, and he would really prefer to bat at No3.

Yesterday they opened with Crawley and the fast bowler Glen Chapple. Their coach Bobby Simpson said: "The balance of the team meant we needed a fourth seamer. Chapple has a good technique and a lot of courage and has scored runs as nightwatchman."

Chapple did manage to survive his opening partner in the first innings. Crawley was lbw, shuffling forward to Martin Bicknell, with only five scored. In the next over Chapple was caught by Mark Butcher to give Tudor his first wicket. And Lancashire were seven for three when Sourav Ganguly trod on his stumps from his first delivery.

It got worse. Neil Fairbrother hung out his bat and was caught at second slip at 33 and without addition Graham Lloyd was caught behind.

Lancashire were relying on Andrew Flintoff, who looked in the sort of form that brought him a violent and unbeaten 135 in that NatWest game. But he was sixth out with the score on 85 when he was caught at forward short-leg off Saqlain Mushtaq and Lancashire's serious resistance was over.

Tudor has bowled faster but rarely straighter. He had Chris Schofield caught at mid-on, Gary Keedy caught at fourth slip and bowled Warren Hegg.

When Surrey batted again Mark Butcher appeared to be back to is best with a well-timed 95 from 134 deliveries. But it was a blow from Alistair Brown, one of the biggest sixes seen here, that will be remembered. He dove Schofield straight on to the balcony of the pavilion's broadcasting box, about 70 feet up.

webTitle: Lehmann run spree paves way for Somerset

fields.headline: Lehmann run spree paves way for Somerset
fields.standfirst:
Somerset 359 & 33-0
Yorkshire 327
fields.trailText:
Somerset 359 & 33-0
Yorkshire 327
fields.body:
Darren Lehmann yesterday became the third batsman to reach 1,000 runs for the season - and, as it happened, the second Australian, a few days after Michael Bevan. He registered the statistic with some jaunty assurance and was then immediately out to an ill-considered flourish of the bat against the Somerset teenager Peter Trego.

Like Bevan, Lehmann cannot command, it seems, an automatic Test place for Australia, though Headingley must wonder why. The omission - he has played only five Tests - is another eloquent reflection of antipodean batting strength.

His half-century, including a six off Ian Blackwell, came off a Somerset attack which persevered rather than threatened. This has been a difficult season for the home captain Jamie Cox, doing his best to disguise the fact that he is too often without his strike bowlers.

From now on Lehmann will be taking on added responsibilities for Yorkshire. The captain David Byas twisted his knee in stepping away from a delivery from Trego, collaps ing and hobbling off to the dressing room and thence to hospital, where his injury was diagnosed as a torn cartilage. There may be surgery next week; he is unlikely to come back this season. But Lehmann has proven qualities as a captain, having already led South Australia.

Somerset gained a lead of 32 on the innings, though they had already been repeatedly put in good heart by the relayed messages of Marcus Trescothick's resilience at Old Trafford on his Test debut. In again, Somerset's Cox and Mark Lathwell scored 33 without loss to put the county 65 ahead.

For most of the day the batting had been better than the bowling. Anthony McGrath's 74 was his highest of the season, with some of his dozen boundaries reminiscent of those richly promising times when he scored his maiden hundred on the England A tour of Pakistan. His one let-off was on 29 when Lathwell should have held him at gully off Graham Rose; his aberration came when he could not make up his mind how to dispatch Blackwell and ended up by offering a submissive return catch.

The left-hander Vic Craven had executed some fluent off-drives as he reinforced his valid claims to become a regular opener. All his good work, alas, was undone when, annoyingly for him, he pulled a long-hop straight to midwicket.

Simon Guy, making his first appearance for the county as wicketkeeper at the expense of Richard Blakey, had taken the gloves with genuine composure. Now his batting was surprisingly mature, and there was no disguising his disappointment when he was denied a deserved 50. He was in a late stand with Ian Fisher, who made his own case for regular inclusion and not merely as a slow bowler reaching 68 not out .

webTitle: Tufnell grinds Essex to a halt

fields.headline: Tufnell grinds Essex to a halt
fields.standfirst:
Middlesex 287 & 93-3
Essex 200
fields.trailText:
Middlesex 287 & 93-3
Essex 200
fields.body:
Sadly, the rain that curtailed the first two days of this Second Division game stayed away from St John's Wood yesterday and we were obliged to endure a full ration of largely soporific cricket. If two divisions have sharpened up the County Championship, this match must be the exception to the rule.

Apart from a sparkling 84 by Mark Ramprakash on the first day and Phil Tufnell's eccentric cameo, the batting has left almost everything to the imagination. That may be harsh on Ronnie Irani, whose responsible knock of 76 carried his team to their solitary batting point yesterday. But circumstances forced even the Essex captain to temper his natural aggression.

Essex began the day with 64 to their name for the loss of Paul Prichard but once his fellow opener Paul Grayson, with only four more added, became the first of Tufnell's six victims, his best return of the season, it was as much as anyone could do to stay awake. We were treated to two measly runs an over for the remainder of the Essex innings.

Mercifully there was the occasional wicket to stifle the yawns. Stuart Law did not hang about long, caught by Angus Fraser at backward point attempting to deposit Tufnell over Old Father Time, and Irani then joined Ian Flanagan. "Bud" managed to occupy the crease for 130 balls for his 21 before edging Tufnell to David Nash behind the stumps; however bad Flanagan and Allen were, they must have been more entertaining than this.

In the third over after lunch Stephen Peters added to his growing reputation as a wasted talent by spooning Fraser to square leg. Three balls later Barry Hyam chased a wide one to give Fraser a double-wicket maiden and leave Essex on 138 for six.

Having made only five scoring strokes in 40 minutes after lunch, Danny Law and Irani added 42 runs in what seemed like a trice but 122 balls can go by just like that when you are fast asleep. To cut a long story short, Essex scraped to 200, despite Tufnell's endeavours.

But Middlesex, bottom of the table with apparently little to play for, showed greater urgency than their promotion-chasing neighbours when they batted again, stretching their lead to 190 with Ramprakash again leading the way, giving themselves a decent chance of victory today.

fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: If Nasser Hussain is a bit uncertain about the precise sequence in which England's batsmen ought to queue up to be rumbled by Courtney and Curtly, imagine how clueless his county counterparts must be feeling at the end of a week of disdain for the alleged natural order that would have delighted Trotsky.
fields.body:
If Nasser Hussain is a bit uncertain about the precise sequence in which England's batsmen ought to queue up to be rumbled by Courtney and Curtly, imagine how clueless his county counterparts must be feeling at the end of a week of disdain for the alleged natural order that would have delighted Trotsky.

At Bristol, the Oval, Derby and Canterbury, the first five innings saw sides stumble to 59 for eight, 120 for five, 12 for three, 131 for five and 98 for four, whereupon totals, respectively, of 122, 308, 310, 394 and 375 ensued.

Pride of place went to Leicestershire's Anil Kumble, whose 50 against Kent more than doubled his summer's output, and Hampshire's Dmitri Mascarenhas, whose maiden century against Derbyshire helped the First Division's basement slummers net four batting points for the first time this season.

Kumble yesterday held sway with bat and ball as Kent struggled to avert the follow-on. Mascarenhas, conversely, was far from the only Hampshire man to prosper.

For only the second time this season, a Hampshire pair shared a century championship stand, Mascarenhas adding 187 for the sixth wicket with Derek Kenway, co-author of the only other such liaison. Their centuries, moreover, trebled the team's term aggregate. By stumps, Derbyshire were still 19 behind and Alan Mullally had claimed four more victims: of the 14 home batsmen to fall thus far, he has nailed 13.

Tradition got a word in at Northampton, where Matthew Hayden maintained his purple patch for Northamptonshire. Dominating an opening stand of 195 with Adrian Rollins against Worcestershire, the captain made his second century in successive games to become the second to 1,000 championship runs this season.

webTitle: Ton puts Stewart in elite group

fields.headline: Ton puts Stewart in elite group
fields.standfirst:
West Indies 157
England 196-3
fields.trailText:
West Indies 157
England 196-3
fields.body:
Yesterday belonged to the Gaffer. Alec Stewart, in his 100th Test match, glorified the occasion with a century of bristling brilliance that wrenched back the initiative seized by West Indies as Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose sought to rectify the damage done to their chances in the third Test by the ineptness of their batsmen.

It was 6.15, and gloomy, when Stewart poked the single on the offside that took him to his 14th Test century and his first against West Indies in this country. As he completed the run he gave a joyous leap, punched the air, and then saluted all corners of the ground. The crowd responded by giving him the sort of lengthy standing ovation usually accorded leaders at party conferences, only this was given with genuine spontaneity.

In a bygone era, hats would have been thrown in the air and never retrieved. Of the 21 previous players who have reached 100 Tests, only three - Colin Cowdrey, Javed Miandad and Gordon Greenidge - marked the occasion with a century. He joins an exclusive section of an already exclusive club.

This was a remarkable effort, as fine an innings as Stewart can ever have played and on the back of a rich international sequence of 101, 100 not out and 97 in the recent one-day series. It has helped place England, 39 runs ahead with seven first-innings wickets in hand, in a strong position in this vital Test.

In on a hat-trick, he was eight not out at tea. But by the close he had reached 105, adding 97 in a long session of 36 overs, during which time he and young Marcus Trescothick, playing his debut Test innings, added 149.

Thus far the pair have added 179 for the fourth wicket, the highest partnership for any wicket against West Indies on this ground with Trescothick fulfilling all the expectations placed upon him by making 65. He is not the sort of lad to look too far ahead but already he will have his eyes on a debut century. The last person to achieve that for England incidentally was Graham Thorpe, who on his own return to the fold was out first ball.

The England innings had begun in such trying circumstances as Walsh and Ambrose probed mercilessly that after 10 overs only three runs had accrued for the loss of Mike Atherton, and Trescothick had yet to get off the mark. Both bowlers were awesome, but Walsh was incisive as well, following the leg cutter that Atherton edged to second slip with a lifter from nowhere that took the shoulder of Nasser Hussain's bat and looped to gully. Hussain had been given a life when Walsh stepped over the boundary rope in taking a catch.

The next ball after Hussain was dismissed, Thorpe was made to look foolish with a wonderful slower ball that hit him on the boot as he turned his head to duck what he thought was a beamer. Walsh had taken three for nought in seven overs. Trescothick for his part had taken 25 deliveries to get off the mark and then on three had been dropped by Wavell Hinds at backward square leg as he hooked Franklyn Rose flat.

The innings needed transformation and with Ambrose giving way to the change bowlers, Stewart was the man, cracking out his offside boundaries as first Rose and later Reon King dropped short and gave him width. His fifty took 63 balls with seven boundaries, his hundred a further 73 deliveries with six further boundaries.

This was no second-fiddle innings from Trescothick, however, for after his steadfast start - no panic, just realism - he played some solid strokes himself, offering the bowler the full face of the bat, taking his singles as readily as he looked for boundaries and providing a foil to Stewart, with whom he began to learn his international trade in the triangular series.

Hinds's drop apart, he might have been caught by more agile fielders than West Indies possess when he mishooked Rose and the ball looped gently over the bowler's head to fall in no man's land. But if it fazed him it did not show as he put his foot down the pitch to biff Adam's left- arm spin over square leg for six to reach his own half-century from 122 balls.

The day ultimately and emphatically belonged to Stewart and England, but it had begun, beneath the blanket of cloud that persisted throughout the day, in positive fashion for West Indies as Adams and Ramnaresh Sarwan continued the process of resurrecting their innings after the damage caused by Darren Gough and his partners on the previous evening.

Adams had some early luck when he played Andy Caddick on to his stumps without dislodging a bail and Sarwan was struck so hard in the ribs by Craig White's bouncer - there is more meat on a butcher's pencil than on Sarwan and White, from an ambling run and easy action, is seriously fast - that he needed a hospital x-ray that confirmed a cracked rib.

The pair survived the first hour, however, taking their fifth-wicket stand to 69 before Sarwan, concentration broken by the first drinks' interval, was lbw for 36 to Cork's first ball after the restart. It set in motion the chain of events that saw the last six wickets fall for 39 runs.

Ridley Jacobs was promptly yorked by the first ball of a new spell from Caddick, and then in quick succession Adams was taken at third slip, Ambrose stunningly caught by Hussain at mid-on and after lunch Dominic Cork rounded things off with two further wickets giving him a flattering four for 23.

Both bowlers were awesome, but Walsh was incisive as well, following the leg cutter that Atherton edged to second slip with a lifter from nowhere that took the shoulder of Nasser Hussain's bat and looped to gully. Hussain had been given a life when Walsh stepped over the boundary rope in taking a catch. The next ball after Hussain was dismissed, Thorpe was made to look foolish with a wonderful slower ball that hit him on the boot as he turned his head to duck what he thought was a beamer. Walsh had taken three for nought in seven overs. Trescothick for his part had taken 25 deliveries to get off the mark and then on three had been dropped by Wavell Hinds at backward square leg as he hooked Franklyn Rose flat. The innings needed transformation and with Ambrose giving way to the change bowlers, Stewart was the man, cracking out his offside boundaries as first Rose and later Reon King dropped short and gave him width. His fifty took 63 balls with seven boundaries, his hundred a further 73 deliveries with six further boundaries. This was no second-fiddle innings from Trescothick, however, for after his steadfast start - no panic, just realism - he played some solid strokes himself, offering the bowler the full face of the bat, taking his singles as readily as he looked for boundaries and providing a foil to Stewart, with whom he began to learn his international trade in the triangular series. Hinds's drop apart, he might have been caught by more agile fielders than West Indies possess when he mishooked Rose and the ball looped gently over the bowler's head to fall in no man's land. But if it fazed him it did not show as he put his foot down the pitch to biff Adam's left- arm spin over square leg for six to reach his own half-century from 122 balls. The day ultimately and emphatically belonged to Stewart and England, but it had begun, beneath the blanket of cloud that persisted throughout the day, in positive fashion for West Indies as Adams and Ramnaresh Sarwan continued the process of resurrecting their innings after the damage caused by Darren Gough and his partners on the previous evening. Adams had some early luck when he played Andy Caddick on to his stumps without dislodging a bail and Sarwan was struck so hard in the ribs by Craig White's bouncer - there is more meat on a butcher's pencil than on Sarwan and White, from an ambling run and easy action, is seriously fast - that he needed a hospital x-ray that confirmed a cracked rib. The pair survived the first hour, however, taking their fifth-wicket stand to 69 before Sarwan, concentration broken by the first drinks' interval, was lbw for 36 to Cork's first ball after the restart. It set in motion the chain of events that saw the last six wickets fall for 39 runs. Ridley Jacobs was promptly yorked by the first ball of a new spell from Caddick, and then in quick succession Adams was taken at third slip, Ambrose stunningly caught by Hussain at mid-on and after lunch Dominic Cork rounded things off with two further wickets giving him a flattering four for 23.

fields.headline: Atherton's mike switch may shock
fields.trailText: Out to Courtney Walsh for one may not have been the best way to celebrate it, but Michael Atherton's achievement in winning his 100th Test cap has rightly been much praised this week.
fields.body:
Out to Courtney Walsh for one may not have been the best way to celebrate it, but Michael Atherton's achievement in winning his 100th Test cap has rightly been much praised this week.

A player of unquenchable spirit and unfathomable guts, he has been England's backbone for a decade - no mean effort given that his own back is about as reliable as a Skoda. Heroic performer though he is, rarely can a sportsman have enjoyed such an unflattering public image. Privately charming, interesting, self-deprecating, with a smile rarely out of his eyes, he comes across in the media as a difficult, cantankerous curmudgeon. The inverse, in short, of many a television entertainer.

As he is a highly intelligent man, this must have been a deliberate policy, constructed while England captain. He must have studied other sportsmen's responses to the media and decided that it is better to be bland than misquoted, better to be known as short and unhelpful than constantly sought out for an opinion.

Nasser Hussain - taking the opposite approach - has said that the problem with being England captain is that anything to do with English cricket ends up on your doorstep. You are expected to have a comment for everything. So it is understandable, perhaps, that Atherton, when skipper, would use his Captain Grumpy act to reduce time-consuming contact. Except that now he is no longer in charge, with more time to be expansive, he seems no more keen to engage with journalists.

The irony in all this is that Atherton seems keen to make a career in the media once he has retired. And the signs are he would be very good at it. His occasional commentary for Test Match Special has been lucid, pertinent, sometimes even funny. His writing is equally sharp.

Let's just hope for his sake that when he finally packs in cricket and takes up a job in the media, he is never obliged to interview a player who provides as little copy as Michael Atherton.

webTitle: Guardian review: Big Chief Elizabeth by Giles Milton

fields.headline: Truth or booty?
fields.standfirst:
Sukhdev Sandhu on Elizabethan swashbucklers in Giles Milton's Big Chief Elizabeth: How England's Adventurers Gambled and Won the New World
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Sukhdev Sandhu on Elizabethan swashbucklers in Giles Milton's Big Chief Elizabeth: How England's Adventurers Gambled and Won the New World.
fields.body:
Big Chief Elizabeth: How England's Adventurers Gambled and Won the New World by Giles Milton 384pp, Hodder & Stoughton, £14.99

One of the most memorable scenes in The Tempest comes when Trinculo first happens upon Caliban, spreadeagled on the ground. Trinculo takes a whiff of the fishy-smelling shape before him and goes into a woozy reverie about the fortune he could make from exhibiting Caliban back home: "Were I in England now, as once I was, and had but this fish painted, not a holiday-fool there but would give a piece of silver. There would this monster make a man - any strange beast there makes a man. When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar, they will lay out 10 to see a dead Indian."

It was not unusual in the 1580s for natives from the New World to be brought over to London, where they were displayed like human cabinets of curiosities for metropolitan audiences to gawp at. It was less common, however, for natives to be ferried to the metropolis for intellectual and strategic reasons. A rare example was Manteo, an American Indian, whose story is one of the highlights of Giles Milton's swashbuckling history of Elizabethan adventurers.

That Manteo could have been seen wandering through Cheapside and the Strand during the autumn of 1584, his hair decked with feathers and his shivering body wrapped in deerskin breeches, was as a direct result of English mercantile ambitions. Conquering America captivated traders and thrill-seekers throughout the 16th century, and many blew fortunes trying to establish colonies there. They were stymied by poor resources and leadership, and by their limited knowledge not only of the bearings and vegetation of the territories they wanted to usurp, but of the languages and customs of those lands' owners. Off they would sail, people like Humphrey Gilbert - arrogant, "tally ho"-ing, eager to employ the techniques of violence refined in Ireland when putting down peasant revolts. Back they would totter, if they were lucky, mumbling tales of starvation and sea-madness.

All things considered, English attempts at empire-building in the New World were naive and half-baked until Walter Raleigh appeared on the scene. Poet and peacock (buffed and pink satin-vested, he cut a dash around a court in which most of the older members were miserable scrotes whose pudding-basin cuts made them look like "old Holland cheese"), he was also Gilbert's younger half-brother. There would be no further voyages, he decided, without better technical expertise. He summoned the Oxonian scholar Thomas Harriot, whose mathematical skills were deployed to work out key principles of navigation. And when Raleigh ordered his men to bring back a native Indian from the American coast, it was Harriot's unparalleled linguistic prowess that proved invaluable. Day after day he quizzed the tattoo-faced Manteo, from whose words he created a 36-character alphabet made up of algebraic symbols, Greek and Roman letters and invented figures. Set down on paper they looked, according to one scholar, "like devills".

The information Manteo provided, however, was divine. Roanoke Island lay close to Jamestown on the eastern coast of America and was rich in wildlife and fertile land; Manteo shed light on its people's habits, tribal customs and battle strategies. And so, ignoring the soothsayers' warnings that "discoveries this yeere attempted are likely to prove but badly", Raleigh appointed the Turk-slaying Sir Richard Grenville and a soldier called Ralph Lane to set up a colony on Roanoke. Violent storms damaged their ship and destroyed their supplies, leaving them reliant on Manteo's diplomatic skills to see them through their initial encounters with the Indians. They also had to deal with Chief Wingina, who, though alarmed by the settlers' almost magical powers over the natives (they had no immunity against the measles and smallpox suddenly introduced to their island), became increasingly irritated by their constant demands for food. Which led to ructions. Which led to his decapitation. Which led to . . .

It's almost impossible to summarise Milton's book, from which marvellous, vivid stories spill out like swagsack booty. If Patrick O'Brian had scripted Gladiator it would read something like this. Even he would have struggled to reproduce the mixture of heroism, violence and tragedy conjured here as Milton charts the tortured - and torturing - paths taken by the English in their quest to establish a permanent settlement in America. There is drama as the young Indian girl Pocahontas steps in at the last moment to stop her father's men "broyle to death" an English captain; romance as she falls in love with John Rolfe, an emissary sent to end the conflict between the natives and the colonists; pathos as watercolourist John White is appointed Governor of Chesapeake Bay but is so timid and incompetent that his own settlers force him to leave behind his daughter and grand-daughter and return to England; mad bravura as Richard Grenville takes on 53 Spanish ships at once; the mystery, only resolved in the epilogue, of the English settlers who disappear for 30 years, leaving behind just a single word scratched on a tree.

Well-known academics such as Stephen Greenblatt who have written extensively about the clash between "Old" and "New" Worlds tend to focus on questions of linguistic colonialism. Milton is not entirely uninterested in language. He includes a funny anecdote about the pride one Englishman took in learning the Indian name for the countryside, Wingandacoa : "This was put into all the official paperwork and it was some months before the English realised that this unpronounceable word - which the Indians kept repeating to Barlowe - actually meant 'you've got nice clothes'." None- theless, he rarely interrogates such terms as "savage". Nor does his lexicon invoke ethics much: actions tend to be "cruel" rather than "immoral".

And action is what Milton is all about. He's in love with deeds, not discourse, harking back to popular 19th-century imperial historians such as JA Froude. When he writes in praise of vigour and manliness you sense a certain nostalgia for an era when bored, braggart men could go gallivanting round the globe in pursuit of "riches, glory and honour". In this sense, Milton is a very contemporary historian. Until recently those who wrote about imperialism did so to "deconstruct" it, or to uncover its subjects' acts of resistance.

The history sections of bookshops today, however, are awash with soldier sahibs, pale explorers and idiosyncratic adventurers. The focus is on gallantry, derring-do, honest pluck. This Biggles-isation of imperialism reflects the move towards popular, narrative-led history kickstarted by the success of Dava Sobel's Longitude . In part this is a welcome progression from that self-hobbling sense of reticence and guilt that the very word "imperialism" has induced in many writers since decolonisation. Most importantly, it is a belated recognition that imperialism offers a fantastically huge - and barely mined - seam of stories. But are stories alone, however entertaining, enough?

 To order Big Chief Elizabeth for £12.99 plus 99p p&p call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: Guardian review: Pastoralia by George Saunders

fields.headline: Beautiful losers
fields.standfirst: Adam Begley enjoys strange satire in George Saunders's Pastoralia
fields.trailText: Adam Begley enjoys strange satire in George Saunders's Pastoralia.
fields.body:
Pastoralia by George Saunders 188pp, Bloomsbury, £9.99

Pastoralia: a good name for a theme park. It suggests rural simplicity tweaked, enhanced by modern technology and superior management skills. Though George Saunders uses it as the title of a story set in a theme park, it could also be his wry comment on the circumstances of the unnamed narrator, whose job is to impersonate a caveman. He lives in a cave and sleeps in a "separate area" equipped with a fax machine. On the cave walls are fake pictographs; outside, a herd of "robotic something-or- others" appears to be feeding.

Saunders's bitterly funny stories here and in his extraordinary debut, CivilWarLand in Bad Decline (1996), succeed in squeezing meaning and emotional resonance out of absurd, post-real predicaments. His satirical jabs are sharp and scary, but also sad and unexpectedly touching. In Pastoralia, the faux -caveman is urged to denounce a "subpar" colleague, but resists with a truth so primitive it shocks: "'She's a friend,' I say." Though he's meek and dim, beset by troubles and half-brainwashed by his inane job, he acquires with that single utterance a provisional heroism. In Saunders's world, that's the best you can hope for.

Saunders specialises in giving losers - the ugly, the weak, the self-absorbed - a flicker of appeal or delusional hope. We meet them in motivational seminars, drivers' education courses, walking home from dead-end jobs. We follow them to places like Sea Oak, with "no sea and no oak, just 100 subsidised apartments and a rear view of FedEx". Inside those apartments, the tenants are watching TV: "How My Child Died Violently is hosted by Matt Merton, a six-foot-five blond who's always giving the parents shoulder rubs and telling them they've been sainted by pain."

Saunders's stories present an unsettling amalgam of degraded language and high art: slogans, jargon and the crippling incoherence of daily speech, arranged on the page with meticulous care. He cherishes the brutal solecisms of the American vernacular, working them for laughs and the odd shot of beauty, too. Who can resist a high school education "mini-session" called "Who You Do Is Up To You"?

Less shocking, less zany than CivilWarLand in Bad Decline, in which the subnormal, paranormal and not yet normal all clamour for a hearing, Pastoralia sticks mostly to plausible absurdities. There's one ghost story, but the supernatural dimension is eclipsed by the ghost's all-too-human complaint: "Why do some people get everything and I got nothing?" The rest of the stories succeed on the strength of fine-tuning, not special effects.

A darling of American critics, Saunders was last year chosen by The New Yorker as one of the 20 best fiction writers under 40. Though his sensibility is easy to spot, it's nearly impossible to pick out his voice. He's a self-erasing author, happy to let other voices do the work. This absence could be ominous - a black hole that sucks in the contemporary scene and spits out satire - but it reads more like confidence, or serene faith, or philosophical calm. Or a good sense of humour.

 Adam Begley is literary editor of The New York Observer. To order Pastoralia for £7.99 plus 99p p&p call Guardian CultureShop on on 0800 3166 102.

fields.headline: Small press corner: Larrey: Surgeon to Napoleon's Imperial Guard
fields.standfirst: Richardson's lively, well-researched book is a study of the man rather than the medicine, but there is lots of gory detail about the battlefield surgery Larrey did so much to advance.
fields.trailText:
Larrey: Surgeon to Napoleon's Imperial Guard
Robert Richardson
(Quiller, £16.99)
fields.body:
Larrey: Surgeon to Napoleon's Imperial Guard
Robert Richardson
(Quiller, £16.99)

How about this for a battlefield anecdote?

"Who is that bold fellow?" asked the Duke of Wellington.

"It's Larrey," someone answered.

"Tell them not to fire in that direction; at least let us give the brave man time to gather up the wounded."

And so saying he doffed his hat.

"Who are you saluting?" enquired the Duke of Cambridge.

"I salute the courage and devotion of an age that is no longer ours," said Wellington pointing at Larrey with his sword.

There is lots more like this in Richardson's lively, well-researched book, which makes use of some previously unpublished material from the Wellcome Institute. It is a study of the man rather than the medicine, but there is (as one would expect from the author of The Abominable Stoma: A Historical Survey of the Artificial Anus ) lots of gory detail about the battlefield surgery Larrey did so much to advance.

fields.headline: Party season in publishing
fields.trailText: The Loafer and assorted publishing ne'er-do-wells had an excellent time at HC imprint Flamingo's summer bash this week, hosted by the ever-ebullient Philip Gwyn Jones.
fields.body:
 The Loafer and assorted publishing ne'er-do-wells had an excellent time at HC imprint Flamingo's summer bash this week, hosted by the ever-ebullient Philip Gwyn Jones. As has become customary, the gathering boasted an exotic theme, which most noticeably involved a naked man dancing with only a live python to spare his blushes, the odd fez and various other bits of Egyptiana. Where will this madness stop, we wonder, as publishers must surely soon run out of far-off countries to plunder for decorative inspiration? To vexed party planners we humbly point out that we have yet to attend celebrations Croatian, Belgian, Tasmanian or Luxembourgeois. A troupe of morris dancers might be novel, or possibly some collective grape-treading. Just a suggestion, obviously.

 At least Flamingo had an excuse for all this sensuous frivolity, their party coinciding with publication of Louisa Young's Tree of Pearls, sequel to Desiring Cairo and a good, old-fashioned belly-dancing romp. Onlookers might have been forgiven, though, that the purpose of the whole affair was a kind of meet-the-neighbours shindig designed to introduce Fourth Estate to their new pals and paymasters at HarperCollins. The prospect of a scrap had clearly whetted some appetites, but both sides maintained their dignity - although a few Fourth Estaters were clearly wondering whether the python was a management technique designed to keep them in line.

 A proper spat has come to pass, however, in this week's London Review of Books, where a letter from former Modern Review editor Toby Young takes John Lanchester to task for an oblique pot-shot at him in a review of Martin Amis's Experience. Various other quibbles on the nature of footnotes follow, provoking Lanchester to a tart response. What kind of future can we expect, when our great intellects can't even agree on matters paratextual?

 The industrious Peter Ackroyd has turned his attentions to writing for the theatre. His first-ever play, The Mystery of Charles Dickens, is to open at the Comedy Theatre in London at the end of the month, with Simon Callow in the title role - although the thesp will also be required appear in the guise of Mr Micawber, Miss Havisham, Mrs Gamp and Bill Sykes.
fields.bodyText:  The Loafer and assorted publishing ne'er-do-wells had an excellent time at HC imprint Flamingo's summer bash this week, hosted by the ever-ebullient Philip Gwyn Jones. As has become customary, the gathering boasted an exotic theme, which most noticeably involved a naked man dancing with only a live python to spare his blushes, the odd fez and various other bits of Egyptiana. Where will this madness stop, we wonder, as publishers must surely soon run out of far-off countries to plunder for decorative inspiration? To vexed party planners we humbly point out that we have yet to attend celebrations Croatian, Belgian, Tasmanian or Luxembourgeois. A troupe of morris dancers might be novel, or possibly some collective grape-treading. Just a suggestion, obviously.  At least Flamingo had an excuse for all this sensuous frivolity, their party coinciding with publication of Louisa Young's Tree of Pearls, sequel to Desiring Cairo and a good, old-fashioned belly-dancing romp. fields.headline: Fiction: 4 Aug
fields.trailText: Lucky Baby Jesus | The Nudist Colony | The Lightning Cage | One Fine Day in the Middle of the Night | Antarctica
fields.body:
Lucky Baby Jesus, by Peter Bradshaw (Abacus, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Sean is well on his way up the greasy pole: as editor of radical (ie conservative) gay magazine Somdomite, he gets to throw parties in Soho nightclubs and utter deathless judgments such as "It's kind of like using the ideologically inflected terminology and flinging it back in their face, sort of thing". The fact that he's heterosexual is mildly troubling, but nothing that can't be concealed under a dyed blond crop - until, that is, he falls in love with a woman. Will he come out and admit he's straight? Bradshaw's wickedly funny debut novel targets metropolitan media life with enough distance and venom to avoid tiresome in-jokes and name-dropping.

The Nudist Colony, by Sarah May (Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

It's something of a jolt to realise that this deeply unsettling novel was written by a 27-year-old first timer: the ambition of style and subject matter suggest a far greater maturity and self-confidence. Ludwig James, disfigured by a rare skin disease and back in London after years spent procuring labour for the jungle empire of a maniacal Brazilian millionaire, runs over 14-year-old Aesop, petty thief and innocent from a Hackney estate. Their subsequent association drives a surreal plot that meanders from the violent London underworld to the ruined rainforest with immense ingenuity, neatly evoking the corruption and decay of both landscapes.

The Lightning Cage, by Alan Wall (Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

There's a theory that novels in which a modern-day protagonist struggles to get to grips with an obscure historical figure have been done, notably by Peter Ackroyd and AS Byatt. But Alan Wall's contribution is by no means superfluous, and his story of a disaffected scholar turning away from the church and back to the world via his study of a minor Augustan poet is both compelling and finely achieved. Particularly impressive is Wall's subtle exploration of the relationship between creativity and mental instability, again something of a cliché but deployed to good effect here. The result is an atmospheric and emotionally charged insight into the perils of obsession.

One Fine Day in the Middle of the Night, by Christopher Brookmyre (Abacus, £6.99)

One of the most delightfully understated lines of this book comes about halfway through, as terrorists swarm all over a disused oil rig - now transformed into the Floating Island Paradise Resort - where pompous Gavin Hutchison is holding a school reunion. "Gavin's party wasn't proving quite as enjoyable as he'd hoped", we hear, which is hardly surprising given the unexpected proliferation of Uzis and rocket launchers. Brookmyre's parody of bullet-strewn, hostage-taking action movies is spot-on, combining quick wit with genuine tension, but also suggests a formidable satirical intelligence.

Antarctica, by Claire Keegan (Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

In the title story of this collection, a married woman in search of illicit adventure debates with her casual pick-up their personal conceptions of hell. For him, solitude; for her somewhere unbearably cold. Later, he handcuffs and abandons her, and she imagines her body being discovered, like that of an Antarctic explorer. Elsewhere, a jealous woman takes the scissors to her sister's beautiful hair, whilst a father searching for his missing daughter battles it out with her mother. The violence in Keegan's stories exists largely in what is not said, an insistent feeling of menace that underwrites the spare, undramatic prose. The effect is unusually disconcerting, and Keegan clearly a name to watch.

fields.headline: Non-fiction: 4 Aug
fields.trailText: The Great War & Modern Memory | Finest Hour | Brasso
fields.body:
The Great War & Modern Memory, by Paul Fussell (Oxford, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Reissued, and still unparalleled as a pop history of the first world war: Anti-Lice Pomade, Maconochie tinned stew, Abbott's Phiteezi Boots, the "ridiculous proximity" of the western front to Blighty. (An officer might see Chu Chin Chow on the London stage, then return to the trenches on Monday morning, to receive there fresh butter and violets by post from home.) Also remains the best companion to the literary war, the poets and novelists who defined modern perception by the dislocation, the great before-and-after divide, between Brasso'ed hype and muddied reality; or, as in Thomas Hardy's poems, foresaw a boneyard future before ever a mortar round was fired.

Finest Hour, by Tim Clayton and Phil Craig (Hodder & Stoughton, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

1940 Britain as oral history. Originally for a TV series, so it has the remembered details: windscreens of lorries on the roads to Dunkirk gleaming with wet sunlight under a rainbow; leaflets in St Paul's printed with "A prayer for protection against air raids"; US journalists buying three tin hats-full of apples on a hot September afternoon, munching, watching the first fires of the London blitz. The authors have a feel for uncertainty, for the unknowability of the outcome, but they can't or won't go beyond direct testimony: no sense that the Britain of then was different from this land now. A book in period clothes but wearing modern make-up.

Brasso, Blanco & Bull, by Tony Thorne (Robinson, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

1950s national service as the anecdotes of Private Thorne 23339788, inheritor of all that had evolved in Britain's army, so peculiarly and pointlessly, through the above-mentioned wars. A million boots in line marched before him: Thorne smooths away the black tapioca-like pimples on his pair with a candle, the back of a metal spoon, and polish. All the expectations Sir Douglas Haig had of his thousands of men going over the top have been reduced to "wearing a beret in anger" after first reshaping the pansy, fluffy, issue headgear. Fine semantic analysis of the subtle distinction between "fock" and "fuck" as noun, adjective and verb, and all the more authentic for not being eptly written.

webTitle: Guardian review: Life at Extremes by Frances Ashcroft

fields.headline: The edge of existence
fields.standfirst:
Phil Whitaker finds life in Earth's harshest regions in Frances Ashcroft's Life at Extremes
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Phil Whitaker finds life in Earth's harshest regions in Frances Ashcroft's Life at Extremes.
fields.body:
Life at the Extremes by Frances Ashcroft 337pp, HarperCollins, £17.99

We are an ambitious species. Not content with colonising virtually every terrestrial habitat, we seem compelled to explore environments that are incompatible with human existence. In Life at the Extremes, Frances Ashcroft considers high-altitude flight, deep-sea diving and space exploration to illustrate the important role the science of physiology has played in human endeavour. Our bodies either adapt, malfunction or cease to function at all when exposed to extremes of temperature, pressure, radiation, atmospheric composition and gravitational force. Potentially fatal conditions such as heatstroke, decompression "bends" and altitude sickness, as well as health problems arising from the micro-gravity of orbit, can be prevented, or at least ameliorated, with an understanding of the underlying physiological changes.

Ashcroft is professor of physiology at Oxford University: her material serves her well. Not only is the science interesting, but the way in which knowledge has been gained constitutes a compelling blend of the intrepid and the tragic. Over the years physiologists and explorers have subjected themselves to severe conditions in attempts to define the processes of, and limits to, physiological adaptation. Life at the Extremes is replete with accounts of scientists incarcerating themselves in test chambers and gradually varying the atmospheric pressure or concentration of oxygen, their capacity for rational thought declining prior to the onset of temporary blindness, unconsciousness and convulsions. Field experimentation has had more serious consequences: limbs and lives have been lost in sub-zero temperatures, and one of the first high-altitude balloon flights returned to earth with two of its three occupants dead.

In tandem with her account of human physiology, Ashcroft describes the ways other organisms have evolved for life under varied conditions. From airless subterranean rocks to hot, acidic geothermal springs, from arid deserts to the oppressive salinity of the Dead Sea, there is virtually no environment on earth in which some form of life cannot be found. There may be only a scattering of primitive, unicellular organisms, but as long as liquid water is periodically present, evolution has resulted in an accommodation between environment and life - hence the excitement over the possibility of water on Mars.

The account of "black smokers", volcanic vents in the ocean floor from which continuous plumes of superheated water are discharged, is particularly noteworthy. The vast, frigid darkness of the deep ocean supports only a sparse population of organisms, yet in the immediate vicinity of black smokers countless shrimp, fish, crabs and clams teem in a precarious ecosystem. "Too close to the smoker and they are boiled alive, too far away and they freeze or starve to death."

Life at the Extremes incorporates a broad sweep of disciplines, from aviation medicine to Greek mythology. Although Ashcroft has enlisted the advice of specialists in a number of different fields, there is the occasional sense that she is overreaching herself. For the most part her command of what is a huge range of subjects appears assured, but a couple of her forays into clinical medicine are oversim plified, if not misinformed, and at times her marine biology extends only as far as descriptions of nameless (but beautifully coloured) fish.

The book is intended for the general reader, and as such the science has to be presented in balanced, comprehensible terms. This is a tricky task, with pitfalls on either side. Although Ashcroft manages it reasonably well, there are passages in which she drifts too far into the language of the academic text. Paradoxically, at other times she appears lacking in rigour. Having previously described how mammalian cells die when heated above 50 C, she comments: "Fortunately, air temperatures on Earth seldom exceed 50 C." Given everything she argues about the tendency for evolution to broker compromises between environmental conditions and life, this statement - and there are others like it - is nonsensical. Self-evidently, mammalian cells have evolved to function in the temperature ranges they have, precisely because those are the temperatures they habitually encounter.

Ashcroft has chosen to punctuate the book with anecdotes from her own life, intended as colloquial hooks on which to hang the next slab of raw science. They can be endearing, but for the most part they are tenuous and obtrusive, if not patronising. Was there any need, in describing Robert Boyle's famous law as to how the volume of gas varies with pressure, to mention that it was "formulated in his Oxford laboratory, which lies not far from my own"?

Life at the Extremes is an eclectic overview, and as such it displays neither the overarching ambition of books such as Richard Dawkins's The Selfish Gene , nor the narrative instinct of writers such as Marcus Chown, whose Afterglow of Creation is a masterpiece of scientific storytelling. Ashcroft has assembled a fascinating collection of material, though, which leaves the reader with a sense of humankind's achievements and, more importantly, a vivid appreciation of the ubiquity and tenacity of life itself.

 Phil Whitaker is a forensic medical examiner and GP. His second novel, Triangulation, was joint winner of this year's Encore Prize.

webTitle: Guardian review: Mr Schnitzel by Stephen Knight

fields.headline: Family romance
fields.standfirst:
Robert Potts on Mr Schnitzel, Stephen Knight's tender memoir
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Robert Potts on Mr Schnitzel, Stephen Knight's tender memoir.
fields.body:
Mr Schnitzel by Stephen Knight 240pp, Viking, £10.99

Stephen Knight is one of Britain's best, if undervalued, poets. His first collection, Flowering Limbs , was an impressive, appropriately surreal account of adolescence; Dream City Cinema a dazzling hymn of entropy. In his first novel, an apparently autobiographical remembrance of his childhood, Knight expresses himself in a different medium without losing any of his effectiveness.

Mr Schnitzel contains two narratives. The main text consists of seven fairy-tales told to Stephen by his father, "stories for a five-year-old unsettled by sleeping in a strange bed in a strange country". The footnotes, which form the other narrative, relate the reasons for that situation. Stephen's mother is Austrian, regretful that she ever left that country and returning every summer; his father is Welsh, and his job often prevents him joining his wife and child until later in the holiday. Father and son are monoglots, and the fairy stories -magical tales of past Austrian naval triumphs - transfigure the baffling country, compensate for the father's absence and obliquely transform family members into fable. The footnotes unfold Stephen's memory of his only adult trip to Austria, revisiting the haunts of his dislocated childhood summers.

These aren't the subversive footnotes of Nabokov, nor the essays on minima of Nicolson Baker; they are contextualisations that seem digressive but show the way home. "I rarely bothered with footnotes in the past - their whiff of pedantry, the way they interrupt the narrative," Knight writes in a preface. "So you can imagine my surprise when they began to grow from the bottom of the page, rising up, until they became as important an act of retrieval as the tales themselves." The act of re-reading his childhood, retrieving it, is what Mr Schnitzel is all about; and it is a moving, often comic, heart-rending process.

Photographs are one aid to remembrance, fables another. Both can fade or fail: "I could never master fixatives," confesses one fairy-tale character, apologising for his disappearing portraits even as he himself vanishes. Meanwhile, the photographs Stephen's father takes pile up in boxes, unlabelled and thus "slipping away, mere curiosities, vanishing in front of me for want of a scribble on the back that said who and when they were".

Holding on or letting go; the core of the narrative is Stephen's mother's decline into grief, alcoholism and madness. The fairy-tales allow the young Knight to mythologise his odd parents; the footnotes show him coming to terms with events. While his mother cannot let go of the homeland she wishes she had never left, Knight can only recover the broken pieces as an adult, after a childhood of denial and incomprehension.

There is no attempt to be tricksy about the unreliability of the narrative: it is simply unknowable, years on, what is genuinely remembered and what has been transformed in memory. It is the endeavour that is important: the acts of restoration and forgiveness. There is a real sadness to this novel, but also a great deal of affection, humour and love.

webTitle: Guardian review: Kingdom of Shadows by Alan Furst

fields.headline: Parisian intrigue
fields.standfirst:
Despite its chilling charm, Chris Petit finds the chief attraction in Alan Furst's Kingdom of Shadows is its sense of nostalgia
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Despite its chilling charm, Chris Petit finds the chief attraction in Alan Furst's Kingdom of Shadows is its sense of nostalgia.
fields.body:
Kingdom of Shadows by Alan Furst 274pp, Gollancz, £16.99

Praised for his adult complexities, his grace and his transcendence of genre, the American Alan Furst writes edgy thrillers set in Europe (often Paris) just before the second world war. Alert to nuance and irony, they have been compared to the work of Patrick O'Brian and John Le Carré.

Essentially, however, Furst writes out of Eric Ambler - the understated collision of realpolitik and individual fate, the slide into action and drift into war, an undercranked unease and a raffish, cosmopolitan cast. This is led in Kingdom of Shadows by Nicholas Morath, a suave, Parisian-based Hungarian exile torn between choice and destiny, romantic and political intrigue; between his mistress in the seventh arrondissement and his shadowy diplomat uncle.

What Furst's admirers omit to notice is how much his writing - for all the political chill - is basted with nostalgia. First Paris, with its bohemian fleshpots and particular pre-war climate (a summons to the Prefecture is "a cold front in the bureaucratic weather of the city"); then there's a yearning for the smoky impressionism of inclement skies, steam trains and cigarettes.

The true attraction, then, of this and the other books (Night Soldiers, The World at Night, Red Gold and The Polish Officer) is as companionable exercises in hindsight, all dominated by a calculated sense of place and romantic departure.

 To order any of Alan Furst's novels, call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.
