Essentially, however, Furst writes out of Eric Ambler - the understated collision of realpolitik and individual fate, the slide into action and drift into war, an undercranked unease and a raffish, cosmopolitan cast. This is led in Kingdom of Shadows by Nicholas Morath, a suave, Parisian-based Hungarian exile torn between choice and destiny, romantic and political intrigue; between his mistress in the seventh arrondissement and his shadowy diplomat uncle. What Furst's admirers omit to notice is how much his writing - for all the political chill - is basted with nostalgia. First Paris, with its bohemian fleshpots and particular pre-war climate (a summons to the Prefecture is "a cold front in the bureaucratic weather of the city"); then there's a yearning for the smoky impressionism of inclement skies, steam trains and cigarettes. The true attraction, then, of this and the other books (Night Soldiers, The World at Night, Red Gold and The Polish Officer) is as companionable exercises in hindsight, all dominated by a calculated sense of place and romantic departure.  To order any of Alan Furst's novels, call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

fields.headline: Leave the brains inside the cranium
fields.standfirst:
Colin Dexter divulges the secrets of the whodunnit to John Cunningham
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Colin Dexter divulges the secrets of the whodunnit to John Cunningham.
fields.body:
He greets you like a former pupil, touched you've remembered to look him up. Cardigan, hearing aid, folds of flesh on face and neck, and a benign manner - though he still can't resist lobbing a quizzy question to see if you're paying attention.

But don't let Colin Dexter kid you that he's just a harmless grammar-school classics master, happily ensconced in his retirement. Sure, he used to teach, but that was decades ago, before he took up writing. In reality, he's a devious old geezer who's just dispatched one of our top detectives.

Morse, of course. "I started with him 27 years ago, and I miss the old boy more than most people. I get lots of letters saying 'It's terribly sad'; 'You're terribly cruel'; 'Why did you do it?'"

Dexter dunnit because of his own encroaching ill health and age. Turning out a tale about Thames Valley's finest every two years was taking too much out of him. And so, 11 books on from Last Bus to Woodstock, he let the chief inspector die, in a tale with a morbidly punning title, The Remorseful Day.

Like those greyheads who sign a form to say they don't want their lives prolonged when terminal illness strikes, Dexter, a crossword king and a former examiner for the Oxford University Board, makes the decision sound easy. But then, he cannily makes everything seem effortless.

And because of this, myths about him have flourished. So is it true that (a) he tried his hand at fiction because he was so bored with a detective novel he once read on hols; (b) that he writes only between switching off the Archers and going down to the pub; and (c) that he's rarely stumped for a twist in a plot?

Yes, yes, and yes. He adds to (a) that it was a rainy Saturday afternoon in Wales; and it was a Miss Silver crime story. His gloss on (b) is that, when younger, he sometimes continued writing after the boozer, into the small hours. "Even doing two or three pages a day, you can soon get a book."

As for (c), if he's stuck, he wanders out from his home in north Oxford to buy a paper. "What I can never do is sit and think if there's music on. But certainly walking along, I've had a few good ideas."

Dexter may write mysteries, but he's a great de-mystifier of his trade. The rule is to get something, however bad, down on paper. "I always write from the beginning to the end, pretty dreadful stuff, really; but you've got the scaffolding up. Then I start at the beginning and go over it again."

If that sounds basic, it's Dexter the teacher, passing on the technique - since, at 69, there'll be no more books, though he's got an idea for a TV play about schools. So now that he's pulling out, how does he rate his own performance - with stunning sales and lucrative TV adaptations? Modestly, of course.

"I've never said anything significant about motive. Some very fine writers, Phyllis James or Ruth Rendell - their primary concern is to look into the abyss of human consciousness. Good for them; but not for me. For me, it's the twists and turns of the whodunnit."

Chandler and Hammett are his favourites; he doesn't enjoy Elmore Leonard or James Ellroy: "The dialogue is wonderful, but I'm not quiet sure if the detective genre is where they should be placed. Not many of us here write about brains splattered on the walls, do we?"

Brains inside the cranium interest him more: the application of his patient, intellectual obsession with problem-setting and solving, transferred to his alter ego, Endeavour Morse, along with shared passions for booze, classical music and words.

Dexter remains an unapologetic pedant. "Anyone who's done the classics is well aware of potential solecisms." And he tests his readers with a few dictionary-stretchers in every book. In the latest, for instance, there's prognathic. Look it up if you don't know.

Essentially, weaving detective tales is a sedentary occupation. Dexter disarmingly admits that he'd cringe if ever he saw a battered corpse, and that his knowledge of how the police operate is gleaned entirely from fellow writers.

"If you were knowledgeable about police procedure or crime in general, you wouldn't write a whodunnit, would you?" When police build up enough evidence against a suspect, a prosecution usually follows. But with a whodunnit - "you blow it all away. The readers know who's done it, but it's too obvious, so it can't be that character."

As he bows out, he's leaving the genre in good nick. While remaining faithful to its conventions, he's added something: that special spark between his two main characters. "A lot of people say, 'I can't follow the plot, but I like the relationship between Morse and Lewis.' In that sense, there is a slightly wider dimension."

In the last few books, Morse and his maker have been drawing closer. Music and mysteries were always mutual interests. Latterly, the two shared an illness, diabetes; both have had the bizarre experience of offering their mortal remains to medical research, and finding it wasn't as easy as they thought.

One opportunity Dexter isn't offering anyone is the chance to write his biography while he's living. "I would never allow that. I've had such a lot of luck, I don't want to risk having someone ridiculously ill-informed doing it. I think it should wait till you are dead. And when you're dead, everyone forgets you anyway, if you write crime fiction."

 To order The Remorseful Day (Pan, rrp £5.99) for £3.99 plus 99p p&p, call Guardian CultureShop on on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: Guardian review: Love, Etc by Julian Barnes

fields.headline: Careless talk costs wives
fields.standfirst:
Despite its ease and panache, Elaine Showalter finds Julian Barnes's sequel, Love, Etc, disappointing
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Despite its ease and panache, Elaine Showalter finds Julian Barnes's sequel, Love, Etc, disappointing.
fields.body:
Love, Etc by Julian Barnes 249pp, Cape, £15.99

Are there any good sequels to great novels? Or, more to the point, any great sequels to good novels? Of course there are fictional trilogies, tetralogies and chronicles: the quartets of Alexandria and the Raj; Updike's Rabbit series; Larry McMurtry's Texas and Anthony Powell's London. Children's series offer the adventures of an Adrian Mole or a Harry Potter. And there are posthumous commercial sequels to famous novels, especially those of Jane Austen. But on the whole, novelists seem to prefer to get it right the first time, and to preserve the illusion of a complete and finished narrative. Salinger hasn't tackled Holden at 50; Burgess didn't imagine Alex as a father; Amis doesn't do John Self as a dot.com entrepreneur.

Until now, Julian Barnes has shared this prejudice against bringing the story up to date. A decade ago, when asked which novels should have sequels, he answered "none". But Talking It Over (1991), he told Guardian interviewer Nicholas Wroe, is the only book he has written that made readers ask what happened to the characters afterwards. In Love, Etc he has returned to the love triangle of Stuart, Oliver and Gillian and picked up the story 10 years later, with the characters once more explaining their personal versions of what happened to an unseen reporter, auditor or reader. Stuart even comments that such a technique is more realistic: "In life, every ending is just the start of another story."

I can understand that readers would wonder how the marriage of Gillian and Oliver, and the career of the jilted Stuart, turned out. Talking It Over not only presents a scandalous tale of a charismatic slacker seducing away the new bride of his more conventional "best friend", but also ends with a sensational scene in which Gillian goads mercurial new husband Oliver into hitting her in the village square for the benefit of lurking, heartbroken ex-husband Stuart, in order to perform an act of emotional exorcism.

Was Oliver really a wife-beater at heart? Would Gill repent her divorce and remarriage? Would Stuart feel avenged and released? "You didn't think that was the end of the story?" Stuart asks the reader in the new book. "Maybe I wish it had been. But life never lets you go, does it? You can't put down life the way you put down a book."

In the 1996 French film version of the novel, also called Love, Etc, the director Marion Vernoux provided a sentimental resolution to these lingering questions. The trio (reimagined as cute French lovers, with Charlotte Gainsbourg as a frail, gamine version of Barnes's strong Gillian and the two men as a juvenile Jules et Jim) meet for a millennial reunion in Normandy, skipping along the beach in matching fur hats. There's a Gallic hint of triangulated desire - the men hold hands behind the woman's back.

But Barnes's sequel is much more cruel. Indeed, Love, Etc is the gothic version of Talking It Over, in which romantic comedy has turned into madness and horror. Because of the scandal, Gill and Oliver have had to leave their idyllic French village and return to the remote higher postal codes of north London, where he has a breakdown after being disinherited by his father and she supports their family with her picture-restoring business. Meanwhile, Stuart makes a lot of money as an entrepreneur in the States. He remarries and redivorces, and finally returns to London; ostensibly on business, but really to carry out his long-fantasised revenge on Oliver.

In many respects, then, plus ça change . Stuart is still literal-minded and businesslike; Oliver is still a fey dilettante, doing the odd stint as a tutor while he writes unmarketable screenplays. Gillian is still the queen of denial, while her French mother still plays at being the wise older woman. New voices have entered the conversation, including Stuart's American second wife Terri, and Oliver's psychiatrist and troubled teenage daughter. Once again, Barnes's mastery of the dramatic form, his ear for the way people talk and his sardonic wit make the book an entertaining read.

Despite its narrative ease and stylistic panache, however, Love, Etc seems much more psychologically contrived than the original novel, and Barnes even, like a picture restorer, strips away some of the original's surface effect. In Talking It Over, Gill's passion for the useless, preening Oliver was hard to fathom or credit, but their affair had an appealing quality of honesty and playfulness. Irrational and even destructive as their behaviour appeared, they took responsibility for it.

But in the sequel, all three are unreliable narrators who lie to themselves as much as they lie to the reader. Oliver, who has plenty of real reasons to be depressed - not least because he is a total loser and fraud - falls into a deep depression over what are hinted to be the failings of others. His clever wordplay has degenerated into irritating campy mannerisms. For example, on Stuart's money: "Stuart: is he replete with the long green? While quaffing and quenching with him I did not, out of sheer tact, enquire too subcutaneously about his sojourn in the Land of the Fee, but it did strike me that if the liquidity was sloshing around his calves like a Venetian flood-tide, he might - to switch city-states - care to Medici some of the moolah in my direction."

Kindly, clueless Stuart has turned into a sadist and stalker who meditates pleasurably on newspaper accounts of vicious revenge: "It was a terrible thing to do, wasn't it? I'm not saying it wasn't. But in a way, what was most terrible about it was that it was also, in a way, quite reasonable. In a terrible way, of course." The enigmatic Gillian has become a tedious "professional victim" who gets her satisfaction from manipulating men into hurting her. The novel ends with a Rashomon-like account of a sex scene that might be a rape.

In life, of course, there are depressives, sadists and masochists, but I found it difficult to believe in the psychological evolution of these particular characters, much less to care about them. They seem to be acting out a schematic reversal of fortune, rather than deepening our understanding. There are also hints of yet another sequel, in which Oliver sells his screenplay and Stuart's business crashes. In the movies, what we want in a sequel is repetition with a twist - the same but different, as in Mission: Impossible 2. From a novelist as gifted as Julian Barnes, we should ask for more than an et cetera.

 To order a copy of Love, Etc for £12.99 plus 99p p&p call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

fields.headline: Eternal hippy
fields.standfirst: Mick Jackson  on Richard Brautigan
fields.trailText: Mick Jackson on Richard Brautigan.
fields.body:
An Unfortunate Woman by Richard Brautigan 120pp, Rebel Inc, £12
You Can't Catch Death by Ianthe Brautigan 256pp, Rebel Inc, £14.99

Despite landing in San Francisco in the 1950s and having some early prose published by City Lights, Richard Brautigan will always be fixed in the counterculture of the late 1960s and early 1970s - Woodstock and love beads - rather than with the Beat generation who came before. That's him staring out from the covers of Trout Fishing in America and The Hawkline Monster like some long-haired pioneer, a different woman beside him in every photograph. His novels and collections of short stories are tender, eccentric meditations which sold by the lorryload. But in the 1980s something happened. His publishers/readers/ reviewers (take your pick) are said to have turned against him. His boozing got out of hand, his depression got the better of him, and in October 1984 he was found in his house by the ocean having shot himself with a .44 Magnum.

For most of the 1990s the only way to get your fix of Brautigan was to trawl through the second-hand bookshops, but over the last couple of years Rebel Inc has been quietly publishing its own editions of his back catalogue. Now it presents two curiosities to accompany them: a "lost" Brautigan novel and a memoir by his daughter, Ianthe.

It's hard to pick up any posthumous publication without some degree of scepticism, and An Unfortunate Woman is no exception. The book takes the form of what Brautigan calls a "calendar map", as he travels from San Fran cisco to Buffalo, Toronto, Chicago, Hawaii and back to his ranch in Montana. Its fragmentary nature needn't necessarily concern us - one of his best collections, The Tokyo-Montana Express , was about as fragmentary as a book could be. What's more troubling are the large gaps between entries and the occasional note of distraction, as if for once the writing is not the most important thing.

His subjects are uncharacteristically sombre (an abandoned cemetery, a rape in the neighbourhood, a friend's death from cancer), although there are enough passages that remind you of him at his idiosyncratic best. His mountain ranch seems to revive his Zen-like humour - who else would contemplate how the snow on the distant Rockies thaws into the stream that flows through his garden where he fills the ice tray for his fridge? But by far the darkest shadow is that cast by Brautigan's approaching suicide. By some terrible twist we find ourselves more omniscient than the author, so that when he talks of looking for "some tranquillity . . . a little more distance between the frustrations and agonies in my life", we know what hope he has of finding it.

Considering how revealing he can be in his own books, it is perhaps not surprising that by the end of You Can't Catch Death , his daughter Ianthe's memoir, we feel that we have not learned a great deal more than we already knew. Through a series of vignettes she recounts her time with him in San Francisco (her parents separated when she was young), their changing relationship and her growing concerns for him. Along the way we hear of his drinking binges: the time he made a bonfire of all the house's telephones, the time he and a friend shot out the numbers on the face of the clock in the kitchen, the benders with Dennis Hopper (which gives some idea of the kind of quantities involved).

At times, Brautigan appears so preoccupied with himself that he threatens to neglect his daughter; she sometimes seems to have more of a parental instinct than he does himself. But it's the stories of the privations in Brautigan's own childhood that are the most affecting. As a young man, he was so hungry he smashed the windows of the local police station hoping to get himself arrested and fed. The plan went badly wrong. He was committed to a mental institution and given EST - something he believed his mother could have saved him from. When he finally got out, he vowed never to speak to her again. Ianthe remembers him showing her a photo - shortly before setting fire to it - and it's only when she sets out to try and track down her grandmother that the writing slips into gear and escapes its self-consciousness.

Johnny Rotten once warned us against trusting hippies. It's Brautigan's fate, having died when he did, to be condemned to a sort of eternal hippydom. But it would be a crime if the manner of his death were to contaminate his books, so that what once read like the words of a revolutionary became a manic depressive's verbal tics. He deserves better - he was an absolute original who found cause for celebration in the most unlikely places. The cover of every book should carry the slogan: Richard Brautigan - the hippy you can trust.

 Mick Jackson's The Underground Man was shortlisted for the Booker. To order An Unfortunate Woman for £10 or You Can't Catch Death for £12.99, both plus 99p p&p, call Guardian CultureShop (0800 3166 102).

His mountain ranch seems to revive his Zen-like humour - who else would contemplate how the snow on the distant Rockies thaws into the stream that flows through his garden where he fills the ice tray for his fridge? But by far the darkest shadow is that cast by Brautigan's approaching suicide. By some terrible twist we find ourselves more omniscient than the author, so that when he talks of looking for "some tranquillity . . . a little more distance between the frustrations and agonies in my life", we know what hope he has of finding it. Considering how revealing he can be in his own books, it is perhaps not surprising that by the end of You Can't Catch Death , his daughter Ianthe's memoir, we feel that we have not learned a great deal more than we already knew. Through a series of vignettes she recounts her time with him in San Francisco (her parents separated when she was young), their changing relationship and her growing concerns for him. Along the way we hear of his drinking binges: the time he made a bonfire of all the house's telephones, the time he and a friend shot out the numbers on the face of the clock in the kitchen, the benders with Dennis Hopper (which gives some idea of the kind of quantities involved). At times, Brautigan appears so preoccupied with himself that he threatens to neglect his daughter; she sometimes seems to have more of a parental instinct than he does himself. But it's the stories of the privations in Brautigan's own childhood that are the most affecting. As a young man, he was so hungry he smashed the windows of the local police station hoping to get himself arrested and fed. The plan went badly wrong. He was committed to a mental institution and given EST - something he believed his mother could have saved him from. When he finally got out, he vowed never to speak to her again. Ianthe remembers him showing her a photo - shortly before setting fire to it - and it's only when she sets out to try and track down her grandmother that the writing slips into gear and escapes its self-consciousness. Johnny Rotten once warned us against trusting hippies. It's Brautigan's fate, having died when he did, to be condemned to a sort of eternal hippydom. But it would be a crime if the manner of his death were to contaminate his books, so that what once read like the words of a revolutionary became a manic depressive's verbal tics. He deserves better - he was an absolute original who found cause for celebration in the most unlikely places. The cover of every book should carry the slogan: Richard Brautigan - the hippy you can trust.  Mick Jackson's The Underground Man was shortlisted for the Booker. fields.headline: First novels
fields.standfirst: The Rising Sun by Douglas Galbraith | The Fig Eater by  Jody Shields | Patrick Robertson, A Tale of Adventure by Brian Hennigan | Welcome To My Planet by Shannon Olson
fields.trailText: Lisa Darnell looks at some of the latest first novels.
fields.body:
Ask publishers what they are looking for right now and they'll shout "big books!" No longer hungry for the angst-ridden confessional, editors are ravenous for swingeing historical plots, preferably set in exotic locations. Douglas Galbraith's The Rising Sun (Picador, £16.99) deliciously fulfils these criteria. At the end of the 17th century, Scotland, caught in a slow stranglehold of English economic sanctions, decided to join the dash for colonial land in South America. The project was an unmitigated disaster and, at a time of persistent famine, precipitated fiscal collapse and the eventual union of the crowns.

Galbraith's salty fictionalisation breathes new life into these lost years. His narrator, canny young maverick Roderick Mackenzie, is a superintendent of cargoes and catalogues the colonial fleet's stocks. He also keeps his own private log book, and it is through this personal record that we learn how what began as a quest for hegemony ended in debacle, scuppered by rain, mud, mutiny and war.

Galbraith's characters are vividly drawn, driven by the self-righteousness born of greed, religious fervour and economic necessity. And although Mackenzie despairs of ever being able to keep up with events, lamenting that "nothing catches history", Galbraith convinces us that he has come close to doing just that.

Fin-de-siècle Vienna is the setting for Jody Shields's psychological thriller The Fig Eater (Doubleday, £9.99). A young girl is found dead in a park, horribly mutilated. As the chief inspector uses the latest forensic techniques to solve the case (powdered carmine, charcoal dust), in the morgue the body is gradually disembowelled for clues (even Ian McEwan may want to look away at this point). The mystery hinges on a partially digested fig found in the stomach. Whereas the chief inspector pursues a rational, scientific enquiry, his wife, haunted by the crime, prefers divination and the tarot. Shields's grasp of time and place is wholly convincing and the writing richly poetic, but she is not a natural storyteller; frequent digressions from the plot, possibly intended to set her writing apart from the thriller genre, make the novel strangely difficult to engage with.

We have an exotic location but a more contemporary theme in Brian Hennigan's Patrick Robertson, A Tale of Adventure (Cape, £10). Travelling salesman Patrick Robertson is a ruthless survivor, speaking only in Machiavellian aphorisms learned from his trade. Motivated solely by his next drink, he is erroneously kidnapped by a gang of hippy conservationists while on a business trip in Thailand and wastes no time in employing his wily tactics to elude their grasp. Inventive and smart, Robertson seduces the reader with chippy prose, macabre humour and unexpected twists. It's a shame, though, that this objectionable chancer had to find redemption in the end.

At first glance Shannon Olson's Welcome To My Planet (Viking, £9.99) seems like another angst-ridden confessional. Shannon (the author doesn't try to pretend it's not autobiographical) is 30, unmarried and depressed. Quitting her dead-end job, she moves back home with her parents, returns to college and goes into therapy. Her problem? While concentrating on the stories of those around her, she is neglecting her own, refusing to break the tie with her mother and take responsibility for her own life.

Olson is not attention-seeking in her humour or her despair, but is simply learning how to be warm, funny and intelligent herself. I didn't, as Melissa Bank promised me on the cover, "stop reading it only to laugh my head off", but I did stop reading to think about what Olson was saying, and I also laughed, in a Jerry Seinfeld kind of way.

webTitle: Guardian review: Karl Marx by Francis Wheen

fields.headline: A loveable old rogue
fields.standfirst:
Nicholas Lezard gives the thumbs up to Comrade Wheen for doing us a favour with his biography of Karl Marx
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard gives the thumbs up to Comrade Wheen for doing us a favour with his biography of Karl Marx.
fields.body:
Karl Marx, by Francis Wheen (Fourth Estate, 431pp, £8.99)

This book created such a stir when it came out that I feel I hardly have to summarize it. Still, here it is: the warts-and-all, lively and highly readable biography of the man whose self-proclaimed heirs shaped half the 20th century. Wheen's technique will be familiar to readers of his column in this paper: respect for the facts, determination to stick up for what one believes in, an instinctive and, I must add, wholly appropriate distrust of those with a right-wing agenda; and a certain matiness of tone at which some readers might raise an eyebrow, as it is, at times, more matey than his Guardian column. For example: Marx may have said that philosophers have interpreted the world, but "the point is to change it", yet Wheen remarks: "Nevertheless, Marx and Engels proceeded to spend the winter of 1845-6 theorising like billy-o as they composed their German Ideology."

You will also find rum coves, boobies, squiffy letters written after lunch and scallywags. Well, this is his way. He more or less directly signposts his influences when discussing Henry Hyndman, the Eton and Trinity-educated socialist who made Marx's last years more of a trial than they already were. "There is more than a trace of him", Wheen writes, "in PG Wodehouse's character Psmith, who converted to Marxism when he was expelled from Eton... thereafter he addressed everyone as 'Comrade'."

Personally, I think Comrade Wheen has done a fine job, and if it takes the shade of PGW to help him on his way then so be it. The key phrase in the first paragraph is "highly readable", for to resurrect Marx for the average reader is to do humanity a favour in both the long and short runs. There were one or two reviewers who despaired that Wheen reduced so much of Marx's political and philosophical thought to what amounts to not much more than the literary equivalent of a thumbs-up; but (a) this is preferable to a thumbs-down, and (b) it will send readers off to the original texts. (Not to mention to Martin Rowson's remarkable cartoon book, Scenes from the Lives of the Great Socialists , in which the pun-laden escapades of Marx and Engels will be seen to have more relation to reality than previously supposed.)

"Rowdiness and blackguardism," wrote Marx in an editorial for the Rheinische Zeitung, "must be loudly and resolutely repudiated in a period which demands serious, manly, and sober-minded persons for the achievement of its lofty aims." A few years later, he was smashing gas-lamps and being chased by the police after an epic pub-crawl up the Tottenham Court Road; while borrowing money from his baker, he would also complain of exiled revolutionaries who never had jobs; long resident in London, he would regularly despair of the workers' failure to do anything momentous with their discontent ("these thick-headed John Bulls, whose brainpans seem to have been specially manufactured for the constables' bludgeons").

Wheen's Marx is a loveable old rogue (Engels emerges as a long-suffering hero); he may have been hypocritical in the kind of minor details that intellectual pipsqueaks like Paul Johnson make so much of; he may have been a hector and an intellectual bully - there was a reason why there were only 11 mourners at his funeral - but he was also charming, funny, and a devoted father. It is this last that I find such an affecting detail, and one that is lovingly treated by Wheen; as for the old man's death, I found myself wiping away a tear, and I dare say I wasn't the only reader to do that.

 To order this book for £6.99 plus 99p p&p call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

fields.headline: Pacey Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Pakistan U-15s v England U15s
fields.trailText: Is a boy old enough at 15 for the pressure of international cricket? Australia appear not to think so. Having tested the water four years ago, they're not playing in this Costcutter Under-15 World Cup. England, too, may wonder if their lads are up to it: unbeaten in qualifying, they were favourites for yesterday's semi-final, but Pakistan saw them off just as comprehensively as the same opponents did last time around.
fields.body:
Is a boy old enough at 15 for the pressure of international cricket? Australia appear not to think so. Having tested the water four years ago, they're not playing in this Costcutter Under-15 World Cup. England, too, may wonder if their lads are up to it: unbeaten in qualifying, they were favourites for yesterday's semi-final, but Pakistan saw them off just as comprehensively as the same opponents did last time around.

England bowled well but their batsmen were undone first by Pakistan's duo of left-arm opening bowlers and then by a trio of slow bowlers. The paralysis inflicted by the spinners on the middle order, and three consecutive run outs near the end, seemed to say much about temperament.

Only Samit Patel seemed capable of mastering the bowlers. This Nottinghamshire player brought to mind a young Colin Cowdrey, in build and in his smoothly controlled driving.

Easily England's most consistent batsman - none of his four innings was under 25 - his demise for 48, lifting a drive against the off-spinner, spelt the end for England at 91 for six.

So Pakistan's youngsters go to Lord's on Thursday, seeking the victory they missed last time. Since their opponents won't be India this time - but South Africa or West Indies - one may hope for more controlled emotion both on and off the field.

Some of the appealing early on against England yesterday was excessive, but otherwise the Pakistani youngsters - many of them smaller than their opponents - demonstrated mature skills. And there is no doubt that 14-year-old Muhammed Naeem will remain a much discussed player.

From the very first occasion that he bowled a hard ball - just one year ago - he did so with either hand. Yesterday, as usual, he bowled orthodox left-arm spin to the right-handers but to England's only left-hander, he bowled right-arm. On occasion he will also bowl in both styles to the same batsman within one over. That must be most disconcerting. He throws with his left arm but writes right-handed, while for hammering or cutting with scissors either hand may be used. Arguably, that gives young Naeem the most gifted hands ever seen on a cricket field, and argues that his left-handed batting may be even more potent than his bowling - which wasn't hugely threatening.

Pakistan had made a slow start against good English seam bowling, and in Dan Broadbent the home side had a tall off-spinner with a high, vigorous swing whose 10 overs for 17 deserved a couple of wickets - denied him only by missed stumpings. But Shahid Yousaf at number four transformed the scene as he merely pushed into drives that raced to the boards. We will surely see more of him - and young Naeem, who illuminated the thrash with glittering strokes and electric running. The ambidextrous colt looks like being quite a cricketer.
